This is the latest economic challenge for the city, which is already reeling from the effects of the unrest.

site_title: Archeologists discover ancient Mayan palace in eastern Mexico
summary: Mexican anthropology officials announced the discovery of a large Mayan palace in Kuluba, eastern Mexico, near Cancun. The six-metre high, 55-metre long, and 15-metre wide structure, dating back 1,000 years, suggests it was inhabited from 600-1050 AD. The palace remains were uncovered by the National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH), providing insight into the lives of the Mayan elite.

site_title: People-moving tunnel to open in Las Vegas: Musk
summary: Elon Musk announced on Twitter that a 1.3 km people-moving tunnel in Las Vegas, built by The Boring Company, is expected to be completed by 2020. The tunnel will connect the Convention Center to the Strip, providing a "traffic busting" alternative for overcrowded cities. This project is part of The Boring Company's efforts to showcase innovative transportation solutions.

site_title: Slovenian wine is fast gaining recognition in US
summary: Slovenian wine is gaining recognition in the US market, with several wineries making it onto luxury dining and residential complex Hudson Yards' wine list in New York. The country's wine industry, which dates back centuries, is experiencing a resurgence with a focus on quality over quantity. Slovenian-born wine promoter Emil Gaspari played a key role in rebranding the country's wine industry, and his efforts have led to Slovenian wines being featured alongside high-end labels like Chateau Margaux and Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon.

site_title: Keppel Bay Tower to be fully powered by renewable energy
summary: Keppel Bay Tower in Singapore will become the country's first existing high-rise commercial building to be fully powered by renewable energy upon its completion in the first quarter of 2020. The 18-storey building will feature 400 sq m of solar panels, resulting in an annual energy yield of about 100,000 kilowatt hours and a reduction of over 2,400 tonnes of carbon emissions per year.

site_title: Grab, Singtel aim to be mainstream digital bank without the cash burn
summary: Grab Holdings and Singtel propose a joint digital full bank in Singapore, aiming to be mainstream without excessive cash burn. Grab will hold 60% stake, while Singtel holds 40%. The bank's goal is to target "underbanked" individuals and drive down costs. This move aligns with the Singapore regulator's objective of preventing bank failures and encourages sustainable banking practices. The digital full bank is expected to be a key player in the matured Singapore market.

site_title: Turkey ups reserve ratios for foreign currency deposits
summary: Turkey's central bank raised reserve requirement ratios for foreign currency deposits by 200 basis points, increasing them to 19% for short-term and 15% for long-term deposits. The move aims to mop up foreign currency liquidity and support lira liquidity, while also increasing official reserves. The central bank expects about $2.9 billion of foreign currency liquidity to be withdrawn from the market as a result. The measure is seen as a step to boost reserves and comes after the IMF warned of low external buffers and high foreign financing needs.

site_title: Dubai budget sets record spending to boost growth ahead of Expo 2020
summary: Dubai has set a record-breaking budget of 66.4 billion dirhams ($18.1 billion) for 2020, a 17% increase from 2019, to boost the economy ahead of Expo 2020. The budget includes 8 billion dirhams in infrastructure spending, down from 9 billion in 2019, and is expected to result in a 3.2% economic growth in 2020, faster than the 2.1% growth in 2019. The government aims to achieve an operating surplus of 1.96 billion dirhams, narrowing the overall deficit to 2.4 billion dirhams.

site_title: Scoot to return to double-digit capacity growth
summary: Scoot, the budget carrier, plans to return to double-digit capacity growth in the next financial year. The airline will take delivery of new aircraft, including 16 Airbus A321neos, to boost capacity and improve profitability. Despite a 6% capacity injection in the current year, Scoot aims to reach 15% growth in the next year. The airline has also added 11 new destinations and will transfer six Indonesian routes to its network. Scoot's CEO, Lee Lik Hsin, believes the airline will be able to ride out the current market challenges and come back to double-digit growth.

site_title: Economics data may quicken stroll into 2020
summary: Economic data may pick up in 2020 as traders return from holiday breaks, with liquidity expected to increase towards the end of the week. The confirmation of a US-China "Phase One" trade deal and Brexit clarity are expected to support equities. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, and Tesla marks its formal entry into India with a launch event.

site_title: Keppel Bay Tower to be fully powered by renewable energy from 2020
summary: Keppel Bay Tower in Singapore will become the first commercial building to be fully powered by renewable energy upon its completion in 2020, with 400 sq m of solar panels generating 100,000 kWh of energy annually. This will reduce carbon emissions by 2,400 tonnes annually. The building's energy consumption is expected to decrease to 115 kWh per sq m per annum, meeting its goal of achieving "super low-energy" status. The initiative is part of Keppel's efforts to reduce its environmental impact and promote sustainable urbanization.

site_title: Pound sterling surge: Calm before the Brexit storm?
summary: The UK's new administration, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, has set a path forward for British businesses despite uncertainty ahead. The pound strengthened to its 19-month high following the election, and the FTSE 100 saw significant gains. However, analysts warn that a no-deal Brexit is possible if negotiations with the EU cannot be reached beyond 2020. The government's withdrawal agreement offers short-term certainty but a hard Brexit will lead to significant trade barriers and economic damage, particularly for the UK's service sector. Investors are bracing for uncertainty, but some assets, such as commercial property, may benefit from the stability.

site_title: KKR, AIMCo to take 65% stake in C$6.6b Canada gas pipe
summary: KKR & Co and Alberta Investment Management Corp agreed to buy a 65% stake in the C$6.6 billion Coastal GasLink Pipeline Project, a Canadian natural gas pipeline project, from TC Energy Corp. The deal, valued at C$4.3 billion, will provide seaborne access for natural gas from the Montney shale formation. TC Energy will retain a 35% stake and record a C$600 million after-tax gain. The project is expected to be completed in early 2023, supplying gas to LNG Canada, a US$30 billion liquefied natural gas export facility.

site_title: Australia hit by extreme heatwave, escalating wildfire threat
summary: Australia is experiencing an extreme heatwave, exacerbating deadly wildfires that have ravaged the nation for months. Temperatures are forecast to soar over the weekend, with some areas expected to reach 45 degrees Celsius. The wildfires have already burned over 6 million acres of forest and bush land, killing nine people and destroying over 950 properties. The crisis has sparked a debate about the impact of global warming and has turned attention to Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative government, which has been criticized for not taking enough steps to curb emissions.

site_title: US drinkers hopped up for India Pale Ales
summary: US drinkers have made India Pale Ales (IPAs) a staple in bars, with a 10-year trend of excessive demand for the bitter beers. Popularized in the US in the 1970s, IPAs have become a defining style of craft beer, with over 8,000 breweries in the country. Bartenders and beer historians attribute the popularity to its unique taste and the counter-culture movement of the 1970s, where drinkers sought locally produced, hoppy beers. While some view IPAs as elitist, others see it as a good introduction to craft beer, with breweries continuing to innovate and expand their offerings.

site_title: The war on diabetes goes digital
summary: Singapore is investing in digital healthcare technology to reduce the cost of managing diabetes, which costs over S$1 billion annually. The disease has nearly doubled in prevalence in 15 years, with 606,000 adults affected. Many people with diabetes remain undiagnosed, putting them at high risk of complications. Digital solutions like the mySugr app are being used to track health information and provide proactive prevention, making disease management more effective and less costly. The technology aims to empower patients to take control of their health and make lifestyle changes to control the disease.

images.alt_text: mySugr is a free mobile app for managing diabetes. Since its June launch in Singapore, the app has garnered nearly 9,000 users.

"Diabetes is a silent disease ... you can have it and not know it until it's quite late ... It's not about providing only clinical decisions like prescribing, it's really about helping them understand what they do, what they eat, how to balance their lifestyle so they can control the disease better." - Roche Diabetes Care's Pedro Goncalves.

site_title: Why the pound's rally could hit a roadblock in 1Q 2020
summary: The pound is set for a yearly gain against the dollar, having recovered nearly 10% since its low in September due to the re-elected government's solid majority and Boris Johnson's pledge to "get Brexit done". However, Danske Bank A/S warns that the start of 2020 could bring political uncertainty, range trading, and potential economic slowdown, which may limit the pound's further growth. The Bank of England's slashed growth expectations and some analysts predict zero growth for the fourth quarter, weighing on sentiment.

images.alt_text: The pound is set for a yearly gain against the dollar, but it may struggle to take off further in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Sao Paulo skyline changes as real estate booms
summary: Sao Paulo's real estate market has experienced a boom, with construction sites sprouting up across the city. In the financial district of Itaim Bibi, five skyscrapers are being built, and newspapers are filled with advertisements for new high-rises. This surge in development is driven by a strong economy and a steady supply of buyers. The city's wealthiest residents are leading the charge, with many seeking to invest in property. The boom is expected to continue, with more high-rise developments planned for the area.

site_title: Brighter prospect seen for USD/JPY
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The USD/JPY pair is expected to trend higher in 2020, with technical indicators pointing to a brighter prospect. A "golden cross" candlestick pattern and widening distance between Exponential Moving Averages (EMAs) suggest buying strength. An uptrend line has also been forming since August, with prices testing support levels and showing higher highs and lower lows. Additionally, the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator confirms strong buying pressure. The US economy's solid growth and labor market support the USD, while Japan's potential fiscal package may lead to JPY weakness, fueling upside momentum for USD/JPY.

site_title: US Treasuries have a hard act to follow in 2020
summary: US Treasuries experienced their strongest year since 2011 in 2019, with a total return of nearly 7%. However, with 10-year rates at 1.88%, the market faces limited scope for additional gains. Analysts, including Priya Misra, expect a rebound in 2020 if the US consumer weakens, driven by a decline in manufacturing. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates on hold for the coming year is also seen as a factor, with investors now pricing in less than one rate cut in 2020.

site_title: India's Internet shutdowns cost carriers millions of rupees in lost revenue
summary: India's internet shutdowns are costing mobile operators around 24.5 million rupees (S$463,765) every hour, according to the Cellular Operators Association of India. The shutdowns, ordered to control protests against a new citizenship law, are also affecting the country's biggest market for social media firms like Facebook and WhatsApp. The Cellular Operators Association of India has criticized the government's approach, saying internet shutdowns should not be the first course of action.

site_title: Wheat could be surprise winner in the partial US-China trade deal
summary: US wheat prices are expected to rise due to speculation that China will meet its wheat-buying quota as part of the partial US-China trade deal. China's failure to meet its quota in the past has led to a surge in demand for American wheat. If China secures the quota, it could represent a 10-15% increase in global demand, benefiting US farmers. Wheat futures for March delivery have already climbed 1.1% in Chicago, while soya bean and corn prices remain unchanged.

site_title: Women take charge in Hollywood's hottest 2020 movies: survey
summary: A survey found that four of the most anticipated 2020 Hollywood movies are directed by women, a rare trend in the industry. The top four films are Wonder Woman 1984, Black Widow, The Eternals, and Mulan, all helmed by female directors. This marks a breakthrough year for female directors in Hollywood, which has historically been male-dominated. The survey of over 2,000 moviegoers also shows interest in other films, including James Bond title No Time to Die and Pixar's Soul.

site_title: The year tech unicorns became donkeys
summary: In 2019, several tech unicorns experienced significant valuation losses after going public, including Uber, Lyft, and WeWork. This phenomenon highlights the importance of accurately valuing companies based on their realistic global reach, rather than relying on American experiences and expectations. Geographic heterogeneity poses significant challenges, with countries like India, Turkey, and Indonesia presenting unique obstacles for digital businesses. Investors must consider these differences to ensure that companies don't get "stuck with the curse of 2019."

site_title: China offers new pre-election inducement to Taiwan with revised law
summary: China has revised a law to simplify investment procedures for Taiwan companies, in an attempt to show goodwill ahead of Taiwan's January 11 elections. The revised law aims to encourage more Taiwanese investment, with China being Taiwan's favorite investment destination. However, Taiwan's government has warned against falling for China's inducements and called for democracy and freedom of speech. This move comes as Taiwan prepares for elections between pro-independence and pro-China parties, with China seeking to sway electors and Taiwan trying to reduce its reliance on China.

site_title: Oil posts longest run of weekly gains since April
summary: Oil prices posted the longest run of weekly gains since April, rising 2.1% to a three-month high, driven by a US-China trade breakthrough and OPEC's output cuts. Crude inventories fell to the lowest in two months, with supplies at the Cushing storage hub declining to a one-year low. The market is expected to continue correlating with equities, but experts warn of an unsustainable situation, citing the market's overbought condition. Oil prices are up 12% this month, with West Texas Intermediate closing at $61.72 a barrel and Brent at $68.16 a barrel.

site_title: Hyflux investor invites noteholders, unsecured creditors to offer debt at minimum 85% discount
summary: Hyflux is inviting noteholders and unsecured creditors to offer their debts for purchase at a minimum 85% discount. The invitation, which starts on Dec 30 and ends on Jan 23, 2020, is open to holders of its 4.25% and 4.6% notes due 2018, as well as other senior debts. The total eligible debt is approximately S$1.8 billion, representing nearly two-thirds of Hyflux's total S$2.8 billion debt. Aqua Munda, the buyer, will accept bids in order of highest offered discount until available settlement funds are used up.

images.alt_text: Aqua Munda is inviting Hyflux noteholders and unsecured creditors to offer their debts for purchase at a minimum discount of 85 per cent.

site_title: Sudan to lift fuel subsidies gradually; double public sector salaries
summary: Sudan's transitional government plans to gradually lift fuel subsidies in 2020 and double public sector salaries to ease inflation. The move aims to alleviate poverty and inflation, which have been exacerbated by the loss of oil production since South Sudan's secession in 2011. The government also plans to increase spending on education and social services, with aid for needy families and provinces affected by conflict. The budget is expected to be finalized in the next two days.

site_title: US dollar retreats as risk appetite returns at year-end
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.6% against a backdrop of rising risk appetite and optimism about a US-China trade deal, with the dollar index falling to 96.951. The euro rose 0.76% to a 10-day high, while trade-sensitive currencies such as the Australian and New Zealand dollars also strengthened. The euro has risen 2.3% against the greenback this quarter, driven by improved Eurozone data and weakness in other currencies.

site_title: Election Budget = goodies galore? Don't hold your breath
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget 2020, expected just before the General Election, is likely to be a policy-driven budget rather than a traditional "Election Budget" with significant cash handouts. Analysts expect targeted support for specific groups, such as low-income workers and SMEs, rather than blanket cash payouts. Climate change is also expected to be a key theme, with the government potentially introducing measures to support businesses and infrastructure planning. The government's fiscal position and long-term plans will guide the allocation of funds, rather than just budget surpluses.

images.alt_text: With Singapore's next General Election expected just round the corner, Budget 2020 has been widely tagged as an "Election Budget".

site_title: China to switch benchmark for floating-rate loans to lower funding costs
summary: China's central bank will switch to the loan prime rate (LPR) as a benchmark for floating-rate loans starting January 1, aiming to lower borrowing costs and support economic growth. The move, announced in August, is expected to help ease financing costs and make interest rates more market-driven. Analysts predict a possible cut in the medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate, which could lead to further lowering of the LPR. China's economic growth slowed to 6% in the third quarter, and the government plans to set a lower target of 6% for 2020 to ward off a sharper slowdown.

site_title: Vietnam court sentences ex-minister to life in MobiFone corruption scandal
summary: A Vietnamese court sentenced former information minister Nguyen Bac Son to life in prison for taking $3 million in bribes in the MobiFone corruption scandal. The scandal involved a 2015 deal where MobiFone overpaid for a 95% stake in a pay television provider, resulting in "serious financial losses" for the government. Son was found guilty of facilitating the deal, while another former information minister, Truong Minh Tuan, received a 14-year sentence. The court also sentenced Audio Visual Global JSC Chairman Pham Nhat Vu to three years in prison and 11 other defendants to between two and 23 years.

site_title: China targets another American product: Books
summary: China has blocked the release of hundreds of American books in response to US tariffs, targeting major publishers and authors including Bob Woodward. The move has caused a near-freeze in regulatory approvals, affecting bestsellers and academic titles, and has raised concerns about the future of publishing in China. The Chinese government has been tightening its control over foreign content, favoring domestic authors and titles that promote its version of socialism. The partial trade truce reached between China and the US may ease the logjam, but publishers remain cautious about future crackdowns.

site_title: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz sees new government by early next year
summary: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz expects his conservative People's Party to form a new government with the environmentalist Greens by mid-January, following a coalition agreement. The OeVP won 37.5% of the votes in the parliamentary election, while the Greens scored 13.9%. This would be the first time the Greens enter government at the national level. Kurz's previous administration collapsed due to a corruption scandal, and the FPOe suffered heavy losses in the election. A coalition would address the top voter concern of the environment.

site_title: Wheat, soybean futures reach highest prices since summer 2018
summary: US wheat and soybean futures reached their highest prices since summer 2018, driven by expectations of increased Chinese buying following a Phase 1 trade deal. Corn futures also hit an eight-week high. The agreement, which eased the trade war, led to Beijing committing to buying more US farm goods, including wheat and soybeans.
