site_title: Ali Wong's Home Truths
summary: Ali Wong's book "Dear Girls" is a humorous and honest account of her life, written for her daughters. The comedian shares quirky and crude stories about her life, including her experiences as a stand-up comedian, her marriage, and her travels. Wong recounts her struggles to make it in the comedy world, including sleeping in squalid hotels and bombing in clubs. The book is meant to be a legacy for her daughters, providing them with insights into her life and the lessons she's learned along the way.

site_title: SembMarine bags 2 offshore platform deals worth over S$550m
summary: SembMarine secured two offshore platform contracts worth over S$550 million, one with North Oil Company for the Al Shaheen oil field in Qatar and another with Total E&P Danmark for the Tyra field in the Danish North Sea. The contracts, valued at over S$550 million, will support redevelopment efforts at both fields and are expected to be completed by 2021. SembMarine's shares closed up 2.34% at S$1.31 following the announcement.

site_title: Joseph Segel, founder of QVC television shopping network, dies, aged 88
summary: Joseph Segel, the founder of QVC, a pioneering television shopping network, has passed away at 88. Born in 1931, Segel revolutionized the way people shop by creating a professional and engaging shopping experience on TV. QVC's success predated the rise of e-commerce giants like Amazon and Walmart, and it remains a household name today. Under Segel's vision, QVC featured live broadcasts of hosts demonstrating products, building relationships with customers, and sharing authentic stories, which became its signature "secret sauce."

site_title: China will relax hukou system to promote freer movement of labour
summary: China announced plans to relax its hukou system, allowing for freer movement of labor and promoting urbanization. The policy aims to ease restrictions on household registration, making it easier to move between employers and improve incentive systems. This move is part of broader economic reforms, including steps to improve state-owned enterprises, stabilize employment, and boost private sector businesses. The relaxation of hukou rules will eliminate barriers for most of China's 300 prefecture-level cities, sparking positive market reactions.

site_title: Social Place's quirky Chinese food passes the taste test
summary: Social Place, a modern Chinese restaurant in Singapore, has received praise for its quirky and fun atmosphere, which encourages customers to interact with their food. The restaurant's dishes, such as noodles in scallion oil, prawn toast, and deep-fried charcoal tofu, are flavorful and enjoyable, despite some minor missteps. The standout dish is the Seafood Crackling Rice Soup, which offers a satisfying and filling experience. Overall, Social Place is a great spot for those seeking a lighthearted and enjoyable dining experience, with a rating of 6.5 out of 10.

site_title: The Expialidocious Burger - Part II
summary: US Commissioner of Food and Drugs Howard Harper meets with Rojak CEO Wong Ming Wei to discuss Rojak's bestselling meat-free patty, The Expialidocious Burger. Harper is concerned about the patty's taste, which he believes could replicate human flesh, but Wong claims he doesn't know what meat it substitutes. Wong attributes the patty's success to "serendipity" and says it's a combination of plant-based ingredients, but refuses to reveal the specific mix. Harper presses for the truth, but Wong remains inscrutable, and the meeting ends with a pregnant pause, leaving Harper uncertain about the patty's ingredients.

site_title: Japan probe into casino bribery case widens, pachinko operator raided
summary: Japanese authorities raided the headquarters of a pachinko operator as part of a bribery investigation into ruling party lawmaker Tsukasa Akimoto, who was arrested on suspicion of accepting bribes related to casino development. The investigation is widening a scandal that could undermine government efforts to develop casinos. Prosecutors have expanded their inquiry into Akimoto's ties to 500.com, a Chinese online gambling operator, and have arrested three other people suspected of bribery. The probe raises questions about the bidding process for casino resorts, which could be worth up to $20 billion a year.

site_title: Funny Business
summary: Comedians John Cleese and Brooke Lynn Hytes are set to perform in Singapore in 2020. John Cleese's show "In Praise of Silly" will feature his signature blend of comedy and mime, while Brooke Lynn Hytes' "Queen of the North" will be a musical drag comedy extravaganza. Cleese will perform at UCC Hall on March 7, and Hytes will perform at Shine Auditorium on March 29, with tickets now on sale through SISTIC.

site_title: Hyflux novates TuasOne project to Mitsubishi
summary: Hyflux has terminated its previous settlement agreement with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) for its TuasOne waste-to-energy project, instead signing a new agreement novating its engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contract to MHI. The deal addresses liquidity issues, ensures project completion, and resolves claims between parties. Hyflux's CEO, Olivia Lum, stated that the novation is necessary to ensure continued funding for the project despite ongoing debt restructuring. The novation is expected to have a material effect on the group's financial performance.

site_title: Countdown 2020
summary: The Marina Bay Singapore 2020 Countdown is a New Year's Eve celebration featuring light projection shows, fireworks, and live performances. The event showcases artworks from social service organizations on iconic structures and offers a grand fireworks musical experience on Star Island. The countdown promises a unique celebration with pyrotechnics, 3D surround sound, and live action. For more information, visit https://www.marinabaycountdown.sg/.

site_title: Governance is not about compliance, but helping firms perform better: UK expert
summary: A leading UK expert on governance and board evaluations, Richard Sheath, emphasizes that corporate governance should be viewed as a tool to help businesses perform better, rather than a burdensome regulatory requirement. He believes that investing in governance will yield a return, as seen in the success of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and the UK's Senior Managers Regime. Sheath also notes that boards are increasingly adopting environmental, social, and governance policies and taking initiatives to ensure strong ESG standards, with merit-based appointments and a focus on promoting diversity.

site_title: 737 Max still grounded, but Boeing is ready to allay public's concern about its safety
summary: Boeing continues to work on technical fixes for the 737 Max, despite a 40% of regular flyers expressing unwillingness to fly on the plane. The company has surveyed thousands of passengers worldwide and is developing strategies to win back public trust, including rebooking flights, providing information cards, and offering human connections. Boeing is also promoting its safety features and acknowledging past mistakes. The Max remains grounded, with no timetable for return to service, as Boeing faces enormous challenges in restoring its reputation.

site_title: China plans to curb financial risks in rental housing market
summary: China's housing ministry plans to curb financial risks in the rental housing market by tightening lending to rental housing companies and capping their rental income from loans at 30%. The move aims to address housing affordability issues as home prices skyrocketed. The government has promoted the rental housing market since 2017 to address these concerns.

site_title: Commercial real estate market in London set for 2020 revival
summary: London's commercial real estate market is poised for a revival in 2020, driven by improved political stability under British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative government. With a commanding majority in Parliament, Johnson can push through Brexit and make good on his promise to leave the EU, boosting investor confidence. This shift is expected to lead to increased deals and activity in the market.

site_title: Record online sales give US holiday shopping season a boost: report
summary: US holiday shopping season saw record online sales, with e-commerce making up 14.6% of total retail sales, a 18.8% increase from 2018. Overall holiday retail sales rose 3.4%. Despite a later-than-usual Thanksgiving, retailers offered omni-channel sales, meeting consumer demand. The growth was attributed to wage growth and a strong labor market, with US consumer spending benefiting from these factors.

site_title: Dining Out in 2020
summary: In 2019, the F&B industry saw the rise of plant-based alternatives, with 'bleeding' Impossible patties becoming a popular burger option. Brown sugar bubble milk tea also gained widespread acceptance. The year also saw a surge in celebrity chef-backed restaurants, while independent Singaporean chef-run eateries like Mustard Seed gained success. Sustainability became a growing concern, with some restaurants and businesses adopting zero-waste practices. As 2019 comes to a close, industry players look to 2020 for new trends and innovations, including a focus on sustainability and innovative food concepts.

site_title: Abe, Kuroda pressure Japan employers to raise wages
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda urged employers to raise wages to boost the economy, citing weak wage growth as a hurdle to inflation. Abe hopes for wage increases during the annual shunto wage negotiations, while Kuroda said the central bank would ease policy further if the economy's momentum towards its 2% inflation goal is threatened. The BOJ has maintained its current policy stance, but Kuroda acknowledged that downside risks to the global economy remain significant.

site_title: Ferrante Fever Returns
summary: Elena Ferrante's highly anticipated novel "The Lying Life of Adults" has been published in Italian, with an English translation set to be released in the first half of 2020. This marks the return of Ferrante Fever, 6 years after her last published work, "The Storyteller". The novel continues Ferrante's signature theme of a young Neapolitan woman coming to terms with her identity, particularly her appearance. Fans eagerly await the English translation, following the success of her previous novels, including the Neapolitan Quartet.

site_title: China slams US defence act over trade restrictions
summary: China opposes the US defence act, which includes trade restrictions on Chinese companies and slows the lifting of sanctions on Huawei. The National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) bars the use of federal funds to buy railcars and buses from China and prevents the US from removing Huawei from a list banning American firms from working with the company. China has agreed to a temporary truce in its trade war with the US, but the new restrictions are seen as interfering in China's internal affairs and will likely harm Chinese companies.

site_title: Drink To This
summary: A Singapore-based start-up, Omniaz, has launched the DRNK AR app, which uses augmented reality and artificial intelligence to provide information about wine, beer, and spirits. The app scans wine labels, offering origin, aromas, tasting notes, and more. Users can also leave reviews and add drinks to wishlists, receiving personalized recommendations based on their preferences. The app is available on the App Store and Google Play.

site_title: UOB partners Prudential, Nickelodeon to enhance parents' planning for kids
summary: UOB has partnered with Prudential Singapore and Nickelodeon Asia to enhance its UOB KidSmart Programme, which helps parents understand their children's strengths and plan their financial development. Since its launch three years ago, the programme has seen a 44% increase in average savings balances among participating parents. The partnership now includes protection and endowment plans from Prudential and educational activities from Nickelodeon, aiming to support Singaporean children's development and financial growth.

site_title: View From The Top
summary: Singapore's Gardens by the Bay introduces the Supertree Observatory, an open-air rooftop deck 50m above the ground, offering panoramic views of the Marina Bay area. The observatory features an indoor space with digital media and interactive experiences, as well as a floor-to-ceiling glass walkway for those with a fear of heights. The Supertree Observatory is open daily from 9am to 9pm and priced from S$10 per adult.

site_title: Red Hot Detox
summary: Pure Wellness Studio in Singapore offers two new infrared light treatments to prepare bodies for 2020, focusing on detoxification, weight loss, and relaxation. Infrared saunas use heat from within the body, emitting three types of wavelengths: near-infrared for skin rejuvenation, mid-infrared for circulation and muscle recovery, and far-infrared for detoxification. These treatments aim to promote overall wellness, offering a unique alternative to conventional saunas.

site_title: Appointing Daiwa Capital to evaluate Accordia Golf Trust's sale of golf courses is par for the course
summary: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) appointed Daiwa Capital Markets Singapore as a joint financial adviser to evaluate the sale of its golf courses. The audit and risk committee initially raised concerns about a potential conflict of interest but deemed it "reasonably resolved and managed". AGT's management assured the Singapore Exchange that any conflict had been addressed. The appointment aims to assist with the evaluation of a non-binding proposal for the sale of all golf courses.

site_title: EC World Reit CFO to resign to pursue personal interests
summary: EC World Reit's CFO, Tng Chin Hwee, will step down on Dec 31 to pursue personal interests. He has been in the role since January 2017. The company is identifying a suitable successor. The board's decision comes as the company's units closed unchanged at S$0.755 on Thursday.

site_title: We are working on bursting your bubble
summary: Researchers are closing in on understanding the causes of asset bubbles, but preventing their growth is a harder problem. Over the past four decades, economists have studied crashes such as the 1987 stock market crash and the 2008 housing bubble, which had devastating effects on the economy. A growing number of economists are focusing on "extrapolative expectations," where investors assume recent returns represent a deep structural trend, leading to price bubbles. Identifying the cause of bubbles is crucial to designing policies to prevent them, but this challenge remains unsolved.

site_title: Margaret Leng Tan, Up Close And Very Personal
summary: Avant-garde pianist Margaret Leng Tan, 74, premieres "Dragon Ladies Don't Weep," a sonic memoir in 3D format, at the Esplanade. The performance, dramatized by Koh Heng Leun and Tamara Saulwick, explores Tan's life, including her childhood, music studies, and struggles with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD). The show also touches on her close friendships with John Cage and George Crumb, and features unconventional music-making methods. Tan aims to "fulfill the equation" of art, life, and theatre by living her life on stage.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives assumes full ownership of Kingsmen Taiwan
summary: Kingsmen Creatives acquired all remaining shares of Kingsmen Taiwan International for NT$1,051,460, increasing its stake from 93% to 100%. The purchase price was based on the book value and net tangible asset value of NT$15,020,862 as of Sept 30. Following the acquisition, Kingsmen Creatives' shares rose 3.49% to S$0.445.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.68 point to 1,603.55. The index saw 1.9 billion lots traded worth RM1.1 billion, with 428 gainers and 305 losers.

site_title: Abhishek Gupta, Co-founder of Circles Life
summary: Circles.Life, a digital mobile service, has disrupted the Singapore telco market by offering lower prices, no-contract plans, and digital plan management, capturing a 5% market share in just three years. The company's audacious marketing stunts, such as its "Telco Freedom" crowdfunding campaign, have also garnered attention. Circles.Life is expanding into new markets, including Taiwan and Australia, and plans to enter Indonesia in the near future. The company is focused on innovation, partnering with other businesses to expand its ecosystem and offering personalized services. Its co-founders aim to revolutionize the telco industry with a completely digital experience.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust agreed to divest the Mapletree Waigaoqiao Logistics Park in Shanghai to a subsidiary of GDS Holdings for 330 million yuan (S$64 million), a 108% premium over its original purchase price in 2008. The Reit manager plans to distribute any divestment gain to unit holders after taxes and expenses. Meanwhile, Parkson Retail Asia is being sued by Parkson Corporation for rental default at an EVO shopping mall in Malaysia, and Hotung Investment Holdings' investee company, Crystalvue Medical Corporation, listed on the Taipei Exchange with an initial public offering price of NT$58.80 (S$2.65).

site_title: In 21st century gender parity should not be a lifetime away
summary: A recent report by the World Economic Forum (WEF) reveals that it will take 99.5 years, on average, to achieve global gender parity in work, education, politics, and health. The report's findings are a significant setback, as they suggest that the progress made towards gender equality in recent years will not be enough to close the gap. The WEF notes that the gender gap in politics and economics will take over 95 and 257 years to close, respectively. The report calls for policymakers and business leaders to take action to ensure women have equal access to high-growth sectors and to equip girls with the necessary skills to compete in emerging fields.

site_title: What should investors do in 2020?
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's dovish shift in 2018 lifted global market sentiment, as the FOMC hiked interest rates only once in 2018 and then cut them three times in 2019. This led to a strong 27% return in the S&P500 index and 7% return in the Hang Seng Index. Despite geopolitical challenges, including the US-China trade war, and uncertainty in 2020, Asian economies and markets may enjoy a moderately positive year. Investors should focus on companies adapting to technology disruption and governments implementing expansionary fiscal policies to address climate change and infrastructure needs.

site_title: Italian coalition hit as minister quits
summary: Italian Education Minister Lorenzo Fioramonti has resigned from the coalition government, citing a failure to meet his demand for a minimum level of funding for schools and research. Fioramonti, from the Five Star Movement, had agreed to take on the portfolio to reverse the trend of underfunding in Italian education. His resignation is the latest blow to the four-month-old coalition government, which faces challenges from far-right and centrist parties. Fioramonti plans to form an independent group in parliament to support Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte.

site_title: Post-Christmas trading sees a quiet session
summary: Post-Christmas trading in the Asia-Pacific region was subdued, with many markets closed or on holiday. Singapore's Straits Times Index was little changed, while China's Shanghai Composite Index advanced 25.47 points or 0.9% to 3,007.35, driven by Beijing's fiscal stimulus plan. Other regional markets, including Japan and South Korea, also ended higher, while Taiwan and Malaysia were flat. Trading volume in Singapore was 1.10 billion securities, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Broadway Industrial Group were among the top performers.

site_title: UOB partners Prudential Singapore, Nickelodeon Asia to enhance parents' financial planning for kids
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Prudential Singapore and Nickelodeon Asia to enhance its UOB KidSmart Programme, which assesses children's strengths and helps parents create a financial plan to support their development. The programme, launched three years ago, has seen a 44% increase in average savings balances for participating parents. Prudential Singapore has added protection and endowment plans, while Nickelodeon Asia has launched the Nickelodeon Academy of Smarts, pairing intelligences with popular characters. The partnership aims to help Singaporean children reach their full potential.

site_title: US applications for jobless benefits fall to three-week low
summary: US jobless benefits filings fell to a three-week low of 222,000 in the week ended Dec 21, down from 235,000, according to Labor Department figures. This decline reflects a solid labor market and indicates emerging data is recovering from recent seasonal volatility. The four-week average rose to 228,000, the highest since mid-February, while continuing claims declined by 6,000 to 1.72 million. The unemployment rate among people eligible for benefits remained at 1.2%.

site_title: New hotel encapsulates Milan tourist renaissance
summary: A new capsule hotel in Milan, Italy, is catering to the city's growing tourist numbers by offering affordable, futuristic accommodations with digital connectivity and social spaces. The hotel, Ostelzzz, features tiny, stacked rooms with amenities like charging plugs, a lockable cupboard, and a bedside table, all for a nightly price of around 19 euros. This marks the first Italian city to have a capsule hotel, and the company plans to expand to six airports and several European cities over the next five years, with a projected annual turnover of 10 million euros.

site_title: The hidden perk New York's mega-rich demand
summary: New York's ultra-high-net-worth residents are embracing modern porte cochères, a French term for an entrance to a building large enough for a coach to enter, as a luxury feature. These covered-driveway-and-entry combinations provide cover from prying eyes and are seen as a shield from photographers and fans. With many buildings selling for seven or eight figures, porte cochères are a high-tech twist, often automated, and take up more space than average Manhattan apartments. Critics argue they are outdated, but developers say they cater to affluent buyers who prioritize convenience and security.

site_title: Capitalists without capital are plaguing capitalism
summary: A significant portion of US public stocks (40%) have negative tangible book value, indicating companies' assets are not worth enough to repay all their debt. Despite this, a fund composed of these companies has outperformed the main US stock market by 24% over the last 20 years. Experts attribute this to the de-materialisation of the economy, where tangible assets are less important, and financial engineers prioritize earnings per share over broader measures of profit. Additionally, a rising number of "zombie companies" with low interest coverage ratios pose concerns for capitalism's process of creative destruction.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit new record highs on trade deal hopes
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices hit new record highs on Thursday, driven by optimism over an imminent US-China trade deal. The S&P 500 rose 3.82 points, or 0.12%, to 3,227.20, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 17.33 points, or 0.19%, to 8,970.21. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 24.01 points, or 0.08%, to 28,539.46, putting the benchmark index on track for its best year since 2013.

site_title: Bruce Lee's daughter sues fast food chain for using father's image
summary: Bruce Lee's daughter, Shannon Lee, is suing Chinese fast food chain Kungfu Catering Management for allegedly using her father's image without permission for 15 years. The company's logo features a dark-haired man in a kung fu pose resembling Bruce Lee, which Shannon Lee claims was used without paying intellectual property rights. She is demanding the logo be removed, compensation of 210 million yuan, and a statement clarifying the company's involvement with Bruce Lee. The company has stated it was authorized by Chinese authorities and is studying the case.

site_title: Home sales jump in 'showstopper' Mumbai
summary: Home sales in Mumbai, India's financial capital, jumped 22% in 2019, the highest in four years, driven by developers building cheaper apartments to bridge the demand-supply gap. Despite a credit crunch and economic slowdown, affordable flats saw a 21% increase in new home starts. Overall housing sales growth slowed to 5%, and average residential property prices rose 1% in 2019. The Indian government's pledge to revive stalled projects may drive recovery in home sales, with most growth expected in the second half of 2020.

site_title: More India protests as Hindu hardliners flex muscles
summary: India witnesses more protests against a citizenship law, with at least 27 people killed in two weeks of demonstrations. Pro-government Hindu hardliners staged a show of force in Hyderabad, while thousands protested in cities like Mumbai and Kolkata, calling for a boycott of the law. The government denies accusations that the law aims to marginalize India's 200 million Muslims, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi claiming it's part of a master plan to ease naturalization procedures for non-Muslim minorities.

site_title: Daiwa to expand real estate trust business amid low rates
summary: Daiwa Securities Group, Japan's second-largest brokerage, plans to expand its real estate investment trust (Reit) business amid low interest rates. The company aims to increase its assets to over 1 trillion yen ($12.4 billion) next year, driven by institutional investors seeking returns on Reits due to negative yields on government bonds. Daiwa will consider private placements and mergers to bolster its assets, following a surge in Reits' values and record lending to the real estate sector. The move aims to capitalize on the favorable market conditions.

site_title: Japan investors plan bigger bets on emerging market debt in 2020
summary: Japanese investors plan to increase their exposure to emerging market debt in 2020, driven by falling bond yields in traditional markets and expectations of looser monetary policy. They're seeking higher yields, particularly in countries like Mexico and South Africa, which have steep yield curves. Japanese investors have been diversifying from low-interest rates at home, with insurers and pension funds recycling their surplus funds into emerging market bonds. This shift is expected to continue, with asset managers looking for opportunities to invest in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Lebanon bank governor does not know how much pound could slump on black market
summary: Lebanon's Central Bank Governor Riad Salameh said "nobody knows" how much the Lebanese pound could slump on the black market, as the country faces its worst economic crisis in decades. The pound has weakened by 30% on the parallel market, and banks have imposed tight controls, driving up prices. Salameh ruled out a break in the peg, which fixes the pound at 1,507.5 to the dollar, and pledged to maintain it, despite a surge in black market dollar prices. A new government is urgently needed to address the crisis.

site_title: 'Ring of fire' eclipse wows across Asia
summary: A rare "ring of fire" solar eclipse occurred on December 26, 2019, visible from a narrow band of Asia, including Saudi Arabia, Oman, India, and Singapore. Annular eclipses happen when the Moon is too far from Earth to completely block the Sun, leaving a thin ring visible. The event drew hundreds of amateur astronomers and photographers, with some describing it as a "once-in-a-lifetime" experience. The next annular eclipse will occur in about 40 years, and the event was visible from southern India to South-east Asia before ending over the northern Pacific.

site_title: Hotter, faster, pricier: 10 records in 2019
summary: In 2019, the world witnessed numerous records, including the hottest month globally with an average temperature of 16.75°C in July. The fastest marathon was completed in 1 hour and 59 minutes. Notable price records include auction prices reaching new heights, with some items selling for record-breaking amounts. These records highlight the extremes of 2019, showcasing the planet's rising temperatures, human endurance, and the increasing value of certain items.

site_title: Malaysia's 3rd automotive policy to focus on next-gen vehicles: analyst
summary: Malaysia's third National Automotive Policy (NAP) will focus on next-gen vehicles, shifting from energy-efficient cars to a roadmap spanning three phases until 2030. Analysts, including Liaw Thong Jung of Maybank Kim Eng, expect tepid vehicle sales growth in 2020 due to a challenging market. The policy's success will shape the nation's automotive industry, competition, and foreign direct investments, making it crucial for policymakers to get it right.

site_title: 'Ring of fire' eclipse wows across Asia
summary: A rare "ring of fire" solar eclipse occurred across Asia, visible from Saudi Arabia, Oman, India, and Singapore on December 26, 2019. Annular eclipses, where the Moon doesn't completely obscure the Sun, leave a thin ring of the solar disc visible. This phenomenon occurs every year or two but is only visible from a narrow band of Earth, with the same pattern repeating only after decades.

site_title: Capital World CFO resigns, following departure of exec director
summary: Capital World's CFO, Kenny Zhang, has resigned to pursue other career opportunities, effective December 31. This follows the departure of executive director Dennis Yong, who left after one year to pursue other business opportunities. With both senior executives gone, CEO Siow Chien Fu is the last remaining member of senior management.

site_title: Hong Kong, Australia, New Zealand: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, Australia, and New Zealand were closed on December 26, 2019, for a public holiday.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat in listless Thursday session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat at 3,222.99 on Boxing Day, with trading volumes at 1.10 billion securities and a total turnover of S$437.53 million. Despite a lack of direction, some stocks like Rigmaker Sembcorp Marine and Broadway Industrial Group rose due to contract announcements. Analysts attributed the subdued session to year-end market conditions, with volatility expected only if unexpected headlines emerge on the geopolitical front.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on US-China trade thaw
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.60% on Thursday, driven by investor confidence in the global economy following the US-China trade thaw. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 23,924.92, while the Topix index gained 0.57%. Trading was thin ahead of New Year holidays. Nissan recouped some losses, while other carmakers such as Toyota and Honda remained stable due to a stable yen.

site_title: Pick Rosé Champagne to celebrate the holiday season
summary: The article discusses the evolution of Champagne and the complexities of the wine industry. Champagne is no longer a simple, amorphous product, but rather a diverse and nuanced wine with different terroirs and character. The industry's attempt to simplify the choices through marketing has been met with criticism, as it can lead to a loss of appreciation for the complexity and diversity of wine. The article recommends exploring the world of Champagne, including rosé Champagnes from grower-producers, which offer a range of styles and flavors. The author highlights several rosé Champagnes that stood out, including the Tarlant Rosé Zero Brut Nature and the Bérêche & Fils Campania Remensis, and encourages readers to try them and discover the beauty of Champagne.

site_title: Ambani's retail unit valued at US$34b in share swap
summary: Mukesh Ambani's retail unit, Reliance Retail Ltd, has been valued at US$34 billion through a stock swap offer with its listed parent Reliance Industries Ltd. The valuation surpasses that of Tesco Plc and is double that of Avenue Supermarts Ltd. The move aims to monetize investments and help employees with illiquid stock options. Analysts estimate the unit's value at plus or minus 30% of the reference value. The valuation is lower than initial estimates, with Reliance Industries' shares slipping 2% in response to the news.

images.alt_text: A stock swap offer to help shareholders of billionaire Mukesh Ambani's unlisted retail business monetise their investment has valued the unit at US$34 billion.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks gain on Sino-US trade hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Thursday, driven by hopes of a Sino-US trade deal in 2020 and investors holding off on selling shares ahead of dividend payments. US President Donald Trump announced a signing ceremony for the first phase of the US-China trade deal. The signing ceremony is set to take place soon.

site_title: Ex-Hengfeng Bank chairman sentenced to death with 2-year reprieve
summary: Former Hengfeng Bank chairman Jiang Xiyun was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve for graft. The Shandong-based bank is undergoing restructuring under government supervision. Jiang's case marks a significant move by authorities to crack down on corruption in the financial sector. The sentence is seen as a warning to others involved in similar misconduct.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore factory output fell 9.3% in November, reversing a growth spike, amid year-end hopes for the manufacturing sector. SembMarine secured offshore platform projects worth over $550m, while Rex International's subsidiary will issue preference shares to raise $17m. The Straits Times Index (STI) remained unchanged.

site_title: Second Chance Properties posts S$2.12m net profit in Q1
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a net profit of S$2.12 million in Q1, nearly 10 times the profit of S$0.22 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 1.89% to S$6.35 million, driven by a 7.14% increase in gold business revenue. Rental revenue from properties fell 4.91% due to the sale of an investment property and lower rentals. Earnings per share increased to 0.28 Singapore cents, and net asset value per share rose to 35.18 Singapore cents. The company expects modest economic growth in Singapore in 2020 if the US-China trade war escalates.

site_title: Egg-standing test goes viral as ring-of-fire eclipse crosses Asia
summary: Thousands of skywatchers in Asia gathered to witness a rare annular solar eclipse, despite a debunked scientific theory claiming an egg would stand on its narrow side during the eclipse due to increased gravity. The theory, which has been discredited, sparked social media interest in Malaysia and Indonesia, where users tested the claim. The eclipse, which occurred on December 26, 2019, was observed across parts of Asia, with no evidence to support the egg-standing theory. The event was a rare celestial occurrence that drew attention from skywatchers worldwide.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust sells bonded warehouse in Shanghai to GDS
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has agreed to sell its bonded warehouse in Shanghai, the Mapletree Waigaoqiao Logistics Park, to a subsidiary of GDS Holdings for 330 million yuan (S$64 million). The sale is above the property's valuation of 196.9 million yuan and is 108% above the trust's original purchase price in 2008. The trust plans to distribute any divestment gain to unitholders, which may be used to fund committed investments or reduce debt.

site_title: FJ Benjamin draws SGX query after rising 22.6% in 1 day
summary: Luxury fashion retailer FJ Benjamin's shares surged 22.6% in a single day, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange. The company stated it is unaware of any reasons for the unusual trading activity. FJ Benjamin reported a net loss of S$670,000 in the first quarter, despite a 28% increase in operating profit. The unusual trading activity has raised concerns, and the company is now under surveillance by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says ready to ease without hesitation if inflation target threatened
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank is prepared to ease policy without hesitation if Japan's inflation target of 2% is threatened. The bank maintained its assessment of a moderately expanding economy and left short-term interest rates at -0.1% and 10-year bond yields around 0%. Kuroda emphasized the central bank's commitment to achieving its inflation target, highlighting its willingness to take action to ensure its success.

site_title: China slams US defence act over trade restrictions
summary: China has expressed strong opposition to a US defence act that includes trade restrictions, including a ban on buying railcars and buses from China and a slowdown of sanctions on Huawei. The National Defense Authorisation Act was signed into law last week, amid a temporary truce in the US-China trade war. China had already criticized the bill for interfering in its internal affairs, and the restrictions are seen as a blow to the country's economic growth and relations with the US.

site_title: Protesters target Hong Kong's malls during Christmas break
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong are targeting shopping malls during the Christmas holiday, calling for attention to their cause and forcing malls and stores to close. The demonstrations have resulted in clashes between protesters and police, with tear gas used to disperse demonstrators. The unrest has further impacted Hong Kong's retailers, with a record 24.3% decline in retail sales in the past six months. Protests are set to continue into the New Year holiday, with a march planned for January 1.

site_title: Singapore factory output posts 9.3% shock drop in November
summary: Singapore's factory output declined 9.3% year-over-year in November, exceeding expectations, due to a decline in the biomedical manufacturing cluster and worsening electronics output, particularly in semiconductors and computer peripherals. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, industrial production fell by 9%. The chemicals cluster also contracted, while precision engineering and transport engineering showed growth. Overall, Singapore's factory production for the 11 months fell 1.6% year-over-year.

site_title: SembMarine bags 2 offshore platform projects worth over S$550m
summary: SembMarine secured two offshore platform contracts worth over S$550 million. The contracts include fabricating platforms for the Al Shaheen oil field in Qatar and the Tyra field in the Danish North Sea. The work, expected to start by 2021, will support redevelopment efforts at the two fields and sustain production capacity. SembMarine's head of offshore platforms stated that the successful bids reinforce the company's engineering expertise in catering to different geographies and operating environments.

site_title: Malaysia imposes anti-dumping duties on China, Japan, South Korea and Vietnam steel imports
summary: Malaysia has imposed anti-dumping duties on steel imports from China, Japan, South Korea, and Vietnam, effective immediately, for a period of five years until December 24, 2024. Duties range from 3.84% for South Korea to 26.38% for most Chinese producers, with the highest duty at 26.39% imposed on all Japanese producers. The duties were imposed after a domestic industry complaint that imported materials were being sold at a lower price than in their respective domestic markets.

site_title: Farm to table? More like ghost kitchen to sofa
summary: New York City is the country's largest market for food delivery, with demand expected to grow. Venture capitalists see this as a lucrative opportunity, investing in startups and efficient systems like food delivery apps. This trend is set to continue in 2020, with investors seeking to capitalize on the market's potential.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.49 points or 0.16% to 1,606.72. Gainers outpaced losers 96 to 49, and volume reached 29.92 million lots worth RM11.58 million.

site_title: Gold makes headway above US$1,500 as 2020 comes into closer focus
summary: Gold prices rose above US$1,500 an ounce as investors positioned for 2020, driven by a focus on the Federal Reserve's rate-cutting pause. The metal advanced for a fourth day, its best run since October, and is up 17% this year, its best showing since 2010. Despite easing US-China trade concerns, gold bulls see a new higher trading range emerging, with some predicting prices could reach US$1,600 an ounce. The climb comes as investors seek havens amid market volatility.

images.alt_text: Gold firmed up a foothold above US$1,500 an ounce as investors positioned for 2020, with post-Christmas gains coming even as equities inched higher and US-China trade concerns eased. Silver rose along with platinum and palladium in what's been a banner year for precious metals.

site_title: Hyflux axes old agreement with Mitsubishi on TuasOne project
summary: Hyflux has replaced an old settlement agreement with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries on the TuasOne waste-to-energy project, replacing an old agreement entered into on February 15, 2019. The new agreement covers the division of payments and discharge of claims, ensuring continued funding for the project despite ongoing debt restructuring. The novation is expected to have a material effect on Hyflux's financial performance, and the company's CEO, Olivia Lum, stated that the deal would help address liquidity problems and complete the $750 million project.

site_title: Putin says Russia has vessel to build Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline: paper
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced that Russia has a vessel, Academic Cherskiy, to complete the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline to Germany. The vessel's slower pipe-laying speed may stretch the project completion by several months due to US sanctions. The project was halted by Swiss-Dutch company Allseas, which was using two vessels to lay the pipeline. Putin had previously stated the project would be completed by mid-2020, but sanctions imposed by the US have delayed its completion.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust: Conflict of interest 'reasonably resolved' in golf course deal
summary: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) has resolved a potential conflict of interest in appointing Daiwa Capital Markets Singapore as a joint financial adviser to evaluate a non-binding proposal for the sale of its golf courses. The audit and risk committee found that the potential conflict has been "reasonably resolved and managed" due to Daiwa Group's alignment with other minority unitholders in ensuring favorable terms for the trust. The manager has also recused a board nominee with a 51% stake in the manager's parent company from the selection process.

site_title: Vividthree enters into exclusive talks to acquire comics animation firm
summary: Vividthree, a Catalist-listed visual effects studio, has entered into exclusive talks to acquire comics animation firm DarkBox Studio. The controlling shareholders of DarkBox have accepted Vividthree's expression of interest, giving the studio until Feb 10, 2020 to negotiate. DarkBox is an international comics IP company with a large following in Asia and the US, and has collaborated with clients like Disney and Nickelodeon. Vividthree shares rose 1.48% following the announcement, with the company describing DarkBox as a pioneer in the comics animation industry.

site_title: E-learning course equips DBS, POSB staff with skills on serving customers with dementia
summary: DBS Bank has rolled out an e-learning course for its 12,000 employees in Singapore to recognize and serve customers with dementia. The 90% of customer-facing staff who completed the course can now identify warning signs to protect customers from potential issues. This initiative comes as dementia is expected to affect 103,000 people in Singapore by 2030, part of the region's aging population.

site_title: China's biggest subsidy-free solar farm powers up in Liaoning
summary: China has launched its largest subsidy-free solar farm, a 500-megawatt unit in Liaoning province, marking a significant shift towards clean energy. The project, valued at 2.9 billion yuan, is part of China's efforts to develop 14.8 gigawatts of subsidy-free solar capacity. These projects will compete with traditional coal and gas-fired plants, paving the way for a more sustainable energy mix in the country.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index easing 0.03% and the Topix index down 0.02%. The move followed other major markets being closed for Christmas. This marks the second day of trading after the holiday break.

site_title: Daiwa to expand real estate trust business as low rates persist
summary: Daiwa Securities Group is expanding its real estate investment trust business as low interest rates continue to drive investors into domestic property funds. The company plans to increase its assets to over 1 trillion yen, with a focus on mergers and acquisitions to bolster its portfolio. This comes as Japan's exchange-traded Reits reach 12-year highs, with institutional investors seeking returns to make up for negative yields on government bonds. Daiwa aims to strengthen its business and capitalize on the growing demand for real estate investment trusts.

site_title: Hot stock: Dyna-Mac surges for 2nd time this week, up as much as 11.2%
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings, an offshore oil and gas contractor, saw its shares surge 11.2% to S$0.157 on Thursday, marking the second price increase this week. The stock rose 8.3% on Tuesday and 10.5% on Wednesday. Satish Malik, the company's former chief development officer, resigned on December 11. No query has been issued by the Singapore Exchange regarding the stock's price surge, and the company has not provided any updates.

site_title: Typhoon Phanfone kills at least 16 in Philippines: officials
summary: Typhoon Phanfone, with winds of 195 kmh, claimed at least 16 lives in the central Philippines on Christmas Day, affecting remote villages and popular tourist areas. The storm also damaged roads, electric posts, and airports, with the airport at Kalibo badly damaged. The typhoon followed a similar path to Super Typhoon Haiyan, the country's deadliest storm, and is considered a less destructive but similar storm. Thousands of people were forced to evacuate their homes, with ferries and plane services suspended.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed in subdued post-Christmas trade
summary: Asian equities experienced a mixed trading session on Thursday, with Tokyo's Nikkei index rising 0.5% and Shanghai increasing 0.4%, while Seoul remained flat. Investors remain optimistic about US-China trade ties, despite recent gains holding. Analysts attribute the improvement in sentiment to the thawing of the US-China trade squabble and easy central bank policy. Oil prices also rose 0.4% due to trade optimism and the Opec+ output reduction agreement, supporting year-end strength.

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at Thursday's open; STI down 0.02%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.02% to 3,220.98 at Thursday's open, with gains outnumbering losses 62-32. Key movers included Broadway Industrial Group, Dyna-Mac Holdings, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while Sembcorp Marine rose 3.9% after securing two offshore projects worth S$550 million. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS down 0.2% and UOB up 0.2%.

site_title: The big shortcoming: A grumpy 2020 for global growth
summary: Global economic growth is expected to dip in 2020, reaching 2.9% according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, its lowest level since the 2009 recession. US President Donald Trump's trade war with China and the COVID-19 pandemic are cited as major factors. Central banks have taken proactive measures, but governments' inaction on climate change and technological advancements pose challenges. The IMF forecasts 3.4% growth, but warns of a "synchronised slowdown and uncertain recovery."

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for public holiday on Wednesday
summary: Financial markets in Australia, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, and South Korea are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. No other key events or market updates are provided in the given article.

site_title: Hotung's investee company Crystalvue lists on Taipei Exchange
summary: Hotung Investment Holdings' investee company, Crystalvue Medical Corporation, listed on the Taipei Exchange on December 25 with an initial public offering share price of NT$58.80. Crystalvue engages in research, development, and sale of ophthalmic diagnostic medical devices. The company's shares remained unchanged at S$1.74.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Rex, Olam, Parkson Retail Asia, Jubilee Industries, Hock Lian Seng
summary: SembMarine secured two offshore platform contracts worth over S$550 million, Rex International raised US$17 million through preference share subscriptions, Olam International booked a one-time gain of US$27 million from divesting a stake in a Gabon joint venture, Parkson Retail Asia faced a writ and statement of claim, Jubilee Industries disposed of its 13.77% stake in EG Industries for S$5.37 million, and Hock Lian Seng's deputy CEO David Chew Tuan Dong resigned to pursue other opportunities.

site_title: Britain's Queen hails climate movement on Christmas Day
summary: Britain's Queen Elizabeth II used her Christmas Day message to praise young environmental campaigners, referencing Swedish teen Greta Thunberg's impact on the climate movement. The monarch called 2019 "quite bumpy" but urged Britons to overcome divisions, drawing parallels between past struggles and the current environmental concerns. Britain set a legally-binding target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2050, and the queen praised new generations' sense of purpose on environmental issues.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.41% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.41% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,208.46, due to a drop in banking stocks. Rex International gained 3.7%, while Broadway Industrial Group jumped 7.1%. Banking stocks fell, including DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank. Other active stocks included Dyna-Mac Holdings, which rose 10.5%, and Eagle Hospitality Trust, which declined 1.8%.

site_title: Oil rises, supported by trade deal, Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by a potential breakthrough in the Sino-US trade war and Opec-led efforts to constrain supply. Brent crude increased 16 cents to $67.36 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate rose 20 cents to $61.31 a barrel. The US-China trade deal, combined with Opec's production cuts and slowing shale activity, is expected to support stronger oil prices in Q1. US President Donald Trump announced a signing ceremony for the Phase 1 trade deal, which may boost demand.

site_title: Italy's education minister resigns over lack of funds for ministry
summary: Italy's Education Minister Lorenzo Fioramonti resigned on December 25, 2019, after failing to secure billions of euros in funding for schools and universities. Fioramonti had demanded a 3 billion euro increase in education spending, but the government refused. The resignation is a blow to the embattled government and underlines internal dissatisfaction within the 5-Star Movement, Fioramonti's party. Fioramonti will remain in parliament and continue to support the government, despite his resignation.

images.alt_text: Italian Education Minister Lorenzo Fioramonti told Reuters on Wednesday he had resigned after failing to obtain from the government billions of euros he said were needed to improve the country's schools and universities.

site_title: Nepal arrests 122 Chinese over suspected cyber scam
summary: Nepal has arrested 122 Chinese nationals on tourist visas over suspected cyber scam involvement, with 8 women among the detained. Police raided nine houses in Kathmandu, seizing over 700 mobile phones, 331 laptops, and nearly 100 desktop computers. The operation was coordinated with Beijing's National Central Bureau. The arrests come after similar crackdowns in the Philippines and Malaysia on unlicensed gaming businesses and online investment scams. Police are investigating the evidence and will take action accordingly.

site_title: Brazil's Bolsonaro says he had partial memory loss after a fall this week
summary: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro said he experienced partial memory loss after a fall at his presidential residence in Brasilia, which was later deemed to be minor. Bolsonaro, 64, was taken to a hospital for a brain scan and was discharged after spending the night. This incident comes after Bolsonaro has undergone four surgeries since 2018 due to a knife attack. Bolsonaro stated he has recovered from the memory loss and is now fine.

site_title: Developer sues Parkson Retail Asia unit for alleged failure to pay rent
summary: PROPERTY developer PKNS-Andaman Development Sdn Bhd has sued Parkson Retail Asia's unit, Parkson Corporation Sdn Bhd, for allegedly failing to pay rent at the EVO shopping mall in Malaysia. PKNS claims RM3.7 million in accrued monthly rental from April 2018 to December 2019, plus RM1.9 million in renovation costs. Parkson Retail Asia disputes the claim, stating PKNS failed to satisfy conditions for rental commencement, and has instructed its solicitors to defend against the suit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly lower in muted trading
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.03% lower on December 25, 2019, due to muted trading during the Christmas holidays. The Nikkei 225 index fell 7.15 points to 23,823.43, while the Topix index decreased 0.45 points to 1,727.77. This followed a mostly lower US session, where shares slid due to tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened marginally lower on Wednesday in the absence of foreign investors for the Christmas holidays, after US shares finished a sleepy holiday-shortened session mostly lower.

site_title: Accrelist to divest stake in Jubilee as part of strategic review; names new director
summary: Accrelist plans to divest a 17.5% stake in Jubilee Industries Holdings for S$6.95 million as part of its strategic review to focus on its medical aesthetics business. The proposed disposal aims to synergize business operations with EG Industries, a substantial shareholder of Accrelist. Following the disposal, Accrelist will undertake a capital reduction exercise, writing off S$72.4 million in accumulated losses and distributing Jubilee shares to shareholders. The company has also appointed Kang Pang Kiang as a new non-executive director, effective December 24.

site_title: Typhoon misery for Philippines on Christmas Day
summary: Typhoon Phanfone pummeled the central Philippines on Christmas Day, bringing a wet and miserable holiday season to millions. Thousands were stranded at ports or evacuation centers, with residents cowering in rain-soaked homes. Despite toppling houses and trees, no deaths were reported. The typhoon's path was similar to Super Typhoon Haiyan, which killed over 7,300 people in 2013. Over 10,000 people sought shelter in schools and government buildings, with many forced to spend the night without sleep.

site_title: New internet outages in Iran ahead of commemorations
summary: Iran experienced a wave of internet outages on December 25, 2019, ahead of commemorations for those killed in unrest last month. The outages, imposed by security bodies, limited international mobile phone line traffic and excluded internal traffic, allowing only domestic websites to be accessible. Disruptions were reported in several provinces, including Alborz, Fars, Kurdistan, and Zanjan. The outages come ahead of planned commemorations for people killed in street violence during demonstrations against fuel price hikes, with officials yet to release an overall death toll.

site_title: Hong Kong Christmas Eve clashes see about two dozen injured
summary: Hong Kong's Christmas Eve saw clashes between protesters and police, resulting in about two dozen injuries. Demonstrators, many wearing masks, took to streets and shopping malls to demand greater democracy, following six months of unrest over a proposed extradition law. Despite the bill's withdrawal, protests have persisted with demands for direct elections and police clashes occurred at multiple locations, including a vandalized HSBC building. The unrest has pushed Hong Kong into its first recession in a decade, with protests likely continuing into the new year.

site_title: Rex unit to issue more preference shares to raise US$17m
summary: REX International's indirect subsidiary Masirah Oil Ltd plans to issue US$17 million worth of preference shares to raise funds for drilling activities and operations in Oman. The shares will be issued at US$477.70 apiece, with Rex Oman, Schroder & Co Banque SA, and management member John Pringle subscribing for 29,015, 6,354, and 210 shares respectively.

site_title: 'More churros, less cops!': New York food vendors feel the heat
summary: New York City street food vendors, many of whom are undocumented migrants, face numerous challenges, including inclement weather, assaults, and arrests. The city's cap on permits has led to a black market in permits, with some vendors paying up to $25,000 for a permit. Women vendors are particularly vulnerable to harassment and fines. A bill has been introduced to eliminate the cap on permits, but opponents argue it would lead to unfair competition with established businesses. The vendors' plight has sparked protests, with some calling for "more churros, less cops."

site_title: Aramco CEO says Saudi-Kuwaiti accord paves way for resumption of oil production
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser announced that a new agreement between Saudi Arabia and Kuwait has paved the way for the resumption of oil production in the Neutral Zone, which produces 500,000 barrels of oil per day. The agreement, signed by Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman and Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Ahmad Nasser al-Mohammad al-Sabah, marks the end of a halt in production that began in 2014 and 2015. The two OPEC members will work to resume production at the earliest opportunity, with oil output divided equally between the two countries.

site_title: Morales claims US orchestrated 'coup' to tap Bolivia's lithium
summary: Former Bolivian President Evo Morales claims the US orchestrated a 'coup' to gain access to Bolivia's vast lithium resources, following his resignation in November amid protests over his re-election. Morales, who has been living in exile, says the US sought to prevent Bolivia from setting the price of lithium, a key component in high-tech equipment. He accuses the US of not forgiving Bolivia for choosing to partner with Russia and China instead. Morales' Movement for Socialism party has named him campaign chief for upcoming elections, which the government has barred him from standing in.

site_title: Record online sales give short US holiday shopping season a boost: report
summary: US holiday shopping season saw a boost in online sales, with e-commerce sales making up 14.6% of total retail and rising 18.8% from November 1 to Christmas Eve. Despite a shortened shopping season due to a later-than-usual Thanksgiving holiday, overall holiday retail sales excluding auto rose 3.4%. E-commerce sales growth was driven by consumers taking advantage of early online deals and a low unemployment rate. The apparel category saw stronger-than-expected e-commerce growth, with online sales rising 17%.

site_title: 'Friends' theme songwriter dies aged 72
summary: Allee Willis, the songwriter behind the iconic 'Friends' theme song 'I'll Be There For You,' has died at 72 due to a cardiac event. Willis, who also co-wrote Earth, Wind and Fire's 'Boogie Wonderland,' was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2018 and won a Grammy in 1985 for her work on the 'Beverly Hills Cop' soundtrack. Despite not knowing how to play music, Willis learned to become a songwriter by listening to rhythms at Motown studios in Detroit, where she grew up.

site_title: Police, protesters clash as Hong Kong celebrates Christmas
summary: Hong Kong's Christmas celebrations were marred by clashes between police and pro-democracy activists, with police using pepper spray and tear gas to disperse crowds. The protests, which occurred in multiple districts, were the latest in a series of demonstrations against Beijing's rule and the city's administration. Pro-democracy activists remained defiant, with one protester saying the government's actions would not silence them. The clashes came as the city struggled with a recession and intensified political polarization, with protesters demanding greater democratic freedoms and police accountability.

site_title: Top Nissan executive to abruptly leave for Electric Motor maker
summary: Top Nissan executive Jun Seki, vice-chief operating officer, plans to leave the company to join Nidec Corp as president and COO. Seki's departure comes at a precarious time for Nissan, struggling to recover from the chaos unleashed by former CEO Carlos Ghosn's arrest and an industry downturn. Nissan shares fell 1.7% in early Tokyo trading, marking the company's year-to-date decline of 27%. Seki will join a company with a market value 60% higher than Nissan's, seeking to become a top supplier for electric vehicles and home appliances.

site_title: Bloomberg's White House campaign used prison labour: report
summary: Billionaire US presidential hopeful Michael Bloomberg used prison labor to make calls for his campaign, according to an investigative report by The Intercept. Bloomberg's campaign contracted with a third-party vendor, ProCom, which runs call centers in New Jersey and Oklahoma, including a state prison. The practice was disclosed after a reporter asked about it, and Bloomberg's campaign ended its relationship with the vendor immediately. Bloomberg called the practice "fundamentally accurate" and said his campaign will vet its vendors more thoroughly in the future.

site_title: Japanese lawmaker arrested on suspicion of accepting bribes over casino: NHK
summary: Japanese lawmaker Tsukasa Akimoto was arrested on suspicion of accepting bribes from a Chinese company interested in setting up a casino in Japan. Akimoto, a senior vice-minister in the Cabinet Office until 2018, oversaw the government's policy on introducing casinos under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plan to stimulate the economy and tourism. Akimoto has repeatedly denied wrongdoing and his office said it had not heard about the reported arrest. The arrest occurred after prosecutors raided Akimoto's office last week.

site_title: Tanzania court charges rights activist with money laundering
summary: A Tanzanian court charged rights activist Tito Magoti with money laundering and other crimes after holding him in custody for four days. Magoti, of the Legal and Human Rights Centre, was arrested on Friday and questioned about his relationship with fellow activists and opposition politicians. Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch denounced the deteriorating human rights situation in Tanzania, citing repression against the media, civil society, and opposition since President John Magufuli's rule began in 2015.

site_title: Trump says it was an 'honour' to appear in 'Home Alone 2'
summary: US President Donald Trump has described his appearance in the 1992 Christmas film 'Home Alone 2' as an "honour". Trump, who appeared briefly in the film, was a young businessman at the time and was filming the movie while acquiring the Plaza Hotel in New York. He mentioned the film was a "big hit" and praised its success. Trump has made numerous cameos in films and series, often playing himself.

site_title: Boeing document dump shows 'disturbing' picture on 737 MAX: official
summary: Boeing released a batch of internal documents on the 737 MAX to regulators and congressional investigators, showing a "disturbing picture" of the company's response to safety issues. The documents, sent hours before Christmas, reveal concerns from Boeing employees about the company's commitment to safety and efforts to divert production plans. The move comes after Boeing ousted CEO Dennis Muilenburg, and the company has faced scrutiny over its handling of the crisis. The Federal Aviation Administration has confirmed receiving the documents, and lawmakers are still reviewing them.

site_title: Boeing CEO's ejection brings stability - temporarily
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg was unexpectedly ousted, replacing David Calhoun, who brings stability but also raises concerns about the company's long-term damage from the grounded 737 MAX. The move comes as Boeing faces a financial crisis, with increased debt and cash-burning operations. Calhoun's background as a trained accountant and former GE executive may indicate the company's priorities have shifted away from safety and engineering. The company must address the 737 MAX issues, including software revisions, pilot training, and potential structural changes, to regain customer and regulator trust.

site_title: Dell to explore buying the rest of Secureworks: sources
summary: Dell Technologies Inc is considering buying the remaining 13.8% of shares in cybersecurity services operator Secureworks Corp, aiming to fully consolidate the business. The move is part of Dell's exploration of acquiring the remaining shares, according to people familiar with the matter. No official announcement has been made, and the deal is considered private.

site_title: Heads of 3 Japan Post firms to resign over improper policy sales: media
summary: Japan Post Holdings' CEO Masatsugu Nagato, Japan Post Insurance President Mitsuhiko Uehira, and Japan Post President Kunio Yokoyama will resign due to improper sales of insurance policies, with 12,836 cases of misconduct found. The number of cases more than doubled from an interim report in September, with 82% of 183,000 policies sold over five years potentially disadvantageous to customers. The companies will step down on Friday as the financial regulator issues administrative punishments.

site_title: Egypt's current account deficit narrows, FDI up in July-September 2019
summary: Egypt's current account deficit narrowed to $1.382 billion in July-September 2019, a decrease from $2.012 billion in the same period last year. Net foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose to $2.353 billion, the first increase in two years. Non-oil FDI, however, remains low, with a three-year low in the third quarter of 2018/2019 fiscal year. This marks a positive trend for Egypt's economy, but challenges persist in attracting foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Egypt's current account deficit narrowed to US$1.382 billion in July to September 2019 from US$2.012 billion in the same period a year earlier, central bank data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: SingHaiyi boss: Property leaves a legacy
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Celine Tang, managing director of SingHaiyi Group, emphasizes that property is about constructing something that spans generations, focusing on human connections and experiences. She believes that owning property is a long-term trend driven by the desire for something tangible and lasting. Tang attributes the success of SingHaiyi Group to its diversified portfolio, including residential and commercial properties in Singapore and other markets. Despite challenges such as a supply overhang and cooling measures, Tang is optimistic about the Singaporean real estate market, citing its stability and government support.

images.alt_text: "In terms of socio-economic and political stability, as well as standards of living such as healthcare and education, Singapore remains a gem within the Asia-Pacific region. Property values here will definitely appreciate. It's just a matter of how quickly, and in what time frame." - Celine Tang (above).

site_title: In 2019, slashing US$65m off price of a mansion wasn't a big deal
summary: The article discusses the phenomenon of "aspirational pricing" in luxury real estate, where sellers list properties for significantly more than their actual sale price. This tactic, used to generate attention and create a sense of exclusivity, has become more prevalent in recent years. However, experts predict that this strategy may fizzle out as buyers become more discerning and value fair pricing. A notable example is the sale of a Los Angeles mansion originally listed at $180 million but sold for $115 million, a 63% discount.

site_title: China to improve mechanism to deal with bond defaults as delinquencies rise
summary: China's central bank, securities watchdog, and state planning commission will publish rules to regulate corporate bond defaults, with a focus on trustee business and creditor meetings. The move aims to improve the mechanism for dealing with bond defaults as delinquencies rise. The default rate among China's private bond issuers reached a record high of 4.9% in 2019, and may increase in 2020. Authorities will also step up credit risk monitoring, stabilize market expectations, and crack down on dodging repayment obligations.

images.alt_text: China's central bank, securities watchdog and the state planning commission will soon publish rules that will regulate the disposal of corporate bond defaults, the newspaper said.

site_title: Oil rises on supply cut pledges and slow return of Gulf field
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude up 81 cents to $67.20 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate up 59 cents to $61.11 a barrel, amid optimism over a potential US-China trade deal and cooperation between Opec and Russia on supply cuts. Opec and Russia agreed to extend and deepen output curbs, but analysts say more is needed to balance the market sustainably. A deal between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to reopen fields could add to supply next year, while US oil production has filled the gap, swelling inventories.

site_title: Emirates airline says president to step down
summary: Emirates airline announced that President Tim Clark will step down in June 2020 after 16 years in the position. Clark, 70, joined Emirates in 1985 and became president in 2003. His retirement comes after the airline's significant growth and expansion in the Middle East and globally.

site_title: China hosts Japan, South Korea with eyes on nuclear North
summary: China hosted Japanese and South Korean leaders for a rare meeting, aiming to unify their stance on North Korea's nuclear program. The gathering came as North Korea threatened a "Christmas gift" - potentially a missile test - if the US doesn't make concessions by year-end. US President Trump downplayed the threat, while China sought to fill the diplomatic void between the US and its Asian allies. The meeting marked the first bilateral meeting between South Korea's Moon Jae In and Japan's Shinzo Abe in over a year, and both countries urged resumption of talks between North Korea and the US.

site_title: Tourism's gifts and woes for Santa and Sami homeland
summary: Tourism in Finland's Lapland region has seen record numbers of visitors, with 2.9 million overnight stays in 2019, driven by China and the Middle East. However, this growth has raised concerns about the impact on the indigenous Sami people and their culture. The Sami Parliament has issued guidelines for "ethically responsible" tourism, calling for respect for Sami traditions and criticism of practices such as dog-sledding and igloo hotels. Authorities are exploring ways to balance economic benefits with environmental and social concerns, including offsetting carbon emissions and promoting eco-aware tourism.

site_title: Card payments in Malaysia to exceed US$80b by 2023: GlobalData
summary: Malaysia's total card payments value is projected to reach $81 billion by 2023, up from $50.4 billion in 2019, according to GlobalData. The share of cash in total payments is expected to decline from 88.1% to 80% during the same period. Government initiatives and lower interchange fees have contributed to the growth of the payment cards market, with the Malaysian central bank waiving interchange fees for domestic debit card payments until 2020. This is expected to further boost payment card acceptance among merchants, driving the use of payment cards in Malaysia.

site_title: In 2019 a US$65m price cut on a mansion wasn't a big deal
summary: US luxury home sellers have adopted "aspirational pricing," listing properties for millions of dollars more than their ultimate sales price, in an effort to generate attention. This strategy, used by sellers like those of a Los Angeles mansion once owned by Tony Curtis, has led to significant price cuts. Experts say the trend may fizzle out as buyers become more discerning and expect fair value. While high-end sales are expected to continue, the disconnect between listing prices and sales prices may diminish.

site_title: China: Stocks climb on stimulus hopes for smaller firms; Hong Kong closes lower
summary: China's stocks rose 0.3% on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index reaching 3,979.88, driven by Premier Li Keqiang's announcement of potential measures to lower financing costs for smaller companies. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.3% to 2,970.19. Li's comments included broad-based and targeted cuts in reserve requirement ratio, relending, and rediscounting.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng deputy CEO to resign
summary: Hock Lian Seng's deputy CEO, David Chew Tuan Dong, is resigning effective December 31 to pursue other opportunities. Chew, 63, has been an executive director since August 2014. The company's shares rose 1.33% to S$0.38 on the news.

site_title: Meatless burgers, hemp cocktails and pasta straws: the year's eco-friendly food trends
summary: In 2019, eco-friendly food trends gained popularity, aiming to reduce carbon emissions. Key trends included plant-based burgers, fish substitutes, insect-based foods, hemp-infused products, and sustainable pasta straws. Other innovations included using waste as ingredients, reducing food waste, and environmentally-friendly beers and wines. Companies like Ben & Jerry's and fast food giants like Burger King and McDonald's joined the flexitarian movement, incorporating alternative proteins and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. These trends aim to promote sustainable food production and consumption.

site_title: ByteDance has no sale plans for TikTok, media report untrue: internal note
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, has denied a media report that it is considering selling the short video platform due to US concerns. In an internal note, TikTok's head Alex Zhu stated that such reports are "inaccurate" and that the company has no plans to sell TikTok. This comes after Bloomberg reported on Monday that ByteDance was exploring options for a TikTok stake sale. The denial aims to reassure users and investors that TikTok's future is secure.

site_title: Decade in review: What the smartphone has wrought
summary: The smartphone has revolutionized the world over the past decade, with 5 billion devices in use globally, and 7.2 billion internet subscriptions, mostly mobile. The iPhone's release in 2007 marked a turning point, with Apple becoming one of the world's most valuable companies. Smartphones have enabled ubiquitous access to information, apps, and social media, but also raised concerns over data privacy and distracted driving. The shift to mobile payments and digital communication has led to the decline of traditional phone calls and the rise of e-commerce.

site_title: Publishers see 2020 as the year more start to get paid for news
summary: Publishers see 2020 as a year where they start getting paid for news content, reversing the trend of tech platforms profiting from their work. Facebook, Google, and startups like Pocket and Medium are paying for articles, with some publishers receiving $1 million to $3 million per year. While payments are still relatively small, media executives are encouraged by the trend, and some see it as a windfall in a shrinking news business. Apple and Google are yet to follow suit, but local publishers are largely ignored by these companies.

site_title: 'Hangover museum' in Croatia makes light of blurry nights
summary: A unique museum in Zagreb, Croatia, called the Museum of Hangovers, has opened its doors to showcase objects and stories from drunken escapades around the globe. The museum features a series of rooms recreating the night out, with visitors encouraged to complete a chalkboard with their own hangover stories. The museum's founders plan to expand to include a "dark room" exploring the dangers of binge drinking, but for now, it focuses on the humorous side of these experiences.

site_title: PM urges Britons 'not to argue' in Christmas message
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged Britons to avoid arguments during the holiday season in a Christmas message, avoiding the topic of Brexit. He instead focused on the importance of Christmas Day to Christians worldwide and offered solidarity to those facing persecution. Johnson's message was seen as a rare opportunity to promote unity, as the country remains divided over its future in the European Union.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch up on oil stocks; NZ hits record in holiday-thinned trade
summary: Australian shares rose 0.04% to a 6,787.80 index level, driven by energy stocks on improved oil prices. Brent crude rose 0.4% to $66.39, amid OPEC's output cut agreement. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index hit a record high, with volumes a fifth of its 30-day average. Energy stocks, including Santos and Woodside, advanced, while the mining sector climbed. The healthcare sector also rose, with CSL and Cochlear gaining.

site_title: Euphoria, greed and fear mark 2010s for commodities investors
summary: The 2010s saw a roller-coaster ride for commodities investors, marked by euphoria, greed, and fear. Mining stocks declined, while chemicals experienced a rise in popularity. A brighter global economy outlook is expected to boost cyclical stocks in 2020. Analysts predict continued appreciation for gold, particularly compared to copper, with chemical companies expected to merge and acquire to boost growth. This trend is expected to continue in 2020, driven by risk-on trades and a shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: Olam books US$27m gain from Gabon divestment
summary: Olam International has booked a one-time gain of US$27 million from divesting 10% of its stake in a Gabon joint venture. The divestment is part of the reorganisation of the joint-venture company, Gabon Special Economic Zone (GSEZ), which aims to develop infrastructure in Gabon. The transaction was completed for US$59 million, releasing US$59 million in cash and resulting in a US$27 million gain for Olam.
