He emphasized the importance of loving the motherland and Macau, which has become a core value in society.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping lavished praise on Macau Thursday for instilling patriotism and rejecting political strife, in stark contrast to his tough words for neighbouring Hong Kong as it convulses with unrest.

site_title: The way forward for open innovation
summary: Companies are shifting from in-house research and development to open innovation, leveraging external knowledge, resources, and networks to improve performance. This approach accelerates product-to-market through licensing intellectual property and attracts ideas from external experts. However, companies must establish a wide range of external partnerships and promote knowledge sharing to develop a successful open innovation ecosystem. Successful examples include Rolls-Royce, which partners with universities and research institutes, and Singapore's Open Innovation Network (OIN), which aims to encourage industry growth through open innovation.

site_title: South Korea cuts 2020 growth target
summary: South Korea has cut its 2020 economic growth target to 2.4% from an initial estimate of 2.6% in July. The country aims to capitalize on easing external risks, including the trade war between the US and China, and boost domestic consumer and corporate spending. The government has also announced a 9.1% increase in fiscal spending and a 62% allocation of budgeted spending to the first half of 2020 to support the economy's recovery. The revised target is higher than market expectations and just above the central bank's forecast of 2.3%.

site_title: 8-year-old is highest paid YouTuber; earned US$26m in 2019
summary: Ryan Kaji, an 8-year-old YouTuber, earned US$26 million in 2019, making him the highest-paid creator on the platform, according to Forbes magazine. His channel, Ryan's World, launched in 2015 and has 22.9 million subscribers. The channel initially focused on "unboxing" videos but now offers educational content. Kaji surpassed Dude Perfect, which earned US$20 million, and Anastasia Radzinskaya, who earned US$18 million, in the Forbes ranking.

site_title: BOE keeps powder dry as Brexit moves into next stages
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) held interest rates at 0.75% in its December meeting, defying calls for an immediate cut. Officials stated that Brexit uncertainty and global growth remain concerns, but expect inflation and growth to pick up over the next few years. The BOE lowered its growth forecast to 0.1% for the fourth quarter and still expects inflation to slow to 1.25% in the spring. The decision comes as the UK prepares to leave the EU on January 31, with a focus on the 2020 trade deal deadline.

site_title: Standards can help governments enhance managing smart cities
summary: Governments are leveraging technology to improve citizen welfare and manage smart cities. The Asean Smart Cities Network aims to promote smart and sustainable development in 10 Asean cities. In Singapore, the Smart Nation Sensor Platform and smart homes enable efficient use of resources and improve situational awareness. Technical standards, such as those developed by ASTM International, are crucial for implementing and managing emerging technologies, ensuring public trust and confidence in infrastructure.

site_title: Swedish central bank ends policy of sub-zero easing
summary: The Swedish central bank, Riksbank, ended its 5-year policy of sub-zero easing by raising its key rate by a quarter point, despite a slowing economy. The move aims to curb risky investing and provide relief to the finance industry. The decision marks a turning point in the history of a policy pioneered by other European economies and the Bank of Japan, which are also exploring negative borrowing costs. The Riksbank's move is expected to test the approach of its global counterparts, including the European Central Bank.

site_title: Now is the time for American sparkling wines
summary: American sparkling wines are gaining recognition globally, despite being largely overshadowed by European counterparts. A recent article highlights the need for consumers to try these wines, which can offer unique flavor profiles and characteristics. Unlike traditional Champagne, American sparkling wines are often made from local grapes and produced using different methods. Three American sparkling wines - Gruet, Roederer Estate, and Schramsberg - were recently featured, showcasing the diversity of American sparkling wines. These wines are available at various price points, making them accessible to a wider audience.

images.alt_text: From left: Roederer Estate Anderson Valley Brut NV; Schramsberg North Coast Blanc de Noirs Brut 2015; and Gruet American Sparkling Wine Brut NV. With sparklers available from all around the wine-producing world, why taste three from the US? The wines themselves answer this question.

site_title: EU extends economic sanctions against Russia for six months
summary: The European Union has extended economic sanctions against Russia for six months until July 31, following an update by French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel on the Minsk agreements aimed at bringing peace to eastern Ukraine. The decision was made due to the agreements' lack of full implementation.

site_title: Swedish, Norwegian crowns lifted by rate decisions
summary: The Swedish and Norwegian crowns rose slightly following central bank policy announcements. The Swedish central bank, Riksbank, became the first to hike its interest rate to zero, ending five years in negative territory. The Norwegian crown was little changed despite the Norges Bank decision to keep rates on hold. The US dollar was down 0.1% against the basket of currencies, unaffected by President Trump's impeachment. The European currencies, including the euro, also saw slight increases.

site_title: US: Wall St edges higher after jobless data; market shrugs off impeachment
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a dip in weekly jobless claims, despite the impeachment of President Donald Trump. The Dow Jones rose 0.14%, the S&P 500 gained 0.04%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.13%. Investors appear to be shrugging off the impeachment, with the market focusing on economic data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US House impeachment vote sets stage for Senate trial
summary: The US House of Representatives voted to impeach President Donald Trump on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, setting the stage for a historic trial in the Republican-controlled Senate. The 230-197 vote on the abuse of power charge and 229-198 vote on the obstruction charge reflected deep partisan divisions. Trump is likely to face a tough time in the Senate, where a two-thirds majority is required to remove him from office. The Senate's top Republican, Mitch McConnell, has predicted there is "no chance" his chamber will remove Trump, and no Republican has indicated they will join Democrats in voting against him.

site_title: Investment banking fees jump 22% to record US$868m for 2019: report
summary: Singapore's investment banking sector generated a record US$868.1 million in fees for FY2019, a 22.1% increase from the previous year. DBS Bank earned the most fees with US$102.4m, while mergers and acquisitions, equity capital markets, and debt capital markets underwriting fees drove the growth. This is the strongest performance since records began in 2000, attributed to improved advisory fees and syndicated lending fees.

site_title: Metal Component can sell dormant Chinese unit without shareholder vote
summary: Metal Component Engineering (MCE) plans to sell its dormant Chinese subsidiary, MCE Industries (Shanghai), to businessman Pan Genfu for 75.5 million yuan (S$14.6 million) without shareholder approval, receiving a waiver from the Singapore Exchange. The sale is considered a non-core asset, and the company expects a gain of about S$8.43 million. The deal is seen as an arm's-length transaction and is not expected to significantly impact MCE's operations or earnings. The sale is subject to Pan Genfu completing due diligence and inking a definitive agreement.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading Thursday afternoon down 0.2% to 3,202.97, tracking Asian market losses. Decliners outnumbered advancers 186 to 151, with Addvalue Technologies slipping 3.1% and Interra Resource gaining 5%. Banking stocks were mixed, while other active securities included Singtel and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Alita Resources, a lithium miner, has secured creditor approval for a deed of company arrangement allowing a Chinese firm to acquire its assets. The deal will result in Alita's delisting from the Singapore Exchange and Australian Securities Exchange. Meanwhile, Citic Envirotech has set a fixed offer price of S$0.55 per share for its takeover bid, and Alliance Healthcare Group has agreed to acquire a 55% stake in healthcare startup Jaga-Me for S$3.5 million. TEE International's share sale has been delayed to Dec 31.

site_title: Lounge In Style
summary: Qantas has opened its new First Lounge at Changi Airport Terminal 1, offering a 1000 sq m space with a tropical design inspired by Singapore. The menu features dishes such as grilled skate in browned sambal butter, created by Australian chef Neil Perry. The lounge includes faux skylights to replicate natural daylight, helping passengers adjust their body clock. The lounge is open to first-class and top-tier frequent fliers from Qantas and oneworld.

site_title: US current account deficit narrows in third quarter
summary: The US current account deficit narrowed to a one-year low in the third quarter, falling to $124.1 billion, the lowest level since 2018. Imports declined sharply, while the surplus on primary income swelled. The deficit on secondary income increased, but overall, the current account gap represented 2.3% of gross domestic product, down from 2.4% in the second quarter. The US is set to become a net exporter of crude and fuel on an annual basis in 2020, thanks to a production surge.

site_title: KS Energy wins fresh contract extension for rig in Vietnam
summary: KS Energy, a Singapore-based oilfield supply and services provider, has secured a contract extension for its KS Java Star 2 jack-up drilling rig in Vietnam, worth approximately US$6.1 million. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on the company's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the year ending December 31. This is the second contract extension for the rig, following a US$5.6 million extension in July 2019.

site_title: Less talk, more action, please, to combat climate change
summary: The National Climate Change Secretariat conducted a survey in May-July 2019, finding that 90% of Singapore residents are aware of climate change and 90% support transitioning to a low-carbon economy. The majority believe climate change is already happening and will affect future generations if no action is taken. 80% of respondents are willing to bear additional costs and inconvenience to play a part in reducing carbon emissions. The survey suggests a strong public support for climate action in Singapore.

site_title: US jobless claims plummet but miss forecasts for bigger drop
summary: US jobless claims dropped by 18,000 to 234,000 in the week ended Dec 14, missing forecasts for a larger decrease. This marks the largest drop since February, but still falls short of expectations. Despite this, claims remain near historic lows and other labor indicators remain healthy. Continuing claims rose 51,000 to 1.72 million, the highest level since August, and the unemployment rate among eligible individuals held steady at 1.2%. The report may raise concerns about the economy if the trend does not return to recent levels.

site_title: Philippines' Cebu Air orders 15 Airbus A320neo family jets
summary: Philippines' Cebu Air Inc has ordered 15 Airbus A320neo family jets worth US$2 billion, with up to 10 of the long-range A321XLR planes. The budget carrier signed the deal during the Paris Air Show in June and finalized the purchase in November. This follows the airline's recent purchase of 16 larger A330neo jets worth US$4.8 billion.

site_title: Singapore firm Avation buys plane with 20m euro green loan
summary: Singapore aircraft leasing company Avation has secured a 10-year, 20 million euro (S$30.2 million) green loan from Deutsche Bank to finance the purchase of an ATR 72-600 plane. The loan, with a principal amount of 20 million euros, will be repaid over 10 years. This purchase is part of Avation's fleet of commercial passenger aircraft, which it leases to airlines globally.

images.alt_text: Avation said the ATR 72-600 turboprop aircraft (pictured), leased to Braathens Regional Airways, emits 40 per cent less carbon dioxide than a comparable regional jet.

site_title: Euro zone bond yields rise, central banks in focus
summary: Euro zone bond yields rose, with Germany's benchmark 10-year bond yield nearing six-month highs, as central banks focused on meetings. Sweden's Riksbank is expected to lift its repo rate to zero, making it the first to dispense with negative interest rates. The European Central Bank, Denmark, and Switzerland have also adopted negative rates. US Treasury yields rose despite the impeachment of President Trump, and investors await Germany's 2020 bond auction calendar, which includes plans to issue its first green bond.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.39 points to 1,595.72. Losers outnumbered gainers 574 to 293, with a total of 2.1 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Real estate investment volume to remain resilient in 2020: CBRE
summary: CBRE predicts Singapore's real estate investment volume will remain resilient in 2020, driven by lower interest rates and macroeconomic stability. Despite a 31.8% drop in total real estate investment volume to S$22.83 billion in 2020, the residential sector drove investment volume, taking up 32.1% of the total. The office sector also contributed significantly, with foreign capital inflows reaching 31.1% of total volumes in 2020, up from 24.3% the previous year.

site_title: Astaka Holdings unit faces contractor's claim
summary: Astaka Holdings' subsidiary, Aliran Asia Sdn Bhd, is claiming RM3.2 million (S$1.05 million) in unpaid sums from Astaka Padu, a Malaysian unit, for work completed as a contractor in 2017. This claim includes interest and costs. The claim was made despite Astaka Holdings' previous rejection of its request to delay its annual general meeting (AGM) and yearly returns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday with a 0.3% loss, snapping a four-day rally, due to investors taking profits and winding down ahead of the festive break. The Hang Seng index closed at 27,800.49, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices barely moved. The losses follow a recent trade deal-fanned boost.

site_title: Three quarters of Asia-Pac businesses consider themselves disrupted by tech change: Baker McKenzie
summary: Three-quarters of Asia-Pacific businesses consider themselves disrupted by technological change, with 30% barely keeping pace and 25% highly adept at exploiting new technologies. The report highlights the need for a top-down, across-the-business response to disruption, as firms struggle to adapt and compete against new entrants born of the online era. Key areas of focus for companies include capturing and using data, cloud computing, AI, and client relationship management systems, with 68% of business leaders identifying big data as a key tech focus.

site_title: Tessa Therapeutics to open cell therapy manufacturing facility next year
summary: TEMASEK-BACKED biotech firm Tessa Therapeutics will open a 90,000 sq. ft. cell therapy manufacturing facility in Singapore next year, enhancing its capabilities in manufacturing and shipments of cell therapy products globally. The facility, which will also house the corporate headquarters, will comply with US FDA, European Medicines Agency, and key Asian regulators. Tessa has produced personalized cell therapies for over 100 patients across five countries and plans to integrate real-time monitoring technology for better standardization and scalability. This move follows recent business and management team expansions.

site_title: Singapore shares dip in lacklustre Thursday session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.12 points or 0.07% to 3,207.42 on Thursday, marking a lackluster session. Markets in Asia-Pacific were mixed, with South Korea posting gains and China being largely flat. Investors showed little reaction to US President Donald Trump's impeachment vote, expecting a likely acquittal in the Senate trial. Trading volume was high, with 1.14 billion securities traded, but decliners outpaced advancers 198-195.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare to make S$3.5m investment in startup Jaga-Me
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group, a CATALIST-listed healthcare operator, plans to invest S$3.5 million in digital healthcare startup Jaga-Me, acquiring a 55% stake. The tie-up aims to leverage Jaga-Me's mobile health capabilities and scalable digital platform for growth. The move follows a board discussion, with Chairman and CEO Barry Thng identifying Jaga-Me as a suitable acquisition target.

site_title: Putin says Trump impeachment based on 'made-up grounds'
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that US President Donald Trump's impeachment, based on allegations of abuse of power, was based on "made-up" grounds. Putin believed the impeachment was a pretext by Democrats to impeach Trump after failing to corner him over Russia election interference claims. He also suggested that Trump's pressure on Ukraine's president to investigate Joe Biden was a separate issue, unrelated to the impeachment. Putin indicated that the Senate's decision on Trump's fate was still uncertain and unlikely to result in Trump's removal from office.

site_title: BMW and Daimler quit carsharing service in US, Canada
summary: BMW and Daimler have announced the discontinuation of their carsharing service, Share Now, in the US and Canada due to lower-than-expected take-up and rising costs. The joint venture, launched a year ago, was expected to invest €1 billion in mobility services. The companies cited a "complicated" market and the volatile global mobility landscape as reasons for the decision, which will come into effect on February 29, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stocks grind higher in pre-holiday trading
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Thursday, driven by gains in media, healthcare, and utilities sectors. The Stoxx 600 index is awaiting the Bank of England's monetary policy decision, while Swedish central bank is expected to hike interest rates. US chipmakers Micron Technology's positive outlook boosted European chipmakers Infineon and STMicroelectronics. Investors have largely shrugged off US impeachment news, with a focus on US-EU trade talks and the upcoming Bank of England decision.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners drag down Australian shares; NZ ends at record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,833.1, driven by losses in banking stocks and miners, while New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high for a second day. Banking stocks, particularly the "big four" banks, led the decline, with National Australia Bank Ltd falling 0.7% after reporting shortcomings in its anti-money laundering systems. The US-China interim trade deal and Brexit developments had eased pressure on markets, but caution remained due to US stocks' steep plunge last year and President Trump's impeachment.

site_title: Taiwan's central bank raises growth outlook amid trade boost
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its 2019 growth forecast to 2.6% and next year's to 2.57%, citing a boost from trade with the US and China potentially ending the trade war. The benchmark interest rate remained unchanged at 1.375%. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg predicted no change, but some noted the central bank may adjust rates if the Taiwan dollar appreciates past NT$30 to the US dollar. The Taiwanese economy showed resilience despite US-China trade tensions, driven by trade redirection and semiconductor investments.

site_title: Property investment volume 'respectable' despite 31.8% drop in 2019: CBRE
summary: Singapore's total real estate investment volume dropped 31.8% to S$22.83 billion in 2019, the lowest since 2016, due to a slower collective sales market. Despite this, the year's performance was considered "respectable" with significant asset transactions. The residential sector drove investment volume, but the trend is unlikely to continue due to unsold residential stock and reduced land for development. The hospitality sector saw a significant increase in hotel-related transactions, driven by rising tourist arrivals and major events. Investment volume in 2020 is expected to remain resilient due to interest from foreign investors and lower interest rates.

site_title: Bank of Japan to begin lending ETFs to investors, unveils details
summary: The Bank of Japan has announced a new scheme to lend exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to investors by up to one year to enhance market liquidity. The central bank will select ETFs from its holdings and lend them to major participants in the ETF market. The move aims to increase market participation and liquidity in the ETF market.

site_title: Ascott Reit, A-HTrust investors to get new stapled units on Dec 31
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) will merge on Dec 31, with unitholders receiving new stapled units. Unitholders of Ascott Reit will receive one Ascott Reit-BT stapled unit for each unit they own, while A-HTrust stapled unitholders will receive S$0.0543 in cash and 0.7942 of an Ascott Reit-BT stapled unit for each security held. The merger, announced in July, received overwhelming investor support. Unstapled Ascott Reit units will trade for the last time on Dec 26, and A-HTrust stapled units will be delisted on Jan 3.

site_title: 'Sizeable' gap between Singapore wealth aspirations and reality: StanChart study
summary: A significant gap exists between Singapore's wealthy individuals' aspirations and reality, with the average monthly sum of US$6,666 projected after retirement falling short of their average wealth aspiration of US$13,611. Only about half of Singapore respondents have reached their halfway mark in reaching their wealth aspirations, beating the global average of 44%. The top financial goals for Singapore's affluent include children's education, while HNWIs prioritize investing in property. Digital investment tools and online portfolios are preferred by the affluent and HNWIs, with savings accounts being a common choice among all three groups.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Research predicts the hospitality sector will be a "dark horse" for S-Reits in 2020 due to demand drivers and limited supply growth. Standard Chartered's Wealth Expectancy Report found Singaporeans' average monthly retirement income falls short of their wealth aspirations. ThaiBev clarified it's not selling its Vietnam business, and the number of women on Singapore company boards increased 4.7% to 18.4% in 2019. Singapore's real estate investment volume dropped 31.8% to S$22.83 billion in 2019, according to CBRE.

site_title: Swiss competition watchdog curbs Swatch watch movement shipments
summary: The Swiss competition watchdog, WEKO, has restricted Swatch Group's shipments of watch mechanisms to other companies until a final decision in mid-2020. Deliveries to existing customers, including Cartier maker Richemont and Chopard, will be suspended from January 1, except for small and mid-sized companies. This decision creates uncertainty for Swiss watchmakers facing competition from smartwatches and slowing demand in Hong Kong. Swatch shares fell 1.1% in pre-market trade.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, ThaiBev, Frasers Property, UOI, Yanlord, Oxley
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) announced a 1.86 billion share subscription for Chinese lender Hengfeng Bank Co, valued at S$360.4 million. Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) clarified it's not seeking a buyer for its Vietnamese business, dismissing "false and baseless" claims. Meanwhile, other stocks to watch include Frasers Property, UOI, Yanlord, and Oxley, but no recent developments were mentioned for these companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks trim early gains on profit booking
summary: South Korean stocks trimmed early gains on Thursday as investors booked profits, despite hitting over seven-month highs. The Kospi index rose 0.08% to 2,196.56, driven by a chipmakers' rally. Analysts attributed the profit booking to concerns over retaining the index's level without strong earnings. Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump became the third US president to be impeached, but market reaction remained muted due to low impeachment prospects. Foreigners were net buyers of 257.8 billion won worth of shares, and the Kospi has risen 7.62% so far this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 12.26 points lower, or 0.77%, at 1,586.85 on Thursday. The index saw a trading volume of 41.08 million lots worth RM21.50 million, with 84 gainers and 75 losers.

site_title: House votes to impeach Trump for obstruction of Congress
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 229-198 to impeach President Donald Trump for obstruction of Congress, becoming the third US president to be impeached. The impeachment is part of a two-article charge, with the House also voting to impeach Trump for abuse of power. Trump will now face a trial in the Senate, where removal from office is unlikely due to Republican control.

site_title: BOE keeps powder dry as Brexit moves into next stages
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) maintained its interest rate at 0.75% during its December meeting, defying calls from two policymakers for an immediate cut. The decision comes as Brexit negotiations move into their next stages, with the UK set to leave the EU on January 31. Officials expect inflation and growth to pick up over the next few years, with a potential series of limited rate hikes needed to meet the 2% inflation target. The BOE also cut its growth forecast for the fourth quarter to 0.1% and expects inflation to slow to 1.25% in the spring.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England (BOE) signalled it will focus on the next phase of Brexit negotiations as two policy makers continued to push for an immediate interest-rate cut.

site_title: Tencent, Sina apps targeted in Chinese privacy crackdown
summary: China has criticized 41 apps, including Tencent's QQ and Sina's sports app, for allegedly forcing users to hand over personal data. The apps were ordered to make changes by Dec 31 or face prosecution. QQ, a popular messaging app, was found to make it hard to deactivate accounts and required authorization of broad data access. Sina Sports was accused of collecting personal information without permission. The industry and information technology ministry has asked over 100 companies to make changes, with more than 8,000 apps complying so far.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as BOJ stands pat
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.29% and the Topix index off 0.13%, due to profit-taking sales with no new market-moving events. The Bank of Japan maintained its policy unchanged, contributing to the decline.

site_title: ThaiBev clarifies not selling Vietnam business; IPO process in early stages
summary: ThaiBev has clarified it is not selling its business in Vietnam, contrary to recent claims. The company is confident in its Vietnamese business, which is a core market and integral to its goal of becoming a regional beverage leader. ThaiBev is still considering a potential Singapore listing of some regional beer assets, but the process is in its early stages with no certainty of a transaction.

site_title: OCBC adds 2 leaders to management committee
summary: OCBC Bank has added two senior leaders to its management committee, with Sunny Quek taking over as head of consumer financial services, Singapore, and Wang Ke appointed as CEO of OCBC Wing Hang Bank (China). Quek, 46, joined OCBC in 2012, while Wang, 51, has held various senior roles, including regional general manager of the Pearl River Delta region. The new appointments reflect the bank's strong internal talent base for succession planning and aim to drive growth in wealth management and Greater China.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up on tech, gold firms; New Zealand scales new peak
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,855.9, buoyed by gains in technology and gold firms, despite Brexit and trade truce developments being addressed. The benchmark closed flat across Tuesday and Wednesday. Technology stocks rose 0.6%, while gold stocks added 0.1%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index hit a record high, up 0.8% after data showed a faster-than-expected economic growth in the third quarter.

site_title: IBM's new battery design taps seawater as alternative mineral source
summary: IBM has developed a battery design that uses materials extracted from seawater, eliminating the need for cobalt, a key component in lithium-ion batteries. The new design, in partnership with Mercedes-Benz, Central Glass, and Sidus, aims to reduce costs and improve charging times. IBM claims its technology outperforms traditional lithium-ion batteries in cost, charging time, and energy efficiency. The company is also working on a quantum computing initiative with the University of Tokyo, aiming to commercialize the technology in the next few years.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps policy steady, offers gloomier view on output
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary settings steady, keeping interest rates at -0.1% and 10-year government bond yields at 0%. Despite a gloomier view on factory output, citing the impact of global risks and the US-China trade war, the BOJ still expects Japan's economy to expand moderately. The decision aligns with the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank's holding pattern for monetary policy. The BOJ also revised its view on industrial production, citing natural disasters, and Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is expected to emphasize the bank's readiness to ease policy if risks threaten the economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets tick lower after healthy rally as dealers step back
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as traders unwound ahead of the Christmas break, following a healthy rally fueled by the China-US trade pact. Despite a recent run of positive economic data, investors were cautious due to ongoing trade uncertainty and Brexit. The Dow and S&P 500 dipped slightly, while the Nasdaq reached an all-time high. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo, also fell, with Seoul remaining flat. Analysts expect a shift in the global growth rally trade in 2020.

site_title: Uptick in women's representation on Singapore boards this year: MSCI study
summary: Singapore saw a 4.7 percentage point increase in women's representation on company boards to 18.4% in 2019, according to MSCI's study. Despite this, the country still fell short of the global average of 20% for female directors. However, Singapore outpaced the global average in having female CEOs (7.7%) and CFOs (30.8%). A separate survey found that 39% of Singapore-listed companies had no female directors, a decrease from 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on upside
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains on Thursday morning, driven by investors unwinding for the festive break and awaiting developments in the US-China trade situation. The Hang Seng index rose 0.09% to 27,908.78, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices were barely moved. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance of the S&P 500 in the US.

site_title: Hot stock: Moya jumps 13% on heavy volume, calls for trading halt
summary: Moya Holdings, an Indonesian water treatment company, saw its shares surge 13.4% on Thursday, with over 25.4 million shares traded. The company had announced plans to issue new shares to its managing director, and Indonesian tycoon Anthoni Salim has a deemed interest of 72.84% in Moya shares. Moya called for a trading halt pending an announcement, amid active trading in the morning. The company's latest bourse filing, made on November 7, noted that it "constantly assesses and/or engages in discussions with parties on new investment opportunities".

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.12%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index losing 3.98 points or 0.12% to 3,205.56. Despite mixed trading, gainers beat losers 61 to 56. Key movers included TEE International, Addvalue Technologies, and Singtel, with DBS and OCBC advancing while UOB slipped. The Dow Jones fell 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.05%. The decline was attributed to a weak US market, with FedEx shares diving on disappointing earnings.

site_title: British PM Johnson sets out plan for power
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to outline his government's plans following a landslide election win, focusing on delivering Brexit and supporting the health service. The Queen will open parliament in a ceremony where Johnson will read out his legislative programme. A bill to ratify Britain's exit from the EU, negotiated by Johnson, will be top of his to-do list, with a goal to "Get Brexit Done" by January 31. Johnson has also vowed to address public services concerns, including a bill to increase spending for the National Health Service.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS sees hospitality sector as S-Reit 'dark horse' for 2020
summary: DBS Group Research predicts the Singapore hospitality sector could be a "dark horse" for growth in 2020, driven by increased demand from traffic diversions, robust event outlooks, and merger and acquisition activities. The sector may see a 1% rise in distribution per unit, with potential for upward surprise. DBS analysts favor sectors with structural growth trends, such as data centers, business parks, and logistics, and expect the sector's yield curve to steepen by 25 basis points in 2020 and 2021, bringing 10-year yields to 2.25%.

site_title: Homeward bound? Deadline looms for North Korea's overseas workers
summary: North Korea's overseas workers, who have earned the country a significant fortune, face a deadline to return home by this Sunday. The UN Security Council ordered countries where they work to send them back as part of efforts to pressure Pyongyang over its nuclear and ballistic missile programmes. Despite the deadline, many workers, including a waitress in Beijing, remain optimistic about returning home for the holidays but plan to return to their jobs abroad. The UN's compliance deadline has raised concerns about the impact on North Korea's economy.

site_title: Micron signals recovery in 2020, says received supply licenses for Huawei
summary: Micron Technology reported a recovery in 2020, citing a "cyclical bottom" in the second quarter. The company received all requested licenses to supply products to Huawei Technologies, its largest customer, despite US restrictions. Micron's quarterly earnings beat Wall Street estimates, with shares rising nearly 4% in extended trading. CEO Sanjay Mehrotra expects the business to recover in the third quarter of fiscal 2020, with continued growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on Bank of Japan meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.12% or 29.84 points to 23,904.59, amid anticipation of the Bank of Japan policy meeting later in the day.

site_title: Puma Energy to sell Australia fuels business for A$425m
summary: Puma Energy, a retail and midstream arm of Trafigura, will sell its Australian fuels business to Chevron Australia for A$425 million. The sale comes amid efforts to rebalance its books after a decade-long buying spree. Puma Energy entered the Australian market in 2013 and paid around US$850 million for the assets. The sale excludes Puma's bitumen business in Australia, which is not part of the transaction. The move follows Trafigura's lowest annual net profit in nearly a decade.

site_title: Oil trader Vitol sues US demanding US$52m tax refund
summary: Vitol, a major independent oil trader, is suing the US government for over US$52 million in fuel taxes it claims were improperly collected. The company, which handles 7.4 million barrels of crude daily, alleges the US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) failed to refund federal excise taxes paid from 2014 to 2017 due to incorrect classification of fuel blends. Vitol claims its production of alternative fuel mixtures entitled it to tax credits, which the IRS allegedly denied. The case is pending in US District Court in Houston.

site_title: Bank of England says third-party supplier misused bank's audio feed
summary: The Bank of England reported that a third-party supplier accessed its audio feed without consent, sending it to high-speed traders to gain an advantage. The misuse occurred since earlier this year and has been curbed once identified. The supplier will not be involved in future press conferences. The Bank of England is investigating the incident further, describing it as "wholly unacceptable."

images.alt_text: Bank of England (BoE) said on Wednesday that a third-party supplier accessed the audio feed of some of its press conferences without consent to provide services to other external clients.

site_title: UK companies fear hit from Brexit migration rules: CBI
summary: UK businesses fear a new post-Brexit immigration system could lead to a shortage of skilled workers and cause economic uncertainty. A CBI survey found 70% of 304 companies believe reduced access to skilled workers is the biggest threat to the labour market. Simplifying the immigration policy is crucial, according to CBI policy director Matthew Fell. The survey also showed weaker hiring expectations and a perception that the UK's labour market has become less attractive to investors.

site_title: UK house prices to rise 2% in 2020 as Brexit uncertainty remains: RICS
summary: UK house prices are expected to rise 2% in 2020, similar to last year's growth, due to ongoing Brexit uncertainty. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's election win, RICS economist Tarrant Parsons believes Brexit uncertainty will weigh on prices and sales volumes. Affordability and low stock levels will continue to affect the market. RICS also forecasts a 2.5% rise in rents and a flat outlook for overall sales volumes. The prediction is in line with a Reuters poll of economists, which also predicts a 1.5% rise for 2020.

site_title: Australian jobs rebound in Nov, pares risk of Feb rate cut
summary: Australian employment rebounded with 39,900 net new jobs created in November, reducing pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates in February. The unemployment rate ticked down to 5.2%, its eighth straight month in the 5.2-5.3% range. While the job market appears to be recovering, economists caution that wage growth will continue to soften, and the Bank still needs to take action. The RBA has pared the chance of a rate cut, with futures now implying a 38% chance of a quarter-point easing in February.

images.alt_text: Australian employment rebounded sharply in November after a shock drop the previous month, while the jobless rate ticked down in a sign the labour market might still have enough life in it to lessen the need for more interest rate cuts.

site_title: Alita Resources creditors approve rescue plan from potential new owners
summary: Creditors of lithium miner Alita Resources have approved a deed of company arrangement (DOCA) for the acquisition of its assets by China Hydrogen Energy (CHE) and its Australian subsidiary Liatam Mining. The plan, which includes the transfer of 100% of Alita shares to Liatam for nil consideration, aims to restructure the company's debt and avoid insolvency. The transfer is subject to court approval and conditions precedent, including the establishment of two creditors' trusts and approval from Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board.

site_title: Solemnity, tension for Trump impeachment reckoning
summary: The US House of Representatives held a historic debate on the impeachment of President Donald Trump, with lawmakers from both parties facing intense pressure and partisan divisions. Despite Republican efforts to slow the process, the chamber's Democratic majority is expected to approve two articles of impeachment, marking a significant step towards Trump's potential removal from office. The solemn and tense atmosphere was marked by heated exchanges and emotional appeals, highlighting the deepening partisan divide in Washington.

site_title: Bank of England to stay on hold as Brexit saga plays on
summary: The Bank of England will maintain interest rates at 0.75% amid Brexit uncertainty, with 69 economists predicting no change. The decision comes despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's proposal to rule out a Brexit extension beyond 2020, which could lead to an economically damaging exit. Economists expect the BoE to keep rates on hold or possibly lower them in 2020, with some predicting a rate cut in August. The Bank's decision is influenced by the uncertainty surrounding Britain's departure from the EU and the potential impact on the economy.

site_title: India leads world in pollution-linked deaths: study
summary: India leads the world in pollution-linked deaths, accounting for 2.3 million deaths in 2017, followed by China with 1.8 million deaths. Pollution is the largest environmental cause of premature death globally, responsible for 15% of all deaths, or 8.3 million people. The report also found that Nigeria, Indonesia, and Pakistan had high numbers of pollution deaths. The US ranked seventh with almost 200,000 deaths. Pollution-linked deaths rates were highest in impoverished countries with poor sanitation and contaminated indoor air.

site_title: Amazon publishes French taxes after accusations of underpayment
summary: Amazon has published its French tax returns, showing it paid 250 million euros in 2019, after accusations of underpayment. The move comes as France has introduced a new digital tax for internet giants, which Amazon has criticized as discriminatory. The US e-commerce giant plans to pass on the costs of the new tax to businesses using its Marketplace platform, rather than taking the hit itself. Amazon's French tax chief, Frederic Duval, said the company's growth in France warrants increased contributions to public services and the French social model.

site_title: Eight-year-old is highest paid YouTuber, earns US$26m in year
summary: Eight-year-old YouTuber Ryan Kaji earned $26 million in 2019, surpassing last year's earnings of $22 million, to become the highest-paid creator on the platform. His channel "Ryan's World" has 22.9 million subscribers and has received almost 35 billion views since its creation. The channel was renamed after a consumer advocacy organization accused it of not clearly denoting sponsored videos. Kaji's earnings surpassed that of "Dude Perfect" and child star Anastasia Radzinskaya, who earned $18 million at age five.

site_title: NauticAWT proposes to buy stake in Thai casual restaurant operator for 70m baht
summary: NauticAWT, an oil and gas engineering group, has entered into a share purchase agreement to acquire a 35% stake in Rich Restaurant Company's Thai casual restaurant operator, Chokdee Dimsum, for 70 million baht (S$3.1 million). This acquisition is part of NauticAWT's expansion into the food and beverage sector in Thailand, funded by proceeds from its July share subscription. Chokdee Dimsum operates 24 branches, serving Chinese-style dim sum and bak kut teh. The acquisition is in line with NauticAWT's diversification into the F&B business, announced in November.

site_title: Casinos didn't bet on how hard it would be to crack the Japanese market
summary: Casino executives in Japan are questioning the feasibility of the US$20 billion gaming market due to difficulties in the approval process. Despite Japan legalizing casino gambling in 2016, the process has been slower than expected, with unclear tax and gaming policies, delays, and local government and resident opposition. This has led to companies like Caesars Entertainment Corp pulling out, and some estimating the cost of building an integrated resort to be around US$10 billion or more. The lack of clarity on government policies governing casinos is adding to the uncertainty, making it harder for operators to decide whether the market is worth the trouble.

site_title: New Zealand economic growth accelerated in Q3
summary: New Zealand's economy experienced accelerated growth in the third quarter, with a 2.3% increase in gross domestic product (GDP) from the previous year, beating economists' forecasts. The growth rate was higher than the 0.7% increase from the previous quarter and matches the 2.1% growth in the second quarter. The Reserve Bank's interest rate may not need to be cut further, with bets on rate cuts decreasing due to improving business confidence and rising house prices.

site_title: Airbus sees strong sales haul this year on Asia demand, long-range A321
summary: Airbus expects to end 2019 with a higher-than-expected order backlog due to strong demand in Asia, particularly for its long-range A321 medium-range jet. The company's sales are expected to surpass deliveries, beating rival Boeing, which is grounded due to the 737 MAX crisis. This growth is attributed to a surge in business in Asia and the launch of the new A321 variant, positioning Airbus for a strong 2019.

site_title: Bushfire state of emergency declared in Australia
summary: A state of emergency was declared in Australia's New South Wales state due to record-breaking heat and bushfires. The emergency, lasting seven days, comes as 100 fires have been burning, with half uncontained, including a "mega-blaze" surrounding Sydney. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian attributed the state of emergency to "catastrophic weather conditions."

site_title: Policymakers and regulators: More discipline, less fear of missing out for 2020
summary: Governments and regulators are entering the new year with a cautious optimism, as the US economy shows signs of recovery and fears of a major recession subside. Policymakers are urged to adopt a disciplined approach to asset prices, recognizing the presence of bubbles and taking steps to mitigate them. This includes implementing measures to rein in excessive exuberance, ensuring level playing fields, and investing in building social and economic resilience. Those who prioritize prudence over short-term gains will be better positioned to weather future economic storms.

site_title: Facebook says it can still locate users who opt out of tracking
summary: Facebook claims it can still locate users who opt out of tracking, despite their selection. The social network revealed in a letter to US senators that clues, such as being tagged in a photo or sharing an address, can help determine a user's location. Facebook argues that knowing a user's general location aids in account protection by detecting suspicious login behavior. The company's statement contradicts Republican Senator Josh Hawley's claim that there is no opting out of personal information, sparking concerns about user control.

site_title: Ex-Worldcom CEO Ebbers granted early release from jail due to ill health
summary: Disgraced former Worldcom CEO Bernard Ebbers, 78, was granted early release from prison due to his poor health. Ebbers served about 13 years of his 25-year sentence for masterminding a $11 billion accounting fraud in 2002. His family claimed he suffered severe mental and physical deterioration, while prosecutors argued he exaggerated his condition. Ebbers will be released from prison in Fort Worth, Texas, following a compassionate release request.

site_title: Online store to relaunch French fashion house Sonia Rykiel
summary: The online store Showroomprive announced the relaunch of French fashion house Sonia Rykiel, nearly five months after its demise. The brand, founded by the "Queen of Knits" Sonia Rykiel, was wound up by court in July due to loss-making. Eric and Michael Dayan, co-founders of Showroomprive, have acquired the brand's assets and plan to promote it in France and abroad, describing it as a "flagship of French heritage". The Sonia Rykiel brand, once an icon of youthful revolt, will relaunch in 2020 as a new adventure for the brand and the entrepreneurs.

site_title: Australia must respect China if relations are to improve - Chinese envoy
summary: Australia must abandon criticism of China and view the country's largest trading partner as an opportunity to improve relations, according to Beijing's ambassador to Canberra. Relations have deteriorated amid accusations of China meddling in Australia's domestic affairs and seeking undue influence in the Pacific region. The ambassador's comments come amid China's economic slowdown, which may put pressure on policymakers. The Australian government's tough stance on China has led to a decline in bilateral relations, and a change in approach is needed for improvement. A meeting between US Senator Rubio and China's Wang on the sidelines of Asean talks is also expected.

site_title: US: Stocks rally shows sign of fatigue as FedEx sinks
summary: US stocks rallied, but showed signs of fatigue, with the Nasdaq reaching a new peak while the Dow and S&P 500 retreated slightly. FedEx shares plummeted 10% after missing analyst estimates due to high e-commerce costs and weak global economic conditions. Investors remained optimistic despite an impending House vote to impeach President Trump, expecting a Republican-controlled Senate to block removal. Meanwhile, German business climate index improved, and a merger between PSA and Fiat Chrysler was announced.

site_title: Europe: Shares tick lower, but defensive buying caps losses
summary: European shares declined on Wednesday due to concerns over a potentially hard Brexit, despite defensive sectors limiting losses. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.13% as automobile makers led losses, while defensive sectors like consumer goods and oil and gas stocks gained. A hard Brexit deadline set by UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and a survey showing improved business morale in Germany partially offset concerns.

images.alt_text: European shares inched lower on Wednesday on worries over a potentially hard Brexit, while gains in defensive sectors capped losses.

site_title: PropertyGuru CEO vows comeback after IPO flop
summary: PropertyGuru's CEO Hari Krishnan vows to revive the company after its failed initial public offering (IPO) in October. The IPO was pulled just two days before its planned listing due to concerns over its valuation of A$1.36 billion. Krishnan says the company will consider alternative options, including a listing in Singapore or the US, if market conditions are right. Despite the setback, Krishnan believes the company's fundamentals are strong, with a proven track record in Southeast Asia and growing revenue. The failed IPO is part of a broader trend in the tech sector where private valuations have not aligned with public markets.

site_title: US dollar gains as Fed rate cuts more unlikely
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and pound due to the Federal Reserve's reduced likelihood of cutting interest rates further. US industrial production rebounded in November, mainly due to an end to a General Motors strike. The dollar rose to a six-day high against six major currencies, while the euro struggled below its 200-day moving average. The US may raise tariffs on European goods, re-igniting trade deficit concerns, and the US dollar is expected to experience weakness in 2020, according to analysts.

site_title: Oil steadies on US crude inventories fall, demand hopes
summary: Oil prices steadied on Wednesday after US crude inventories fell by 1.1 million barrels to 446.8 million barrels, contrary to industry expectations. Brent futures gained 7 cents to $66.17 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) ended down 1 cent at $60.93 a barrel. The data, combined with expectations for an uptick in demand next year due to the resolution of the US-China trade fight, supported oil prices. Opec+ plans to cut production by 500,000 barrels per day from January 1 to support the market.

site_title: Boeing's MAX freeze divides suppliers into haves and have-nots
summary: Boeing has temporarily halted production of its 737 MAX aircraft, exposing contrasts in the US-dominated supply chain. The move affects about 680 suppliers, with niche machine shops and those providing materials or structures, such as Spirit AeroSystems, likely to be disproportionately impacted. Boeing may pay suppliers to continue working, but payments may not come quickly. The halt has created uncertainty about Boeing's ability to increase production levels once the MAX resumes flying, potentially affecting suppliers' access to capital and talent.

site_title: Bolivia orders arrest of ex-president Morales
summary: Bolivia's attorney general ordered the arrest of exiled former president Evo Morales on charges of sedition and terrorism. Morales, who fled Bolivia in October after a disputed re-election, denied the allegations, calling them "illegal, unfair, and unconstitutional." The interim government, led by Jeanine Anez, has barred Morales from standing in upcoming elections, which are expected to be held early next year. Morales, who ruled Bolivia for nearly 14 years, has vowed to continue his political struggle despite his arrest.

site_title: Researchers say may have found cause of mad cow disease
summary: Researchers believe they may have found the cause of mad cow disease, a neurodegenerative illness in cattle, by injecting a scrapie variant into mice that developed the prion of bovine origin. The study, published in PNAS, shows that the illness can jump from one species to another, supporting the presence of classic mad cow disease in natural form in the scrapie variant prions. This finding brings an experimentally underpinned explanation to the appearance of mad cow disease in the UK in the 1980s, which then spread globally.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Public housing market recap for 2019
summary: Mohamed Ismail Gafoor, chairman and CEO of Propnex, reviews the 2019 public housing market trends and predictions for 2020. Key trends include a decrease in public housing prices and an increase in demand for affordable housing. Gafoor also notes that the market is expected to be more competitive in 2020, with more developers launching projects. Overall, the public housing market is expected to remain stable, with some fluctuations due to government policies and economic factors.

site_title: Blockchain payment startup Terra expands to Singapore, hires ex-Uber exec
summary: Terra, a blockchain payment network, has established its South-east Asia hub in Singapore with plans to expand across the region. Rahul Abrol, former Uber Asia-Pacific head of strategy, has joined Terra as head of international business and strategy. Terra aims to grow its on-the-ground network through partnerships with local businesses, including Carousell and Qoo10, and will launch its stablecoin-powered mobile payment app in Singapore in early 2020. The startup plans to set up operations in at least five other markets, including Taiwan and Thailand, with the goal of acquiring a license from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: M&G Real Estate adds 12 properties to Japan portfolio
summary: M&G Real Estate has acquired a 12-property residential portfolio in Japan, increasing its Japanese exposure to 22% and residential exposure to 10%. The portfolio, comprising properties in prime districts in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Fukuoka, is the company's second residential acquisition in Japan this year, following a $57 million purchase in October. M&G Real Estate expects a moderate supply of new homes in Japan, sustaining high demand for rental homes and aiming to provide stable and core income for its investors.

site_title: India's 'chilli region' needs to get hotter
summary: India's North Eastern Region (NER), known for its unique products like the Bhut Jolokia chili, could benefit from a global branding exercise, "Brand North East", highlighting its strengths in healthy living, environmental sustainability, social responsibility, and service orientation. The region has a vast production of bamboo products, a growing medical tourism sector, and a well-educated workforce. However, its exports are limited, with only US$500 million in 2015-16. To boost growth, the NER should focus on the services sector, particularly tourism, education, and information technology, and leverage its transit trade potential with neighboring countries.

site_title: China says lifting some UN sanctions on North Korea could help break deadlock
summary: China and Russia are pushing the UN Security Council to lift some sanctions on North Korea to ease humanitarian concerns and break the deadlock in denuclearization talks. China's UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, stated that lifting sanctions is necessary to accommodate North Korea's concerns, which are "legitimate." A draft resolution proposes lifting a ban on exports of statues, seafood, and textiles, and easing restrictions on infrastructure projects and North Koreans working overseas. The resolution requires nine votes in favor, with no vetoes by the US, France, Britain, Russia, or China, to pass.

site_title: China's liquidity jitters about to test bond market again
summary: China's central bank is expected to provide liquidity to the financial system in January to avoid panic in the bond market, driven by a "liquidity hole" of 2.8 trillion yuan due to withdrawals for the Chinese New Year holiday. Analysts predict the central bank may cut reserve ratios or inject funds through open-market operations, but no massive net liquidity injection or interest-rate cut is expected. The move aims to stabilize the market without fueling inflation, which is at a seven-year high, and is seen as a short-term solution rather than a broader easing cycle.

site_title: Oil − Have mercy
summary: Gold prices rose after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada and threatened others, sparking a bearish outlook for oil. Oil prices fell as a result. Meanwhile, China's solar stocks surged amid efforts by Beijing to calm price wars. OPEC announced a reduction in oil demand for the next four years. Additionally, reports emerged that Aster was in talks to buy Exxon's Singapore stations and Chinese tycoons are investing in Indonesia's aluminium industry.

site_title: Immerse yourself in the holiday spirit
summary: A Weekend magazine special edition explores how people are celebrating the holiday season with unique decorations, festive menus, and community events. The article features chefs from around the world sharing their favorite Christmas recipes, a Tokyo Christmas light display, and a look at the Singapore Biennale, a socially-inclusive art exhibition. Meanwhile, a private members' club founder discusses his mission to create spaces for entrepreneurs and creatives to inspire one another. The issue also touches on various lifestyle topics and upcoming events.

site_title: Ascott on track to achieve global target of 160,000 units by 2023: CEO
summary: Ascott, the lodging business unit of CapitaLand, is on track to achieve its global target of 160,000 units by 2023, CEO Kevin Goh said. The company aims to open about 10,000 units in 2020 and has already signed 25 new franchise and management contracts for over 3,400 units across Asia-Pacific and Africa. Ascott has reached about 115,000 units in over 700 properties worldwide, with more than 60% of its operational portfolio generating S$182.1 million in fee income.

site_title: WeWork gets US$1.75b credit line from Goldman Sachs
summary: WeWork has secured a US$1.75 billion senior secured letter of credit from Goldman Sachs as part of SoftBank Group's US$9.5 billion bailout. The credit line, expected to be available in January, will free up approximately US$800 million in restricted cash. The facility is part of a three-part bailout that includes a tender offer to buy WeWork shares, acceleration of a US$1.5 billion payment, and new debt. The tender offer is ongoing but not expected to be completed until the first quarter of 2020, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Oklahoma uni sued over struggling luxury dorm project
summary: The University of Oklahoma is being sued by a non-profit that financed the $250 million Cross Village luxury dorm project. The lawsuit claims the university broke its promise to rent retail and parking spaces, making the project financially unviable. The non-profit seeks over $250 million in damages, stating it would not have built the dorm if assured of a revenue stream from commercial space and parking. The case highlights the risk of projects relying on third-party support to ensure bondholders are repaid.

site_title: UK inflation holds below BOE target before rates meeting
summary: UK inflation remained at a three-year low in November, at 1.5% annual rate, below the Bank of England's 2% target. This is the second consecutive month of low inflation, ahead of the BOE's interest rate announcement on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The BOE said last month that inflation would probably fall to 1.25% in early-2020, but was likely to be back above its 2% target in three years' time.

site_title: Climate change to have greater impact on investments in 2020: Schroders
summary: Climate change is expected to have a greater impact on investments in 2020, according to a Schroders report. Growing public concern, regulatory pressure, and demands for corporate climate disclosures are driving asset flows into climate-related investments. Retail investors prioritize climate action, and financial regulators are introducing climate change investment stress tests. This may lead to significant changes in portfolios as regulatory pressure builds. Total global equity earnings could be hit by up to 15% due to transition risks. Climate-related risks and opportunities will become a norm among stakeholders.

site_title: StanChart stops funding three S-E Asia coal plants worth US$7b
summary: Standard Chartered has stopped funding three coal-fired power plants in South-east Asia, worth an estimated US$7 billion, amid global pressure to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The projects, in Vietnam and Indonesia, are among several in the region facing funding challenges. The move by the Asia-focused bank comes as environmental groups and investors pressure the coal industry to align with the Paris Climate Agreement's goal of virtually ending coal power by 2050. This decision is seen as a significant step in reducing carbon emissions and aligning finance with climate goals.

site_title: Breakdancing countertenor with the voice of an angel
summary: Polish countertenor Jakub Jozef Orlinski is a rising star in classical music, hailed as the "baroque 'n' roll" star for his unique blend of 18th-century music and hip-hop. At 29, he has gained international recognition, including being named Young Artist of the Year by Gramaphone magazine, and has performed in concert halls and opera houses worldwide. Orlinski's charisma and versatility have also made him a social media sensation, with a viral video of him singing in Bermuda shorts and sneakers. He is now signed to Warner Classics and is working with contemporary composers to combine his two passions, including a potential hip-hop opera inspired by Hamilton.

site_title: STI among gainers in mixed Asian trade
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,209.54, adding 8.74 points or 0.3% on Wednesday, outperforming other Asian markets. Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Taiwan posted gains, while China and Japan were lower. Local banks, such as DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank, drove the STI's gains. Companies like ISOTeam, Broadway Industrial Group, and Oxley Holdings also saw increases. Trading volume was 1.30 billion securities, 9% over the daily average in the first 11 months of 2019.

site_title: Thailand holds key rate, cuts economic forecasts as exports stumble
summary: Thailand's central bank, Bank of Thailand, left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low of 1.25% as exports suffered due to the US-China trade war and a strong baht. The Bank of Thailand also trimmed its 2019 GDP growth forecast to 2.5% from 2.8%, citing the economic impact. The decision was made after the monetary policy committee voted unanimously.

site_title: Japan raises economic growth forecast for next fiscal year
summary: Japan's government has raised its economic growth forecast for the next fiscal year to 1.4% in price-adjusted real terms, up from 1.2% previously, due to an expected boost from a $122 billion fiscal package. The forecast is driven by stronger domestic demand and capital spending, which is expected to grow 2.7% next fiscal year. Exports fell for the 12th consecutive month in November, with shipments to the US and China declining, but the government expects the fiscal package to offset weakness in external demand.

images.alt_text: Japan's shipments to the US declined for the fourth straight month, falling 12.9 per cent in the year to November, hurt by reduced shipments of cars, construction machinery and car parts.

site_title: HK cancels New Year's Eve fireworks amid security concerns
summary: Hong Kong's New Year's Eve fireworks will be cancelled for the first time in a decade due to security concerns amid ongoing protests. The event will be replaced with a multimedia light show, featuring projections on skyscrapers and small-scale pyrotechnics. The cancellation follows a 56% year-on-year decline in tourist arrivals in November, and comes after several high-profile events, including a rugby tournament and a music festival, were scrapped. The Hong Kong Tourism Board prioritizes public safety, citing the need to adapt to the current situation in the city.

site_title: UOI to buy 146 Robinson Road from UOB for S$52 million
summary: UNITED Overseas Insurance (UOI) plans to buy the 12-storey office building at 146 Robinson Road from United Overseas Bank (UOB) for S$52 million. The property will be UOI's first real estate investment, and it intends to move its operations into the premises. The acquisition aims to enhance UOI's corporate image and branding, while providing a hedge against rental increases in the property market and diversifying its income stream. The transaction, valued at 13.74% of UOI's net tangible assets, requires shareholder approval and is expected to be completed by Feb 28, 2020.

site_title: Historic marine-fuel switch looms, but key countries aren't ready
summary: The International Maritime Organisation's (IMO) new rules to reduce sulphur oxide emissions from ships are set to take effect in January, but enforcement is uncertain. Despite 95 countries agreeing to implement the rules, key countries with significant oil-refining capacity, such as South Africa and the UAE, have yet to prepare. Enforcement will rely on individual states, but transparency and consistency are lacking, raising concerns about a level playing field. The IMO estimates that up to 20% of vessels may initially break the rules, but international pressure to comply means that non-compliance would be costly for shipping companies.

site_title: Luxury TV and stereo maker B&O warns of sales decline, lower profit margin
summary: Bang & Olufsen (B&O) issues its fourth profit warning in a year, citing fierce competition and poor sales, resulting in a 31% sales decline in the second quarter. The company expects revenue to drop 13-18% in its 2019-20 financial year and its earnings before interest and tax margin to drop 4-9%. B&O's CEO Kristian Tear attributes the slump to increased competition in wireless earphones and unsatisfactory sales, and vows to create a new three-year plan to address the issue. The company's share price has fallen by 70% over the past year.

site_title: Oxley JV company appoints developer for Negeri Selangor land
summary: Oxley Holdings' joint-venture company, Peninsular Teamwork, has appointed Grand Place Development to develop a 6.1588-hectare residential housing project in Negeri Selangor, Malaysia. The landowner will receive 103 million ringgit (S$33.7 million) plus a percentage of development profit. The development agreement is conditional on approval from relevant authorities and revisions to existing plans. Grand Place Development is an affiliate of Trinity Group, a boutique developer with a track record in Klang Valley, Malaysia.

site_title: COEs all down in year's last tender
summary: COE premiums in Singapore's last tender of 2019 ended lower, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp at S$32,889, and those above 1,600cc or 130bhp at S$36,000. Commercial vehicle COEs closed at S$23,200, while motorcycle premiums dropped to S$3,658. The gap between Category A and B premiums narrowed to less than S$4,000, down from S$10,000 or more, due to private-hire fleet owners switching to smaller cars and the pre-launch sale of the new Toyota Corolla Altis.

site_title: Who will be next to merge in the S-Reit universe?
summary: Industry watchers predict further consolidation in the S-Reit sector in 2020, with three potential merger candidates. ESR Reit and Sabana Reit are seen as a likely combination due to ESR's control of Sabana Reit's manager and its plans to scale. Another potential merger is between Cache Logistics Trust and Cromwell European Reit, driven by the ongoing rivalry between their sponsors. The third potential combination is between CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Retail China Trust, with CapitaLand seeking to expand its overseas presence.

site_title: Hyflux plot takes another twist with new debt offer
summary: A new player, Aqua Munda, a Singapore-registered firm, has entered the Hyflux debt market with a proposal to buy out the company's debt, totaling around S$1.8 billion, or nearly two-thirds of Hyflux's total debt. This development may unsettle the rescue package currently on the table for Hyflux, which signed a S$400 million deal with Utico last month. Aqua Munda, backed by a Middle Eastern investor group, offers a quicker repayment option, but creditors may need to accept a steeper discount to exit the saga.

site_title: Tencent-backed Beike mulls US$1b IPO
summary: Beike Zhaofang, a Tencent-backed Chinese online property brokerage platform, is considering a potential US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company, which launched in 2018, is working with an adviser for the share sale, which could take place as early as 2020. This comes after a Chinese online real estate broker raised US$78 million via a downsized IPO in November. Beike's offering is at an early stage, and details may still change.

site_title: Hong Kong is not Crimea, thankfully
summary: Hong Kong's ongoing social turbulence, sparked by the extradition bill in June 2019, bears similarities to the 2014 Crimea crisis, including large-scale protests and involvement of big powers. However, key differences include Hong Kong's lack of desire for independence and China's firm control over the territory. Unlike Crimea, Hong Kong's stability and prosperity depend on its own hands, and large-scale casualties are unlikely due to China and the West's reluctance to intervene militarily. The territory's future lies in regaining its reputation and addressing its underlying issues.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Japfa proposes a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to raise up to S$93.5 million, using funds to repay borrowings. Koufu subsidiary Super Tea enters a joint venture in Indonesia, while Yanlord Land Group sells out 149 apartment units in Hangzhou, generating S$405 million in pre-sales. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen collaboration in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks notch a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Peugeot-maker PSA and Fiat Chrysler to merge; deal will create US$46b automaker
summary: PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV agreed to a 50-50 merger, creating the world's fourth-largest automaker with a $46 billion stock-market value. The combined company will be led by PSA's Carlos Tavares and Fiat's John Elkann. The deal aims to pool resources for product development, manufacturing, and purchasing, addressing growing industry challenges such as trade wars, electric vehicles, and emissions regulations. The merger will give PSA a presence in North America and help Fiat gain ground in low-emission technology.

images.alt_text: The combined company will be led by PSA chief executive officer Carlos Tavares (left), with Fiat chairman John Elkann (right) holding the same role at the enlarged firm.

site_title: Japan plans to trim total government bond issuance next fiscal year
summary: Japan plans to trim its total government bond issuance by 0.5% next fiscal year, marking the seventh straight year of declines. The government aims to sell 128.8 trillion yen of Japanese government bonds, down from this year's 129.4 trillion yen. This move aims to balance supporting growth with reining in huge public debt, despite rising fiscal spending. The plan excludes increases in issuance for maturities over 40 years, which will remain unchanged.

site_title: 'Tis the season to be wary for minority shareholders at three companies
summary: Three related companies, ASTI Holdings, Advanced Systems Automation, and Dragon Group International, are at risk due to Michael Loh Soon Gnee's resignation as executive chairman and CEO. Loh owns 19.89% of ASTI and 19.91% of ASA, giving him an indirect 25.08% interest in ASA and 8.16% interest in DGI. The companies have racked up five consecutive years of losses, with ASTI reporting a net profit of S$19.7 million in FY2018. Loh received S$23 million in remuneration from FY2014 to FY2018, including a S$8 million "bonus and management incentive" for FY2018. The companies' boards have overlapping directors, raising concerns about conflict of interest and effective governance. SGX has asked DGI to make a reasonable exit offer, and Loh's son's remuneration was disclosed without prior announcement.

site_title: German business morale hits six-month high: survey
summary: German business morale reached a six-month high in December, with the Ifo Institute's business climate index rising to 96.3 from 95.1 in November. This suggests the German economy grew 0.2% in the fourth quarter, beating expectations. Despite a manufacturing crisis, companies are more optimistic about their business outlook, with exports welcoming easing US-China trade tensions. However, the industrial sector remains in recession, and the government has lowered its economic growth forecast for 2020 to 1%.

site_title: Tee International wins new engineering, construction contracts
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Tee International has won new engineering and construction contracts worth approximately S$20 million. Its outstanding order book stands at S$364 million, with contracts not expected to impact earnings for the current financial year. Tee International shares fell 0.1 Singapore cent or 1.72% to S$0.057 following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore malls evolve to stay relevant despite online shopping threat
summary: Singapore's retail scene is evolving to stay relevant despite the threat of online shopping, with landlords investing and upgrading malls. Online shopping accounts for 6.1% of overall retail sales, and savvy landlords have adjusted quickly to the changing environment. Retail Reits, such as Mapletree Commercial Trust, have seen significant returns, with some averaging 23% in the first 11 months of 2019. Malls are focusing on experiential retail, offering lifestyle experiences and services beyond just shopping. Despite a decline in October's retail sales, online sales are expected to remain low, and brick-and-mortar retail remains relevant, with many e-commerce retailers expanding their physical footprints in malls.

site_title: US finalising rules to limit sensitive tech exports to China and others
summary: The US Commerce Department is finalizing rules to limit exports of sensitive technologies to China and others, including quantum computing and 3-D printing technologies, mandated by a 2018 law. The rules, expected to be submitted to international bodies for approval, will establish a level playing field for US companies abroad but may take until mid-2021 to review and go into effect. The move is seen as a reprieve for US industry, which had feared broad regulations that would stymie exports.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as record-setting rally runs out of steam
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, marking a breather from a record-setting rally, after FedEx cut its annual profit forecast for the second time this year. The Dow Jones rose 0.09%, the S&P 500 gained 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.13%. The record-breaking rally appears to be running out of steam, with investors taking a cautious stance amid tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Nvidia touts chip deals with China's Alibaba, Baidu, Didi
summary: Nvidia has secured deals with China's Alibaba, Baidu, and Didi to use its chips for product recommendations and self-driving vehicle development. Alibaba saw a 10% increase in click-through rates using Nvidia's chips, while Didi will use chips for both on-road and back-end data center applications. Nvidia also plans to announce a "federated" learning system for carmakers to share training data without sharing ownership. The deals mark a significant expansion of Nvidia's use in artificial intelligence and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Phase 2 launch of Hangzhou's Yanlord Riverside Gardens fully sold
summary: Yanlord Land Group has sold out all 149 apartment units from the Phase 2 launch of its Yanlord Riverside Gardens project in Hangzhou, China, generating 2.09 billion yuan (S$405 million) in total contracted pre-sales. The average selling price per square meter was 70,697 yuan, with a total gross floor area of 29,625 sq m. This follows a successful inaugural launch in October, where all 120 units were sold. The project is Yanlord's third in Hangzhou, and the company remains confident in the Hangzhou real estate market.

site_title: Private equity luring companies to stay private for longer: EY
summary: Private equity firms are luring companies in Singapore to stay private for longer, with 70 Asean-focused funds aiming for $8.5 billion in capital as of June. This trend, driven by longer investment horizons, is enticing companies to delay listings and instead focus on growth.
