Private equity funds can bring benefits such as professional management, discipline, and operational expertise, but some companies prefer to stay private due to self-sustainability. The trend is expected to continue, with investors seeking more flexibility to sell at a suitable timing.

images.alt_text: The proliferation of private equity funds looking to tap growth in the region is enticing some companies in Singapore to stay private for longer, according to senior executives at global consultancy Ernst & Young (EY).

site_title: Another Hoe Leong subsidiary served with writ of summons
summary: Hoe Leong Corp's subsidiary Polaris Ship Management was served with a writ of summons by the Singapore State Courts over a claim of S$44,365 by Travelcue Management for plane tickets purchased by Polaris between April and August this year. This is the second time a Hoe Leong subsidiary has been served with a writ, following Arkstar Voyager, Arkstar Unicorn, and Arkstar Eagle 3 being served by Can Marine Systems earlier this month. Hoe Leong is seeking legal advice on the matter.

site_title: NAB says it has reported bank's flaws to money laundering regulator
summary: NAB has reported shortcomings in its anti-money laundering systems to the money laundering regulator AUSTRAC, amid a potential new scandal just weeks after regulators filed a lawsuit against the bank over fee charges. NAB chairman Philip Chronican stated the bank had upgraded its systems and was committed to fixing the issues, while AUSTRAC's lawsuit against Westpac, the country's second-largest bank, had prompted questions about other banks facing similar action. The shortcomings were described as "not of the scale reported in other organisations" by Chronican.

site_title: Singapore private home prices to rise 2% in 2020, 2021: Fitch Ratings
summary: Singapore private home prices are expected to rise by 2% in both 2020 and 2021, according to Fitch Ratings. The housing NPL ratio is predicted to increase slightly, but remain low at 0.4% to 0.5%. Improving borrower affordability and lower interest rates are expected to contribute to rising property prices. However, Fitch notes that the government may cool the market if home prices rise more than justified by economic fundamentals, citing a possible increase in macro-prudential measures. Mortgage lending growth is forecast to remain subdued in the near term.

images.alt_text: Prices of private homes in Singapore are expected to show modest growth over the next two years, rising by about 2 per cent in both 2020 and 2021, down from nearly 8 per cent in 2018. This is according to the Fitch Ratings' Global Housing and Mortgage Outlook 2020 report on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil falls as US inventories rise but demand hopes stem bigger drop
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after US industry data showed a surprise build-up in crude inventories, but expectations for an uptick in demand next year due to a US-China trade deal resolution kept losses in check. Brent crude futures dropped 0.6% to $65.69 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 0.9% to $60.42 a barrel. Despite a surprise increase in US crude inventories, OPEC+ plans to cut production further, supporting the market and preventing a further slide in prices.

site_title: OCBC, DBS take top two spots in regional sustainable finance league table
summary: OCBC Bank and DBS Bank have taken the top two spots in Bloomberg's 2019 mandated lead arranger (MLA) league table for green loans and renewable energy loans, with OCBC leading with US$1.01 billion and DBS second with US$903.7 million. OCBC also claimed top spot in Debtwire's MLA league table for green loans and sustainability-linked loans, totaling US$1.26 billion. The banks' commitment to sustainable finance is part of their larger goals, with OCBC aiming for a S$10 billion sustainable finance portfolio by 2022 and DBS pledging to stop financing new coal-fired power plants.

site_title: UOB to buy more shares in troubled Chinese lender Hengfeng Bank
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) announced it will buy 1.86 billion shares in troubled Chinese lender Hengfeng Bank Co for S$360.4 million, as part of a capital-increase exercise. The majority of the shares will be subscribed by state-owned investment companies, becoming controlling shareholders in a bid to prop up the bank's floundering state. This follows the takeover of Baoshang Bank Co in May and state-owned financial companies buying stakes in Bank of Jinzhou. The move aims to drive regional connectivity and business opportunities in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 22.16 points to 1,599.11, closing higher on Wednesday. Volume reached 2.5 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 423 gainers surpassing 417 losers.

site_title: Frasers Property buys more shares in Frasers Property Thailand
summary: Frasers Property Limited (FPL), a Singapore-listed company, is acquiring more shares in Frasers Property Thailand (FPT) through open-market purchases. On Wednesday, FPL bought 620,400 shares at 15.04 Thai baht, and expects to complete additional purchases on Thursday and Friday, totaling S$1.09 million and raising its stake to 80.89% by December 20. This follows a previous purchase last Friday that raised its stake to 80.82%. FPL shares rose 1.18% on Wednesday to S$1.71.

site_title: Procurri partners Ingram Micro to beef up IT asset disposition capabilities
summary: Procurri, a data centre services firm, has partnered with Ingram Micro to offer a global IT asset disposition (ITAD) solution. The partnership provides ITAD, asset recovery, and recycling services in over 80 countries, utilizing 26 global ITAD processing facilities. The combined expertise of both companies aims to meet clients' value recovery, compliance, security, and environmental needs, enhancing their ITAD offerings and providing a more comprehensive solution for corporate clients globally.

site_title: Washington is the most exciting food city in America
summary: Washington, D.C. has emerged as the most exciting food city in America, surpassing Los Angeles and New York. The city's diverse culinary scene is characterized by its affordability, accessibility, and high-quality options. Neighborhoods like Columbia Heights, Capitol Hill, and the Wharf offer a range of restaurants, from fine dining to casual eateries. The city's high percentage of two-income, highly educated residents and its high median income contribute to its thriving food culture. Washington is also a hub for innovative concepts, including fast-casual spots and ethnic restaurants, and is home to many celebrity chefs and food activists, including José Andrés.

site_title: Johnson's Brexit gamble sparks bets for BOE rate cuts in 2020
summary: Traders have increased bets on the Bank of England (BOE) cutting interest rates in December 2020, with an 80% probability of a 25 basis point cut, due to concerns over Brexit uncertainty and a potential economic downturn. The BOE's Monetary Policy Committee is expected to keep rates at 0.75% at its review. This comes as the UK economy faces further challenges, including the weakest factory performance in over seven years and a shrinking economy for the second month. The bets reflect fears that Brexit uncertainty could lead to economic gloom and pressure the BOE to adopt a more growth-supportive policy stance.

site_title: In the Japanese valley of the dolls
summary: In Japan's remote mountain village of Nagoro, residents have populated empty buildings with life-sized dolls to create a community, as the village has no children and its elementary school closed in 2012 after the last two students graduated. The village now has around two dozen adults living there, with no signs of reversing the trend. This unusual approach to population has become a unique aspect of the village's identity.

site_title: Dealmakers will test Johnson's open-market credentials
summary: The UK's new pro-market government, led by Boris Johnson, faces a test of its open-market credentials as foreign companies consider buying London-listed rivals. Despite having a veto via a "golden share," Johnson's administration is taking a more interventionist stance on mergers and acquisitions, with stricter restrictions on bidders in sensitive sectors. The Competition and Markets Authority is also increasing scrutiny, raising concerns about the level of scrutiny being applied. Johnson is torn between pleasing his new Labour supporters and attracting foreign investment, potentially leading to a more cautious approach to foreign takeover bids.

site_title: AIG names COO Peter Zaffino as president
summary: American International Group (AIG) named COO Peter Zaffino as its new president, effective January 1, 2020. Zaffino will continue to serve as COO and chief of its general insurance business, replacing CEO Brian Duperreault. Zaffino joined AIG in 2017 and led a turnaround effort for the company's general insurance unit, achieving its first underwriting profit since the global financial crisis in May. The move recognizes Zaffino's value to the company, with CEO Duperreault praising his contributions.

site_title: Japfa proposes 1-for-10 rights issue to pare debt
summary: Japfa, a mainboard-listed agri-food firm, proposes a 1-for-10 rights issue to pare debt. The issue price of S$0.50 per share represents a 13% discount to the closing price. The rights issue aims to raise S$93.5 million, with Rangi Management, controlled by Japfa's executive chairman, committing to subscribe for 136 million rights shares. The proceeds will be used to repay existing borrowings, enhancing financial flexibility.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 falling 0.2%. The pound fell against the US dollar and euro, fueled by Brexit fears. In other markets, Singapore stocks rose 0.4% and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong sees another wild IPO swing from 84% gain to a loss
summary: Hong Kong's Maike Tube Industry Holdings, a Chinese pipe maker, experienced a wild debut, surging 84% before closing 5.7% lower. This follows a similar trend seen in Snack Empire Holdings, which nearly tripled then fell 6.2% from its offer price. The IPO market in Hong Kong has slowed this month, with only two companies trading on Wednesday. Initial public offerings have slowed globally ahead of the Christmas period, following Alibaba Group Holding's large secondary offering last month. Maike Tube's shares are now 5.7% below their offer price.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, Peugeot owner PSA agree on binding merger in US$50b deal
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot owner PSA agree on a binding merger worth US$50 billion, creating the world's fourth-largest car maker. The deal, expected to close in 12-15 months, aims for annual cost savings of 3.7 billion euros by combining technologies and shared purchasing agreements. PSA boss Carlos Tavares will become CEO of the merged entity for an initial five-year term. The merger does not affect a lawsuit filed by General Motors against FCA over alleged union bribing.

site_title: Singapore private home prices to grow 2% in 2020, 2021: Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings forecasts Singapore's private home prices to grow 2% in 2020 and 2021, driven by macro-prudential measures and stable mortgage performance. This follows a decline of 0.7% in Q3 2018 to Q1 2019 due to regulatory tightening and mortgage rate increases. The agency expects low unemployment and stable loan performance to support mortgage lending growth, with a slight increase in housing non-performing loan ratio.

site_title: Crisis at Bang & Olufsen deepens with fourth warning in a year
summary: Bang & Olufsen's crisis deepens with its fourth earnings revision in a year, citing lower-than-expected sales and a 25% plunge in shares. The company's sales are projected to decline as much as 18% this year, with operating profit and cash flow also worse than predicted. The new CEO, Kristian Tear, says a strategic direction change is needed, while the company faces increased competition, slower sales execution, and excess inventory levels. The company's future as an independent entity is uncertain, with investors calling for a partner or turnaround.

images.alt_text: Bang & Olufsen (B&O) laid bare the full extent of the crisis engulfing the Danish maker of high-end televisions and music systems with its fourth earnings revision in a year, raising the pressure on its new leader to accelerate a turnaround or find a partner.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 0.3% on Wednesday amid mixed markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to close at 3,209.54, driven by gains from local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The index outperformed other regional markets, including Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Taiwan, which also posted gains. However, China and Japan fell. The mixed market sentiment is attributed to a strong finish to the year, with investors looking to kick back into "Christmas mode" and defend profits. Trading volume was 1.30 billion securities, with a total turnover of S$1.05 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to grow 2% in 2020 and 2021, driven by macro-prudential measures and stable mortgage performance. OCBC Bank topped two 2019 sustainable finance league tables for the Asia-Pacific region. Acesian Partners settled legal disputes and issued a profit warning. US firm WaterBridge Holdings raised US$345m for a Permian expansion. Aztech Group is considering an IPO of its tech unit on the Singapore Stock Exchange, potentially raising S$400m. Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% on Wednesday.

site_title: Koufu expands in Indonesia with Super Tea joint venture
summary: Koufu's subsidiary Super Tea has entered a joint venture to develop and operate food and beverage outlets in Indonesia, using 5.5 billion rupiah (S$540,000) for 55% equity stake. Partner PT Berkah Cipta Adirasa will hold the remaining 45% stake. The joint-venture company aims to expand Koufu's business in Indonesia, aligning with the group's long-term objectives of growth and revenue enhancement.

site_title: Russia, China make UN proposal to ease North Korea sanctions
summary: Russia and China proposed easing UN sanctions on North Korea in response to the country's denuclearization efforts. The proposal, which does not detail specific steps for relief, calls for an end to certain sanctions measures, such as banning imports of North Korean fish products and textiles, and exempting inter-Korean rail and road projects from existing sanctions. The proposal also welcomes the continuation of dialogue between the US and North Korea, but faces uncertainty as it was not put forward with a deadline for a vote.

site_title: Apple, Google, Amazon to create common standard for smart home devices
summary: Amazon, Apple, and Google have announced plans to develop a common technology standard for smart home products, aiming to improve compatibility and the consumer experience. The project, led by the three tech giants, will enable devices from different manufacturers to communicate with each other, expanding the potential for a more connected home ecosystem. The protocol is expected to be widely adopted across various smart home systems and assistants.

site_title: Trump faces historic rebuke as House votes on impeachment
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to become the third US president to be impeached by the House, with lawmakers voting on the historic move on Wednesday. Trump's impeachment is seen as a rebuke for his pursuit of a political vendetta, but the Republican party is fully behind him, making removal unlikely. Senate Republicans are also unlikely to convict him when they hold a trial next year. The impeachment vote marks a significant moment in Trump's presidency and will likely have long-lasting implications for his legacy.

site_title: Nvidia touts chip deals with China's Alibaba, Baidu and Didi
summary: Nvidia has secured chip deals with China's Alibaba, Baidu, and Didi, a ride-hailing service. Alibaba uses Nvidia's chips to increase click-through rates by 10%, while Didi employs its chips in self-driving cars and data centers. Nvidia will also announce a "federated" learning system, allowing car makers to share training data without sharing actual data, at an event in Suzhou, China. These deals mark Nvidia's growing presence in the artificial intelligence and self-driving car markets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end slightly lower on profit-booking; won weakens
summary: South Korean stocks ended slightly lower on Wednesday, with the Kospi index down 0.92 points to 2,194.76, due to profit-booking from recent rallies. The Korean won weakened, while bond yields fell. Foreigners bought 380.7 billion won worth of shares, particularly tech-related equities, with Nomura predicting another semiconductor super-cycle between 2020 and 2021. Despite the decline, the Kospi has risen 7.53% this year.

site_title: UOI to buy 146 Robinson Rd from UOB for S$52m
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) plans to acquire the 12-storey Overseas Union Trust Building in Singapore's financial district for S$52 million. The property, with a 99-year lease, will be UOI's first real estate investment, intended to boost its corporate image and branding. The acquisition aims to diversify UOI's income stream and reduce profit volatility, providing a hedge against rental increases. The transaction, valued at 13.74% of UOI's net tangible assets, requires shareholder approval and is expected to be completed by February 28, 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower on profit taking
summary: Tokyo shares ended lower on profit taking, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.55% to 23,934.43. Investors locked in gains following recent market rallies, despite positive economic data and a US-China trade deal. The broader Topix index also fell 0.50%.

site_title: China IPO hopefuls surge to three-year high encouraged by market reform
summary: China has seen a surge in companies seeking to go public on the mainland, with about 580 companies waiting approval to list in Shanghai or Shenzhen, a three-year high. Market reforms, including the creation of the STAR Market, have encouraged this growth, with 420 Chinese firms waiting for approval and 161 applying to the STAR Market. The number of IPOs is expected to remain active in 2020, driven by reforms aimed at reducing reliance on bank lending and improving the efficiency of the stock market.

site_title: Australian dollar awaits jobs data, kiwi at 1-week low as dairy prices falls
summary: The Australian dollar remains unchanged ahead of monthly employment data, while the New Zealand dollar falls to a one-week low due to a decline in dairy prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates again in 2020, with financial futures predicting a 50-50 chance of a cut in February. November's internet job vacancies index fell 1.3% to its largest drop in seven months, and the national jobless rate must fall below 4.5% for the Reserve Bank to generate wage or inflation pressures.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as miners, banks weigh; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 4.1 points to 6,851.4. Gains in healthcare and energy stocks offset weakness in financials and miners. Oil Search Ltd jumped 3.3% after a drilling assessment, while healthcare stocks reached a record close. Meanwhile, two major banks, Westpac and NAB, lost 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively, amid regulatory scandals. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6% to a record close, driven by a gain in Heartland Group Holdings.

site_title: Auditors need 'urgent reform'; UK review calls for breakaway from accounting
summary: A UK review of the audit sector has recommended a breakaway from the accounting profession to address concerns over bad practice and corporate failures. The review, led by Donald Brydon, calls for a standalone industry with its own governing principles to increase confidence in business. It recommends auditors be more transparent and skeptical in their work, and undergo training in forensic accounting. The review also suggests redefining audit's purpose and setting new qualifications for auditors. Urgent reform is needed to prevent unnecessary corporate failures and job losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Wednesday on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.37% on Wednesday, extending a two-day rally, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng index reached 27,946.74, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.95 points. Despite US trade uncertainty, Asian markets remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng index climbed 0.37 per cent, or 103.03 points, to 27,946.74.

site_title: OCBC tops 2 regional sustainable finance league tables for 2019
summary: OCBC Bank topped two 2019 sustainable finance league tables for the Asia-Pacific region, excluding Japan, with US$1.01 billion in Bloomberg's MLA league table for green loans and US$1.26 billion in Debtwire's MLA league table for green loans and sustainability-linked loans. The bank's market share in Debtwire's table was 8.43%, and it has committed over S$4 billion to sustainable financing, with a target to build a S$10 billion sustainable finance portfolio by 2022.

site_title: US firm backed by GIC-affliate raises US$345m for Permian expansion
summary: US-based WaterBridge Holdings LLC has raised $345 million to expand its operations in the Permian Basin by acquiring nearly 100 miles of pipeline and seven disposal wells. The company, backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC's affiliate Five Point Energy, issued $195 million of common equity and $150 million of preferred equity to finance the deals. This acquisition brings WaterBridge's long-term commitments in the Delaware sub-basin to over 600,000 acres, solidifying its position in the US oil patch.

site_title: Indonesia faces backlash over baby lobster export ban
summary: Indonesia's new fisheries minister, Edhy Prabowo, has proposed lifting a ban on exporting baby lobsters, known as seeds, sparking criticism that it could deplete stocks and boost the fishing industry in competitor countries like Vietnam. The ban was implemented in 2016 to conserve the population, but Prabowo argues it encourages smuggling and supports livelihoods. Former fisheries minister Susi Pudjiastuti defended the ban, saying it would lead to overexploitation and depletion of lobsters in Indonesia's oceans. President Joko Widodo has intervened, calling for a review of the ban that considers both environmental and economic aspects.

site_title: StanChart exits 3 South-east Asia coal plants worth estimated US$7b
summary: Standard Chartered has pulled financing for three coal-fired power plants in South-east Asia, estimated to be worth US$7 billion, amid a global push to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The move follows Credit Suisse's decision to stop financing new coal-fired power plants. The affected projects include Vung Ang 2 and Vinh Tan 3 in Vietnam, and Java 9 and 10 in Indonesia. The decision is seen as a major blow to the coal industry, with environmental groups praising the move as a crucial step in aligning finance with the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

site_title: Xi Jinping visits gambling hub Macau as nearby Hong Kong seethes
summary: China's President Xi Jinping visited Macau, a major gambling hub, to mark its 20th anniversary under Chinese rule. The visit comes as Hong Kong, a former British colony, is experiencing anti-government protests for six months. Xi announced supportive policies for Macau, aiming to diversify its economy, and met with government officials and business representatives. The visit is seen as a reward for Macau's stability, unlike Hong Kong, where Beijing's influence is seen as encroaching on freedoms. Security measures were tightened, with some media barred entry and protests rare in Macau.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange to slash IPO price-to-trading gap in 2020: executive
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Stock Exchange plans to slash the IPO price-to-trading gap to a single day, aiming to achieve this by the fourth quarter of 2020. The move aims to reduce exposure to market falls between pricing and trading, making it easier to compete with rival exchanges. This change follows Alibaba's recent paperless listing, and the exchange is also considering reforms to make IPO pricing more flexible. The goal is to boost Hong Kong's position as a top IPO hub, despite recent political turmoil and market volatility.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.04 points or 0.13% to 1,578.99. Volume reached 57.39 million lots worth RM28.81 million. Gainers outpaced losers 128 to 66.

site_title: Facebook says it can locate users who opt out of tracking
summary: Facebook claims it can locate users who opt out of tracking by using clues such as being tagged in a photo at a specific location, check-ins, shared addresses, and IP addresses. The social network argues that knowing users' general locations helps protect accounts from suspicious login behavior and battle misinformation. Facebook is preparing for California's data privacy law, which will give users the right to see what data is collected and shared. The company maintains that users have no control over their personal information.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon up 0.25% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.25% or 7.94 points to 3,208.74. Advancers outnumbered decliners 164 to 153, with 565.3 million securities worth S$424.9 million changing hands. Banking stocks led gains, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank. Singapore Press Holdings rose 3.3% after announcing a joint venture win to install digital display screens across Housing Board estates.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher mirroring gains in Wall Street; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.13% to 6,856.20, mirroring US gains after upbeat economic data, but losses in the financial sector tempered gains. Energy and healthcare stocks boosted the market, while the financial sector fell 0.8% due to misconduct allegations. New Zealand's benchmark index advanced 0.7% to 11,342.03, driven by gains from Kathmandu Holdings and Oceania Healthcare.

site_title: Japan set to compile record budget in FY2020/21: draft
summary: Japan is set to compile a record annual budget for FY2020/21, with a general-account budget of 102.66 trillion yen, exceeding last year's 101.5 trillion yen. The government estimates 63.51 trillion yen in tax revenue and plans to trim new bond issuance to 32.56 trillion yen, marking a decline for the 10th consecutive year.

site_title: Aztech Group mulls S$400m IPO of tech unit on SGX
summary: Aztech Group Ltd, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is considering a potential initial public offering (IPO) of its technology unit, Aztech Technologies Pte, which could raise up to S$400 million. The unit aims to seek a valuation of up to S$1 billion, joining other companies like ThaiBev and Far East Consortium International in listing in Singapore. The IPO plans are still in early stages and may not result in a deal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as investors lock in profits
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on December 18, 2019, as investors locked in profits despite positive market sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.18% to 24,023.76, while the Topix index edged lower by 0.14% to 1,744.80. The decline was attributed to investors taking profits ahead of a US-China trade deal and positive economic data.

site_title: Hong Kong international students' fear and rebellion
summary: Hong Kong's universities, home to over 18,000 international students, have become a focal point of violent clashes between police and protesters. The city's democracy protests, which began six months ago, have led to a decline in enrollment from mainland China and a rise in concerns among international students. Some students, like Malaysian student Celia Cheng, plan to continue their studies despite their families' reservations, while others, like a German exchange student, are considering leaving the country. Universities are taking steps to address the safety concerns, with some considering increased security measures.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise but dealers show signs of slowing
summary: Asian markets rose 0.2% in early trade on Wednesday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street, which clocked up more records following healthy US housing and industrial output data. However, investors appear to be taking a "well-earned rest" after the recent trade deal-fueled rally. Sterling extended losses after Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to outlaw an extension to the Brexit transition past 2020, which may limit the UK's ability to hammer out a full-blown trade pact with the EU.

site_title: Thailand wants more first-time visitors as they spend more
summary: Thailand aims to boost tourism revenue by targeting first-time visitors, who spend 10-20% more than repeat tourists. The country plans to increase first-time visitors to over 10 million in 2020, up from 10% of overall arrivals. This goal is part of a strategy to capitalize on the growing number of travelers from Central Asia, Eastern Europe, and Latin America. Thailand's tourism sector is expected to generate 2.22 trillion baht (S$99.55 billion) in receipts in 2020, a 5% increase from 2019.

site_title: Asian business sentiment bounces back, but caution abounds: poll
summary: Asian business sentiment has rebounded to an 18-month high, with firms reporting a pickup in sales, but most are holding off on hiring due to trade war uncertainty. The Thomson Reuters/Insead Asian Business Sentiment Index jumped 13 points to 71 for the fourth quarter, with optimism outnumbering pessimism for the first time in nearly a decade. While conditions have improved, economists warn that uncertainty and protectionism remain a concern, with China's economic growth at its slowest in about a generation.

site_title: WeWork arranges US$1.75b credit line with Goldman Sachs
summary: WeWork has arranged a $1.75 billion senior secured letter of credit with Goldman Sachs as part of SoftBank's $9.5 billion bailout. The facility, which is expected to be available in January, will free up approximately $800 million in restricted cash. This is part of a three-part bailout that includes a tender offer to buy WeWork shares and new debt. The tender offer has launched but is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2020, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: PBOC adviser warns of local debt chain reaction, urges action
summary: China's central bank adviser, Ma Jun, warns of a "chain reaction" of local debt defaults that could damage market confidence. He urges authorities to take measures to prevent systemic risks, suggesting stronger local-government financing vehicles (LGFVs) could take over weaker counterparts. Ma also recommends that LGFVs seek public listings or acquire listed firms to boost financing abilities. The warning comes amid market debate over China's easing of deleveraging drive, with the recent Central Economic Work Conference downplaying urgency to clean up the financial system.

site_title: Samsung Electronics board chairman jailed on union-busting charge
summary: Samsung Electronics board Chairman Lee Sang Hoon was sentenced to 1-1/2 years in jail for sabotaging union activities at the company's repair unit in 2013. The Seoul Central District Court found that Lee and other executives had developed strategies to hinder the union's operation, including gathering sensitive information about union members and inducing subcontracting firms with active unions to close. The verdict marks a significant shift in South Korea's judicial system, which previously gave lenient sentences to convicted businessmen. The ruling also highlights the need for Samsung's new leader to build industrial relations in line with global standards.

site_title: Acesian Partners settles legal disputes, issues profit warning
summary: Acesian Partners has settled long-standing legal disputes with its wholly-owned subsidiary, Acesian Star (S) Pte Ltd, without payment. The settlement is expected to result in a write-off of S$5.1 million of non-recoverable assets. Acesian Partners also issued a profit warning for the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2019, citing the adverse impact on consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share. The company's financial position remains stable, and it will focus on restructuring its businesses. Shares were unchanged at S$0.013.

site_title: Australia's NAB says no money kept for "fees for no service" lawsuit
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has denied keeping cash set aside to settle a lawsuit accusing it of charging customers fees for no service, despite having already started paying back A$276 million to customers. ASIC filed a lawsuit alleging nearly 9,000 times of wrongly charged fees, potentially totaling A$9.75 billion in fines, but NAB Chairman Philip Chronican said the substance of the allegations is "materially less" and the matter will need to go to court for adjudication.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands protest in France over pension reform plans
summary: Hundreds of thousands of French protesters took to the streets on Tuesday in opposition to the government's pension reform plans, which have sparked nearly two weeks of crippling transport strikes. The protests, which saw 615,000 people participate in over 100 rallies, have disrupted travel plans, with only one in four high-speed TGV trains running. The government has vowed not to give in to union demands to drop the overhaul, which critics say could force millions to work beyond the official retirement age of 62.

site_title: ANZ promotes ex-CFO of New Zealand unit to top job
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) appointed Antonia Watson, former chief financial officer of its New Zealand unit, as the new CEO of the division. The move comes after the sudden departure of the previous CEO over a dispute regarding expenses. ANZ's New Zealand unit has faced scrutiny from the central bank over internal risk controls and capital requirements. Watson's appointment was approved by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, and she previously managed director of retail and business banking at ANZ NZ.

site_title: New Zealand seeks more powers to monitor banks, increase transparency at RBNZ
summary: New Zealand's finance minister, Grant Robertson, plans to expand the government's powers to monitor banks and increase transparency at the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ). A governance board will oversee financial stability matters, and measures will be introduced to increase oversight. Additionally, a NZ$50,000 deposit insurance per institution will be introduced. These moves are part of the Review of the Reserve Bank Act, with the goal of improving financial stability and accountability.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand government plans to expand its powers to monitor banks and hold directors and executives more accountable for their actions, the finance minister said in a statement on Wednesday.

site_title: Finance's final frontier? British watchdog probes data sharing
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is investigating the possibility of extending "open banking" rules to include data sharing between banks and non-bank financial institutions to increase innovation and choice. The FCA aims to create "dashboards" to help consumers track their finances and make informed decisions. The probe follows instances of unfair price discrimination in various financial markets, and the FCA seeks public feedback until March 2020 to inform its decision-making process.

site_title: Singapore digital bank wannabes must prove they can make money
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore is placing greater emphasis on profitability and strong capital requirements for digital banks vying for licenses. Grab Holdings and Razer, among others, must demonstrate how their millions of users can generate profits. The two firms have expressed interest in bidding for one of the five digital banking licenses, which is part of a government strategy to strengthen competition in financial services. The MAS will assess each applicant's ability to make money and meet capital requirements to grant the licenses. A decision is expected to be made in the coming months.

site_title: Hong Kong's airlines face job cuts and even bankruptcies
summary: Hong Kong's airlines face significant challenges due to six months of anti-Beijing protests, which have deterred tourists and led to a decline in passenger traffic. Cathay Pacific Airways reported its fourth consecutive monthly drop in passenger traffic, while Hong Kong Airlines had seven planes seized by the Airport Authority due to unpaid payments. The industry's global headwinds and potential job cuts and bankruptcies are now exacerbated by the ongoing protests, putting the future of Hong Kong's airlines at risk.

site_title: Key countries aren't ready as historic ship-fuel switch nears
summary: Historic rules to reduce sulfur oxide emissions from ships take effect in two weeks, but countries with significant oil-refining capacity have yet to sign up, raising concerns about enforcement. South Africa and the UAE have agreed to implement the rules but lack domestic laws and regulations. Inspections of ships are expected to be limited, with some countries using drones to identify non-compliant vessels. The lack of enforcement could lead to cheating and undermine the billions of dollars invested in reducing emissions. Up to 20% of ships may initially break the rules, but international pressure to comply is expected to increase.

images.alt_text: Historic rules to clean up pollution in the shipping industry are two weeks from taking effect, but there are signs that enforcing the new legislation will prove tricky.

site_title: Trade and fiscal policy action needed to avoid global 'liquidity trap': BoE's Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that central banks' policy tools may become ineffective if governments do not cooperate on trade and fiscal policy to avoid a global "liquidity trap." He emphasized the need for coordination, particularly in reducing trade tensions, to boost the world economy. Carney's comments come as interest rates in the UK and euro zone remain near record lows, leaving central banks with limited firepower for future downturns.

site_title: US Congress approves space force, Russia pipeline sanctions
summary: The US Senate approved a $738 billion defense spending bill, creating a new space force within the US Air Force, with a 3.1% raise for military personnel. The bill also includes sanctions on Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline, aiming to curb its energy ambitions. The legislation, which passed 86-8, marks a significant increase from last year's funding, with $635 billion allocated to the Pentagon and $23.1 billion for the US nuclear arsenal's maintenance. The bill is expected to go to President Trump for signature.

site_title: Singapore shares nudge lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.24%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.24% to 3,193.06, driven by a mixed trading session. Broadway Industrial jumped 8.4% after a potential merger and acquisition deal, while banking stocks were mixed. Other notable movers included Singtel, which shed 2.4%, and Yongnam, which gained 4.8% after securing five civil engineering contracts. US stocks, including the Dow and S&P 500, reached record highs, with the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.1%.

site_title: FedEx cuts 2020 profit, cites 'significant challenges'
summary: FedEx reported a 39% decline in adjusted net income to $660 million, or $2.51 per share, for its fiscal second quarter, missing analysts' average estimate. The decline was attributed to lackluster global trade and the end of its relationship with Amazon. The late arrival of Thanksgiving shifted revenue from the Cyber Week holiday delivery surge into December, further hurting results. FedEx's shares fell 6.5% in after-hours trade to $152.58.

site_title: Japan's exports fall for 12th month as shipments to US, China drop
summary: Japan's exports fell 7.9% year-on-year in November, marking the 12th straight month of decline, as shipments to the US and China dropped. Exports to Asia also fell 5.7% and those to China declined 5.4% for the ninth month. Japan's overall imports sank 15.7% year-on-year, leading to a trade balance deficit of 82.1 billion yen. The decline in exports raises concerns of a fourth-quarter contraction in Japan's economy, which had shown signs of growth in the third quarter.

site_title: New Hyflux investor floats offer for debts
summary: A Singaporean firm, Aqua Munda, has made an offer to buy over S$1.8 billion in debts of Hyflux, a beleaguered water cleaning company, including contingent and trade debts. The offer is open to note holders and unsecured creditors of Hyflux and its subsidiaries until January 10, 2020. This comes weeks after Hyflux signed a S$400 million rescue deal with Emirati utilities group Utico, following a failed talks with an Indonesian consortium. Aqua Munda's offer is the latest twist in Hyflux's restructuring efforts, which face further hurdles, including a vote by creditors on the Utico deal.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MLT, Yongnam, SPH, ISOTeam, Broadway Industrial, Straits Trading
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) refinanced seven properties in Malaysia through new seven-year medium-term notes, resulting in a 0.6% decline in MLT units. Yongnam Holdings secured five civil engineering contracts worth S$101.3 million for Singapore and Hong Kong projects, leading to a 0.69% gain in Yongnam shares.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap four-day rally on Unilever warning, hard Brexit fears
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to a sales warning from Unilever and fears of a hard Brexit. The UK's FTSE 100 index held steady, despite reports that Prime Minister Boris Johnson will rule out any Brexit extension beyond 2020. Investors remain cautious, citing uncertainty over the US-China trade deal and the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: UK's new 'people's government' to boycott Davos
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will boycott the upcoming Davos summit in Switzerland, along with his ministers. Johnson, who recently won a landslide victory, has expressed concerns about attending an event dominated by the global business and political elite. This decision comes as part of his "People's Government" pledge to prioritize public services and social justice over elitist gatherings. Johnson's predecessor, Theresa May, also skipped this year's event due to Brexit pressures, but sent a trade minister instead.

site_title: Jane Fonda tried to meet Trump with 'beautiful' climate activists
summary: Hollywood legend Jane Fonda attempted to meet with President Donald Trump in 2016 with a group of climate activists, including Pamela Anderson, to convince him to tackle global warming. Despite discussing the idea with Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, Fonda was met with no response. This led her to move to Washington and use her celebrity influence to drive mass mobilizations. Fonda now participates in non-sanctioned protests outside the US Capitol, hoping to spark a mass movement to force the government to act on climate change, despite feeling that Trump is "traumatised" and lacking in empathy.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX shutdown big blow to planemaker, US economy
summary: Boeing has halted production of its 737 MAX jet due to a prolonged regulatory process and the need to safely deliver 400 stored aircraft. The temporary shutdown is expected to have a significant impact on the US economy, with analysts predicting a 0.5% hit to first-quarter growth. The halt will also affect suppliers, potentially dooming some companies, and mar US growth through the loss of investment and exports. The crisis is expected to weigh on Boeing's earnings for years to come, with potential losses exceeding $1 billion per month.

site_title: Singapore easing property curbs seen unlikely as election looms
summary: Singapore is unlikely to ease property cooling measures ahead of a potential high-stakes election in the first half of 2020, despite calls from developers to relax curbs. The city-state is grappling with a housing oversupply, with almost 32,000 units in the pipeline, and analysts warn that relaxing curbs could send prices spiraling. The ruling People's Action Party is expected to win the upcoming elections, and any pre-election measures are likely to focus on the public housing segment. Cooling measures may be recalibrated at some point, but for now, the government appears satisfied with the current pace of price increases.

site_title: Ratings agencies take UK off downgrade watch after Johnson's win
summary: Ratings agencies Standard & Poor's and Fitch removed the UK from downgrade watch after Prime Minister Boris Johnson's election victory, citing reduced risk of a no-deal Brexit. S&P raised Britain's outlook to stable, while Fitch took the country off its rating watch negative list. Johnson plans to pass legislation to prevent a Brexit extension request, but experts say this leaves little time for trade agreement negotiations. Ratings agencies expect a no-deal Brexit to be avoided by requesting an extension beyond December 2020.

site_title: I have fewer rights than in witch trials: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed on Tuesday he has fewer rights than those accused during the 17th-century Salem Witch Trials, amid an impeachment vote expected in the House of Representatives. Trump, facing impeachment for alleged abuse of office in Ukraine, wrote a six-page letter to Nancy Pelosi, calling the impeachment a "total sham." The House is expected to vote on impeachment on Wednesday, with a likely acquittal in the Senate in January. Trump's allies, including Senator Josh Hawley, dismissed the impeachment as a "joke," while Democrats argue Trump's actions constituted abuse of power.

site_title: Oil rises further above US$65 on trade hopes, supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Tuesday, driven by hopes that the US-China trade deal will boost oil demand in 2020. Brent crude futures gained 76 cents to $66.10 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 73 cents to $60.94 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) will cut oil supply by 500,000 barrels per day from January 1, supporting the market. Analysts expect oil prices to remain stable despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Most asset managers will be zombie firms: PGIM boss
summary: PGIM's CEO, David Hunt, predicts that 80% of asset managers will become "zombie firms" due to the rapidly changing industry. Most firms struggle to attract new money, with institutional clients demanding lower fees and concentrating their business with select managers. Active equities are under particular pressure, with easy access to cheap index funds exposing underperformance. Hunt believes only three business models will thrive: indexing giants, boutique firms specializing in specific assets, and multi-asset investors with global reach.

site_title: China's university admissions conundrum: Who should have priority?
summary: China's university admissions system has sparked debate over fairness and equity. Despite a special program aimed at students from poorer regions, many well-off urban households still have an advantage in securing top university spots. The program's implementation has led to criticism, particularly when a Peking University offer was revoked for students from Henan province due to lower scores. Meanwhile, China has been actively promoting foreign students, aiming to increase its international rankings. Critics argue that this approach perpetuates social inequality and wastes public resources. Experts suggest alternatives, such as focusing on world-class universities and enhancing elementary education to help poor students access top universities.

site_title: There's many a slip between safety and ship
summary: Shipping insurers report paying out approximately $40 million annually in injury claims, with a six-year study revealing the most frequent incidents at sea are lifting-related slips, trips, and falls, costing over $85 million. The study highlights the need for comprehensive reporting requirements for injury and near-misses to advance safety at sea. Experts emphasize the importance of incorporating safety data into ship management systems and safety cultures, with contributing factors including situational awareness, spills, and poor housekeeping.

site_title: Joe Biden 'healthy', says medical check-up
summary: US President Joe Biden is healthy and fit to serve, according to his physician's letter released by his campaign. Biden, 77, has atrial fibrillation, hyperlipidemia, and seasonal allergies, but works out daily. His medical check-up comes as age has become an issue in the 2020 presidential election, with top candidates including Biden, Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, and Elizabeth Warren all in their 70s. Biden's campaign had pledged to release his medical records before the Iowa caucuses.

site_title: New protests erupt against India law as police face brutality claims
summary: Protests against India's citizenship law, which critics say is anti-Muslim, erupted in several cities, including Kolkata, Kerala, and New Delhi. The law grants citizenship to non-Muslims from neighboring countries and has sparked days of protests, clashes, and riots, leaving six people dead and dozens injured. Authorities have imposed internet blackouts and used force to quell the unrest, while the Supreme Court heard petitions calling for a probe into allegations of police brutality. The protests are part of a larger challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, which has been in power since 2014.

site_title: HK unrest sparks flight of US$5b in investment capital: BOE
summary: The unrest in Hong Kong has led to a US$5 billion capital outflow since April, accounting for nearly 1.25% of the region's GDP, according to the Bank of England. The flight of capital was triggered by protests against a bill allowing extradition to mainland China, which led to a recession and a slump in property prices. The Bank of England monitors Hong Kong closely due to its position as a major financial center, with UK banks such as HSBC and Standard Chartered at risk.

site_title: France launches procedure for 5G licences
summary: France has launched a procedure for assigning 5G frequency licences, with the government setting a fixed price of 350 million euros for a 50 MHz bloc and 70 million euros for a 10 MHz bloc. Junior Economy Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher stated that the government and telecoms regulator Arcep designed a mechanism to sell 50 MHz basic blocs at a fixed price, with operators required to deploy their network across the French territory. The total allocation is 310 MHz of spectrum, to be sold over 15 years for the 50 MHz blocs and four years for the 10 MHz blocs.

images.alt_text: The French government said on Tuesday it had launched a procedure for assigning 5G frequency licences after it approved specifications proposed by the communications regulator and the financial conditions for the licences.

site_title: Macau to celebrate Chinese rule as Hong Kong seethes
summary: Macau is set to celebrate 20 years since its return to China, with Beijing praising the city's growth on gambling and deference to authoritarian rule. This contrasts with Hong Kong, where six months of pro-democracy protests have occurred under the "one country, two systems" model. Despite Macau's economic success, it has vulnerabilities. The city's stability is a stark contrast to Hong Kong's unrest, highlighting the differing experiences of the two regions under Chinese rule.

site_title: US: Stocks edge to records again after solid economic data
summary: US stocks edged to records on Tuesday, driven by solid economic data and a US-China trade agreement that reduced tariffs risk. Industrial production rebounded sharply in November, and permits to build new homes reached a 12-year peak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.1%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached records for the fourth straight session, with some analysts attributing the upbeat sentiment to greater certainty on Brexit and the global economy's upward trend.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks edged to records again on Tuesday after good economic data added to positive momentum following announcement of a US-China trade agreement last week.

site_title: Singapore NODX falls less in Nov, analysts see signs of recovery
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports (NODX) contracted at the slowest pace in November, with a 5.9% year-on-year decline, beating expectations. Electronics exports, however, continued to decline, but economists believe the sector has bottomed out. Non-electronic exports expanded 1.3% year-on-year, driven by growth in non-monetary gold, machinery, and engines. Analysts see signs of recovery and predict a modest expansion of 2-4% in 2020.

site_title: Australia's NAB faces 'fees for no service' lawsuit
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has filed a lawsuit against National Australia Bank (NAB) for allegedly charging customers "fees for no service" in financial advice. The regulator claims NAB failed to issue or issued defective fee disclosure statements. This is the latest misconduct allegation against Australia's financial sector, following a government inquiry's criticism of the industry for the practice. The lawsuit is part of ongoing efforts to regulate the financial sector and prevent such misconduct.

site_title: Show us the body, demand investors who lost millions after crypto boss' death
summary: Investors in QuadrigaCX, a cryptocurrency exchange, are demanding that the body of its founder Gerald Cotten be exhumed to determine if he faked his own death. Cotten died in December 2018, taking the passwords to the site's $180 million in cryptocurrencies with him. The demand comes amid rumors and conspiracy theories that Cotten might have faked his own death and escaped with the funds. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police are being asked to conduct an exhumation and post-mortem autopsy by spring 2020.

site_title: UK job vacancies fall, wage growth slows in Brexit-hit labour market
summary: The UK labour market and manufacturing sector experienced nervousness due to Brexit uncertainty, with job vacancies falling below 800,000 for the first time in two years and wages growing at their slowest annual pace since 2018. Employment rose marginally, leaving the jobless rate unchanged. The UK is set to crash out of the EU at the end of next year unless a trade deal is reached within 11 months, with the prime minister making it illegal to extend the transition period.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group Holdings, a new unlisted entity, has seen less than 1/5 of its 15,000 shareholders complete share allocation steps. Over 75% of eligible shares have been successfully allocated. SIIC Environment Tech formed a joint-venture with Shanghai Overseas to invest in Chinese environmental companies, including Taizhou Water. San Teh will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange after a buyout offer. Straits Trading Company joined a consortium to buy a Shanghai shopping centre for $468.9 million.

site_title: STI misses out on Asia's post-trade deal party
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower, despite a rally in Asian markets, as the banking sector dragged down the blue-chip index. Taiwan's Taiex Index advanced 1.3% to 12,097.01, its first close above 12,000 since 1990, driven by better-than-expected Chinese factory and retail sales data. Analysts attributed the Singapore market's underperformance to concerns over narrowing net interest margins for lenders.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to dispose of 12 Europe properties
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has entered into a master sale and purchase agreement to dispose of 12 European properties in the Netherlands, Denmark, and France for 65.7 million euros (S$99.2 million), a 15.2% premium to the original purchase price and 4.1% above market value.

site_title: Sustainability investing takes off in South-east Asia
summary: Sustainability investing is gaining momentum in South-east Asia, with a significant increase in capital flowing to companies that contribute to environmental and social progress. According to Bain research, 56% of private equity deals in the first half of 2019 involved sustainable investments, up from 30% in 2017. The total deal value of sustainability investments reached US$3.2 billion in the first half of 2019, surpassing 2018. Investors are attracted to business opportunities with solid returns that address environmental problems or social needs, with impact investors seeking to achieve both financial and social goals.

site_title: Tinder, Netflix, Tencent lead bumper year for apps
summary: Tinder, Netflix, and Tencent Holdings topped the 2019 ranking of consumer spending on non-gaming apps, with subscription services driving revenue growth. Games with in-app purchases, such as microtransactions, led overall rankings. Total new app downloads and consumer spending are expected to break records in 2020, with consumer revenue projected to reach nearly $90 billion. Video-centric apps and subscription-based services are expected to intensify in importance and revenue.

site_title: SPH's 21%-owned JV wins HDB digital display tender with S$1.82m bid
summary: SPH's 21%-owned JV, Target Media Culcreative (TMCC), won the Housing Board's tender to install 6,000 digital display screens across HDB estates for S$1.82 million, beating out three other bidders. The screens will display news, information, and commercial ads, and nearly double TMCC's display network to 14,000 screens. The contract will run from next year, with TMCC paying hardware and software costs and a licence fee to the HDB.

site_title: Targeted approach to market regulations to continue
summary: Singapore's stock market regulator, SGX RegCo, plans to continue its targeted approach to market regulation in 2020, focusing on rewarding well-behaved listed companies with incentives such as the Fast Track Version 2 program. The regulator aims to improve corporate governance standards and fight corporate malfeasance, including manipulation and unusual trading activities. Changes include quarterly reporting, scrapping the minimum trading price, and an enhanced retail bonds framework. The regulator also plans to launch a whistle-blowing office and enhance rules governing issue managers.

site_title: Vanguard sees 2020 slump in credit returns as US growth sputters
summary: Vanguard predicts a 2.5-3% gain in US credit returns in 2020, down from 14.6% in 2019, due to economic growth falters. The asset manager forecasts 1% US economic growth, less than the 1.8% consensus, and sees only a 25% chance of a recession. Vanguard expects interest rates to remain stable, but high-yield bonds could see a 4.5-5% gain. US equity returns are forecasted to range 3.5-5.5%.

site_title: Manulife US Reit staff bring cheer to the elderly
summary: Manulife US Reit staff in Singapore visited the Dignity Kitchen, a home for the elderly, to bring cheer to the residents. The staff served tea, coffee, and other drinks, while also surveying the tables laid out for the day. This act of kindness is part of the company's efforts to give back to the community.

site_title: Indonesia's property firms set for bumper year
summary: Indonesia's property firms are expected to have a bumper year, with shares of construction and real estate companies predicted to surge 32% on average in 2020, according to analyst predictions. The industry's recovery is driven by low interest rates, rebounding commodity prices, and a shift towards mass-market units. Analysts expect a rebound in mass-market residential and industrial property sales in 2020, despite concerns over high debt levels and refinancing risk.

site_title: Seven Hong Kong Airlines planes seized after missed payments
summary: Hong Kong Airlines' seven planes were seized by the Airport Authority after the airline missed payments, deepening concerns about its financial struggles. The seizure, under the Airport Authority Ordinance, allows the authority to sell the planes if not repaid within 60 days. Hong Kong Airlines' operations remain normal, but the move is a sign of the airline's liquidity challenges, with analysts warning of a significant deterioration in earnings for the carrier. The seizures come as Hong Kong's aviation sector faces its toughest year since the global financial crisis due to anti-Beijing protests and economic slowdown.

site_title: Aussie regulator probes Westpac directors, executives
summary: Australia's banking regulator, APRA, is investigating Westpac directors and executives over alleged money laundering breaches, marking the first time APRA has used its increased investigative powers. The bank will hold an extra A$500 million in capital and faces a potential two-year investigation. APRA deputy chairman John Lonsdale said there are "potentially substantial gaps in risk governance" that need to be closed. The investigation follows Austrac's allegations that Westpac breached anti-money laundering laws up to 23 million times between 2013 and 2019.

site_title: Britain to change law, no-deal Brexit looms
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to change the law to prevent the Brexit transition period from being extended, setting up a potential no-deal split with the European Union by the end of 2020. Johnson aims to ratify a new free-trade agreement before the December deadline, despite EU leaders warning it's unlikely a deal can be finalized in time. The move is part of Johnson's effort to force through Britain's divorce from the EU without further delay, now that his party has a majority in Parliament.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment soars to 20-year high
summary: US homebuilder sentiment reached a 20-year high in December, jumping 5 points to 76 on the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. This marks the largest monthly increase since 2017 and a 20-point gain for the index this year. The gauge of prospective buyer traffic climbed 4 points to 58, matching the highest level since 1998, and current sales surged by 7 points to 84, the best reading since 1999. The data suggests a further strengthening in housing permits and new-home sales, despite supply-side constraints and higher development costs.

images.alt_text: The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index jumped five points to 76, the biggest monthly increase since the end of 2017.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust refinances 7 Malaysian properties
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has refinanced seven Malaysian properties through the issuance of new seven-year medium-term notes, totaling about RM445 million. The refinancing was completed through a special-purpose vehicle and will mature in December 2026. The move had no material impact on the trust's FY2018-19 distribution per unit, net asset value, and gearing. The trust's units shed 0.6% following the announcement.

site_title: Time for corporates to act on climate change
summary: A group of 78 US-based multinational corporations, representing key sectors of the economy, have signed to support the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. The CEOs, who employ 2 million people and union leaders who represent 12.5 million workers, aim to reduce greenhouse emissions, which have reached critical levels. Despite governments' efforts, the agreement's implementation relies on corporate commitment. The agreement's failure to limit global warming to 1.5°C by 2030 is a concern, but scientists suggest fast action can reduce carbon emissions within 12 years and limit global increases below 2°C.

site_title: UAE pledges gentle start to new rules for marine fuel
summary: The UAE has pledged a gradual implementation of new marine fuel regulations, allowing oil tanker owners to adjust to the changes. The country will initially take a flexible approach to enforcing the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2020 rules, which limit sulphur content in ships' fuel to 0.5%. Ships with non-compliant fuel will be subject to spot checks, and authorities will not initially impose penalties. The UAE aims to achieve full compliance in two years, with a ban on carrying overly sulphurous fuel set to take effect in March.

site_title: A-HTrust suspends trading; books closure on Dec 18
summary: Trading of Ascendas Hospitality Trust's (A-HTrust) stapled securities was suspended on Dec 17, with books closure set for Dec 18. The trust's manager plans to determine entitlements of securityholders regarding a trust scheme of arrangement with Ascott Residence Trust, with allotment and payment expected by Dec 31. The delisting is scheduled for Jan 3, 2020, following approval by securityholders in October.

site_title: The year the markets stopped believing in unicorns
summary: The tech industry's "unicorn" era, characterized by startups valued at over $1 billion, has experienced a significant downturn in 2019. Initially expected to bring in billions of dollars in IPOs, companies like Uber, Lyft, and WeWork have seen their shares drop by one-third. This decline is attributed to the companies' lack of profits and concerns about their valuations and growth prospects. Despite the poor performance of some unicorns, private investment in tech remains strong, with sovereign wealth funds and venture capitalists continuing to invest in startups.

site_title: European car sales heading for flat year despite boost in November
summary: European car sales rose 4.5% in November, the third consecutive monthly gain, but remain down 0.3% for the year. Despite the November boost, four of the region's five largest markets have seen a decline in sales since January. This marks a mixed trend for the European automotive industry, which has been affected by economic woes, trade wars, and industry slowdowns.

site_title: Boeing temporarily halts production of 737 Max
summary: Boeing temporarily halts production of 737 Max jets in January 2020 due to ongoing safety concerns following two crashes that killed 346 people. The decision confirms investor fears of a prolonged recovery and uncertainty for the company. The halt will affect 40 jets produced per month at a Renton, Washington facility, with 400 stored aircraft to be delivered instead. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has delayed the aircraft's return to service, and major air carriers have pushed back their return dates. Boeing will continue to pay its workers despite the production stoppage.

site_title: Star Wars fever grips Hollywood with Rise of Skywalker premiere
summary: The highly anticipated Star Wars film, "The Rise of Skywalker," premiered in Los Angeles, marking the conclusion of the epic Star Wars trilogy of trilogies. A galaxy of VIPs, including Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, and Daisy Ridley, attended the world premiere. The film is expected to gross $200-225 million at the North American box office, with analysts predicting a stellar opening. Director JJ Abrams returns after his successful 2015 film "The Force Awakens," but controversy surrounds his involvement due to the initial script being rewritten. The film concludes the Skywalker saga, with fans receiving closure and satisfaction for their favorite characters.

images.alt_text: Fans in Star Wars costumes attending the world premiere of Disney's Star Wars: Rise of Skywalker at the TCL Chinese Theatre in Hollywood, California on Dec 16.
Veterans Harrison Ford (above) and Mark Hamill arrived to bid farewell to the movies that launched their careers in style.

site_title: Instagram fights falsehoods with help of fact-checking allies
summary: Instagram has expanded its fight against misinformation by partnering with fact-checkers worldwide, following its US launch earlier this year. The platform uses third-party allies to identify and label false content, reducing its distribution and displaying warning labels. It also uses image matching technology to find further instances of the content and apply labels. Additionally, Instagram will automatically label identical content posted on Facebook if it is rated false or partly false on the platform. This move aims to combat photo and video-based misinformation globally.

site_title: Aussie dollar falls, pound tanks on fresh trade fears
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a weekly low on Tuesday due to a central bank's hint of another interest rate cut as early as February, contributing to a weakening of other currencies. Meanwhile, the British pound plummeted after Prime Minister Boris Johnson revived the risk of a hard Brexit, stating that extending the transition period beyond 2020 would be illegal. These developments fueled trade-related concerns and contributed to the decline in currencies.

site_title: US: Dow dips at open; S&P 500, Nasdaq slightly higher
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 14.14 points, or 0.05%, to 28,221.75 at the open on Tuesday, pressured by a decline in Boeing shares amid the 737 MAX crisis. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indexes rose, with the S&P 500 opening higher by 3.95 points, or 0.12%, to 3,195.40, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 15.24 points, or 0.17%, to 8,829.47.

site_title: Yongnam expects uplift with S$101.3m worth of new contracts
summary: Yongnam Holdings, a Singapore-listed steelmaker, has secured five new civil engineering contracts worth S$101.3 million for infrastructure projects in Singapore and Hong Kong. The contracts, including a sub-contract for a major infrastructure project in eastern Singapore, are expected to positively impact the company's financial performance for the year to Dec 31. CEO Seow Soon Yong stated that the company's capabilities in handling infrastructure mega-projects demonstrate its technical and engineering prowess.

site_title: Impeachment IV: A national tragedy
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives are unlikely to result in his conviction in the Senate due to a Republican majority. The impeachment process, which began in the House, accuses Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, similar to the 1974 case against President Nixon. However, the Senate has never convicted a president in its history, and it's expected that Trump will not be impeached and removed from office. The impeachment case is seen as a highly politicized and divisive issue, with Democrats and Republicans unable to agree on the wisdom of impeaching the president.

site_title: SPH's 21%-owned JV wins S$1.82m digital display deal
summary: SPH's 21%-owned JV, Target Media Culcreative, won a S$1.82m digital display deal with the Housing Board for 6,000 panels at HDB estates. The joint venture beat out other companies, including state investor Temasek Holdings' Mediacorp, with a successful bid. The pilot project aims to install, operate, and manage the display panels.

site_title: Recovery on track for Singapore's hoteliers
summary: Singapore's hotel industry appears to be recovering from a downcycle, with tourist arrivals rising 2.3% year-on-year to 15.85 million in the first 10 months of 2019. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) averaged S$191.40, up from S$189.20 in 2018. Occupancy rates averaged 87.2%, with average room rates slightly higher. Analysts predict further growth, with RevPAR projected to increase by 2-5% in 2020. The upcoming MICE calendar and potential events in Singapore are expected to drive hotel demand, while a lower-for-longer interest rate environment and a higher debt ceiling could provide a boost to the S-Reit sector.

site_title: ISOTeam launches S$28.9m equity fundraising exercise
summary: ISOTeam, a Catalist-listed building maintenance company, is launching a S$28.9 million equity fundraising exercise. The company will place 84 million new shares at S$0.24 each and issue warrants and shares to a Japanese investor, Taisei Oncho. The deal aims to raise S$19.4 million from the share placement and S$9.5 million from the Taisei Oncho deal, primarily for mergers and acquisitions and business expansion. The issuance must be approved by an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: New investor offers to buy out some of Hyflux's creditors
summary: A new investor, Aqua Munda, has offered to buy out some of Hyflux's creditors, estimated to be around S$1.8 billion, including contingent liabilities. This move comes as the water treatment company faces financial difficulties. The offer is made to holders of Hyflux's 4.25% and 4.6% notes due in 2018 and 2019, as well as to the unsecured creditors of Hyflux and three of its subsidiaries. The deal aims to provide a lifeline to the struggling company.

site_title: Indonesia warns on EU trade deal, dairy imports amid palm oil spat
summary: Indonesia is prepared to walk away from EU free trade talks over palm oil concerns, while launching a probe into EU dairy imports amid subsidies. Indonesia, the world's top palm oil producer, has filed a WTO lawsuit against the EU, citing an unfair policy. The EU's stance on palm oil has led to a rise in trade tensions, with Indonesia threatening to impose tariffs on EU dairy products if the EU does not reconsider its stance. Talks on a comprehensive economic trade agreement (CEPA) are set to continue despite the tensions.

site_title: Instagram expands fact-checking globally
summary: Instagram has expanded its fact-checking program globally, following its launch in the US earlier this year. The program, which uses third-party fact-checkers, aims to reduce the spread of misinformation on the platform. Content deemed false will be downgraded in news feeds, labeled with a warning, and ignored by search and recommendation tools. Instagram will also automatically label identical content from Facebook if it is posted on its platform. The move is part of Instagram's efforts to combat misinformation, which has been a challenge across the social media industry.

site_title: Top Glove Q1 profit up 1.2% on better nitrile glove sales
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, reported a 1.2% increase in its Q1 profit to RM111.4 million due to strong growth in the nitrile glove segment. Revenue fell 4.2% to RM1.21 billion, mainly due to lower average selling prices and raw material prices. The company attributed the growth to technology advancements, automation, and digitalization, as well as increased nitrile capacity. However, weaker contributions from natural rubber and vinyl glove segments, as well as higher natural rubber latex prices, impacted performance.

site_title: Japan industry ministry gets 45.9b yen extra budget to strengthen resource policy
summary: Japan's industry ministry has secured 45.9 billion yen from the country's supplementary budget to strengthen its resource policy and secure supplies of key commodities. The move aims to diversify rare earths and cobalt sources, reducing reliance on China, which dominates the global supply chain. Japan also plans to increase self-sufficiency ratios for oil and gas, aiming to boost oil and gas self-sufficiency to 40% by 2030. The additional budget will be used to support LNG projects in Russia and Arctic areas, and to fund equity investments to raise self-sufficiency ratios.

site_title: Stay nimble, flexible in late cycle rebound
summary: The global economy is at a late-cycle inflection point, but late cycle doesn't mean end cycle. Expect a moderate growth reacceleration in early 2020 due to geopolitical risks abating, China's growth slowdown stabilizing, and monetary policy easing. The US Federal Reserve is likely to keep interest rates low, and consumption growth will remain resilient. Geopolitical risks, such as Brexit and the US-China trade standoff, have diminished, and a US-China trade truce could provide support to global corporate confidence. Investors should be prepared for some sharp rotation within risk assets and consider growth-sensitive equity markets, emerging market bonds, and credit opportunities.

images.alt_text: Geopolitics represent both risk and opportunity. Brexit and the US/China trade standoff were the headline geopolitical stories of 2019. However, the probability of a worst case scenario on both issues has clearly diminished.

site_title: Straits Trading unit joins consortium to buy Shanghai mall
summary: Straits Trading Company has joined a consortium to buy a shopping center in Shanghai's Sanlin district for 2.42 billion yuan (S$468.9 million). The company's subsidiary, SRE Venture 16, will hold a 37.7% stake in the joint venture. The purchase is part of Straits Trading's strategy to redeploy capital into potentially higher-return real estate opportunities. The deal is expected to be completed in early 2020, with minimal impact on the company's earnings and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: ECB may need more flexibility around inflation target
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may need to reassess its inflation target, with Estonian central bank chief Madis Müller suggesting the bank consider a band target for price growth. The ECB is preparing a review of its monetary policy next year, amid concerns that economic fundamentals have changed since its last review in 2003, leading to persistent downward pressures on inflation. This could lead to a reevaluation of the bank's unprecedented stimulus efforts.

site_title: NGSC, facing delisting, inks supply-chain management JV deal
summary: NGSC, a Mainboard-listed company facing mandatory delisting, has signed a joint-venture agreement with businessman Charlie In to provide telecom-related supply-chain management services. NGSC will hold a 51% stake in the joint venture, pending a one-year extension or moratorium from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to its potential delisting. The deal aims to help NGSC address its delisting concerns and explore new revenue streams.

site_title: South Korea financial regulator sees bubble in housing prices
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission Chairman Eun Sung Soo warned of a potential property market bubble, stating it's "surely a bubble." He emphasized the need for preparedness, despite not predicting a collapse. The warning comes after the government announced new regulations targeting high-priced homes in select districts, including tighter mortgage rules and higher tax rates.
