This marks a stark contrast to previous policymakers who avoided describing the market as a bubble, highlighting concerns about the country's rapidly rising housing prices.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare cannot appoint directors, execs without bourse's nod
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Camsing Healthcare has been barred from appointing directors or executive officers without first getting approval from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) for up to three years, following a notice of compliance issued on Tuesday. The restriction came after chairman and controlling shareholder Lo Ching's bid to oust and replace some directors was withdrawn. The regulator noted that any changes to the board composition could compromise oversight of an ongoing special audit.

site_title: US industrial output rebounds sharply in November
summary: US industrial output rebounded sharply in November, with a 1.1% surge, the largest increase since May 2010. This was largely due to a bounce back in motor vehicle and parts production following the end of a six-week strike at General Motors. Manufacturing also saw a 1.1% gain, the biggest since February 2018. While total industrial production and manufacturing output are still lower than in November 2018, the news is a positive sign after seven months of declines.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.60 points to 1,576.95, closing higher on Tuesday. The index saw a volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 439 to 359.

site_title: Broadway Industrial gets fresh trading query from SGX RegCo
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a precision manufacturer, received a fresh trading query from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) due to unusual price movements in its shares. The query, the second in six months, is related to ongoing merger and acquisition talks, which the company is conducting as part of a strategic review. Broadway Industrial has assured SGX RegCo that it has not made any decisions or entered into agreements regarding the talks, and there is no certainty that they will progress beyond the current stage.

site_title: China to grant regular tariff waivers for US farm imports
summary: China will provide regular tariff waivers to US farm imports, following a phase one trade deal, according to sources. Waivers, previously given in tranches, will now be issued more frequently to encourage Chinese companies to purchase US goods subject to retaliatory tariffs. This move aims to help China meet its commitments and alleviate pressure on its agricultural sector, which has been impacted by African swine fever.

site_title: After 25 years, Mariah Carey's All I Want for Christmas Is You tops US charts for first time
summary: Mariah Carey's holiday classic "All I Want for Christmas Is You" has finally topped the US charts after 25 years, reaching No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for the first time. The song, released in 1994, had previously been excluded due to its status as an album cut, but streaming metrics and a new video helped propel it to the top. This milestone marks Carey's 19th No. 1 hit and her first Christmas song to reach the top spot in six decades.

site_title: Pound declines as Brexit-deadline pledge ends honeymoon period
summary: The pound has declined by 0.9% to US$1.3219 after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's pledge to end the Brexit transition phase by the end of 2020, potentially leading to a no-deal split with the EU. This move has revived concerns about the Brexit deadlock, causing UK-focused stocks to fall by over 1%. Sterling had previously climbed following the Conservative Party's victory in the UK general election, fueling optimism for a speedy resolution. EU leaders warn that a deal is unlikely in the 11-month period between Brexit day and the December deadline.

site_title: EU lawmakers tweak proposed rules on sustainable investments
summary: EU lawmakers agreed to support tweaked proposals governing sustainable investments after rejecting a deal last week. The proposals aim to establish a global standard for green bonds and other climate-conscious investments. The changes, approved by analysts and environmental groups, leave the door open for labelling nuclear energy as sustainable, but with a "no-harm" test. The bill is expected to be approved by EU member states on Wednesday and then sent to the European Commission for signing into law.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat after two sessions of gains
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Tuesday, ending 0.04% down at 6,847.30 after a two-session gain. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 2% in the previous sessions due to optimism over trade deals and interest rate cuts. However, losses in gold stocks and a decline in financial sector shares offset gains in material and energy stocks. The benchmark index was weighed down by a 1% drop in gold stocks and a 0.9% drop in Westpac Banking Corp, which faces a banking regulator investigation.

site_title: Mencast Holdings unit inks waste treatment contract worth S$24m
summary: Mencast Offshore & Marine, a unit of Mencast Holdings, has secured a three-year contract worth S$24 million to sell waste treatment services to an unnamed oil supermajor. The contract, set to run from February 2020 to January 2023, is expected to contribute positively to the company's debt-wracked operations and will not have a material impact on earnings and net tangible assets. The deal is seen as a positive step for the company, which has been struggling financially.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.2% on Tuesday, bucking regional uptrend
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.2% on Tuesday, bucking the regional uptrend. Despite a US-China interim trade deal and improved Chinese factory and retail sales data, the STI was weighed down by the performance of the banking trio, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank (UOB) experiencing declines. Analysts attributed the dip to concerns over narrowing net interest margins, but noted that UOB's conservative management of its balance sheet and potential for higher dividends make it a top pick.

site_title: Hong Kong unemployment rises to highest level since 2017 in November
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to 3.2% in November, the highest level since 2017, due to months of protests damaging the city's economy. The jobless rate in the consumption and tourism-related sector reached a three-year high of 5.2%, while the food and beverage sector saw a 6.2% jobless rate, the highest in over eight years. A slowdown in tourism and reduced spending have hit shopping malls, hotels, and restaurants. The intensity of the unrest appeared to ease in November after pro-democratic candidates won local elections.

site_title: Palladium tops US$2,000; market watchers forecast further rise
summary: Palladium prices surged to a record US$2,000 an ounce, surpassing US$2,000 for the first time. The metal's annual advance is driven by a sustained global deficit, making it difficult to fill. Market watchers expect further price increases, with Citigroup forecasting a potential rise to US$2,500 next year. The global demand for palladium, driven by tighter emissions rules, has outpaced supply, leading to a 58% price increase this year. The metal's price is expected to continue moving higher, but with increased volatility.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than one percent on Tuesday, driven by a record-breaking lead from Wall Street fueled by the China-US trade deal. The Hang Seng index rose 1.22% to 27,843.71, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 1.27% to 3,022.42. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.33% to 1,708.78. The gains follow a strong performance on US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Analysts predict Indonesia property firms are set for bumper year
summary: Indonesia's property-related stocks are predicted to surge 32% in the next year, according to analyst predictions. The industry has recovered from dwindling demand, driven by low interest rates and rebounding commodity prices. Sales of new homes grew 14% in the July-September period, and developers are shifting to mass-market units. The prospect of eased foreign ownership restrictions and a recovery in crude palm-oil prices may also boost sales. However, concerns remain about high debt levels and refinancing risk.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end at 7-month high as chipmakers jump
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 7-month high on Tuesday, driven by a rebound in chip prices and improved risk sentiment following the "Phase one" trade deal between the US and China. Chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix surged 3.7% and 4.7%, respectively. The won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell, while foreigners bought more local stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher supported by US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, supported by US rallies, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.47% to its highest level since early October. The rally followed strong Chinese factory output data and a detente in the US-China trade relationship. US stocks also reached record highs, despite tariff uncertainty, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Indonesian domestic demand to remain soft in 2020 despite accelerating reforms and stabilising exports: Citi
summary: Citi expects Indonesian domestic demand to remain soft in the first half of 2020, driven by rising administered prices, including electricity and cigarette excise. Citi projects a 4% inflation rate, the upper end of Bank Indonesia's target, and a flat to slightly lower GDP growth rate of 5.0% in 2020. Reforms aimed at enhancing the business environment and attracting foreign direct investment are expected to pass, but Citi notes that the broader FDI outlook still relies on lifting non-tariff restrictions. Exports are expected to stabilize, driven by a rebound in palm oil exports and steady growth in selected clothing sectors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports continued to contract in November, driven by shrinking electronic exports. Less than a fifth of Old Noble shareholders have completed steps to receive new shares in Noble Group Holdings. Cromwell E-Reit has agreed to dispose of 12 European properties. Allianz Real Estate has appointed Danny Phuan as Asia-Pacific head of acquisitions. Meanwhile, Singapore shares dropped 0.2% on Tuesday, bucking regional trends, with the Straits Times Index ending at 3,200.80.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil exports continued to contract in November as a result of shrinking electronic exports, which outpaced the growth of other exports like gold and non-electric engines and motors.

site_title: Real estate investment in Asia-Pac to outperform other regions in 2020: JLL
summary: Real estate investment in Asia-Pacific is expected to outperform other regions in 2020, reaching $125 billion in the first three quarters of 2019, a 10% year-over-year increase, according to JLL. Foreign investments in Asia-Pacific are at a decade-high, driven by private equity funds and large-scale transactions. The consultancy predicts a stronger investor appetite for logistics, with investors becoming more creative to access quality assets. Additionally, JLL expects growth in the green building sector, flexible workspaces, and strategic mergers and acquisitions, driven by geopolitical uncertainty and slowing economic growth.

site_title: Toyota to use advanced self-driving tech in commercial vehicles first
summary: Toyota plans to first deploy advanced self-driving features in commercial vehicles, such as taxis and ride-sharing services, before adding them to personal cars. According to James Kuffner, chief of Toyota Research Institute-Advanced Development, this approach will allow for easier application of self-driving technology that doesn't require constant human monitoring. Toyota aims to release its first Level 2 autonomous car, capable of driving itself on highways, within the next few decades, and is taking a longer view on self-driving cars compared to competitors.

site_title: French unions make pre-Christmas push to block pension reforms
summary: French trade unions are using transport strikes and mass protests to try to block President Emmanuel Macron's planned pension reform before Christmas. The nationwide movement has entered its second week, with 80% of trains out of action in the Paris region, causing traffic congestion and disrupting Christmas shopping. The unions, seeking to make a major show of force, are expecting hundreds of thousands to march through central Paris, despite a survey showing 55% of people believe the strikes are unacceptable. The unions are pushing for Macron to ditch the reform, which aims to streamline the pension system and encourage people to work until 64.

site_title: China wants to avoid flood of infrastructure investment in 2020
summary: China's state economic planner announced it will make "precise" and "effective" investments in transportation infrastructure in 2020, focusing on filling gaps rather than a flood of investments. The government will prioritize market-driven decisions and resource allocation, with key projects including the Sichuan-Tibet railway and public roads in rural China. This strategy aims to achieve goals outlined in the 13th "five-year plan" set to end in 2020.

site_title: SoftBank's Son says Japan should make AI mandatory subject for college students
summary: SoftBank Group Corp CEO Masayoshi Son recommends making artificial intelligence a mandatory subject for Japanese college students to close the gap with the US and China. He cites the need to focus on areas like autonomous driving and DNA-centred medicine to address Japan's rapidly aging society. Son suggests collaborating with US tech giants instead of competing against them, highlighting the importance of leveraging their close relationship. This move aims to foster innovation and help Japan stay competitive in the field of AI.

site_title: Top Glove Q1 profit up 1.2% on better nitrile glove sales
summary: Top Glove's Q1 net profit rose 1.2% to RM111.4 million, driven by strong growth in the nitrile glove segment. Technology advancements, automation, and digitalization contributed to better sales and profits. Revenue decreased 4.2% to RM1.21 billion due to lower average selling prices and raw material prices. The company's nitrile capacity expansion enabled it to grow sales and capture a bigger market share, but was offset by weaker contributions from other segments.

site_title: JPMorgan raises 2020 oil price view on Opec+ cuts, improved economic outlook
summary: JPMorgan has revised its 2020 oil price forecast to US$64.5 per barrel, citing tighter supply-demand balance due to Opec+ output cuts and improved global economic growth. The bank expects prices to slip to US$61.50 in 2021. The revised forecast reflects the Opec+ agreement to cut output by 500,000 barrels per day in the first quarter of 2020, and stronger economic growth in emerging markets. Global oil demand growth is expected to remain at 1 mbpd.

site_title: Hong Kong needs to do more to stop violence, resolve problems: government
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Secretary Matthew Cheung expressed disappointment over recent protest violence, urging the government to resolve deep-rooted problems to stop the violence. Following a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Cheung stated that the work of stopping violence has not been completed. The city gears up for more anti-government demonstrations, with protests scheduled for Tuesday and beyond. The protests, which began over a proposed extradition law, have been fueled by concerns over China's encroachment on Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: China's oil imports are most world's ever seen and still growing
summary: China has broken records for crude oil imports, surpassing the US high-water mark of 10.77 million barrels a day in June 2005 with 11.18 million barrels in November. Despite economic slowdown, China's oil imports are expected to continue rising as new refineries ramp up and trade tensions with the US ease. The country's leaders rely on state-owned energy giants to boost domestic oil and gas output, and are also investing in renewable energy to reduce oil demand in the long run. China's oil imports are expected to remain a significant factor in its economy.

site_title: Gojek closes in on deal to buy 5% of Indonesia taxi operator Blue Bird: sources
summary: Gojek is nearing a deal to buy 5% of Indonesian taxi operator Blue Bird for approximately US$30 million, valuing the company at about US$600 million. The acquisition would mark a significant expansion for Gojek, building on their existing partnership and bolstering its presence in the market. The deal is seen as a response to mounting competition from Grab Holdings Inc., with analysts citing potential synergies and increased market share. Blue Bird shares have gained 5.1% following the news, with the company's valuation rising to a record high.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon down 0.05% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading Tuesday afternoon down 0.05% to 3,204.45, despite 161 gainers outnumbering 134 losers. Banking stocks declined, with DBS and United Overseas Bank falling 0.5% and 0.6% respectively. Other stocks, including Singapore Press Holdings and Mapletree Commercial Trust, rose 1.9% and 1.3% respectively. The decline comes after Singapore's non-oil exports contracted in November, mainly due to shrinking electronic exports.

site_title: Spain's Telefonica to drastically reduce Huawei kit for core 5G network
summary: Spain's Telefonica plans to reduce its reliance on Huawei for its core 5G network by 2024, opting for multiple suppliers instead. The decision is a technical one, not driven by security concerns, despite US President Donald Trump's allegations of Huawei gear being insecure. Telefonica will continue to buy radios and antennas from Huawei, but will instead source core equipment from other providers to ensure security and data protection. Fellow European operators Vodafone and Deutsche Telekom are also adopting this strategy, with Deutsche Telekom holding off on contracts until German politicians agree on Huawei's national security status.

site_title: ANZ chairman says bank can meet capital requirements without fresh money
summary: ANZ Chairman David Gonski stated that the bank is confident in meeting higher capital requirements without raising new capital from shareholders. The announcement comes after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand highlighted the need for improved internal risk controls at ANZ's New Zealand unit.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slip at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.3%. The Paris CAC 40 reversed 0.1% gains from the previous day. The decline followed a strong rally the previous day, with investors seemingly brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend a stocks rally.

site_title: China won't resort to massive infrastructure stimulus as investment slows
summary: China will adopt a targeted approach to boosting investment and refrain from massive stimulus in its infrastructure push, according to the state planner. Fixed asset investment grew 5.2% from January-November, but infrastructure investment slowed further. Policymakers have brought forward 1 trillion yuan in local government special bonds to finance infrastructure projects. China has confidence in achieving its full-year economic targets, with a proactive fiscal stance and prudent monetary policy. Beijing will focus on resource allocation through the market, rather than resorting to stimulus measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.38 points, or 0.22%, to 1,572.73 at 9:03am on Tuesday, with volume reaching 62.30 million lots worth RM25.52 million. Gainers outpaced losers 133 to 50.

site_title: Lynas fails to get Malaysian approval for higher processing limit, shares slide
summary: Lynas Corp, an Australian rare earths miner, failed to secure approval from a Malaysian regulator to increase its lanthanide concentrate processing limit for 2019. As a result, the company's total neodymium and praseodymium production for 2019 will be similar to that of 2018. Lynas shares slid 5.8% after the announcement, but analyst Andrew White believes the miner's profitability may not take a significant hit due to other factors. The US Department of Defence's push to increase rare earths capabilities in the US may also support Lynas' fortunes.

site_title: Allianz Real Estate hires ex-Keppel Capital exec as Asia-Pacific head of acquisitions
summary: Allianz Real Estate has appointed Danny Phuan, a veteran of the real estate sector, as Asia-Pacific head of acquisitions. Phuan, who joined the firm on December 2, brings over 25 years of experience to the role. His appointment is part of Allianz Real Estate's efforts to strengthen its presence and acquisition capabilities in the region, with a target to allocate 10% of its global portfolio in Asia. Phuan reports to APAC CEO Rushabh Desai and will oversee sourcing and execution of transactions across the region.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as China-US trade deal buoys sentiment
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, buoyed by the China-US trade deal, which removed uncertainty and sparked a surge in equities. The deal, announced on Friday, will see Washington wind back tariffs and China increase US goods purchases. Asian markets continued their rally on Monday, with all three main indexes ending at all-time highs. Sterling took a hit as fears of a no-deal Brexit emerged, while Christmas cheer continued on trading floors.

site_title: 14 miners dead after southwest China mine blast
summary: Fourteen miners were killed in a coal and gas blast at a mine in southwest China's Guizhou province on Tuesday. Two people remain trapped underground. The accident occurred at the Gaunglong coal mine, part of a series of mining incidents in China with lax safety regulations. The incident follows a mine flood in Sichuan province that killed five and trapped 13 miners. China's State Council had ordered a crackdown on production-related safety issues in November.

site_title: US$5b flee Hong Kong funds amid unrest: Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England reports that US$5 billion of capital has fled Hong Kong investment funds since April due to unrest, accounting for nearly 1.25% of the region's GDP. The unrest, sparked by a proposed extradition bill, led to violent clashes and a recession in the city. The Bank of England closely monitors Hong Kong due to its financial significance, with UK banks such as HSBC and Standard Chartered having passed stress tests. Analysts have estimated that deposits may have left Hong Kong for Singapore, contradicting the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's claims of no significant capital outflows.

site_title: Taiwan's stock benchmark hits 12,000 for the first time since 1990
summary: Taiwan's stock benchmark, the Taiex, reached a 12-year high of 12,097.01, surpassing 12,000 for the first time since 1990. The Taiex gained 1.3% and 24% for the year, driven by a surge in electronic product exports and semiconductor sales. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), the world's largest chip supplier, reported record sales and a 9.7% year-on-year increase. The Taiwan dollar also rose, near its highest level against the US dollar since June 2018, as the country's economy shows resilience despite global trade tensions.

site_title: The CEO trying to fix palm oil says he's no orangutan killer
summary: CEO Carl Bek-Nielsen of United Plantations Bhd, a palm oil producer, defends his company's practices against criticism that the industry contributes to deforestation and animal extinction. He emphasizes that while "rogue players" exist, many companies, including his own, are working to improve sustainability. Bek-Nielsen highlights his company's achievements in producing sustainable palm oil, including its commitment to environmental, social, and governance practices. He argues that boycotts of palm oil are counterproductive, as they punish both guilty and innocent companies. The industry needs a "carrot" to encourage more sustainable production, and Bek-Nielsen advocates for a shift in consumer demand to support certified sustainable palm oil.

site_title: Indonesia's Alpha JWC Ventures closes US$123m tech fund
summary: Alpha JWC Ventures, an Indonesian venture capital firm, has closed its second fund at US$123 million, a record for an Indonesia-focused early-stage VC fund. The firm has backed 14 startups, including Kopi Kenangan, and has seen a 3.2x increase in the net asset value of its debut fund. The closure of the second fund underscores growing interest in fostering Indonesian startups, which have given birth to internet giants like Gojek and Tokopedia.

site_title: 'Star Wars' grips Hollywood with 'Rise of Skywalker' premiere
summary: The highly anticipated "Star Wars: Rise of Skywalker" premiered in Los Angeles, bringing together a galaxy of VIPs from the space saga. The film, the final installment in the epic trilogy of trilogies, was attended by veterans Mark Hamill and Harrison Ford, as well as special guests from Steven Spielberg to Spike Lee. Analysts predict a massive opening at the domestic box office, with Disney chief Bob Iger stating that fans will receive "some kind of closure" and "satisfaction" for their favorite characters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Tuesday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% on Tuesday, following a third consecutive record close on Wall Street, driven by optimism over the China-US trade deal. The Hang Seng index climbed to 27,630.69, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The rally came as investors sought to capitalize on potential improvements in the US-China trade talks, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares struggle to advance as financials temper China optimism
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Tuesday, driven by upbeat Chinese data and positive comments from a top White House adviser on the US-China trade deal. However, financial sector losses and steep declines in gold stocks limited gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,855.6. Key contributors to the rally included BHP Group and Rio Tinto, while Westpac Banking Corp and the Big Four banks faced regulatory pressures.

site_title: San Teh to delist from SGX on Dec 19
summary: San Teh, a Singapore property firm, will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on December 19 at 9am following a compulsory acquisition by the Kao family, which acquired 95.38% of the company's shares at S$0.28 apiece. The acquisition closed on November 21. San Teh had applied to delist on November 1 and requested share suspension on November 22. The move marks the end of San Teh's listing on the SGX.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to dispose of 12 properties in Europe
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has entered into a master sale and purchase agreement to dispose of 12 properties in the Netherlands, Denmark, and France for 65.7 million euros (S$99.2 million). The sale includes 5 properties in the Netherlands, 2 in Denmark, and 5 in France, with a total estimated capital gain of 5 million euros, expected to increase the Reit's net asset value. The disposal is part of Cromwell E-Reit's strategy to recycle capital into new investments, improve the occupancy rate by 0.7%, and enhance the Reit's distribution per unit and net asset value per unit.

site_title: Sim Lim Square launches 2nd bid for collective sale with extra space
summary: Sim Lim Square, a six-storey mall in Singapore, has launched its second collective sale tender with an additional 27% of built-up space, offering developers a higher plot ratio and potential lower development charges. The reserve price remains unchanged at over S$1.25 billion, with a closing date of Dec 30. The mall's increased built-up space and potential for reduced land rates could attract foreign funds and institutional investors.

site_title: Superman's cape sells for nearly US$200,000 in Hollywood auction
summary: Superman's first movie cape from the 1978 film sold for nearly US$200,000 at Julien's Auctions in Los Angeles. The cape, one of only six used during filming, was part of a collection of 400 cinephile items, including costumes from Star Trek, Ghostbusters II, and The Lord of the Rings. Other notable items included Patrick Stewart's Captain Jean-Luc Picard uniform (US$28,800) and Leonard Nimoy's Romulan costume (US$20,000). The auction marked a successful sale for the auction house, with multiple rare Hollywood memorabilia items finding new homes.

site_title: Zilingo acquires software firm nCinga Innovations in US$15.5m deal
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based fashion technology platform, has acquired nCinga Innovations in a US$15.5 million cash and stock deal to enhance its global supply chain capabilities. The acquisition will enable real-time data access and automation of factory floor operations, expanding Zilingo's presence in the US, Europe, and Australia. This move aims to bring transparency to supply chain and manufacturing processes for Zilingo's customers, driving growth and market access.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports continue slide in November
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports continued to contract in November, falling 5.9% year-on-year, with electronic exports declining 23.3% due to shrinking demand for integrated circuits and other electronic components. Non-electronic exports grew 1.3% in November, driven by increased exports of non-monetary gold and non-electric engines and motors. The decline was largely attributed to a decrease in exports to Hong Kong, the European Union, and China, with the exception of Thailand and Indonesia.

site_title: Pound falls on report Johnson planning new Brexit deadline
summary: The British pound dropped 0.7% to $1.3236 after reports that UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is seeking a hard line on Britain's transition period after Brexit, potentially delaying a trade deal with the EU. The move contradicts hopes for a flexible approach, and analysts say it may lead to a decline in the UK economy. The news follows a massive relief rally after the UK election, and sterling's peak of $1.3516 is now seen as a near-term peak.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Tuesday; STI up 0.05%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.05% on Tuesday, driven by a rally in US markets sparked by the new US-China trade deal. The Straits Times Index gained 1.46 points to 3,207.55, with SunMoon Food and Sen Yue being the top gainers. Despite a positive trend, local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB declined. The US markets closed at record highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all rising.

site_title: Less than a fifth of Old Noble shareholders have completed steps to get new shares
summary: Less than one-fifth of Old Noble shareholders have completed steps to receive new shares in Noble Group Holdings, with 2,000 out of 15,000 registered shareholders fulfilling requirements. Over 75% of allocated shares have been successfully distributed to the online share portal operated by Fluyd. Shareholders must provide identity and address documents, and bank account details to receive shares, with a three-month extension until March 19, 2020, to register.

site_title: Australian regulator investigates Westpac directors, executives after scandal
summary: Australia's banking regulator, APRA, launches its first formal investigation using the Banking Executive Accountability Regime (BEAR) to examine Westpac directors and executives over alleged money laundering breaches. The investigation follows a self-assessment program that found Westpac needed to toughen its oversight of non-financial risk. Westpac will be required to hold an extra A$500 million in capital and faces potential charges of giving false or misleading information to auditors, which carry up to five years in jail. The investigation could take up to two years to complete.

site_title: A-HTrust suspends trading; books closure on Dec 18
summary: Trading of Ascendas Hospitality Trust's (A-HTrust) stapled securities has been suspended as the trust manager determines entitlements for A-HTrust stapled securityholders regarding a scheme of arrangement. The books closure is set for Dec 18, and the expected allotment and issue of consideration units and cash consideration is Dec 31. The delisting is scheduled for Jan 3, 2020.

site_title: UK's Johnson to have law for Brexit arrangements to end by Dec 31 next year: ITV
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to pass a law by December 31 next year that will end the UK's arrangements for leaving the European Union. The revised Withdrawal Agreement Bill will be put before parliament on Friday, with Johnson's large majority expected to secure its passage. This move aims to formalize the UK's exit from the EU by the agreed deadline.

site_title: After 25 years, Mariah Carey's 'All I Want for Christmas Is You' tops US charts
summary: Mariah Carey's 'All I Want for Christmas Is You' has finally topped the US charts after 25 years, marking a milestone for the holiday classic. The song, released in 1994, has become a love-to-hate cliché. Carey expressed excitement on Twitter, calling it a "dream come true." The song's long-awaited success may have caught some by surprise, but it solidifies its place as a modern holiday staple.

site_title: Investors in cryptocurrency exchange demand founder's body be exhumed
summary: Investors in QuadrigaCX, a cryptocurrency exchange, are demanding the exhumation of founder Gerald Cotten's body to rule out the possibility that he faked his own death. Cotten died in December 2018 from Crohn's disease, but the company's clients lost access to $180 million in cryptocurrencies due to his passing. The clients' lawyers claim that Cotten's widow, Jennifer Robertson, could not find the passwords to his laptop, fueling speculation and conspiracy theories that he may have faked his death to escape with the funds. The demand for an exhumation is due to "decomposition concerns" by spring 2020.

site_title: Instagram says will fight misinformation with fact-check allies
summary: Instagram has expanded its fight against misinformation by partnering with fact-checkers globally, following a US launch earlier this year. The move aims to expose deception in shared photos and videos. By partnering with fact-checkers worldwide, Instagram seeks to combat misinformation on its platform, building on its existing efforts in the US. This expansion marks an important step in Instagram's ongoing efforts to combat misinformation.

site_title: Canada predicts slower growth, deficit to climb in 2020
summary: Canada's finance minister predicts economic growth of 1.6% in 2020, the best among G-7 countries, but a rising deficit of C$26.6 billion. Despite this, the government projects a balanced budget by 2024-2025. Canada's debt-to-GDP ratio remains low at 31%, and the country is not at risk of a recession. The government plans to increase the deficit with investments to boost the economy and support Canadians, following an election promise of tax cuts for the middle class.

site_title: Volkswagen says production suspended in Algeria
summary: Volkswagen has suspended production in Algeria due to a corruption investigation into its local partner, Sovac, led by Mourad Oulmi. The factory, which assembles kits for Volkswagen, Audi, Seat, and Skoda vehicles, has been shut down, leaving 700 employees without work. This decision comes amid a broader crackdown on corruption in Algeria, following the ousting of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika in April.

site_title: Australia's central bank opens door to Feb rate cut if needed
summary: Australia's central bank, Reserve Bank of Australia, has indicated it may cut interest rates as early as February if household incomes remain depressed or the labor market worsens. The bank expressed concern over weak wage growth and its impact on inflation and consumption. The RBA has already lowered rates three times since June and has the ability to provide further stimulus if needed. A rate cut is currently priced in by financial markets, with some policymakers suggesting more drastic measures, such as buying government bonds, could be necessary.

site_title: Japan factory activity shrinks for 8th month in December
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted for the 8th consecutive month in December, with the Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing PMI falling to 48.8 from 48.9 in the previous month. The decline in output and new orders threatens to tip the economy into contraction in the current quarter. New export orders shrank for the 13th month, but showed signs of bottoming out. Policymakers are concerned about the impact of the slump on consumer spending, which has been hurt by a sales tax hike.

site_title: SIIC Environment forms JV to invest in China environmental companies
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED SIIC Environment Holdings has formed a joint venture (JV) company with Shanghai Overseas (BVI) and its controlling shareholder to invest in environmental companies in China, particularly in the Yangtze River Delta. The JV, Shanghai Yangtze River Delta Water Environment Investment Fund, has a committed capital of HK$100 million (S$17.3 million), with each party holding 40% equity. The JV will invest in Chinese water supplier Taizhou Water, with SIIC Environment Tech contributing approximately S$7 million. The investment complements the company's existing water projects and allows further development in Taizhou's utility industry.

site_title: US lawmakers fault regulators on T-Mobile-Sprint tie-up
summary: US Democratic lawmakers criticized the Federal Communications Commission for its approval of the T-Mobile-Sprint merger, citing a "troubling lack of transparency" and "apparent lack of appropriate process." The lawmakers questioned whether the original analysis was altered to downplay competition risks and raised concerns about private conversations between T-Mobile representatives and FCC commissioners. The deal, valued at US$26 billion, was approved on a 3-2 vote and is conditioned on the divestment of Sprint's prepaid division. Critics claim it will reduce consumer choices and lead to higher prices.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Extinguishing heartburn
summary: The Money FM podcast "Extinguishing Heartburn" discussed various health topics, including heartburn prevention. The podcast covered a range of topics, including lifestyle changes, dietary modifications, and stress management techniques. Experts shared their advice on how to alleviate heartburn symptoms, including avoiding trigger foods, managing stress, and incorporating probiotics into one's diet. The episode aimed to provide listeners with practical tips and strategies for managing heartburn.

site_title: SEC permanently bars ex-Goldman banker over 1MDB bribery
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has permanently barred former Goldman Sachs executive Tim Leissner from the securities industry due to his role in a massive bribery scheme related to Malaysia's 1MDB scandal. Leissner used third-party intermediaries to bribe Malaysian and Abu Dhabi officials to secure lucrative business from 1MDB. As part of the settlement, Leissner will surrender $43.7 million in ill-gotten gains, which will be offset by a forfeiture settlement with the Justice Department. Leissner is scheduled to face sentencing in June.

site_title: Lumos will use fresh funds to extend 'smart helmet' product line
summary: Singapore-based startup Lumos has secured US$2.14 million in seed funding to extend its "smart helmet" product line. The company, which aims to increase cycling safety, has previously raised US$1.5 million and has partnered with Apple and Grab. The fresh funds will be used to launch a new product in Q2 2020 and expand its app and software functionality. Lumos has shipped its 100,000th helmet and has operations in Shenzhen and Hong Kong, with 25 full-time employees.

site_title: French hoax costs Bloomberg 5m euros in fines
summary: France's financial markets watchdog fined Bloomberg 5 million euros for distributing a fake news report that triggered a 19% plunge in Vinci's shares, wiping 6 billion euros off the company's value in 2016. The report claimed Vinci had sacked its CFO and restated its accounts due to accounting errors, but was later found to be false. Bloomberg did not verify the information before publication, violating journalistic ethics. The company plans to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: France's financial markets watchdog on Monday hit Bloomberg with a five million euro (S$7.6 million) fine for a report based on a fake news release that triggered a plunge in the shares of French construction giant Vinci and wiped billions off its market value.

site_title: Australian government to borrow A$55b in year to 2020
summary: The Australian government plans to borrow approximately A$55 billion in the year to June 2020, down from its initial plan of A$58 billion. This includes the issuance of new bonds, with A$27.2 billion already issued, and buybacks of short-dated bonds. The government aims to establish a new bond line maturing in May 2032 and will conduct bond sales via regular tenders.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Yanlord, United Engineers, Oxley, Cromwell E-Reit, Citic Envirotech, SIIC Environment
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks saw developments that may impact trading on Tuesday. Singtel's chairman-designate, Lee Theng Kiat, will take over on January 15, 2020. Yanlord Land Group plans to delist United Engineers, reversing an initial proposal. Oxley Holdings sold an office block in Dublin for S$173.6 million. Cromwell E-Reit entered a master sale and purchase agreement to dispose of 12 European properties. Citic Envirotech's buyout bid was deemed fair and reasonable, and SIIC Environment formed a joint venture to invest in environmental companies in China. Uni-Asia Group consolidated its stake in Regina Bulkship.

site_title: Sun Hung Kai's Adam Kwok calls on HK govt to help struggling hotels
summary: Hong Kong's wealthiest family, the Kwoks, are urging the government to help the struggling hotel industry due to declining revenue. Hotel revenue for Sun Hung Kai Properties fell 40% in November and December, and 30% for the entire second half of 2019, due to the pro-democracy protests. The Kwoks, worth $38 billion, are calling on authorities to refer to stimulus policies used during the 2003 SARS epidemic. Despite the challenges, Sun Hung Kai is moving forward with a new hotel opening, citing its affordable prices and focus on Hong Kong's recovery.

site_title: Copyright probe, raids stoke fear in Russian IT
summary: Russia's tech community is alarmed following raids on web company Nginx, one of the country's biggest IT success stories, in a copyright probe. Co-founder Maxim Konovalov condemned the raids as "racketeering", citing US$670 million acquisition by F5 Networks earlier this year. Nginx's web server software is used by a third of the world's active websites. The probe has sparked fears of further crackdowns on the IT industry in Russia.

site_title: British Airways pilots accept pay agreement to end strikes
summary: British Airways pilots have accepted a pay agreement, ending months of dispute and a historic two-day strike in September that cancelled 1,700 flights and disrupted 200,000 passengers. The 11.5% wage increase over three years was proposed by Acas and recommended by the BALPA union, which members voted nearly 9 to 1 to accept. The agreement comes after airline giant IAG reported a 9% decline in net profit in the third quarter due to the strikes, which hurt performance.

site_title: Trump popularity edges up during impeachment
summary: US President Donald Trump's approval ratings have reached their highest point, at 43%, according to a Quinnipiac University survey, despite facing impeachment proceedings. Despite 52% disapproving of his job performance, strong economic figures have contributed to the growth in support. The economy's record low unemployment and positive feelings about its growth have been key factors in Trump's increased approval ratings. However, opinions on impeachment remain divided, with 45% backing removal from office and 51% opposing.

site_title: Europe: Shares touch all-time high as trade, Brexit fog clears
summary: European shares reached an all-time high on Monday, driven by a preliminary US-China trade deal and optimism over the British Conservative Party's election victory. The FTSE 100 rose 2.3%, with big dollar earners and banks benefiting from the gains. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index also hit a record high, while Germany's DAX lagged behind. Investors largely ignored lacklustre data, focusing on trade and Brexit concerns that have weighed on global markets this year.

site_title: Yuan and Australian dollar below four-month highs
summary: TRADE-SENSITIVE currencies like the Australian dollar and Chinese yuan remain below four-month highs, as investors express caution over a lack of details in the US-China trade agreement. Sterling, however, remains strong after the Conservative Party's election win. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher supported by US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by US shares reaching fresh record levels due to a US-China trade deal and upbeat economic data. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.49% to 24,070.73, while the Topix index rose 0.42% to 1,744.22. This rally follows a 5-day gain in Singapore stocks and comes despite US President Trump's recent threats.

site_title: Brazil, China finalising soymeal export protocol: Abiove
summary: Brazil and China are finalizing a protocol to set health standards for domestic processors to export soymeal to China. The protocol aims to allow Brazilian companies to compete with Chinese soy processors. The move is expected to increase soymeal exports, particularly as demand is expected to rise in China due to restored pork production after African swine fever. Brazil's soybean processing is expected to grow by 9 million tonnes by 2023, with 80% of exports going to China. The protocol is seen as a key step for Brazilian companies to tap into China's growing market.

site_title: Oil rises on US-China trade hopes, still below 3-month highs
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Monday, with Brent crude oil futures settling up 12 cents to $65.34 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate crude up 14 cents to $60.21 a barrel. The increase was driven by hopes for a US-China trade deal, which could boost energy demand. However, analysts remain cautious, noting that the market is still weighing the merits of the deal and seeking clarity on its terms.

site_title: Telenor says Huawei will still play role in 5G rollout
summary: Telenor has reaffirmed its partnership with Huawei for Norway's 5G rollout, despite US pressure. Huawei will continue to play a role in modernizing the 5G network, working alongside Ericsson. Telenor plans to phase out Huawei network components over a 4-5 year period. The move comes amid increased scrutiny of Huawei's security in Europe. Despite this, Huawei welcomes competition and looks forward to continuing its collaboration with Telenor.

site_title: November 2019 was second hottest on record: US
summary: The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) announced that November 2019 was the second-hottest November on record, with global land and ocean surface temperatures 0.92°C above the 20th-century average. This was just shy of the record set in 2015. Sea-ice coverage in the Arctic and Antarctic also reached near-record lows, with the Arctic being 12.8% below average. The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service also confirmed November 2019 as the joint-hottest November in history.

images.alt_text: Last month was the second hottest November in the 140-year global climate record, a US government agency said Monday, adding that polar sea ice also shrank to near-record lows.

site_title: Lee Theng Kiat named chairman-designate of Singtel
summary: Lee Theng Kiat, 66, has been named chairman-designate of Singtel, starting Jan 15, 2020. He will also serve as a non-executive, non-independent director. Lee is Temasek International's former CEO, with a 52.5% stake in Singtel, and will recuse himself from Temasek's deliberations on Singtel. He has asked not to receive director's fees and will serve in his personal capacity. This appointment follows the planned retirement of Simon Israel, who has led the Singtel board since 2011.

site_title: Jetstar to cut capacity, may sell planes, as pilot dispute drags on
summary: Jetstar to cut domestic capacity by 10% in January due to ongoing pilot dispute, which may cost up to A$25 million. The airline is considering selling three Boeing 787-8 jets to offset the financial impact. Industrial action by pilots has already disrupted operations, with a 4-hour work stoppage on Dec 14 and 15. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots has ruled out further action beyond Friday, but negotiations remain stalled. The airline aims to reduce costs and maintain long-term sustainability.

site_title: US: China trade deal lifts Wall Street to 3rd day of records
summary: US stocks closed at record levels for the third consecutive day, driven by the new US-China trade deal and upbeat economic data from China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 added 0.7%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.9%. The deal eliminates some negative trade scenarios, but analysts caution that the market's rally may not be justified. Meanwhile, Boeing shares sank 4.3% due to reports on the 737 MAX production timeline.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street rally sparked by the new US-China trade deal lifted US stocks to their third straight record closes on Monday.

site_title: China gets twin boost from trade deal, better November data
summary: China's economy showed a strong rebound in November, with industrial output and private consumption exceeding expectations, rising 6.2% and 8% respectively. This boost adds to optimism from the recently announced trade deal, which could lift GDP growth by 0.5 percentage points in 2020. However, downside risks remain, including debt sustainability and rising defaults, and uncertainties from the trade war will continue to impact corporate capital spending. The government aims to maintain stability and keep growth within a "reasonable range" in 2020.

site_title: Familiar risks reappear in 2020, but amplified; agility is key for businesses
summary: US presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg's election is expected to bring relief to international businesses, but the underlying issues of instability and uncertainty are likely to persist. Recent years have seen a resurgence of political risk, technological advancements driving transparency and opacity, and growing frustration among the public over perceived injustices. As the US election approaches, businesses will need to adapt to a more complicated and tactical geopolitical landscape, with increased risk of cyber conflict and trade disputes. Agility will be key to navigating these challenges.

site_title: Seeing opportunities in uncertainty
summary: Key thought leaders will gather at Possibilities 2020 to discuss business opportunities in 2020 amidst economic and geo-political uncertainties. Experts, including Parag Khanna and Garick Kea, will share insights on navigating the current landscape and leveraging opportunities in the Asean market. They emphasize the importance of resilience, agility, and clear vision for SMEs to thrive in a volatile environment. The event will also highlight the potential of the RCEP agreement and the need for businesses to prioritize digital productivity and cross-border activities.

site_title: Qantas to put more experienced crew on board world's longest flights: sources
summary: Qantas plans to increase the number of experienced pilots on board its world's longest non-stop flights, including the Sydney-London route, for the first 18 months to evaluate fatigue. The airline has conducted crew fatigue studies on test flights and proposes to use a one captain, two first officers, and one second officer crew on these flights. Qantas has also offered to crew non-stop flights to London and New York with a similar crew configuration. The airline's pilot union has expressed concerns over the proposal, but negotiations are expected to resume in the new year.

site_title: Colliers extends deadline for The Arcade's S$780m collective sale
summary: Colliers International has extended the deadline for the en bloc sale of The Arcade in Singapore's central business district by two months to March 5, 2020. The site's reserve price of S$780 million will now translate to a land rate of S$2,840 per square foot per plot ratio. The 20-storey development comprises 127 office and retail units, with owners potentially receiving between S$700,000 and S$29.9 million from a successful sale. The site's long 999-year land tenure and central location have drawn strong interest from developers.

site_title: The Obama hack: How to lead like a president in crisis situations and stay cool
summary: Former US President Barack Obama shared his secret to maintaining his "cool" in stressful situations during a discussion in Singapore. He attributed it to his team and process, emphasizing the importance of assembling a talented and integrity-driven team and setting up a process to analyze problems from various angles. Obama emphasized his ability to manage stress by trusting his process and having confidence in his team's decisions. He also touched on the challenges of leading during the 2008 financial crisis, shedding 8 million jobs, and the need for leaders to make informed decisions despite uncertainty.

site_title: Boeing says to halt 737 MAX production next month
summary: Boeing will temporarily suspend 737 MAX production starting next month due to the ongoing grounding of the aircraft following two crashes. The company has no plans to lay off or furlough workers, instead prioritizing the delivery of stored aircraft. This decision follows Boeing's previous statement that it would continually evaluate production plans if the grounding continued longer than expected.

images.alt_text: Boeing said Monday it would temporarily suspend production of its globally grounded 737 MAX jets next month as the company struggles to get the beleaguered aircraft back in the air after two crashes.

site_title: Australia cuts forecasts for wages, growth and budget surplus
summary: Australia's mid-year budget update showed the government's finances are under pressure, with forecasts for wages, growth, and budget surplus cut. The Treasury lowered its forecast surplus to A$5 billion (S$4.66 billion) from A$7.1 billion, and predicted narrower surpluses for the next three fiscal years. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg cut forecasts for gross domestic product and wages growth, but dismissed concerns and vowed to pay down Labor's debt with sustainable surpluses. The Reserve Bank of Australia has cut interest rates to spur hiring and investment, and economists warn the downgraded wage growth estimate may still be overly optimistic.

site_title: A radiant revival of Der Rosenkavalier
summary: Simon Rattle led a triumphant performance of Richard Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier at the Metropolitan Opera, with a winning cast. The 2017 production, directed by Robert Carsen, successfully balanced the opera's sublime and beloved scenes with its heavy-handed comedy, with Rattle expertly navigating the challenge. The performance showcased the conductor's ability to make the most of the opera's clunky episodes, resulting in a memorable and engaging production. Rattle's insightful account of the opera was praised for its nuance and sensitivity, elevating the opera to new heights.

site_title: New normal in US-China ties? Compete and co-operate
summary: US and Chinese trade negotiators have agreed to delay new tariffs on $160 billion in Chinese goods, marking a possible truce in the 21-month economic warfare between the two countries. The deal involves China spending $50 billion on US farm products, strengthening intellectual property protection, and opening its financial markets to foreign competition. The agreement, described as a "phase one" deal, leaves most difficult issues for "phase two" talks next year. This development suggests China and the US can manage and cooperate, despite being competitors and rivals, and could benefit both nations.

site_title: S Korea tightens housing rules to curb price surge
summary: South Korea has announced new property regulations to curb the surge in home prices. The proposed rules include banning mortgage lending on properties valued over 1.5 billion won and lowering loan-to-value ratios for those valued between 900 million won and 1.5 billion won. The government also plans to raise home ownership tax and closely monitor the market's effect. The measures aim to prevent property market disturbance and ensure stable supply and demand, following criticism of the government's inaction to curb the price spike.

site_title: IFF reaches US$26.2b deal for DuPont's nutrition unit
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances (IFF) reached a $26.2 billion deal to acquire DuPont's nutrition division, outbidding Kerry Group. The new company will have an enterprise value of $45.4 billion, with DuPont shareholders holding 55.4% and IFF shareholders 44.6%. The deal is IFF's largest ever and comes as businesses tap into wellness products amid growing consumer health consciousness. DuPont will receive a one-time cash payment of $7.3 billion, and IFF CEO Andreas Fibig will lead the new company.

site_title: Updates on UE, Citic Envirotech buyouts
summary: United Engineers (UE) and Citic Envirotech are inching closer to privatization. Chinese developer Yanlord Land Group has updated its offer to acquire UE, which would value the company at S$1.72 billion. The offer has been extended to Dec 30, and shareholders can withdraw their acceptances within eight days. A separate buyout bid for Citic Envirotech, valued at S$0.55 a share, has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by an independent financial adviser. Both companies are expected to hold extraordinary general meetings to vote on the planned delistings on Dec 31.

site_title: China's November home prices growth slowest in nearly 2 years
summary: China's home prices grew at their weakest pace in nearly two years in November, with average new home prices rising 0.3% from the previous month, lower than the 0.5% growth reported in October. The property market, a key driver of China's economy, continues to cool due to tightening policies aimed at preventing speculation. Despite some local easing efforts, funding pressure persists, with over 450 property developers going bankrupt this year. Analysts expect a slow recovery in new construction next year, with property prices forecast to grow 3.1% next year, the lowest over a calendar year since 2015.

site_title: IPOs in Asia-Pacific resilient this year, but could slow down in 2020
summary: Asia-Pacific's initial public offerings (IPOs) remained resilient in 2019, with 668 deals and proceeds of nearly US$90 billion, despite global listing activity declines. The region accounted for seven of the top 10 exchanges by deal numbers and five by proceeds. Mainland China and Hong Kong drove the market, with Greater China seeing a 28% surge in proceeds. However, EY expects a modest decline in IPO activity in 2020, driven by investors' increased scrutiny of valuations and new policies in Hong Kong.

site_title: World's top instant-coffee shipper targets S-E Asian market
summary: Brazil, the world's largest shipper of instant coffee, is boosting exports to South-east Asia, targeting local rivals such as Vietnam. A bumper crop of robusta beans and the devaluation of Brazil's currency have given its exports a cost advantage, with exports to the region increasing by 4.4% in the first 11 months of 2019. Brazil is projected to ship 4 million bags of instant coffee this year, surpassing the previous record of 3.9 million bags in 2016, as it takes over the top spot for robusta beans from Vietnam.

site_title: Amazon gets final approval for new HQ despite organised labour protest
summary: Amazon has received final approval to build its second headquarters, HQ2, in Arlington County, Virginia, after a 5-0 vote by the county board. The approval came after Amazon pledged $20 million for affordable housing and vowed to crack down on labor fraud on the construction site. The decision came after a four-hour hearing where union carpenters expressed concerns over payroll fraud by contractors and subcontractors. This final approval allows Amazon to begin building the twin 22-storey headquarters buildings.

site_title: Xi vows support for HK leader during 'most difficult' time
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed unwavering support for Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam during a meeting in Beijing, calling the current situation "the most difficult" in Hong Kong's history. The meeting comes amid ongoing anti-government protests, which have entered their seventh month, and concerns over press freedom and economic impact. Xi reiterated support for Lam's leadership and promised continued backing for the Hong Kong police to uphold the law, while also expressing hope for unity in Hong Kong.

site_title: Boeing mulls temporary halt to Max production
summary: Boeing is considering temporarily halting production of the 737 Max, its best-selling jet, amid regulatory clearance for the grounded aircraft's return looking increasingly likely to slip beyond January 2020. The halt would save cash and be less disruptive than a slowdown, according to analysts. The company is studying contingency plans for various scenarios, including a pause in production to conserve cash and avoid widespread layoffs. A decision could come as soon as Monday, as Boeing's board reviews manufacturing plans for the 737 program.

site_title: If you can't beat them in 5G, buy them
summary: The US is facing a strategic threat from China's lead in 5G technology, with no indigenous manufacturer and a "coherent national strategy" lacking. In response, the Trump administration has taken steps to meet the 5G challenge, including a national spectrum strategy and a $20 billion fund for rural broadband. However, the administration's mixed messages on Huawei and other Chinese companies have undermined efforts to convince other countries not to use their equipment. A potential solution is for the US to purchase Huawei's 5G patents, licenses, and technical blueprints for a one-time fee, allowing the US to modify the source code and gain control over the technology. This could be a key step in protecting US interests and dominating the 5G market.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's stock market rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, companies such as Grab and OCBC announced leadership changes. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, and Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for the global equity index by mid-2026. These developments signal a shift in market trends and economic outlooks, with a focus on green and transition finance, as well as growth and policy changes in key markets.

site_title: Jumanji 2 makes US$60m debut
summary: Jumanji: The Next Level debuted in first place at US$60.1 million in the US, surpassing industry projections and outperforming fellow December releases Richard Jewell and Black Christmas. The film's opening marks a healthy jump from its predecessor and is the highest debut for a December comedy and live-action movie for stars Kevin Hart and Jack Black.

site_title: UK business malaise deepened before Dec 12 polls
summary: The UK economy experienced its worst downturn since mid-2016 before the December 12 polls, according to a survey. The IHS Markit/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers' Indexes (PMI) showed a decline in both services and manufacturing sectors, with the composite PMI falling to 48.5, its lowest level since July 2016. This suggests the economy is on course to contract in the fourth quarter. The decline was unexpected and may impact Prime Minister Boris Johnson's new government, which will address the economic concerns.

site_title: BMW-Daimler ride-hailing venture steps up its challenge to Uber
summary: BMW and Daimler's ride-hailing venture, FreeNow, aims to double revenue this year and next, challenging Uber's dominance in Europe and Latin America. FreeNow forecasts 2.4 billion euros in gross merchandise volume for 2019, with half of its 130 cities already profitable. The company pursues a collaborative approach with regulators to avoid legal battles, requiring drivers to undergo in-person background checks. Despite varying transport regulations, FreeNow expects ride-hailing to remain its main growth driver and is exploring options to expand its services.

site_title: Climate change: Why a new outlook is needed
summary: The UN climate summit in Madrid ended with a compromise deal, but progress was hindered by key countries including Australia, the US, Canada, Russia, India, China, and Brazil. Global carbon emissions have risen by 4% since 2015, and reductions of over 7% per year are needed in the 2020s to limit global warming to 1.5°C. The UK will host the next summit in Scotland, aiming to strengthen commitments on emissions. A new approach is needed to tackle global warming, with a focus on decentralized policies and empowering sub-national organizations.

site_title: Tory victory will boost UK housing prices by 2%: report
summary: The UK is expected to see a 2% increase in house prices next year, according to a report by Rightmove. This growth will be driven by a more certain Brexit process and low interest rates, which will boost affordability. Regional variations will occur, with the north seeing the largest gains. London prices will rise by 1%, the first increase since 2016. A lack of supply is expected to underpin prices, and demand is expected to pick up in the spring.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust issues 10b yen maiden green bond
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) issued a 10 billion yen (S$123.7 million) eight-year unsecured green bond, its first green bond under a new sustainability financing framework. The proceeds will be used to refinance green buildings in its portfolio. The bond has a fixed coupon of 0.729% per annum and will mature on November 16, 2027. This issuance is part of CCT's S$2 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme and is unconditional and irrevocably guaranteed by the trustee.

site_title: STI dips, market awaits phase one details
summary: Asian equities experienced a tame start to the week after the US and China agreed on a phase one trade deal, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,206.09, a decline of 7.96 points or 0.25% due to profit-taking. Despite the agreement, market watchers are awaiting further details on tariffs, intellectual property, and agricultural produce purchases. Investors are also rotating out of real estate investment trusts (Reits) as interest rates remain low, with some analysts recommending selective picks in e-commerce and data centre-focused Reits.

site_title: Curating data to drive business decisions
summary: Companies can counter the problems created by misused, fake, or ambiguous data by adopting a three-pronged approach: moderation, management, and transparency. This is crucial for businesses to make informed decisions, avoid reputation damage, and comply with data protection regulations like GDPR. A data curator and data protection officer (DPO) can help oversee data management, ensure transparency, and promote responsibility. Effective moderation is also necessary to prevent inaccurate data from influencing decisions, particularly with the increasing use of AI and big data analytics. By implementing these measures, businesses can improve data quality, reduce errors, and gain a competitive edge.

site_title: Diversify amid economic uncertainty: HSBC
summary: HSBC Global Asset Management advises investors to diversify across geographies and asset classes amid economic uncertainty, particularly in Asian equities and Asian high yield bonds. Asian equities, driven by earnings recovery and compelling valuations, are expected to outperform. Emerging markets such as China, India, and Indonesia are expected to benefit from structural trends. HSBC also notes that Asian high yield bonds offer attractive yields and a strong local investor base. Despite concerns over a potential economic recession, HSBC expects slow, steady growth in 2020.

site_title: Car sector weakness saps industrial jobs in Germany
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector experienced a decline in industrial employment for the first time in nine years, with a 0.2% month-on-month fall in December. The car industry was particularly affected, with a 1.1% contraction and thousands of job cuts announced by major carmakers such as Volkswagen and Daimler. The decline is attributed to the ongoing effects of the "dieselgate" scandal and the global impact of the American trade conflict with China. Germany's share of global car production has shrunk to below 6%, making it more dependent on good trading relations with China.

site_title: BMW-Daimler ride-hailing venture steps up Uber challenge
summary: BMW's ride-hailing venture FreeNow expects to double revenue to 2.4 billion euros in 2019, with half of its 130 cities in Europe and Latin America already profitable. The company aims to improve profitability while increasing revenue, amid pressure from Uber and Lyft to show profitability. FreeNow plans to scale up quickly once regulations are met, exploring options to complement its main business with private-hire services and car sharing. The company has received over 1 billion euros in funding from BMW and Daimler, and is open to exploring options for potential partners.

site_title: Modest economic recovery expected for Singapore in 2020
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a modest recovery in 2020, driven by a broadening growth recovery, albeit sluggish, with a forecasted 1.8% gross domestic product (GDP) growth. Trade tensions between the US and China remain the main risk, with failure to reach a partial trade deal potentially derailing hopes of an export recovery. Other sectors, such as tourism and manufacturing, are also expected to show improvement, with services growth strengthening on financial, business, and tourism-related activities. However, headwinds from US-China trade, Federal Reserve, and Brexit uncertainties, as well as labour market softening, are also anticipated.

site_title: World's biggest hedge fund returns found in Singapore
summary: Singapore is home to two of the world's top-performing hedge funds, with the Vanda Global Fund gaining over 300% this year, followed by the Quantedge Capital Pte, which has a 63.1% return. The country's hedge funds, which manage $47.3 billion in assets, outperform their global peers, with an average return of 9.4% in 2019. Experts attribute the success to the region's wealthy investors willing to take risks, smart data-driven graduates, and a well-developed ecosystem for futures trading. The phenomenon challenges conventional wisdom about the high fees and mediocre returns of hedge funds.

site_title: Chinese President Xi vows support for Hong Kong leader: media
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed support for Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam, calling her "courageous" in governing the city in exceptional times. Xi also backed the police in upholding the law, following months of protests in the Asian financial hub. Meanwhile, a separate article mentions China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Goldman Sachs takes its climate policy up a notch as global talks falter
summary: Goldman Sachs has updated its environmental policy framework, pledging to decline financing for new thermal coal mines and upstream Arctic oil exploration and development. The company aims to invest $750 billion in climate transition and inclusive growth finance over the next decade. This move is seen as a significant step by environmental groups, who have welcomed Goldman's stricter stance on fossil fuel financing. The decision comes as global climate talks in Madrid faltered, failing to agree on key issues such as carbon pricing and finance.

site_title: 2020s: Decade when HR gets more strategic
summary: The 2020s are predicted to be the decade where HR emerges as a strategic function, driven by the rapidly changing business environment and the need for companies to adapt to new ways of working. With the rise of remote work and non-traditional labour trends, HR must develop broader skill sets, including people analytics and technology infrastructure, to support the modern workplace. Companies must also build strategies to keep workforces agile, leveraging gig workers and agile working frameworks to maintain healthy margins through volatility. Ultimately, HR's ability to blend "soft" and "hard" parts of the business will be key to building a sustainable competitive advantage.

site_title: Winding-up application against Chinese Global Investors withdrawn
summary: A winding-up application against Chinese Global Investors Group has been withdrawn after the company paid S$42,300 to its former CFO, Kemmy Koh. The application, filed by Koh's lawyers over unpaid salary, was ordered withdrawn by the High Court on December 13. The company's board of directors announced the payment in an update on December 16. The payment relates to Koh's salary for the April to July period, including Central Provident Fund contributions and interest.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.29% due to profit-taking following a previous rally fueled by a US-China trade deal and Britain's election. The Topix index also declined 0.18%.

site_title: As Tokyo 2020 beckons, Schooling gets down to serious business
summary: Singapore's Olympic champion Joseph Schooling is in the US to train with former coach Sergio Lopez after struggling with his weight, which is 8-10kg above his racing weight. Schooling won the 2016 Olympics 100m butterfly gold medal and recently won his favorite event at the Southeast Asian Games. His doctor commented that he is heavy with fat, not muscles, which may have affected his performance. Schooling aims to regain his competitive form and achieve his full potential.

images.alt_text: The silver lining is that Schooling's SEA Games time of 51.84 is an improvement of the World Championships time.

site_title: Yanlord no longer plans to maintain UE's listing in buyout offer
summary: Chinese developer Yanlord Land Group will no longer attempt to maintain United Engineers' (UE) listing in its buyout offer, reversing its initial proposal. With a stake of over 81% of ordinary shares and 99.16% of preference shares, Yanlord plans to exercise its rights of compulsory acquisition under the Companies Act if the stock's free float falls below 10%. The offeror's decision affects the close of the offer, now extended to Dec 30, and allows shareholders to withdraw their acceptances within eight days.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday at 1,569.35, down 1.81 points. The index saw 2.3 billion lots traded worth RM1.8 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 453 to 376. This marks a decline from previous sessions.

site_title: Food supply chain transparency will support Singapore's '30 by 30' food security goal
summary: Singapore, ranked as the world's top food-secure nation, aims to produce 30% of its nutritional needs by 2030. To achieve this goal, increasing local production and fortifying food supply chains with transparency and trust are key areas of focus. The government is exploring the use of blockchain technology to track food supply chains, improve crop yield and nutritional quality, and reduce food waste. This move is expected to bolster Singapore's ambition to be an agri-food hub, while also addressing concerns about food waste and climate change.

images.alt_text: IOT sensors can use blockchain technology to track vegetables, fruits and food on their journey from field to grocery stores.

site_title: Australia: Shares post best gain in 7 months on rate cut hopes, trade optimism
summary: Australian shares surged 1.6% to their best gain in nearly seven months on Monday, driven by a downgrade in the country's growth outlook and hopes for a domestic rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 110 points to 6,849.7, boosted by a preliminary trade deal between the US and China, which eased tensions on a 17-month tariff war. Resource stocks, including BHP Group and Woodside Petroleum, also gained, as investors became more optimistic about the economy.

site_title: Peugeot maker PSA has French backing for Fiat deal
summary: PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot, has secured French government backing for its planned merger with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles. The deal, which could be approved this week, aims to create a global powerhouse to challenge Volkswagen. The new company would be based in the Netherlands and have sales of over eight million vehicles annually, with brands including Peugeot, Citroen, Jeep, Alfa Romeo, and Ram. The move is in response to growing industry pressure to pool resources for product development, manufacturing, and purchasing amidst trade tensions and the shift towards electric and self-driving technology.

site_title: Soccer's FIFA goes after Blatter, Platini in bid to recover 2 million Swiss francs
summary: FIFA has filed a claim in a Swiss court to recover 2 million Swiss francs (S$3.6 million) paid inappropriately by former FIFA President Joseph Blatter to former French football star Michel Platini. The payment was made in 2011 for work Platini did a decade earlier, and both Blatter and Platini were banned from soccer in 2015 for their roles in the corruption scandal. FIFA claims the payment was an "undue gift" with no contractual basis, and is seeking restitution.

site_title: Thai bourse aims to surpass Singapore's capitalisation by 2023
summary: The Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) aims to surpass Singapore's market capitalization by 2023, currently at $689 billion. SET President Pakorn Peetathawatchai believes the Bangkok bourse can achieve this target without replacing Singapore as the region's prime securities hub.
