summary: Asian markets surged on news of a partial US-China trade deal and optimism over the UK's Brexit outcome. Stocks rose across the region, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai gaining 2.6%, 2%, and 1.8% respectively. The UK's Boris Johnson won an election victory, giving him a mandate to pull the country out of the EU. However, experts caution that the trade deal and Brexit details still need to be finalized, and potential uncertainties may emerge.

site_title: Google, Apple asked if apps like TikTok must disclose foreign ties
summary: US Rep Stephen Lynch asked Google and Apple if mobile apps must disclose foreign ties, citing concerns over Chinese investment in apps like TikTok and Grindr. TikTok is owned by Chinese company ByteDance, while Grindr is set to be sold to a Chinese gaming company due to US national security concerns. Lynch's inquiry follows reports of sensitive data being collected by foreign companies and shared with their host governments, posing national security risks. Neither Google nor Apple responded to requests for comment.

images.alt_text: The chair of a US congressional panel wrote to Alphabet's Google and to Apple on Friday to ask what, if any, disclosures mobile apps are required to make regarding overseas ties, a concern that follows reports of Chinese investment in popular apps such as TikTok and Grindr.

site_title: Singapore Nov marine fuel sales hit 8-month high; low-sulphur soars to record
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales reached an 8-month high in November, with 2.076 million tonnes of low-sulphur fuel sold, more than double the previous record. This represents over half of the total 4.076 million tonnes sold, a 4% increase from last year. The IMO 2020 regulations, set to limit sulphur content in fuels, have caused logistical issues, including limited barge availability and a narrowing VLSFO-MGO price spread, affecting prompt fuel deliveries.

site_title: Pork crisis makes pig farmer world's fastest-rising billionaire
summary: China's pork crisis, caused by African swine fever, has led to a surge in pork prices, resulting in a significant increase in the net worth of some pig farmers. Qin Yinglin, chairman of Muyuan Foodstuff Co, has seen his net worth quadruple to $8.6 billion, making him the fastest-growing billionaire. Other companies, including WH Group and New Hope Group, have also benefited from the crisis, with their profits surging and their net worth increasing. The crisis has led to the deaths of millions of pigs and has pushed inflation to a multi-year high.

site_title: Trump says report on trade deal with China 'completely wrong'
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that a Wall Street Journal report on a US trade deal with China is "completely wrong", specifically about tariffs. The tweet led to a decline in US stocks.

site_title: Europe: Decisive UK election, trade deal lift shares close to record high
summary: Europe's benchmark share index rose 1.1% on Friday, nears record high, after a breakthrough in US-China trade talks and hopes of an orderly Brexit. The UK-focused FTSE mid-cap index jumped 3.4% after the Conservative Party's landslide election victory, raising expectations for a Brexit deal within weeks. Despite some caution, stocks are on track to end the year more than 20% higher, their biggest annual gain in a decade.

site_title: US: Wall St steady as US, China announce trade deal
summary: The US stock market remained steady on Friday as the US and China announced an initial trade agreement, reducing some US tariffs on Chinese goods. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials closed at record highs, with the tech sector leading gains. Investors expressed relief over the averted risk of trade escalation, and optimism about policy follow-through on Brexit and the trade deal. The S&P 500 rose 0.7% for the week, its ninth gain in the past 10 weeks, and the benchmark index has gained 26% so far in 2019.

site_title: Global trade optimism dims safe-haven appeal
summary: Gold prices experience strong negative pressures due to heightened market optimism and a weaker US dollar. Despite US economic data showing signs of stability, Federal Reserve policymakers kept interest rates steady, reducing gold's safe-haven appeal. Global risk assets are expected to surge, and gold's non-interest yielding nature makes it vulnerable to fading downside risks in the first quarter of 2020, with key technical levels at US$1,487.00 and US$1,445.00.

site_title: Grab launches electric vehicle roadmap in Indonesia, inks major partnerships
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based firm, has launched an electric vehicle (EV) roadmap in Indonesia, partnering with Hyundai, Astra Honda Motor, and Gesits to launch pilots of two- and four-wheel EVs in the Greater Jakarta region. The partnership aims to drive EV adoption, with 20 Hyundai Ioniq Electric cars set to be used in a pilot project starting in early 2020. The move follows a $2 billion investment by SoftBank into Grab to build an EV ecosystem in Indonesia, with a goal of reaching 2 million EVs by 2025.

site_title: Special menus for the festive season
summary: Winestone, a restaurant at Mercure Singapore on Stevens, is offering festive menus for Christmas, including a four-course set dinner and a curated five-course dinner menu on Christmas Eve. The menus feature dishes like Mango Gazpacho, Asian-Inspired Braised Short Ribs, and Roasted Turkey Roll, paired with selected wines from Italy and France. A 20% discount is available for fully paid reservations before Dec 20, 2019, with a bottle of wine on the house for the first 10 diners. The promotion is valid until Dec 30, 2019.

site_title: Reits (December 14-15, 2019)
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, with prices expected to test the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset in Seoul. WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy property in Singapore, and New World is selling its China property assets after a loan deal. These trends indicate a resilient real estate market.

site_title: SIA Engineering inks 10-year contract with France's Safran Aircraft Engines
summary: SIA Engineering Company has signed a 10-year contract with Safran Aircraft Engines to provide engine maintenance services for the CFM LEAP engine, used in the Airbus A320neo family and the Boeing 737 MAX. The agreement includes quick-turn and modification embodiment services for both LEAP-1A and LEAP-1B engines. The dedicated facility is expected to start operations in 2020 and will support the maintenance, repair, and overhaul of the LEAP engine. The deal is not expected to significantly impact SIA Engineering's financial performance.

site_title: A clarion call for greater corporate sports sponsorship
summary: Goldbell Financial Services, a subsidiary of the Goldbell Group, has sponsored local athletes in sailing, floorball, and jiu-jitsu, including seven athletes who earned medals at the Southeast Asian Games in Manila. CEO Alex Chua attributes the company's support to the athletes' passion and grit, as well as its ethos of supporting smaller teams and SMEs. The sponsorship covers training expenses, flights, accommodation, and uniforms, with the goal of helping athletes grow both on and off the mat. Chua encourages more companies to support athletes by providing work-life balance and financial assistance.

site_title: Chinese fintech platform raises US$312m in US IPO
summary: OneConnect Financial Technology, a fintech platform, raised approximately US$312 million in its US initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at around US$3.7 billion. This is significantly lower than its US$7.5 billion valuation from last year. OneConnect, which provides technology solutions to financial institutions, had revenues of 1.55 billion yuan in the first nine months of 2019, but reported a widening loss of 1 billion yuan. The IPO comes after the company changed its listing venue to New York to achieve a higher valuation.

images.alt_text: Ping An Insurance's OneConnect Financial Technology said on Thursday it raised around US$312 million in its US initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at around US$3.7 billion.

site_title: US retail sales rise less than expected in Nov
summary: US retail sales rose 0.2% in November, less than expected, as Americans cut back on discretionary spending. This could lead economists to lower GDP growth estimates for the fourth quarter, currently around 1.8%. The core retail sales, excluding automobiles, gasoline, and food services, edged up 0.1% in November, following a 0.3% increase in October. This data contrasts with recent upbeat economic reports, including strong labor market and manufacturing data, and may prompt the Federal Reserve to adjust its interest rate expectations.

site_title: Germany's Delivery Hero acquires South Korea's Woowa for US$4b
summary: Germany's Delivery Hero has acquired South Korea's top food delivery app operator Woowa Brothers for $4 billion, forming a joint venture based in Singapore. The deal is the largest global play for a food delivery app and aims to take on competitors like Uber Eats in Asia. Woowa, the market leader in South Korea, cited a survival strategy in the intensely competitive market. The acquisition expands Delivery Hero's presence in the fast-growing Asia market, but analysts suggest Woowa needs to adapt to local consumer preferences.

site_title: Is tact curbing our impact?
summary: The UBS Optimus Foundation, a 20-year-old philanthropic organization, is challenging traditional notions of philanthropy by openly discussing return on investment and risk assessment. The foundation has pioneered social finance and impact measurement, launching development impact bonds and achieving significant social impact. With a growing network of ultra-high net worth philanthropists, the foundation aims to increase philanthropic capital and tackle global challenges. It expects donations to reach $100 million by next year, driven by a shift towards strategic and involved philanthropy, and plans to continue innovating and evolving funding mechanisms.

site_title: UK vote lifts clouds of uncertainty for firms
summary: The UK's general election has lifted uncertainty for firms, with some Singapore players with a presence in the UK stating their longer-term strategy remains unchanged. The Conservative Party's majority is seen as a mandate for Prime Minister Boris Johnson's "get Brexit done" vow, bringing some certainty to firms. However, the lack of a clear path to Brexit's departure continues to pose business risks, with industry watchers calling for a way forward that would lessen Brexit's impact on UK businesses and trading partners.

site_title: Pound soars and stocks surge after Tory victory
summary: The UK Conservative Party won a majority of 76 seats in the general election, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's victory sending sterling and UK stocks surging. Sterling reached a daily high of US$1.35, up 5% on the previous day, while the FTSE 250 index rose 10.6% to 21,758. The victory could lead to the break-up of the UK union, with potential consequences for Northern Ireland and Scotland, where nationalist parties are seeking referendums on independence.

images.alt_text: Shares that rose between 5% and 15% included Marks & Spencer, Barclays Bank and home builders Persimmon and Barratts. The UK results and hopes of a US-China trade deal also lifted German, French and other European markets.

site_title: When retailers hit record sales of 40 times the daily average - in just one day
summary: In South-east Asia, online shopping festivals like 11.11 have achieved record sales, with a notable example being an Indonesian haircare brand Ellips, which saw sales 40 times its daily average in just one day. These festivals empower local SMEs by providing a platform for digitalization and scaling, driving new shopping experiences through interactive content and entertainment. However, the region still faces challenges in logistics and payment infrastructure, which must be addressed to realize the immense potential of e-commerce. The future of these festivals and e-commerce in the region is promising, with potential for growth to reach 20% penetration and 50 million parcels delivered daily within 10 years.

images.alt_text: E-commerce has taken consumers and retailers to the next level, with 11.11 becoming the world's biggest online sales festival.

site_title: Christmas comes early for Tories in historic win
summary: The UK's Conservative Party, led by Boris Johnson, won a historic fourth consecutive term in office, increasing their seats in the House of Commons. Johnson's campaign focused on "getting Brexit done," despite the reality that this may lead to years of negotiations with the EU. The election result comes amid a dynamic context, with traditional partisan voting patterns eroding and nearly half the country voting for different parties across three elections. Johnson's government plans to push through his Brexit deal quickly, potentially leading to a no-deal Brexit if negotiations fail.

site_title: Beijing has built thousands of cheap apartments no one wants
summary: Beijing's affordable housing program, introduced in 2016 to control prices, has resulted in thousands of cheap apartments that remain largely unsold. The program, which included strict price caps and small unit sizes, has led to an oversupply of apartments, with only 46% sold as of mid-December. Many buyers are deterred by the quality of the units and their remote locations, with some offering discounts to attract buyers. The program's failure highlights China's challenges in addressing its affordable housing crisis, with developers facing significant losses and the government struggling to find effective solutions.

site_title: Medtech firm AWAK Tech raises US$40m in round co-led by Vickers Venture
summary: AWAK Technologies, a Singapore-based medtech firm, has raised US$40 million in an oversubscribed financing round co-led by Vickers Venture Partners and an unnamed global medical products company. The funds will be used to prepare the AWAK peritoneal dialysis device for late-stage clinical studies and commercialization. The device, which weighs a couple of kilograms and doesn't require medical supervision, aims to significantly reduce the infrastructure and cost associated with current dialysis treatments for end-stage kidney disease patients.

site_title: Discovering the Dark Knight
summary: Comic artist Greg Capullo discussed his experience working on DC Comics' Dark Knight series, including his collaborations with writer Scott Snyder on Dark Knights: Metal and The Last Knight on Earth. Capullo revealed that working with Todd McFarlane on Spawn was intimidating but ultimately enjoyable, and that he found his own niche working on Batman with Snyder. He also expressed enthusiasm for reimagining Batman's rogues gallery and returning to work on Spawn after a hiatus. Capullo offered advice to aspiring artists, emphasizing the importance of going with their own flow and not trying to follow in the footsteps of others.

site_title: New York seeks to address homeless crisis with bill to build 1,000 new flats a year
summary: New York City is set to address its homeless crisis with a bill requiring developers of affordable-housing projects to reserve 15% of units for the homeless. The measure, which applies to buildings with over 40 units, could add 1,000 new apartments per year, nearly doubling the 1,300 under development. The bill, passed by the City Council, aims to increase affordable housing and provide a safe roof for homeless New Yorkers, with the goal of designating at least 15,000 units for homeless people.

site_title: Grab launches EV roadmap in Indonesia, inks major partnerships
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based tech firm, has launched an electric vehicle (EV) roadmap in Indonesia, partnering with Hyundai, Astra Honda Motor, and Gesits to launch four- and two-wheel EV pilots in the Greater Jakarta region. The pilots will use 20 Hyundai Ioniq Electric cars, with Grab users able to choose EV rides in early 2020. The move is backed by a $2 billion investment by SoftBank to build the EV ecosystem in Indonesia, aiming to reach 2 million electric vehicles by 2025.

site_title: Pound jumps against Singdollar; further strength likely but not at same pace
summary: The British pound surged 2% against the Singapore dollar following the UK's Conservative victory in the general election. The pound jumped to 1.82 SGD, mirroring its 2% gain against the US dollar. The pound's strength is expected to continue, but at a slower pace.

site_title: Oracle misses revenue estimates; no plans to hire new co-CEO
summary: Oracle Corp reported a 7% decline in revenue from its traditional licensing business and a 3% increase in cloud services revenue, falling short of quarterly estimates. Despite this, the company's cloud services revenue rose to $6.81 billion, surpassing its top competitors Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Corp. Chairman Larry Ellison stated that there are no plans to hire a new co-CEO, following the passing of former co-CEO Mark Hurd in October. Oracle expects third-quarter adjusted profit to be between 95 and 97 US cents per share.

site_title: StarHub, NUS to pilot 5G virtual-reality and AI solutions
summary: StarHub and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have teamed up to pilot virtual reality (VR) and artificial intelligence (AI) solutions in a net-zero energy building. The 5G lab, set to be operational early next year, will use 5G technologies to design and test advanced VR and AI solutions, focusing on use cases such as immersive classes and drone-based facade inspection systems. The partnership aims to enhance learning, advance research, and address industry needs and challenges, leveraging 5G's ultra-reliable and low-latency communications.

site_title: Greek housing sector's growth picks up in third quarter
summary: Greece's housing market saw a 9.1% year-over-year increase in apartment prices in the third quarter, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of growth. The capital city of Athens outperformed with prices rising 11.9% year-over-year. The growth is attributed to a growing economy and foreign interest, particularly from Chinese, Turkish, and Russian buyers. The home ownership rate in Greece is 80%, significantly higher than the EU average. This marks a significant recovery from the 42% decline in home prices between 2008 and 2017.

site_title: Gallant Venture proposes S$10.3m private placement to Moya managing director
summary: Gallant Venture, a Singapore-based company, proposes a S$10.3 million private placement to Moya Holdings Asia's managing director, Irwan Atmadja Dinata. The deal involves issuing 87.3 million new shares at S$0.118 apiece, a 1.69% premium to the previous day's volume-weighted average price. The funds will be used to repay a syndicated term loan outstanding in 2020. The shares will be listed on the Singapore Exchange after receiving in-principle approval.

site_title: Trade deal hopes nudge Singapore shares up 0.6% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% on the week, closing at 3,214.05, driven by positive news on the US-China trade deal and the Conservative Party's victory in the UK general election. Asian markets also saw gains, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 2.6% and the MSCI Asia ex-Japan Index adding 1.2%. Despite some volatility, investors remain optimistic, with cyclical stocks performing well, including Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Venture Corp. However, concerns about China's silence on the trade deal remain, with analysts warning that the euphoria may resume once Beijing gives its nod to the deal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.82 points to 1,571.16. The index saw 2.9 billion lots traded worth RM2.5 billion, with 493 gainers and 390 losers.

site_title: HK property share sales boom amid China curbs
summary: Hong Kong's property share sales have surged amid China's funding curbs, with real estate offers raising $3.1 billion this year, a 40% increase from 2018. Chinese developers are turning to Hong Kong for funds, making the property sector the top contributor to follow-on sales. Strong investor demand has driven up shares of large developers, such as Midea Real Estate Holding Ltd and China Vanke Co. The boom is expected to continue, with many developers expected to post robust sales growth this year. This trend is a result of China's efforts to rein in home prices and reduce debt.

site_title: Diversification - the psychological shield to better investment decisions
summary: Investors can reduce costly mistakes by diversifying their portfolios, according to a recent article. Historically, stock market outperformance has rotated between regions every six to ten years, with US markets outperforming Asian markets for seven and a half years. However, diversification allows investors to stick to a disciplined approach without emotional toll. A study found that an equally weighted US and Asia portfolio returned 49% or 8.3% per annum, with lower volatility. Diversification also helps investors manage individual stocks, reducing the impact of "recency bias" and allowing for rational decisions to be made during periods of underperformance.

site_title: Delivery Hero's US$4b order corners kimchi market
summary: Delivery Hero has acquired South Korea's largest food delivery app, Woowa, in a $4 billion deal. The acquisition gives Delivery Hero control of the country's online food delivery market, valued at 83 billion euros (S$125 billion). Despite concerns over competition regulators, the deal has boosted Delivery Hero's share price by nearly 20%. The acquisition also includes a Vietnam unit and a joint venture in Singapore, expanding the company's presence in the region. The deal justifies the valuation, with Woowa's revenue jumping 84% in the first nine months of 2019 and operating margin at 18.4% last year.

images.alt_text: Delivery Hero has snapped up a tasty dish. The German group's US$4 billion deal to buy the South Korea's biggest food delivery app means it has cornered a wealthy and expanding market. Hearty growth and profitability justify the valuation, while a new Singaporean outpost adds extra spice.

site_title: More SGX FX futures traded in November amid surge in offshore yuan contracts
summary: SGX FX futures trading reached $110 billion in November, a 12.5% month-on-month increase and 9% year-on-year growth. Despite subdued global markets, USD/CNH futures surged, with $79.6 billion traded in November, a 38% year-on-year increase. The yuan gained 0.3% against the US dollar, while the Indian rupee weakened 1.3% despite strong foreign portfolio investments. The pound surged to a 19-month high following the UK's parliamentary majority win, sending the market into a more stable period.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust secures US$75 million in loans to partially finance US$84.5 million acquisition of three Marriott-branded hotels. Meanwhile, SingPost sells substantially all assets of its two US e-commerce subsidiaries, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, to ID Logistics and Visible Supply Chain Management, respectively. Raffles Infrastructure partners with a South Korean asset management company to submit proposals for a US$800 million township development project in Bangladesh. Sim Leisure Group appoints Seah Kheng Hong as CFO, and CapitaLand's substantial shareholders, Blackrock and PNC, cease to hold 5.06% stake due to decreased collateral.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on upbeat trade news, fading Brexit worries
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday, driven by news of a potential US-China trade deal and the UK's Conservative Party's election win. This eased trade tensions and boosted investor confidence. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,739.7. The gains were also influenced by the expected UK's exit from the European Union under Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

site_title: GIC to buy European logistics portfolio for 950m euros
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has signed an agreement to acquire a pan-European logistics real estate portfolio, Maximus, for approximately 950 million euros (S$1.44 billion). The portfolio spans over 1 million sq m of industrial space in core logistics hubs across Germany, Poland, and other European countries. GIC's wholly-owned P3 logistics platform will manage the portfolio, which includes a diversified tenant base in the automotive, e-mobility, and e-commerce sectors. The acquisition is one of the largest real estate investment deals in Europe this year and supports GIC's strategy to scale up its logistics platform.

site_title: Women and wealth: Three findings and their risks
summary: Research on women's financial habits reveals three key findings: women prefer to communicate about money and investing through stories rather than charts, they tend to invest in causes and concerns that matter to them, and they are not risk-averse but rather risk-aware. These findings demand changes from the investment industry to better serve female clients, including using female-friendly communication styles and offering socially responsible investment options. However, if not implemented, these changes pose risks for both financial advisers and female clients, including career risks for advisers and holding too much cash for female clients.

site_title: The base of BMW's mighty 3
summary: The BMW 320i is the base model of the 3 Series range, offering a balance of performance and affordability. It features a 1.998cc turbocharged engine, producing 184hp, and an 8-speed automatic gearbox. The car has a spacious cabin, digital infotainment system, and Apple CarPlay, but lacks Android Auto. It has a smooth ride, agile handling, and a lively engine, making it a desirable option for those who want a luxurious driving experience without breaking the bank. With a starting price of S$208,888, the 320i is an attractive choice for those seeking a BMW without the hefty price tag of its pricier variants.

site_title: StarHub, NUS to pilot 5G virtual-reality and AI solutions
summary: StarHub and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have teamed up to pilot virtual reality (VR) and artificial intelligence (AI) solutions using 5G technologies in a net-zero energy building. The research activities will focus on developing use cases to enhance learning, advance research, and address industry needs. Two key projects are being developed: one for immersive classes using 5G augmented reality and VR, and another for a real-time, drone-based facade inspection system. The 5G laboratory is set to be operational early next year.

site_title: EU agrees to start British trade talks after Brexit deal approved
summary: The European Union's 27 national leaders agreed to start trade talks with Britain after the Brexit deal's ratification and effective implementation. The EU will focus on a "level playing field" to guarantee fair competition, and aims for zero tariffs, quotas, and dumping. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said time is extremely short, with 11 months to negotiate a broad field of agreements, including in education, transport, fisheries, and other areas. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson skipped the summit due to an election victory.

site_title: Raffles Infra partners Korean fund to bid for Bangladesh project
summary: RAFFLES Infrastructure Holdings is partnering KORAMCO Fund, a South Korea-based asset management company, to bid for a US$800 million township development project in Bangladesh. The partnership aims to provide financial funding expertise and real estate development expertise for the project, which will develop accommodation for the middle- to low-income group. The project involves working alongside other companies such as Surbana Jurong and CNQC Engineering & Construction.

site_title: Singapore's marine fuel sales hit 8-month high in Nov, low sulphur soars to record
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales reached an 8-month high in November, with 2.076 million tonnes of low-sulphur fuel sold, more than double the previous record. This represents over half of the total 4.076 million tonnes sold, a 4% increase from last year. The surge in low-sulphur fuel sales is driven by the shipping industry's transition to cleaner fuels ahead of the global sulphur cap, set by the International Maritime Organization.

site_title: China coy on 'BIG' trade deal announced by Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a potential trade deal with China, but Beijing remained coy, cautioning that any agreement must be "mutually beneficial." Trump tweeted that a "BIG DEAL" was imminent, but China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying declined to confirm. The proposed deal, reportedly worth $50 billion, includes China spending on US farm goods, tightening intellectual property protections, and opening financial services markets. However, tensions remain high, with China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi accusing the US of "suppressing" China across various fields.

site_title: Indonesia president defends bid by family to enter politics
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has defended his son and son-in-law's decision to run for mayoral posts in regional elections, dismissing accusations of creating a political dynasty. Widodo, who started his second term in 2014, had been seen as a clean break from the military elite, but his family's involvement in politics raises concerns. Critics argue that this move will tarnish Widodo's reputation, while supporters see it as a natural extension of his family's involvement in politics.

site_title: Miner BHP Group's chief transformation officer to depart
summary: BHP Group's chief transformation officer, Jonathan Price, will leave the company next year as the miner shifts responsibility for its strategy away from executive leadership. This comes after the departure of chief technology officer Diane Jurgens. The company has seen improved safety, reliability, and returns through its transformation strategy, but now individual asset and function leaders will oversee the strategy. Price will oversee the transition and then return to the UK with his family. The move is part of incoming CEO Mike Henry's efforts to prepare for Andrew Mackenzie's departure at the end of the year.

site_title: Clashes erupt in Delhi over citizenship law; PM Abe cancels visit
summary: Violent clashes erupted in Delhi, India, between police and thousands of university students over the contentious new citizenship law, which critics say undermines India's secular foundations. The law offers citizenship to six minority groups from neighboring countries, but not Muslims. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe canceled a planned visit to India due to the unrest. Two people were killed in Assam state in protests against the law, which the UN human rights office called "fundamentally discriminatory in nature." Protests have been ongoing in Assam for decades, with critics arguing it will strain resources and marginalize indigenous communities.

site_title: Private equity bidders line up for Thomas Cook airline Condor
summary: At least three private equity firms, including Apollo, have emerged as potential buyers of Condor, Germany's profitable airline. Condor has drawn interest after receiving a 380 million euro bridging loan to avoid insolvency following the collapse of its parent company Thomas Cook. Binding offers for Condor will be submitted before Christmas, with Apollo exploring partnerships with German travel operators to improve its chances of acquiring the airline.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on trade deal details, up 0.6% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% on the week, closing at 3,214.05, driven by the US finalizing terms for a "Phase One" trade deal and the Conservative Party's victory in the UK general elections. Markets in Asia-Pacific also surged, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 2.6% and the MSCI Asia ex-Japan Index adding 1.2%. However, concerns over China's silence on the trade deal cap gains, and investors rotated out of real estate investment trusts, weighed on the market.

site_title: Trump: Wall Street Journal story on China trade deal 'completely wrong'
summary: President Donald Trump disputed a Wall Street Journal story on a US-China trade deal, calling it "completely wrong," particularly regarding tariffs. According to sources, a deal in principle had been reached, with the US suspending tariffs on $160 billion in Chinese goods and Beijing agreeing to buy more US agricultural products. Trump has signed off on the deal, and a White House announcement may come shortly, but details are still being worked out, with one former trade negotiator noting that the devil is in the written agreement.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher as Sino-US trade tensions ease
summary: South Korean shares reached a 7-month high on Friday as the US and China edged closer to resolving their trade tensions. The US agreed to suspend tariffs on $160 billion worth of Chinese consumer goods and roll back existing tariffs in exchange for China's pledge to increase US farm product purchases in 2020. The KOSPI index rose 1.54% to 2,170.25, with foreigners buying $436.69 million worth of shares. This marks the sharpest weekly gain since February 2016, with the KOSPI gaining 4.2% for the week.

site_title: Deutsche Bank considering cutting bonus pool by as much as 20%
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering cutting its bonus pool by up to 20% amid a radical restructuring under CEO Christian Sewing. The move aims to reduce costs by billions of euros, following a 5% decline in the bank's workforce this year. Revenue at the investment bank was down 11% in the first nine months of the year, but Sewing sees "momentum" in the division. The bank spent 1.9 billion euros on bonuses last year, with this year's pool expected to reflect the shrinking workforce. A final decision has not been made yet.

site_title: SoftBank-backed OneConnect set to raise US$312m in US IPO: source
summary: OneConnect Financial Technology, backed by SoftBank, is set to raise approximately US$312 million in its US initial public offering (IPO) priced at US$10 per share. The company plans to sell 31.2 million American depositary shares (ADS). The IPO is scheduled for Thursday.

site_title: Magnus Energy widens Q1 net loss to S$270,000
summary: Magnus Energy reported a widened net loss of S$270,000 in its Q1, down from S$100,000 a year ago. Revenue decreased 21% to S$4 million due to the winding down of its oil and gas equipment segment in South-east Asia since 2017. Operating income fell 81% to S$159,000, mainly due to the absence of gain on disposal of business. The company's lower revenue and operating income resulted from the closure of its business segment.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up over 2.5% on UK election, trade talks
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei stock index rose 2.55% to 24,023.10, its highest level since early October, due to hopes for a US-China trade deal and Britain's ruling Conservative Party's big election win paving the way for Brexit. The market reacted positively to US President Donald Trump's reported plan to call off steep tariffs and slash duties on Chinese goods. Sterling also held steady against the US dollar, with exporters such as Panasonic, Toyota, and TDK gaining ground.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei stock index jumped more than 2.5 per cent on Friday, boosted by hopes for a US-China trade deal, and a big election win for Britain's ruling Conservative Party that paves the way for Brexit.

site_title: Winning big, UK's Johnson on course to deliver swift Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory, securing an outright majority in Parliament with 368 seats, allowing him to deliver Brexit swiftly. Johnson, who campaigned on the slogan "Get Brexit Done," vowed to respect the democratic will of the British people and ratify the Brexit deal with the EU, potentially leaving the UK on January 31. The outcome marks the ultimate failure of opponents who plotted to thwart Brexit through legislative combat and prompted massive protests.

site_title: Beijing's legal influence triggers disquiet in Hong Kong financial sector
summary: Beijing's criticism of Hong Kong's court decision on a face mask ban has raised concerns among global firms operating in the financial sector. The criticism, from China's top legislature, questioned the power of Hong Kong's High Court, fueling worries about mainland interference in commercial contracts. This has led some global firms to consider alternative dispute resolution centers, such as Singapore, and has sparked internal discussions about "plan B" for critical contracts. The concerns are fueled by Beijing's increasing influence over the local judicial system and Hong Kong's autonomy under the Basic Law.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC acquired a European logistics portfolio for 950m euros, while ARA H-Trust secured US$75m in loans to fund the purchase of US hotels. Medtech firm AWAK Tech raised US$40m in a financing round co-led by Vickers Venture. SIA Engineering signed a 10-year contract with France's Safran Aircraft Engines. Meanwhile, Singapore Post's US units sold substantially all their assets. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% for the week, driven by a mooted trade deal.

images.alt_text: GIC has signed an agreement to acquire a pan-European logistics real estate portfolio, Maximus, for around 950 million euros (S$1.44 billion) from funds managed by affiliates of alternative investment manager Apollo Global Management.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon up 0.57% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.57% on Friday, driven by gains from local banks and Asian markets, following reports of a China-US trade agreement and UK election results. The STI advanced 18.12 points to 3,212.79, with 684 million securities worth S$647.9 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 185 to 143, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC also in the green. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: US: Wall St dips as Trump dashes hopes of imminent trade deal
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Friday as President Trump disputed a report on a potential trade deal with China, tempering hopes for an agreement before new tariffs were set to take effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.06%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.04% after Trump tweeted that a report by The Wall Street Journal was "completely wrong." The news dampened hopes for a trade deal, leading to a decline in stock prices.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 8.41 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 28,123.64.

site_title: AI puts final notes on Beethoven's Tenth Symphony
summary: A team of musicologists and programmers has been working on completing Ludwig van Beethoven's Tenth Symphony using artificial intelligence, ahead of the 250th anniversary of his birth in 2027. Beethoven left only a few notes of the piece before his death in 1827. The progress has been impressive, but the computer still needs to learn more, according to Christine Siegert, head of archives at Beethoven House in Bonn.

site_title: Citi gives extra day off in Hong Kong, says on track to beat targets
summary: Citigroup plans to give its Hong Kong staff an extra day off in 2020, despite pro-democracy protests in the city. The bank's CEO, Angel Ng, praised staff for working through "extreme difficulty" and said the Hong Kong business is on track to beat revenue targets. Third quarter revenue rose 8%, driven by a 10% increase in average deposits. The move follows a similar announcement by competitor HSBC, which is also giving its local employees an extra day off. The bank's decision highlights its resilience in the face of turmoil in the city.

site_title: Corbyn says will not lead Labour into future UK election
summary: Jeremy Corbyn announced he won't lead the Labour party in the next UK general election, despite predictions of a crushing defeat. Corbyn won his north London seat for the 10th time, but the party is expected to lose 52 seats, securing 191 in the 650-seat parliament. Corbyn defended his "manifesto of hope" but acknowledged Brexit polarized the debate, contributing to the poor results. He will lead the party during a "process of reflection" into what went wrong, rather than immediately stepping down.

site_title: Pound soars as Johnson heads for landslide British election win
summary: The British pound surged more than 2% on Thursday as Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party looked set for a landslide election victory, making an orderly exit from the European Union likely. Sterling reached a 19-month high versus the dollar and its strongest levels against the euro since 2016. Investors believe the Conservative win will enable Johnson to deliver Brexit with his withdrawal agreement on January 31, ending immediate fears of a UK-EU crash-out.

site_title: Two Chinese cities relax rules to shore up property markets
summary: Two Chinese cities, Nanjing and Zhengzhou, have relaxed rules to boost property markets. Nanjing now allows diploma holders from vocational institutes to buy homes, while Zhengzhou introduces a residency permit for long-term renters after one year of renting. The moves aim to prop up moribund markets, but critics worry they may undermine the central government's efforts to control property speculation. Chinese leaders reiterated that "homes are for living, not for speculation." The relaxation of rules comes as China's house prices are expected to grow 3.1% next year, the lowest over a calendar year since 2015.

site_title: We have a powerful mandate for Brexit: Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that his government appears to have won a powerful new mandate to get Brexit done, unifying the country and taking it forward. He increased his vote share by 1.8 percentage points, winning 25,351 votes in his Uxbridge seat. The Conservative Party made gains in the Midlands and North, putting it on course for its best result since 1987, as the UK's exit from the EU is expected to proceed.

site_title: Mexico ratifies modified North American trade deal
summary: Mexico's Senate ratified the modified North American free trade agreement with the US and Canada, making it the first country to sign on after over two years of negotiations. The agreement, known as USMCA, was introduced with tougher labor enforcement provisions and is expected to replace the 25-year-old Nafta. The path to ratification for the US and Canada also appears clear, following a series of additions that won the support of key Democrats and labor unions. The agreement is expected to stimulate Mexico's economy and instill confidence in investors.

site_title: Asia: Markets celebrate early Christmas on trade, Brexit optimism
summary: Asian markets celebrated an early Christmas on Friday, with stocks surging on reports of a US-China trade deal and Brexit optimism. The deal, signed by Donald Trump, will cancel fresh US tariffs and roll back previous measures. The news boosted the pound and led to a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. Investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. The positive sentiment also lifted the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) by 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Delivery Hero to buy South Korea's Woowa Brothers for US$4b
summary: Delivery Hero has agreed to acquire South Korea's Woowa Brothers for US$4 billion. The acquisition aims to tap into the booming food delivery market in Asia. A joint venture in Singapore will also be established to further expand their presence. This deal marks a significant move by Delivery Hero to strengthen its position in the global food delivery market.

site_title: Indian tech startup xto10x expands to Singapore, hires ex-Carousell exec
summary: Indian tech startup xto10x has expanded to Singapore, opening an office and hiring ex-Carousell executive Chai Jia Jih as its new CEO for South-east Asia. Chai will lead a team that includes Maneesh Mishra and Pranjal Kanwar, and co-founder Binny Bansal will also be based in Singapore to support the team. xto10x helps startups scale up through software, knowledge, and capabilities in various areas. The firm's global CEO Saikiran Krishnamurthy sees opportunities for growth in South-east Asia, where many startups are reaching the scale-phase.

site_title: Malaysia raises export tax for crude palm oil for first time in over a year
summary: Malaysia has raised its export tax for crude palm oil for the first time in over a year, to 5% for January, citing a national customs department. The move comes after the country lowered the tax to zero in August 2018. Traders expect Indonesia to follow suit, which could impact global palm oil prices and influence the implementation of Indonesia's 30% biodiesel target. Malaysian palm oil futures rose 1% to RM2,913 per tonne following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge on trade deal reports
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.85% on Friday morning after reports of a partial US-China trade deal, which led to the cancellation of fresh tariffs. The Hang Seng index rose to 27,494.51, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also gained 0.76% and 0.74%, respectively. The news boosted investor confidence, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.49 points or 0.48% to 1,574.83 on Friday, with a trading volume of 66.51 million lots worth RM30.84 million. Gainers outpaced losers 183 to 39.

site_title: China to buy US$50b in US farm products in return for tariff concessions: US sources
summary: The US and China have reached a tentative agreement to suspend some tariffs on Chinese goods and reduce others in exchange for Beijing's pledge to hike purchases of US farm products to $50 billion in 2020, a significant increase from 2017. The agreement is seen as a step towards de-escalating the trade war, which has slowed global growth and dampened profits for companies worldwide. The terms of the agreement were not officially confirmed by the White House, but US sources described a "Phase 1" deal that includes intellectual property and financial services protections.

site_title: SingPost's bankrupt US units sell assets
summary: SingPost's US e-commerce subsidiaries, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, have sold substantially all of their assets after filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. ID Logistics acquired Jagged Peak's assets for $15 million, while Visible Supply Chain Management (VSCM) acquired TradeGlobal's assets for an undisclosed amount. The sales do not impact SingPost's financials, as the subsidiaries were deconsolidated prior to the bankruptcy. This follows an earlier unsuccessful attempt to sell the businesses, and VSCM will continue to operate TradeGlobal, protecting over 350 jobs.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on Sino-US 'phase one' trade deal; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a four-month high on Friday, driven by a "phase one" trade deal between the US and China in principle. The deal includes China agreeing to reduce tariffs and make $50 billion in agricultural purchases. Metals and mining stocks jumped, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto up 2p and 1.6% respectively. However, gold miners tumbled 2.4% as risk sentiment improved. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5% amid a slower pace of manufacturing activity.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Friday, with metals and mining stocks jumping to a four-month high, after sources said the United States and China reached a "phase one" trade deal in principle.

site_title: More SGX FX futures traded in Nov amid surge in offshore yuan contracts
summary: SGX FX futures trading reached US$110 billion in November, a 12.5% month-over-month increase and 9% year-over-year growth. Despite subdued global markets, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a surge in USD/CNH futures, with volumes exceeding US$828 billion year-to-date. The yuan gained 0.3% against the US dollar in November, driven by reports of a phased rollback in US-China tariffs. In contrast, India's rupee market saw low volatility and weak trading momentum, with volumes totaling US$29 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares advance after Wall St rally; STI up 0.52% at Friday's open
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.52% at Friday's open, tracking US Wall Street gains after US President Donald Trump boosted hopes of an imminent trade deal with China. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,211.17, with gains outnumbering losses 95 to 28. Banking stocks, including DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank, advanced, while Golden Agri-Resources slipped 2.3%. The US market had surged to close at record highs after Trump's tweet about the trade deal.

site_title: Obama Effect
summary: Former US President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle are set to speak in Singapore on December 14 and 16, respectively, at the Singapore Expo Hall. The couple, known for their leadership experiences and bestselling memoirs, have been staying busy since leaving the White House. They recently produced the documentary "American Factory," which won rave reviews and is expected to perform well in upcoming awards season. This marks the Obamas' first public events in Singapore, showcasing their enduring popularity as a presidential couple.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks soar on trade deal reports
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 2% on Friday after reports of a partial trade deal between China and the US, which led to Washington canceling tariffs. The Hang Seng index rose 2.57%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also increased. The news lifted investor sentiment, boosting Asian markets and leaving the US stock market near record highs despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng index soared 2.57 per cent, or 693.62 points, to 27,687.76.

site_title: Medtech firm AWAK Tech raises US$40m in round co-led by Vickers Venture
summary: AWAK Technologies, a Singapore-based medical technology firm, has raised US$40 million in an oversubscribed financing round co-led by Vickers Venture Partners and an unnamed global medical products company. The funds will be used to prepare its AWAK peritoneal dialysis device for late-stage clinical studies and commercialization. The device has shown promising results in its first-in-human study and has been granted breakthrough device designation by the US FDA. This latest funding brings the company's total funding to over US$60 million since its inception, aiming to revolutionize dialysis therapy and improve patient convenience and comfort.

site_title: Global trade war and rising protectionism taking toll on Asia Pacific, SEA remains bright spot
summary: The global trade war and rising protectionism are taking a toll on Asia Pacific's economic growth, with regional growth expected to slow from 3.8% in 2018 to 3.3% this year. Emerging economies in the region are expected to grow 5.2% this year, while advanced economies are expected to grow 2% in 2019 and 2020. Despite this, Southeast Asia remains a bright spot, with 42% of regional policy experts expecting growth in the region over the next year. The top five risks to regional growth include increased protectionism, trade wars, and a slowdown in the US and Chinese economies.

site_title: SIA Engineering inks 10-year contract with France's Safran Aircraft Engines
summary: SIA Engineering has signed a 10-year contract with France's Safran Aircraft Engines to provide engine maintenance services for the LEAP engine. The agreement will support the maintenance, repair, and overhaul ramp-up of the engine and includes services for CFM LEAP-1A and LEAP-1B engines. The dedicated facility will start operations in 2020, with SIA Engineering contributing to the ramp-up of the LEAP engine, which powers the Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX aircraft.

site_title: Pound jumps as exit poll shows Conservative majority in UK elections
summary: The British pound surged 2% against the dollar and 1.6% against the euro after exit polls showed the Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, likely to win a parliamentary majority, seen as hastening Brexit.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' business mood gloomiest in nearly 7 years
summary: Japan's big manufacturers reported their lowest business mood in nearly 7 years in the fourth quarter, citing the US-China trade war and soft global demand. The Bank of Japan's survey also showed a worsening business sentiment among non-manufacturers due to the increase in domestic sales tax. This gloomy outlook may lead to increased pressure on the BOJ to maintain or boost its stimulus program to prevent a recession.

site_title: Facebook says ready for new California privacy law
summary: Facebook has confirmed it is ready for California's new data privacy law, the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), set to take effect in January 2020. The law gives users the right to see what data is collected about them and with whom it is shared. Facebook has made investments to help users manage their privacy and has added self-serve tools to download or delete data. The company supports the passage of the CCPA, which aligns with its global commitment to transparency and control, and has been likened to the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA Engg, ARA H-Trust, Chip Eng Seng, Gallant, Stamford Tyres
summary: SIA Engineering signed a 10-year agreement to provide engine maintenance services to Safran Aircraft Engines. ARA H-Trust took out US$75 million in unsecured loans to fund its US$84.5 million acquisition of three US hotels. Chip Eng Seng's subsidiary acquired Raffles Campus (Malaysia) for S$24.4 million. Gallant Venture proposed to issue S$10.3 million worth of new shares. Stamford Tyres reported a loss of S$867,000 for the second quarter.

site_title: US tests ballistic missile over Pacific
summary: The US tested a medium-range ballistic missile over the Pacific, the second test in four months of an offensive missile banned by the US-Russia arms treaty. The Air Force launched the missile from Vandenberg Air Force Base, which flew over 500km before plunging into the Pacific Ocean. The test informs the development of future intermediate-range capabilities and may be a signal to North Korea, which has demonstrated its own cross-Pacific nuclear threat. The US ambassador to the UN warned Pyongyang of consequences if it follows through with a major weapons test in the new year.

site_title: Airbus beats Boeing to become preferred supplier for Qantas Sydney-London flights
summary: Qantas has chosen Airbus as its preferred supplier for up to 12 A350-1000 jets for its Sydney-London flights, beating Boeing after a hard-fought contest. The flights are expected to begin in the first half of 2023, pending a pay deal with pilots and a final order decision in March. Airbus's A350-1000 is seen as a safer choice due to Boeing's recent issues, and the deal could be worth up to $4.4 billion. This selection cements Airbus's lead in ultra-long-haul flying and could impact Boeing's plans for the 777-8.

site_title: ARA H-Trust obtains US$75m in loans to fund purchase of US hotels
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust has obtained US$75 million in loans to fund the US$84.5 million acquisition of three Marriott-branded hotels in the US. The loans consist of a US$66 million term loan and a US$9 million revolving credit facility. The acquisition is ARA H-Trust's first US hotel purchase. The stapled securities of ARA H-Trust closed at 87 US cents, up 0.6% or 0.5 cents, following the loan announcement.

site_title: Razer mulls digibank retail licence but notes tight Dec 31 deadline
summary: Razer is considering applying for a Singapore digital banking licence, but is unsure if it can meet the December 31 deadline. The company's chief strategy officer, Lee Li Meng, believes its strong reach among millennials and youth will be an advantage, but notes the four-month application process is "tight". Razer has been approached to form a consortium with other companies, but the complexity of such joint efforts may hinder its chances.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens up nearly 2% after UK exit poll
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose nearly 2% on Friday, boosted by hopes for a US-China trade deal and a predicted UK Conservative Party election win, setting the stage for Brexit. The broader Topix index also increased 1.48%. These gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Boeing acknowledges 737 MAX won't fly until 2020
summary: Boeing has acknowledged that its 737 MAX aircraft won't return to service until 2020, contrary to previous expectations. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) expressed concerns that Boeing is rushing to get the jets back in the air, citing delays and a lack of thorough review. The FAA wants Boeing to work with them to support their requirements and timeline, with a focus on safety. Major carriers have also expressed skepticism about Boeing's optimistic timeline, and American Airlines has pushed back its return-to-service date to April 7.

site_title: Star Wars fans camp outside LA theatre week before film opens
summary: Star Wars fans have begun camping outside Hollywood's Chinese Theatre, with 20 enthusiasts already on site seven days before the premiere of "The Rise of Skywalker." The group expects to swell to 150, with fans traveling from the UK and Japan to secure a spot. The tight-knit community has been camping for the Star Wars premiere since 1999's "The Phantom Menace," with fans spending their days playing board games and watching old movies, and their nights sleeping in sleeping bags. The group plans to attend the glitzy red-carpet premiere on Monday.

site_title: A US 'deal in principle' with China on trade may be more limited than October pledge
summary: The US and China have reached a "deal in principle" on trade, with the US suspending tariffs on $160 billion in Chinese goods and Beijing agreeing to buy more US agricultural products. However, the deal may be narrower than the promised "Phase 1" agreement, with details still being worked out. The agreement is seen as a step towards easing tensions, but the US and China have yet to agree on specific terms, including the purchase of agricultural products. The deal may be announced by the White House soon, with a looming deadline of December 15 for tariffs on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: The White House reached a "deal in principle" with Beijing on trade, sources briefed on the talks said on Thursday, but it may be narrower than the "Phase 1" deal US President Donald Trump promised in October.

site_title: A Taste of Christmas
summary: Local F&B personalities share their holiday gift ideas for fellow food lovers. A Thermapen infrared meat thermometer is a top recommendation, praised for its speed and accuracy. Other gifts include gourmet ingredients, artisanal chinaware, and cookbooks. Unique seasonal produce, specialty sauces, and locally-sourced goods are also on the list. Some chefs prefer gadgets like BBQ smokers and remote thermometer probes, while others opt for nostalgic enamelware or mockmills. Gift ideas also include chocolates, chocolates-making kits, and exclusive food items like Marmite Peanut Butter and artisanal olive oils.

site_title: Snarky Trump tells Greta Thunberg to 'chill' and see movies
summary: US President Donald Trump dismissed climate activist Greta Thunberg's Time Person of the Year award, telling her to "chill" and go to the movies. Thunberg responded with a witty remark on Twitter, referencing Trump's own behavior. The exchange highlights the polarizing nature of Thunberg's climate activism and Trump's skepticism about the issue. Trump has a history of dismissing climate change, and Thunberg's rise to fame has made her a target for criticism from world leaders.

site_title: Beijing has built thousands of cheap apartments no one wants
summary: Beijing's government introduced a price cap program in 2016 to provide affordable housing for middle-class citizens, resulting in thousands of cheap apartments that remain largely empty. The program, which includes restrictions on unit sizes and price limits, has led to an oversupply of apartments, with some selling at 10% lower prices due to a "crazy price war." Many buyers are dissatisfied with the quality of the units, and developers are facing significant losses. The program's failure to meet its goal of providing affordable housing has raised concerns about the government's ability to address the city's housing affordability crisis.

site_title: EU welcomes clear UK Conservative victory as clarity over Brexit
summary: European diplomats welcomed the UK Conservative Party's apparent decisive election victory, which brings clarity to Britain's withdrawal from the EU. The Conservatives are expected to have an 86-seat majority in the 650-seat parliament. This development is seen as a step towards agreeing a trade deal by the end of 2020, but challenges remain.

images.alt_text: European diplomats on Thursday welcomed the clarity an apparently decisive election victory for the Conservative Party gave to Britain's stalled withdrawal from the EU, but said it would be challenging to agree a trade deal by the end of 2020.

site_title: GIC to buy European logistics portfolio for 950m euros
summary: GIC has agreed to acquire a pan-European logistics real estate portfolio, Maximus, for approximately 950 million euros (S$1.44 billion). The portfolio, managed by P3 Logistic Parks, spans over 1 million sq m of industrial space in core logistics hubs across Germany, Poland, and other countries. The acquisition is part of GIC's strategy to scale up its P3 logistics platform. The deal is expected to close in Q1 2020, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Gallant Venture proposes S$10.3m private placement to Moya managing director
summary: Gallant Venture is proposing a S$10.3 million private placement to Moya Holdings Asia managing director Irwan Atmadja Dinata, with shares priced at S$0.118 apiece. The issue represents 1.61% of Gallant's enlarged share capital and will be used to repay part of a syndicated term loan due in 2020. The new shares will be listed on the Singapore Exchange, pending in-principle approval.

site_title: Heartrending Drama
summary: Netflix's "Marriage Story," starring Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, has garnered a dozen accolades at the early stage of the awards season. The film, written and directed by Noah Baumbach, follows a married couple's amicable breakup that turns ugly when they hire divorce lawyers. Baumbach's personal experience with a divorce from actress Jennifer Jason Leigh influenced the film. With its Oscar potential, "Marriage Story" is now streaming on Netflix.

site_title: Flexi-Mediterranean cooking appeals at Pistachio Grill
summary: Pistachio Grill, a Middle Eastern eatery in Singapore, has moved to Wheelock Place and is drawing a healthy crowd with its home-style cooking tailored for the local palate. The restaurant, run by Egyptian chef Khaled Elelimi, serves flexi-Mediterranean food with a mix of sweet and savory flavors, including pizza, pasta, and French-inspired dishes. The pita bread is a standout, with various toppings and spreads available. The restaurant's dishes are hearty and wholesome, making it a crowd-pleaser, but vegetarians may have an advantage in terms of lighter options. Overall, Pistachio Grill scores 6.5 out of 10 for its generous and authentic food.

site_title: China is world's top caviar producer - and Kaluga Queen reigns
summary: China has surpassed Iran and Russia as the world's top caviar producer, with Kaluga Queen, a Chinese company, accounting for over a third of global production. The company breeds sturgeons in Qiandaohu Lake in eastern Zhejiang province and produces 86 tonnes of caviar annually, mostly for export to the European Union, US, and Russia. Chinese caviar has overcome past food scandals and now commands high prices, with some varieties selling for up to 180,000 yuan per kilogram, rivaling the price of a Ferrari.

site_title: US calls on China not to interfere in Taiwan election
summary: The US has urged China not to interfere in Taiwan's upcoming election, where President Tsai Ing-wen is seeking a new term. US diplomat David Stilwell stated that China's actions can lead to increased tensions, and the US seeks dialogue and peaceful resolution. Tensions between the US and China have been rising, with China viewing Taiwan as part of its territory awaiting reunification. The US has provided arms to Taiwan while recognizing only Beijing, and the US expects China to respect Taiwan's internal affairs.

site_title: Some of the best wine moments of 2019
summary: The article highlights 12 exceptional wines from 2019, each with unique characteristics and stories behind their production. These wines, chosen for their lasting impressions, include La Violetta's Das Sakrileg Riesling, Luke Lambert's Yarra Valley Nebbiolo, Tiberio's Trebbiano d'Abruzzo, and others. The wines were selected for their exceptional quality, nuanced flavors, and the stories of their producers, showcasing the diversity and excellence of the wine world.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on optimism for a US-China trade deal
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 1% on Thursday on optimism for a US-China trade deal, with Brent crude futures settling at $64.20 a barrel and WTI crude futures at $59.18 a barrel. US President Trump tweeted that the US was close to a big deal with China, while a source briefed on talks said the US had reached a "phase-one" trade deal in principle. The deal's implications for oil demand are uncertain, with some analysts expecting a tighter market and others a potential oversupply.

site_title: US Fed leaves interest rate unchanged, optimistic about economic outlook
summary: The US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at its final meeting of the year, signaling an indefinite pause in rate changes. Officials projected no rate changes in 2020, with only one possible increase in 2021 and another in 2022. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell expressed optimism about the economic outlook, citing a strong job market and moderate growth. The decision reflects the Fed's comfort with the economy's record-long expansion, despite risks from weak factory data and trade uncertainty.

site_title: Traditional Thai massage get Unesco heritage status
summary: Traditional Thai massage, known as Nuad Thai, has been awarded UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage status. Originating in India and practiced in Thailand for centuries, the ancient technique involves body-folding, sharp-elbowed movements to target acupressure points and relieve muscle aches. The massage has been popularized through a specialty school that opened in the 1960s, training over 200,000 massage therapists in 145 countries. The recognition is expected to promote the practice locally and internationally, with an hour-long massage costing as little as $5 in Thailand.

site_title: US property firm surprises staff with US$10m in bonuses
summary: US property firm St John Properties surprised employees with holiday bonuses totaling $10 million, averaging $50,000 per recipient based on tenure. The bonuses were announced to celebrate the company's goal of developing 20 million square feet of commercial space, with one employee receiving over $200,000. The company's president said the bonuses aimed to recognize all employees' roles and not just titles, with the goal of achieving equality in the achievement. The move drew widespread attention and excitement among employees, with many expressing gratitude and life-changing financial benefits.

site_title: Europe: ECB, upbeat trade news push up shares before UK election outcome
summary: Euro zone banks saw their best day in two months after ECB chief Christine Lagarde's comments, with the Stoxx 600 index closing up 0.3% and euro zone banks rising 2.8%. US-China trade developments also boosted shares, with Washington offering to cancel tariffs on Chinese goods. European shares remained steady before the UK election outcome, with London's FTSE 100 index firming around 0.7%. The ECB kept interest rates steady, and Lagarde hinted at a strategic review of the bank's business.

site_title: JJ Abrams comes down to earth about Rise of Skywalker
summary: JJ Abrams, director of Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker, acknowledged his struggles with ending stories, admitting he's "never been great at endings." Abrams took on the daunting task of concluding the Skywalker saga after declining the initial offer for The Force Awakens trilogy. He worked under pressure, incorporating unused footage of late actress Carrie Fisher and facing significant creative challenges. The film's completion marked the end of Abrams's involvement in the Star Wars series, but Lucasfilm president Kathleen Kennedy plans to continue the franchise, exploring new projects and TV series, including a potential reboot of the Jedi storyline.

site_title: Eurozone slowdown shows signs of easing: Lagarde
summary: Eurozone slowdown shows signs of easing, with ECB President Christine Lagarde stating "some initial signs of stabilisation" and a "mild increase in underlying inflation." The eurozone's economic growth is expected to be 1.1% in 2020 and 1.4% in 2021, with inflation forecast to reach 1.6% in 2022. The ECB's policy meeting resulted in no changes to interest rates, and Lagarde announced a strategic review to assess whether the inflation goal needs to be adjusted, aiming to start it in January.

site_title: SIA, Apple CEOs discuss digital collaboration
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) CEO Goh Choon Phong met with Apple CEO Tim Cook during Cook's visit to Singapore, discussing digital collaboration and potential partnerships. SIA showcased its digital initiatives, including the Kristal iPhone app, which uses Apple devices to streamline operations. Approximately 65% of SIA's mobile app users use Apple devices, higher than Apple's global market share. The two companies have collaborated on app design, with SIA using nine enterprise apps for its daily operations.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies to records on reported China trade deal
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Thursday, driven by reports of a potential trade deal between the US and China. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose 1% and 0.7% respectively, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.8%. President Trump tweeted that the two sides were "VERY close to a BIG DEAL" with China, following months of uncertainty. Investors also reacted positively to analyst upgrades for companies like General Electric and Starbucks. The positive sentiment lifted stocks despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split views among Federal Reserve officials.

site_title: Uber promises new measures to combat sex assaults in France
summary: Uber has pledged new safety measures in France to combat sex assaults. Following a meeting with equalities minister Marlene Schiappa, Uber's French boss Steve Salom promised to immediately deactivate driver accounts if a sexual assault allegation is made and contact authorities to pass on available information. A facial recognition device will also be launched to verify the identity of drivers. These measures come after Schiappa summoned Salom over the issue.

site_title: World's oldest art found in Indonesian cave
summary: Researchers have discovered a 44,000-year-old cave painting in Indonesia that may be the world's oldest figurative artwork. The 4.5-meter wide painting, found on the island of Sulawesi, depicts a prehistoric hunting scene with half-human hunters chasing wild animals. The study, published in Nature, suggests that this ancient artwork points to an advanced artistic culture, challenging previous assumptions about human creativity and artistic development. The painting's age and significance have sparked excitement among archaeologists and art historians.

site_title: Britain Brexit bound as Johnson set for big parliamentary majority
summary: Britain's Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, is set to win an overwhelming majority in parliament, securing a comfortable majority of 86 seats. This outcome will deliver Brexit on January 31, as forecast. The exit poll showed the Conservatives winning 368 seats, the worst result for Labour since 1935. Johnson's party is expected to have the largest parliamentary majority since Margaret Thatcher's 1987 victory.

site_title: Pitch Control
summary: Richard Mille has released a new watch model, the RM 11-04 Automatic Flyback Chronograph Roberto Mancini, celebrating the Italian national football team's manager Roberto Mancini. The watch features blue accents, representing the team's colors, and includes dedicated counters for tracking half-time, extra-time, and overtime. The design is a tribute to Mancini's return to the team and his role in the upcoming Euro 2020 tournament.

site_title: It's a done deal for cash offer for POSH
summary: Quetzal Capital's cash offer for PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) has received over 90% valid acceptances, making it unconditional. The offer price of S$0.215 per share represents a 97.2% premium over the last traded price and a 35.3% premium over the 12-month volume-weighted average price. The closing date for the offer has been extended to January 2, 2020. Provenance Capital advises shareholders to accept the offer, citing it as "fair and reasonable."

site_title: In A Holiday Mood
summary: Key entertainment events and releases include a new pantomime adaptation of Peter Pan by W!ld Rice, a medieval-themed dinner-theatre production Valhalla & The Chambers of Asgard, and the final episode of the Star Wars saga, Star Wars: The Rise Of Skywalker. The stage version of Cats opens at Marina Bay Sands, and Universal Pictures' film adaptation of Cats is also set to release. Music-wise, Bing Crosby's re-mastered album Bing At Christmas and Pentatonix's album The Best Of Pentatonix Christmas are highlights of the season. Notable book releases include Robert Sabuda's pop-up Christmas books and Toni Morrison's collection of quotes, The Measure Of Our Lives: A Gathering Of Wisdom.

site_title: On The Prowl
summary: Andrew Lloyd Webber's CATS is set to return to Singapore, opening at Sands Theatre on December 17 and running until January 5. The stage production, based on T.S. Eliot's Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats, features the iconic pop hit 'Memory' and has been a global phenomenon, visiting 20 cities this year. The show requires extensive props, including 116 wigs and 226 costumes, and has a dedicated team of 45 pairs of jazz shoes per week. Tickets are available from S$50 through Sistic.

site_title: Twitter plans to build 'decentralised standard' for social networks
summary: Twitter plans to establish an independent research group, BlueSky, to create an open and decentralized system for social networks, allowing users to access the same network through various services. The system, which will not be owned by any single private company, aims to enable targeted access to like-minded individuals while promoting healthy conversations. Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey believes this approach will allow the company to focus on building open recommendation algorithms and innovate without centralized enforcement of global policy. The project will be funded by Twitter and will take many years to complete.

site_title: Best World 'on track' to complete independent review, audit committee says
summary: Best World International's audit committee says the independent review into its sales practices in China is on track to be completed as planned, with fieldwork expected to be finished in mid-December and a draft report due in early January 2020. The committee has made significant progress, despite some outstanding document requests, and Changsha Best has provided additional information. A summary of key findings is expected in early February, and trading in shares will resume once the review is completed.

site_title: Strong sales of China's construction equipment suggest construction boom
summary: China's construction equipment sales saw a 21.7% increase in November, with excavator sales rising almost twice as fast as in October. Heavy truck sales also rose 13.8% during the same period. These sales suggest that Beijing's efforts to boost the economy through infrastructure spending are taking effect, with the Finance Ministry earmarking 1 trillion yuan in special purpose bonds for infrastructure projects in 2020. This increase in infrastructure spending is expected to continue into 2020, with local governments planning to sell more of the debt to fund projects.

site_title: Magnus Energy agrees on EGM date with requisitioning shareholders
summary: Magnus Energy Group has agreed to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on January 9, 2020, after reaching a compromise with requisitioning shareholders who initially proposed a different date. The EGM will consider and approve resolutions, including the re-election of an independent director and the appointment of new directors. The company will also consider appointing Baker Tilly as auditors, despite the shareholders' initial proposal. If the shareholders proceed with their own EGM, Magnus will still hold its own separate meeting.

site_title: China's Xi to unveil plans to make Macau a financial hub, says report
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping plans to unveil policies to diversify Macau's economy, aiming to make the former Portuguese colony a financial hub. The plans include establishing a yuan-denominated stock exchange, accelerating a yuan settlement centre, and allocating land for Macau. The measures are intended to boost Macau's economy, which has been hit by slow growth in China and declining gaming revenue. The announcement comes as unrest continues to trouble neighboring Hong Kong, with China seeking a contingency plan in case the situation worsens.

site_title: A Knack for Design
summary: Veteran designer Kelley Cheng, founder of The Press Room, credits intuition as the key to good design, citing the "X" factor that sets standout designs apart. Cheng, who has 20 years of experience, believes that artistic and intuitive touch is essential for creating beautiful designs, and not something that can be taught. Her retrospective exhibition, "Proportion & Emotion," showcases her work, including 20 projects and 20 new collaborations with international designers, highlighting the blurred lines between art and design.

site_title: Revival of UK economy depends on local and foreign investment
