summary: Chinese investors more than doubled their Hong Kong stocks purchases this year, defying market headwinds from protests and the Sino-US trade war. Mainland investors bought HK$208 billion in Hong Kong stocks from January to November, a 150% increase from 2018. They hunt for bargains in the US$4.5 trillion stock market, with some firms seeing a 20% discount between Hong Kong and mainland shares. Analysts believe the trend will continue, with abundant room for mainland investors to increase their exposure to Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: Banks gave US$745b to groups planning new coal power plants: NGOs
summary: Financial institutions have provided US$745 billion to companies planning new coal-fired power plants over the past three years, according to environmental groups. The funding comes despite global pressure to reduce fossil fuel emissions and meet the 2015 Paris climate agreement. The top three lenders are Japanese banks Mizuho, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation. Environmental groups are urging banks to stop financing the sector and align their portfolios with Paris climate goals. The funding contradicts efforts to cap global warming at 1.5 Celsius and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.

site_title: Almost 6m Filipinos lifted out of poverty in 2018, Philippines says
summary: The Philippine Statistics Authority reported that nearly 6 million Filipinos were lifted out of poverty in 2018, with 16.6% of the population living below the poverty threshold of 10,727 pesos (S$287.06) a month for a family of five. This represents a decline from 23.3% poverty incidence in 2015. The government's efforts to boost spending on social welfare may be contributing to the reduction in poverty rates.

site_title: Asian shares gain as Trump fuels trade deal optimism, oil firm on Opec+ output cut
summary: Asian shares rose on Friday, driven by US President Donald Trump's upbeat comments on trade talks with China, which sparked buying despite a lack of agreement. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index gained 0.5%, while Japan's Nikkei added 0.3%. Oil prices remained near two and a half-month highs after OPEC+ producers agreed to cut output by 500,000 barrels per day. The US dollar index fell to a one-month low, while sterling reached a seven-month high ahead of the UK election.

site_title: Asia bond markets show signs of angst as fiscal talk swirls
summary: Asia's bond markets are experiencing anxiety due to growing fiscal stimulus plans in Japan and New Zealand, raising concerns among investors. The US$91 billion proposed economic stimulus in Japan and New Zealand's plans to fast-track infrastructure spending have led to a rise in bond yields in Tokyo and Wellington. This move is seen as a response to central banks' limited monetary policy options, with some strategists warning that investors may face disappointment in fiscal expectations. The trend is part of a growing trend of fiscal stimulus in Asia, with India and South Korea also increasing spending.

site_title: China drafts new rules to control rural plastic pollution
summary: China has drafted new rules to control rural plastic pollution, aiming to reduce soil contamination and boost crop yields. The regulations, open to public consultation, will establish a management system for the production, sale, and recycling of plastic film used by farmers. The rules require farmers to use only film meeting quality standards, collect plastic waste, and encourage reusing old film. China uses 2 million tonnes of plastic film annually, with a recycling rate of 180,000 tonnes, and aims to make 90% of its farmland safe for agriculture by the end of next year.

site_title: China central bank injects 300b yuan via one-year medium-term loans, keeps rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), injected 300 billion yuan into the market through one-year medium-term loans, exceeding the previous day's 187.5 billion yuan. The interest rate remained unchanged at 3.25%. This move came after a marginal interest rate cut in November and follows efforts to prop up a slowing economy. Another batch of 286 billion yuan worth of one-year MLF loans is set to expire on December 16.

site_title: China aims for south-east to be 70% self-sufficient in pork
summary: China has issued a three-year plan to recover its pig production after African swine fever devastated the nation's largest hog herd, with a goal of achieving 70% self-sufficiency in pork for the southeast region by the end of 2020. The plan includes subsidies, land permits, and insurance for pig breeders, and aims to improve prevention and control of the disease. Analysts estimate the herd may have dropped by 60% or more, but Beijing remains optimistic about recovery, citing consumer inflation and Lunar New Year demand as key drivers.

site_title: Uber says it received over 3,000 reports of sexual assault in US in 2018
summary: Uber reported 3,000 US ride-hailing incident reports in 2018, a 16% decline in serious categories of sexual assault, and 99.9% of trips ended without safety incidents. The company received 235 reports of non-consensual sexual penetration and 280 of attempted non-consensual penetration, mostly filed by women. Uber released its first biennial US Safety Report, aiming to improve accountability and safety, following a cultural turnaround under new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi, who prioritized improving the company's culture and safety.

site_title: Singapore shares inch higher at Friday's open; STI up 0.14%
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.14% to 3,178.50 points, driven by slight gains on Wall Street overnight. Investors await news on a possible US-China trade deal, with a fresh round of tariffs set to kick in on Dec 15. Banking stocks led the early morning trade, with DBS and United Overseas Bank gaining 0.2% and 0.3% respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong unrest contributed 2 pct points to Q3 GDP contraction: official
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 3.2% in the third quarter, entering recession for the first time in a decade, due to social unrest and the US-China trade war. Financial Secretary Paul Chan attributed 2% of the contraction to social unrest, citing "rough estimates". The city's GDP contracted 2.9% from the previous year, with the US-China trade war and violent protests weighing heavily on the economy.

site_title: No legal basis for Magnus Energy to challenge EGM resolutions: requisitioning shareholders
summary: Magnus Energy Group's four requisitioning shareholders will not respond to the company's arguments regarding an upcoming EGM. They claim Magnus has no legal basis to challenge proposed resolutions, including one to remove director Seet Chor Hoon and another to remove directors appointed after a requisition notice. The shareholders deemed Magnus' arguments "baseless," prompting the company to seek legal advice. Magnus will proceed with the preparation of the shareholders' circular and will send out the EGM notice and circular to shareholders by Dec 20.

site_title: SoftBank will have 'last laugh' with WeWork deal: analyst
summary: SoftBank's investment in WeWork, a coworking startup, may ultimately benefit the company. Analyst Chris Lane of Sanford C Bernstein suggests WeWork can achieve profitability if SoftBank overhauls the business plan and focuses on the corporate office market. Lane likens WeWork's business model to Starbucks', where branding and global scale give it an advantage. He estimates WeWork can grab 8% of the emerging market for pre-fitted offices, leading to a potential enterprise value of $28.8 billion by 2025, making SoftBank's 80% stake worth $19.1 billion.

site_title: Japan finance minister says BOJ's low-rate policy not behind megabank's fee moves
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said he doesn't believe the Bank of Japan's low-rate policy is behind Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's consideration of implementing fees on banking services. The megabank is weighing fees on dormant accounts and other services, citing costs for management. Aso stated that low interest rates have affected regional banks, but not a large bank like Mitsubishi. He doesn't think the bank's decision is related to the central bank's negative interest rate policy.

site_title: IPS Securex bags S$3.6m maintenance order from government agency
summary: IPS Securex has secured a S$3.6 million order from an undisclosed government agency in South-east Asia to provide one-year maintenance support services starting from Dec 12, 2019, to Dec 11, 2020. This is an extension of a contract signed in 2017 with the same government agency.

site_title: Decision biases in the boardroom
summary: Corporate boards often exhibit decision biases, similar to those in everyday life, which can lead to severe errors. Common biases include confirmation bias, overconfidence bias, and groupthink. To improve decision-making, corporate boards can adopt strategies such as regular training on cognitive biases, developing procedures to reduce biases, and embracing diverse boards with relevant experience. By doing so, boards can make better decisions and contribute to the long-term success of their companies, particularly in areas like risk management, corporate governance, and strategy execution.

site_title: Hong Kong police chief calls for peace ahead of big protest march
summary: Hong Kong police chief Chris Tang urged citizens to demonstrate peacefully ahead of a large-scale pro-democracy march on Sunday. The march, organized by the Civil Human Rights Front, comes after a period of relative calm following record gains by pro-democracy candidates in the November local elections. Tang called on citizens to set a global example of peaceful assembly, while also urging the organizer to assist police in maintaining order. The unrest in Hong Kong is a major challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping, who has been in power since 2012.

site_title: Putin and Zelensky in first talks to revive Ukraine peace efforts
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky are set to meet in Paris on Monday for talks aimed at reviving Ukraine peace efforts. This marks the first face-to-face meeting between the two leaders, and while a breakthrough is not expected, the talks are seen as a step forward in ending Europe's only active war. The summit will focus on implementing the Minsk accords, which call for a ceasefire, withdrawal of heavy weapons, and restoration of Ukrainian control over its borders.

site_title: SPH Reit borrows A$205m to fund Australia mall stake purchase
summary: SPH Reit has secured A$205 million in secured loans from Westpac Banking Corp to fund its A$670 million acquisition of a half-stake in Westfield Marion Shopping Centre in Adelaide, Australia. The deal, inked in November, will be partially funded by a perpetual securities issuance and private placement. The loans will be used to fund the acquisition and working capital. SPH Reit's gearing is expected to increase to 29.5% from 27.5%. The other 50% stake will be held by Scentre Group. The acquisition is expected to be completed by end-2019.

site_title: Bilibili inks 800m yuan contract to broadcast League of Legends in China
summary: Bilibili, a Chinese video site, has signed a three-year contract worth 800 million yuan (S$154.7 million) to broadcast League of Legends events in China. The deal, which covers 2020-2022 World Championship events, grants Bilibili exclusive domestic broadcasting rights. This move comes as the e-sports market in China heats up, driven by the country's large gaming market and affluent younger generation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SPH Reit, MLT, Golden Agri-Res, EHT, Chasen, Silkroad Nickel
summary: Keppel Corp invested S$80 million in Swiss energy firm MET Group, with plans to jointly explore European energy infrastructure assets. SPH Reit secured S$194.8 million in loans to finance its proposed acquisition of a half-stake in Westfield Marion Shopping Centre in Adelaide, increasing gearing to 29.5%.

site_title: Feel-good Christmas
summary: Capella Ubud in Bali is donating 1% of its website bookings until the end of December to Trash Hero Indonesia, a non-profit organization promoting environmental conservation. The resort's proceeds will support Trash Hero's programs and a children's book on waste management. This initiative aims to educate the younger generation on sustainable waste management practices and support a zero-waste future.

site_title: World Bank adopts more than US$1b annual China lending plan over US objections
summary: The World Bank has adopted a plan to lend China $1 billion to $1.5 billion annually from 2020 to 2025 in low-interest loans, despite US objections. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed opposition, calling for China to "graduate" from low-income country loan programs. The World Bank's board expressed broad support for the plan, which aims to aid China's structural and environmental reforms.

site_title: Japan's household spending posts fastest decline in 3.5 years
summary: Japan's household spending plummeted 5.1% in October, the largest decline in 3.5 years, as consumers cut purchases following a 2% sales tax hike and natural disasters disrupted business. This marks a reversal from the 9.5% growth in September and a 11.5% drop from the previous month. Analysts attribute the decline to the tax hike and a powerful typhoon that affected business. The data raises concerns about consumer spending and the overall economy, with the government approving a $122 billion fiscal package to support growth amid offshore risks.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates coverage on Lendlease Global Reit with 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Lendlease Global Reit with a "buy" call and a 12-month price target of S$1.05. The analyst cites the Reit's initial portfolio, which includes 313@somerset in Singapore and Sky Complex in Milan, as offering a mix of resilience, growth, and visibility. The portfolio's leases have inbuilt rental escalation and a forward yield of 5.6%, making it more attractive than retail peers. DBS's target represents a 14% upside from the current price, despite risks in Singapore and Italy, tenant concentration, and interest rate risks.

site_title: Hong Kong protests cost embattled MTR operator HK$1.6b
summary: Hong Kong's MTR Corp Ltd reports that six months of protests have caused approximately HK$1.6 billion in damage to its subway system, with passenger use dropping 14% from last year. The damage, combined with reduced operations and revenue, is expected to result in lower-than-expected 2019 profits. Despite this, the company maintains its overall financial position remains sound.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on lingering hopes for trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending Wall Street rallies on hopes for a US-China trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% to 23,373.00, while the Topix index gained 0.21% to 1,715.02. US and Chinese negotiators are working to finalize a preliminary trade deal announced in October, which would block new tariffs expected to take effect this month.

site_title: 498m new Ascendas Reit units to start trading on Dec 6
summary: Ascendas Reit has issued 498 million new units, priced at S$2.63 apiece, to partially fund its acquisition of 30 business park properties in the US and Singapore for S$1.66 billion. The new units will start trading on the Singapore bourse on December 6. The total number of Ascendas Reit units in issue will increase to 3.61 billion. Holders of the rights units will be entitled to any distributions from October 1 to December 31.

site_title: Canada sees 'tough challenge' getting trade deal ratified by US
summary: Canada's Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland has described the ratification of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement as a "tough challenge". The agreement, signed in 2018, has been delayed by Democratic lawmakers' demands for changes, including stronger drug protections. Freeland is working with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Mexico's deputy foreign minister to find a solution. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has expressed optimism that a version of the deal can be reached, but Freeland acknowledges the challenge of finding common ground between Pelosi and the Trump administration.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Friday, driven by optimism over a potential partial trade deal between China and the US. The Hang Seng index rose 0.49%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.10%. The rally comes despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend tariffs, with investors choosing to focus on the potential trade deal.

site_title: US considering troop boost to counter Iran
summary: The US is considering deploying 5,000 to 7,000 troops to the Middle East to counter Iran, amid rising tensions following the US withdrawal from a denuclearization pact and sanctions on Iranian oil exports. The deployment is reportedly in response to attacks on US assets by Iranian-linked groups. The move comes as Iran faces major protests over a gas price hike. Defense Secretary Mark Esper is said to be considering the plans, which would be a significant increase in US military presence in the region.

site_title: Firm behind experimental Alzheimer's drug makes case for approval
summary: US pharmaceutical company Biogen presented new data on its experimental Alzheimer's drug aducanumab, which showed the treatment slowed cognitive decline by 23% and loss of autonomy by 40% in patients. The company halted trials in 2019 but later resumed testing after reevaluating the data. Experts welcomed the new findings but also urged caution, citing the need for more scrutiny before approval from the US FDA. The FDA's response is expected to provide clarity on the drug's potential effectiveness in treating Alzheimer's disease.

site_title: Japan firms back tighter foreign ownership reporting rules: poll
summary: A majority of Japanese firms (62%) support the government's decision to tighten foreign ownership reporting rules, citing national security concerns. The new law requires foreign investors to report holdings once they accumulate a 1% stake, down from 10%. The move has drawn criticism from foreign investors, who argue the threshold is too low and could deter foreign investment. Some firms believe the regulation could prevent outflows of technology and management know-how, while others see it as a symbolic and political move.

site_title: Big European banks face call to end funding for firms building coal-fired plants
summary: European banks are urged to stop lending to utilities developing new coal-fired power plants, amid the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement's goal to virtually end coal power by 2050. A UN report suggests nearly all coal-fired power plants would need to close by mid-century to curb global temperatures. Environmental groups are calling on banks to sever all lending to utilities, citing the urgent need to curb climate change. The call comes as 190 countries meet in Madrid to assess progress on the Paris Climate Agreement.

site_title: US' Pompeo brings Iran pressure campaign to Morocco
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Morocco, discussing efforts to isolate Iran and other regional issues. The meeting with Moroccan counterpart Nasser Bourita focused on Iran's influence, conflicts in Libya, and terrorism, but did not bring up the issue of Iran-US relations. Pompeo stated that the US and Morocco have a great relationship, making their people safer. Morocco has had tense relations with Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution, and the kingdom severed relations last year over accusations of arms shipments to Western Sahara.

site_title: Major European investors urge EU to enshrine climate goal in law
summary: Major European investors, representing over $9 trillion in assets, have urged the European Union to enshrine the EU's 2050 climate neutrality goal in law. The move aims to increase confidence in environmentally responsible projects and counter the "catastrophic" impact of ignoring climate change, which could cost the global economy $23 trillion. The investors' call comes as EU President Ursula von der Leyen has made combating climate change a priority, with a proposed "Sustainable Europe Investment Plan" supporting $1 trillion in investment over the next decade.

site_title: Major US, global cities slowing amid worldwide slump: report
summary: A new report by Oxford Economics predicts that major US and global cities will experience slower growth in 2020 and 2021 due to the global trade slowdown. Nine of the top 10 cities, including Silicon Valley, will slow, while China's metropolitan areas will bump US cities out of the top 10 by 2021. London is the lone city expected to post a modest improvement, while American high-tech cities, such as San Jose, will see their growth rates cut in half.

site_title: Japan firms brace for economic contraction after Olympics, seek more stimulus: poll
summary: Japanese firms expect the economy to contract after the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, with 65% anticipating a contraction, and 65% urging the government to provide fresh stimulus. The economy is expected to shrink 2.5% in October to December, rebound 0.6% in the first quarter, and then accelerate to 1.2% annualized growth in the July to September quarter. The government is already set to roll out an economic spending package of around $120 billion, but firms are calling for more support to avoid a slump.

site_title: Oil little changed despite Opec+ plan to deepen cuts
summary: Oil prices remained steady to slightly firmer on Thursday despite Opec+ planning a deep 500,000-barrel-per-day output cut in the first quarter of 2020. The deal, which would last for three months, excludes condensates from cuts for non-Opec allies like Russia, potentially benefiting the country. Oil futures ended at US$63.39 for Brent crude and US$58.43 for West Texas Intermediate, with Brent up 0.6% and WTI unchanged. The move aims to counter booming US output and support Saudi Arabia's budget and state-owned oil company's initial public offering.

site_title: Malaysia must ensure that Apec remains sustainable and relevant
summary: Malaysia, as the new chair of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) bloc, faces the challenge of ensuring the grouping remains sustainable and relevant. The past two Apec summits have been marred by disagreements and cancellations, including the shelving of this year's summit in Chile due to violent protests. With the global economy experiencing slower growth and trade tensions between the US and China persisting, Malaysia must map out new priorities and goals for Apec, building on the bloc's past successes, including a region-wide decrease in average tariffs and a nearly tripled regional economy over the past 30 years.

site_title: Huawei sues FCC in fight for greater US market access
summary: Huawei has filed a lawsuit with the US Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, challenging the Federal Communications Commission's decision to bar the use of federal subsidies by rural carriers purchasing its equipment. The company claims it was unfairly labelled a national security threat and didn't receive due process. This move comes as Huawei fights American sanctions and curbs, stepping up a worldwide legal campaign to protest what it deems unfair treatment by the US and its allies.

site_title: Trudeau pushing tax cuts, climate in test for minority government
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau unveiled a legislative agenda that includes tax cuts and tougher climate actions, marking the first test of his minority government. The agenda, outlined in a throne speech, also includes plans for net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 and a national prescription drug plan. Trudeau must rely on opposition party support to stay in power, after rejecting a formal coalition and facing criticism for a recent gaffe with US President Donald Trump. The Canadian leader will need to find common ground with opposition parties to pass the agenda and avoid triggering snap elections.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How businesses can tackle the talent crunch
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how businesses can tackle the talent crunch, featuring Robin Matlock, senior vice-president and chief marketing officer at VMWare. Matlock emphasizes the importance of women in tech, citing her own pioneering role in introducing "software-defined" IT. She advises businesses to create a diverse and inclusive work environment, invest in training and development, and provide opportunities for women to advance in their careers. The conversation highlights the need for businesses to adapt to changing talent demands and prioritize talent acquisition strategies.

site_title: Pelosi directs House committee to draft articles of impeachment
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi directed a House committee to draft articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump, citing his effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate a political rival as a historic step towards removing him from office. The impeachment fight is unfolding as Trump runs for re-election in 2020. Three constitutional law experts testified that Trump's conduct represents impeachable offences, while a Republican expert called the inquiry rushed and flawed. If passed, articles of impeachment would lead to a trial in the Senate on whether to convict Trump and remove him from office.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip, Glencore slides to 3-year low
summary: European shares fell slightly, with the pan-European STOXX 600 closing down 0.1%, amid mixed signals on a US-China trade deal. Glencore shares slid to a 3-year low due to a bribery investigation. Germany's industrial orders fell unexpectedly, suggesting a manufacturing downturn. Investors remain cautious due to US President Trump's trade comments, which have created uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore keeps building until the buyers come
summary: Singapore's property market, which experienced a speculative bubble in 2018, has been cooled down by the government's introduction of buyer's stamp duties and tighter loan-to-value norms. The number of unsold new homes has increased to nearly 4,400, but prices are rising at a moderate 2.1% annually. The government aims to prevent a repeat of the 2010-2013 experience and maintain public housing as a priority for voters. With overseas buyers' participation currently subdued, developers are cutting back on land purchases, but the government's land sales programme is expected to release more housing units, potentially putting downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield partners Suzhou Industrial Park
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has partnered with Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) to expand investment opportunities in the region. The partnership, announced after a memorandum of understanding signing in Singapore, utilizes Cushman & Wakefield's offices in South-east Asia. The move aims to increase investment opportunities in SIP, a high-quality and pilot free trade zone.

site_title: Special Feature: Presents for the Family
summary: Aesthetic doctor Iroshini Chua shares her Christmas shopping tips, emphasizing the importance of starting early. She usually begins shopping in November to avoid last-minute rush and chaos. Chua recommends one-stop shopping, highlighting Raffles Arcade as a convenient option with exclusive gift ideas under one roof. By doing so, individuals can avoid the panic and stress associated with Christmas shopping.

site_title: Return Of Eve
summary: A stage adaptation of the classic film All About Eve, starring Gillian Anderson and Lily James, will be screened at the Esplanade Theatre Studio on Dec 6 and 8. The play, directed by Ivo van Hove, is a retelling of the 1951 Oscar-winning story about an aspiring actress who infiltrates the life of a Broadway star. The film adaptation is set to showcase the talents of Anderson and James in the iconic roles of Bette Davis and Ann Baxter.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG GLB 35 review: A speedy seven-seater
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GLB 35 is a unique vehicle that blends high-performance thrills with family utility, featuring a 306hp turbocharged engine, all-wheel drive, and improved suspension and brakes. With its spacious interior and comfortable handling, the GLB 35 is an entertaining option for family bus duty. Although it's not a full-on AMG model, it's priced sensibly, likely in the $250,000 range, and will have no direct rival when launched in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Hummingbird targets antibody discovery hurdle in fighting cancer
summary: Singapore-based Hummingbird Bioscience is developing a proprietary Rational Antibody Discovery (RAD) platform to identify and create potent antibodies against cancer-causing proteins. The company has secured $19 million in funding and is conducting pre-clinical studies for two antibodies targeting HER3 and VISTA proteins, which are associated with various types of cancer. Hummingbird aims to file Investigational New Drug (IND) applications with the FDA for the anti-HER3 and anti-VISTA drugs in Q2 and Q3 2020, respectively.

site_title: Saudi Aramco raises US$25.6b in biggest-ever IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco raised $25.6 billion in its largest-ever IPO, valuing the energy giant at $1.7 trillion. The IPO, priced at 32 riyals per share, was oversubscribed 4.65 times, despite concerns over transparency and governance practices. The sale falls short of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's goal of a $2 trillion valuation. The IPO is seen as a key part of the prince's plan to diversify the oil-reliant economy, but critics question whether the funds will be enough to cover the kingdom's budget deficit.

site_title: HK's Raffles Family Office opens in Singapore
summary: Raffles Family Office, a Hong Kong-based multifamily office, has launched its Singapore office to serve clients in the Asean region. The firm aims to grow its assets under management to at least $5 billion by next year and double that figure by 2021. Raffles Family Office will focus on investing in startups, incubating other family offices, and leveraging strategic partnerships to expand its client base. The firm's CEO, Kwan Chi Man, stated that they are looking at making more direct investments into startups, particularly those with an environmental, social, and governance (ESG) angle.

site_title: Sustainable Shopping
summary: The Sustainable Christmas Fair will be held from December 7 to 8 at Novotel and Mercure Singapore on Stevens, featuring eco-friendly products, home décor, and fair-trade items. Visitors can enjoy a 25% discount voucher for lunch or dinner at participating restaurants, including Winestone, Food Exchange, and Fudebar, which offer festive buffets and take-out options. The event aims to promote sustainable living, allowing shoppers to go green while gift shopping.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Silkroad Nickel has signed a binding head of agreement with three Indonesian companies to form a joint venture to build and operate smelter facilities for nickel pig iron production. Eagle Hospitality Trust will undergo an audit of its Queen Mary lease agreement, while Design Studio Group has announced the resignation of its CEO and the appointment of an interim CEO. The MAS and PBOC are set to deepen their collaboration in green and transition finance.

site_title: Among New World whiskeys, Australian ones are standing out
summary: Australian whiskey is gaining recognition globally, with many distilleries emerging as distinct regional styles. Unlike traditional Scotch, Australian whiskey often employs local ingredients, such as brewer's malt and aged in smaller casks, resulting in a unique flavor profile. Australian distillers, like Bill Lark, are experimenting with different styles, including bourbon and rye influences. With relaxed government regulations, Australian distilleries are now exporting to the US and other countries, setting the stage for a potential "whiskey arms race" among regional styles.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust added to STI, Golden Agri-Resources dropped
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has been added to the Straits Times Index (STI) while Golden Agri-Resources will be excluded, following the latest quarterly review by FTSE Russell. The STI reserve list also includes Suntec Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel Reit, and NetLink NBN Trust. The next review will take place in March 2020, and the indexes are reviewed quarterly to include eligible initial public offering stocks. This change reflects the companies' market capitalization and eligibility for inclusion in the index.

site_title: Warren accuses Bloomberg of 'buying the election'
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren accused former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg of trying to buy the 2020 election with his advertising spending. Warren stated that she doesn't believe elections should be for sale and that billionaires shouldn't have a monopoly on the Democratic nomination. Bloomberg has spent $59 million on ad time, primarily targeting Super Tuesday states. His campaign denies any attempt to buy the presidency, emphasizing Bloomberg's commitment to addressing economic inequality.

site_title: Toronto housing prices on the up amid tightening supply
summary: Toronto's home prices rose 0.6% in November, accelerating at the fastest annual pace since 2017. Demand outpaces a dwindling supply of listings, with active listings falling 27% from a year earlier. Benchmark prices for condos increased 9.5% over the past year, while single-family detached residences saw a 5.1% gain. Realtors caution that prices could continue rising due to the lack of listings, with the Toronto Real Estate Board's chief analyst predicting further price growth if listings don't increase.

site_title: O Christmas Tree
summary: The tradition of decorating a Christmas tree originated in the 16th century with Protestant reformer Martin Luther, who added lighted candles to a tree to recreate the twinkling stars he saw in the winter sky. The practice has since spread globally, with Singaporeans decorating trees in various sizes, from small homes to large displays in shopping malls like Ngee Ann City. This festive tradition is an integral part of the holiday season, symbolizing warmth and light during the winter months.

site_title: Special Feature - Making a Difference
summary: Entrepreneurs Nelson and Terence Loh, co-founders of Novena Global Lifecare, are strong advocates for Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and have incorporated it into their corporate culture. Their efforts led to the launch of the inaugural Education Benefit Gala (EBG), which will raise funds for four Singapore charities supporting education and training for marginalized women and children. Former US President Barack Obama will be the keynote speaker at the Dec 14 event, with an expected S$5 million in donations. The cousins aim to build a strong CSR culture that can also serve as an example for other companies to follow.

site_title: Deutsche Bank gives Crypto enthusiasts some hope
summary: Deutsche Bank strategist Jim Reid suggests that cryptocurrencies may experience a breakout decade due to rising doubts about government-backed currencies amid higher inflation. This contrarian call is based on the firm's Imagine 2030 report, which proposes alternative ideas for the next 10 years. According to Reid, increasing concerns about government-backed currencies could drive more people to digital assets, potentially leading to a surge in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Pound rises against euro on expected Tory win
summary: The pound rose against the euro on Dec 5, 2019, as opinion polls suggested the Conservative Party would win an outright majority in the Dec 12 election, removing near-term uncertainty over Brexit. Sterling reached a two-and-a-half-year high versus the euro, gaining 0.3% to 84.31 pence, and also rose 0.3% to US$1.3146. Analysts attributed the gains to the breaching of key technical levels and positive technical developments, with many foreign exchange strategists forecasting sterling would rise to US$1.33 in six months and US$1.35 in a year.

site_title: For smart cities, the future is regional
summary: Asean's smart cities will benefit from closer economic and technological cooperation among themselves or with external economies like China, the US, and Korea. The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) Smart Cities Network (ASCN) aims to facilitate smart, sustainable, and technologically-enabled urban development across Asean. The ASCN's formation represents a natural evolution of Asean centrality, allowing Asean to engage other major economies and access a larger pool of capital and markets. This shift in smart city development is driven by the emergence of a new digital economy, where regional flows of data, capital, and ideas are increasingly interconnected.

site_title: Jaguar F-Pace SVR review: A cat with claws and character
summary: The Jaguar F-Pace SVR is a high-performance luxury SUV that delivers both power and practicality. Powered by a 5.0-liter V8 supercharged engine, it produces 550 horsepower and features adaptive suspension, wide air intakes, and massive 22-inch wheels. The SVR model is built by Jaguar-Land Rover's Special Vehicle Operations division and is the third model to receive SVO's go-faster treatment. The F-Pace SVR offers a balance of feral and friendly, making it enjoyable to drive both on and off the road, with a starting price of S$388,999.

site_title: What's 'fair' when it comes to carbon emissions?
summary: The US and Australia, two countries heavily invested in fossil fuels, have been criticized for their high carbon emissions. Despite having less than a twentieth of the world's population, they emit one-sixth of the world's fossil fuel emissions. An average American or Australian generates nearly 17 tonnes of carbon dioxide pollution per person every year, compared to 3.5 times the global average. The Trump administration's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement and propose to roll back vehicle fuel efficiency standards is seen as unfair to the rest of the world and poses a significant threat to global efforts to combat climate change.

site_title: South-east Asia's economic growth 'to stay at 4.5% next year'
summary: South-east Asia's GDP growth is expected to remain at 4.5% in 2020 due to high US-China trade tensions, despite some countries' efforts to cushion the economic slowdown. Vietnam's GDP growth is projected to slow to 6.6% due to weaker Chinese import demand, while Singapore is likely to announce measures to support its economy. Other countries, such as the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia, will cut interest rates and implement fiscal stimulus to mitigate the economic impact of trade tensions.

site_title: New Mercedes GLC - Lofty mission for a tall car
summary: Mercedes-Benz has launched new versions of its GLC and GLC Coupe in Singapore, rounding off a busy year for the luxury-car maker. The new models, which debuted on November 29, are designed to stand out with their tall profile. The launch comes as Mercedes-Benz continues to expand its presence in the Singapore market.

site_title: Digital transformation pivotal to future of Singapore SMEs
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are expected to prioritize digital transformation in 2020 to improve productivity, customer service, scale, and attract talent. Government support and aid, such as the SME Portal's Tech Depot and Enterprise Singapore's (ESG) digitalisation initiatives, are available to help SMEs overcome physical geographical borders, manpower limitations, and resource constraints. Successful digital transformation involves focusing on desired outcomes, selecting the right solutions, and leaving room for failure to minimize costs. Companies like Hotel Re! and Soilbuild Group have implemented digital solutions to increase efficiency, reduce manual labor, and improve customer experience.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore launches second run of Scale-up SG
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) launched the second run of Scale-up SG, a 2.5-year program to accelerate the growth of 18 local mid-sized companies. The program, which began in July, aims to help companies in various industries, including B2B and consumer brands, to scale rapidly and contribute to Singapore's economy. Since the program's inception, about half of the 25 companies in the first run have formulated growth plans, with 12 expected to double their growth rates. ESG plans to roll out similar programs for smaller enterprises, focusing on building capabilities rather than providing subsidies or grants.

site_title: Best wine books not always about wine
summary: A new wave of books on wine is emerging, focusing on cider, sommeliers, and wine culture. "Uncultivated: Wild Apples, Real Cider and the Complicated Art of Making a Living" by Andy Brennan explores the tension between nature and industry in the cider world. Meanwhile, "The Cider Revival: Dispatches From the Orchard" by Jason Wilson delves into the resurgence of cider in the US and Europe. "Becoming a Sommelier" by Rosie Schaap offers a behind-the-scenes look at the sommelier profession, while "Vignette: Stories of Life & Wine in 100 Bottles" by Jane Lopes chronicles her journey to become a Master Sommelier.

site_title: Jakarta's MRT network set for US$40b expansion
summary: Indonesia plans to spend approximately $40 billion to expand its metro network in Jakarta, with the goal of building 230 km by 2030. This expansion, part of President Joko Widodo's plan to create a $7 trillion economy by 2045, will boost the country's construction companies and revive a rivalry between China and Japan. The project, currently in the selection phase, will add six new lines to the existing system and is expected to rival Hong Kong and Singapore's rail networks in length.

site_title: Taking on mental health in the office
summary: A professional shares a personal account of workplace depression, highlighting the common misconception that someone "functioning" well may be struggling with mental health issues. The article aims to raise awareness and encourage open conversations about mental health in the office. Experts and thought leaders discuss related topics, including the risks of cyber threats and the importance of engaging with interviewers during job interviews. The piece seeks to promote a culture of understanding and support for mental health in the workplace.

site_title: Kampong Bugis, River Valley GLS sites up for application
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has made available for application two government land sales sites: a white site in Kampong Bugis and a hotel site in River Valley Road. These sites were recently carried over from the second-half 2019 GLS programme to the first-half 2020 GLS programme. The URA seeks exceptional concept proposals for the development of these sites.

site_title: A Locavore Christmas
summary: Chef Eelke Plasmeijer, owner of Bali's Locavore restaurant, emphasizes that sustainable Christmas dining doesn't have to mean depriving oneself of meat. Instead, opt for well-raised, locally sourced meat or use secondary cuts. He recommends cooking vegetables in animal fat for added flavor. Locavore achieves near-100% sustainability through practices like using leftover ingredients, fermenting food waste, and partnering with sustainable kitchen appliance brand Sub-Zero and Wolf. Chef Plasmeijer advocates for leading by example and promoting sustainable habits among his team and local community.

site_title: What's the point of the Turner Prize, anyway?
summary: The 2019 Turner Prize, a prestigious British art award, was awarded to a collective of four artists, Lawrence Abu Hamdan, Helen Cammock, Oscar Murillo, and Tai Shani, who proclaimed themselves a collective to make a strong statement of community and solidarity. The jury unanimously agreed to award the prize to the collective, who each received a quarter of the $52,000 prize money. This move was seen as a subversive act to challenge the traditional winner-takes-all model of the prize, and to highlight the growing skepticism of art institutions' progressiveness.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.6% in November
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore increased 0.6% in November, the largest monthly rise this year, despite a 13.5% drop in resale volume. Non-mature estates saw a 2% year-on-year increase, while mature estates fell 2%. Prices for three-room, four-room, and five-room flats rose 0.1%, 1.2%, and 1.1% respectively. The most expensive resale flat sold for S$1.08 million, while buyers underpaid by an estimated S$1,000 on average.

site_title: Catalina buying Asia Capital Reinsurance to build regional portfolio
summary: Catalina Holdings, a Singapore-based insurance and reinsurance player, has reached an in-principle agreement to buy Asia Capital Reinsurance Group (ACR) in a deal expected to close in the first half of 2020. The acquisition aims to build a regional portfolio for Catalina. The deal is subject to approvals and marks a significant expansion for the company.

images.alt_text: Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of ACR, said: "This was a shareholder-led process, which has culminated in a successful exit. Catalina has the experience and expertise to deliver on ACR's outstanding commitments to clients and take the business into a new direction."

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drop to seven-month low
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped to a seven-month low of 203,000 for the week ended Nov 30, according to the Labour Department. This is the lowest level since mid-April, beating economists' forecasts of a rise to 215,000. The four-week moving average of initial claims fell to 217,750, suggesting the labor market remains solid despite the slowing economy. The claims data has no impact on the November employment report, which is set to release on Friday, and is expected to show a 180,000 job increase.

site_title: Shiseido opens first domestic factory in 36 years
summary: Japanese cosmetics firm Shiseido has opened its first domestic factory in 36 years in Otawara, Japan, capitalizing on the "Made in Japan" cosmetics boom. The new factory aims to focus on high-end prestige brands, leveraging Japan's attention to detail and cultural value. The move is part of Shiseido's 120 billion yen investment plan, which includes two more factories in Japan, creating 1,000 jobs and making it the town's biggest private employer. The company plans to use advanced tech and human intervention for its highest-range products, while relying on human craftsmanship and skills for some processes.

site_title: The Reserve Bank of India just did something crazy
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) held its benchmark interest rate at 5.15% despite expectations of a rate cut, citing concerns over rising inflation. Headline inflation breached the 4% medium-term target in October, driven by food price increases. The decision is seen as a surprise and may sap confidence, particularly given the country's struggling economy. RBI governor Shaktikanta Das is under scrutiny for prioritizing inflation targets, which some argue are ineffective. The move may have been premature, given the global economic outlook and India's domestic growth rate.

site_title: Manulife US Reit joining FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index
summary: Manulife US Reit will join the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index on December 23, increasing trading liquidity and visibility for institutional investors. The inclusion is a result of the Reit's strong growth, with its market capitalization tripling to US$1.5 billion since its IPO three and a half years ago. CEO Jill Smith sees the move as a positive step for the company, bolstering its position as the US Reit of choice and paving the way for continued growth in 2020.

site_title: Double Christmas
summary: The Chia family, a dual-income household, is celebrating Christmas together in a unique way. The two families, consisting of Mr. and Mrs. Chia and their two children, have moved into semi-detached houses in Siglap, allowing them to combine their celebrations. The families have decorated their houses with festive decorations, including plastic trees, gold and silver baubles, and poinsettias. They will host a dinner party for 30 friends and family members on December 21, with a focus on homemade food and decorations. The families enjoy making their own decorations, and they look forward to dressing up their homes for Chinese New Year next year.

site_title: Balancing familiar with unexpected
summary: Newly installed head chef Zach Elliott-Crenn brings modern Australian and European influences to Maggie Joan's, a Singaporean restaurant known for its unique back-lane dining experience. The menu features inventive dishes such as butternut financier, Coffin Bay oysters, and Hokkaido scallops, showcasing a balance of familiarity and unexpected twists. While some dishes, like the pan-seared scallops, fall short, the overall experience is enjoyable and polished, earning a rating of 7. The restaurant's cozy, subterranean space and creative menu make it a standout in Singapore's dining scene.

site_title: Dreaming of a green Christmas
summary: A more sustainable Christmas is possible without sacrificing magic, according to a recent article. The article suggests alternatives to traditional Christmas trees, conscious feasting, and eco-friendly gift ideas. It also highlights the importance of reducing waste and embracing a zero-waste lifestyle. The article aims to provide readers with ways to make their celebrations more environmentally friendly, from casual dining to thoughtful gift-giving, without losing the essence of the holiday season.

site_title: Thakral Corp sets up venture to invest in Japan properties
summary: Thakral Corp has established a joint venture, Thakral Umeda Properties (TUP), to invest in Japanese properties. The JV will hold about 79.1% of TUP, with collective direct shareholdings, and will invest in Osaka properties through TMK Japan. The directors believe this investment is part of their strategy to diversify assets and enhance shareholder value in Japan, capitalizing on the country's strong economic fundamentals and tourism boom. TUP will issue 1 million shares worth 100 million yen, with the proceeds used to conduct business and distribute net profits.

site_title: Meeting Singapore's foodtech ambitions
summary: Singapore aims to become a leading food and nutrition hub in Asia by 2025, with a focus on innovative technologies and sustainable practices. The country's government has set a "30 by 30" goal to meet 30% of its nutritional needs, and the food industry is adopting vertical farming, alternative food formulations, and sustainable packaging solutions. To achieve this, Singapore needs a skilled workforce with technical and business capabilities, and the government is investing in education and training programs to develop future-ready food industry professionals. Collaboration with international partners, such as New Zealand, is also crucial in driving developments in the sector.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2020 to be fully solar-powered
summary: The Singapore Airshow 2020 will be the first to be fully solar-powered, with 15,000 solar panels generating 7,840 megawatt hours of power annually. The event, held from Feb 11 to 16, will feature a trade exhibition, high-level meetings, and aerial displays, with over 65 top aerospace and defence companies expected to participate. Despite geopolitical tensions, the show's organizers are optimistic, citing the aviation industry's long cycle and the event's focus on long-term sustainability. New initiatives include an Innovation Forum and "talent development" programs targeting youths.

site_title: Pelosi instructs House panel to draft articles of impeachment against Trump
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has instructed the House Judiciary Committee to draft articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump over his effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate a political rival, Joe Biden. Pelosi cited Trump's abuse of power and withholding of military aid as reasons for the impeachment. A hearing with constitutional law experts previously concluded that Trump's actions were impeachable offenses. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and called the inquiry a hoax.

site_title: Journey to Japan - Hidden dining gems
summary: Tokyo, Japan is a culinary destination that offers unique dining experiences. As the city prepares for the 2020 Olympics, travelers can explore hidden gems such as Sushi M, a restaurant offering a new take on traditional sushi. The article highlights various one-of-a-kind dining spots across Tokyo, encouraging readers to venture off the beaten path and discover the city's hidden culinary treasures.

site_title: Freebies not enough to clear Manhattan's luxury condo inventory
summary: Extell Development, a New York-based real estate developer, is struggling to sell its luxury condos in Manhattan despite offering incentives and negotiable prices. In the third quarter, five apartments at The Kent sold or went under contract, leaving 51 units up for grabs. The developer has tried various strategies to lure buyers, including waiving common charges and offering rent-to-own programs. Despite efforts to increase sales velocity, the market remains competitive, and Extell's lower-priced luxury offerings are also struggling to find buyers.

site_title: Japan leans on fiscal stimulus to keep recession at bay
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a 26-trillion yen (S$325 billion) stimulus package to support the economy, which is facing an export slump, natural disasters, and the fallout from a recent sales tax increase. The package, which includes fiscal measures worth around 13 trillion yen (S$165 billion), aims to boost growth by about 1.4 percentage points. The measures include disaster relief, protection against economic risks, and preparation for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Economists have cast doubt on the package's effectiveness, with some estimating it may only boost growth by 0.2 percentage points.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit to invest 53m euros for 20% stake in Swiss energy firm
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings is investing 53.02 million euros (S$80 million) for a 20% stake in MET Group, an integrated European energy company. The investment is part of a strategic partnership to jointly explore European energy infrastructure assets. MET Group has businesses in natural gas, power, and oil markets across 15 European countries. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Keppel Corp's financials and has led to a slight increase in Keppel Corp shares to S$6.70.

site_title: Optimism over US-China deal sends STI up
summary: US-China trade deal optimism boosts Asian markets, with the Straits Times Index (STI) regaining Wednesday's losses to end at 3,174.19, a 0.5% advance. The STI saw broad gains across Asia-Pacific markets, while South Korea ended lower. Analysts attribute the rally to reports that the final details of the US-China deal could be finalized by the end of the week.

site_title: HSBC, Aramco kick Barclays off EMEA league
summary: HSBC has been promoted to the top 10 equity arrangers in Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) after Saudi Aramco's record-breaking IPO, displacing Barclays. This move comes as HSBC has secured a significant deal with Aramco, marking a return to the top tier for the bank after a five-year absence.

site_title: Watch Out For Christmas
summary: Rolex has released two new watches for the holiday season: the OysterPerpetual Day-Date and the Yacht-Master 42. The Day-Date is a dress watch with a rich history, first introduced in 1956, and now comes in five colorful versions. The Yacht-Master 42 is a sports watch designed for sailing and regattas, featuring a bi-directional bezel and 70-hour power reserve. Both watches are certified Superlative Chronometers and are available in precious metals, making them ideal gifts for the holiday season.

site_title: US factory orders rebound in Oct; shipments unchanged
summary: US factory orders rebounded 0.3% in October, lifted by rising demand for machinery and transportation equipment, after two straight monthly declines. Data also showed bookings for computers and electronic products rose. October's gain was in line with economists' expectations, but factory orders decreased 0.4% compared to October 2018. The gains were likely limited by persistently weak business confidence.

site_title: Birthday Party
summary: The Naked Finn is hosting a birthday party on Dec 8, featuring a series of dining events, including a lunch by Odette's Julien Royer and a burger flip by Ta Vie's Hideaki Sato. Homegrown singer Joie Tan will perform from 2-5pm, and an alfresco market will offer freshly baked goods, seafood, and drinks. Reservations are selling out fast, and the event is open to pets. The party will take place at The Naked Finn's Gillman Barracks premises.

site_title: Singtel names Kelly Rosmarin as CEO-designate of Optus and Consumer Australia
summary: Singtel has named Kelly Bayer Rosmarin as CEO-designate of both Optus and Consumer Australia, effective April 1, 2020. She will join the Singtel management committee and drive customer experience improvements and market share growth. Rosmarin takes over from Allen Lew, who will become CEO group strategy and business development, and country chief officer for Thailand. This move aims to capitalize on 5G growth and the digitalization of the Australian economy.

site_title: Signs are pointing to global economic recession
summary: Global economic recession signs are emerging, with 90% of countries experiencing slowdowns, according to the International Monetary Fund. A decade of easy monetary policy has fueled a "dangerous bull market," with reckless lending and mispricing of credit risk. Despite warning signs, such as Argentina's technical default and China's increasing corporate bond defaults, markets and policymakers appear complacent. Experts warn of a violent repricing of risky assets, which could lead to large financial market strains. The article concludes that the prolonged bull market is likely to end in an epic collapse, echoing economist Hyman Minsky's warnings.

site_title: US: Wall Street inches higher as Dec 15 tariff deadline looms
summary: US stocks rose marginally on Thursday as investors awaited news on a potential interim trade deal between the US and China before a new round of tariffs on Dec 15. Tech stocks led gains, with President Trump and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stating that US-China trade negotiations are "on track" and "going well". The market has been volatile due to conflicting reports on a "phase one" agreement, but investors remain cautiously optimistic.

site_title: Grab aims to drive Asean e-wallet adoption with latest card launch
summary: Grab has launched its GrabPay Card in Singapore, aiming to drive Asean e-wallet adoption and borderless payments. The virtual card, which allows users to spend from the GrabPay wallet, will be available in the Philippines in the first quarter of next year and two other Asean markets later in 2020. This move is part of Grab's ambition to become a leading wallet for the region's rising middle class.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel signs definitive head of agreement to operate Sulawesi smelter
summary: Silkroad Nickel has signed a definitive head of agreement with Renewable and Sustainable Energy Holding and other companies to form a joint venture to build and operate smelter facilities for nickel pig iron production in Sulawesi, Indonesia. The joint venture, New.Co, will be majority-owned by Silkroad and will operate 12 blast furnaces with the option to purchase. The agreement includes a power supply agreement and a nickel ore supply agreement, with Silkroad's subsidiary PT TAS providing a guarantee on the quality and quantity of nickel ore. The deal is subject to regulatory and corporate approvals.

site_title: Britain's fraud office opens Glencore bribery investigation
summary: Britain's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) has launched an investigation into Glencore, a global commodity trader, over suspected bribery. This follows a US Department of Justice enquiry into corruption in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Venezuela, and Nigeria. Glencore has operations in over 150 countries and has seen its shares fall over 20% this year. The company has cooperated with the investigation and CEO Ivan Glasenberg plans to step down next year. Analysts predict the SFO action will add to Glencore's problems, but its impact remains unclear.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust to begin audit of Queen Mary lease agreement
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust announced that it will undergo an audit of its lease agreement with the City of Long Beach for the Queen Mary, a practice of good lease management. The audit, the sixth of its kind, covers the financial statements for 2017 and 2018, periods before Eagle Hospitality Reit owned the leasehold interest. The audit aims to ensure good stewardship of the Queen Mary and will not disrupt business operations, with any updates to be announced accordingly.

site_title: GM, LG Chem to build US$2.3b battery plant in Ohio
summary: General Motors (GM) and LG Chem have agreed to invest $2.3 billion in a new battery plant in Lordstown, Ohio, creating 1,100 jobs. The plant will produce battery cells for GM's next-generation electric vehicles, including a truck launching in 2021. The investment aims to lower battery costs and accelerate GM's pursuit of an all-electric future. The plant's annual capacity will be 30 gigawatt hours, surpassing Tesla's Gigafactory in Nevada.

site_title: Boomers have outgrown real Christmas trees
summary: The US Christmas tree industry is facing a significant decline in production, with Christmas tree production falling nearly 30% from 2002 to 2017. The main cause of this decline is the increasing preference for artificial trees, driven by ageing baby boomers opting for convenience and reusability. According to the USDA's Census of Agriculture, Christmas tree production fell from 21 million to 15 million between 2002 and 2017. The industry is now hoping that younger adults will want to recreate holiday experiences with their own offspring, but the trend suggests a shift towards artificial trees.

site_title: EU leaders push for rapid post-Brexit talks
summary: EU leaders are pushing for rapid post-Brexit talks, fearing a no-deal scenario that could harm the UK's economy. The EU's Michel Barnier will draw up a mandate for a future relationship with the UK immediately after its withdrawal. The UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised a swift withdrawal from the EU by the end of 2020, despite a senior EU diplomat calling the trade deal timetable "nearly impossible". The EU and UK are set to discuss the election aftermath at a two-day EU summit in Brussels, with the UK vote taking place on December 12.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust added to STI, Golden Agri-Resources excluded
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has been added to the Straits Times Index (STI), while Golden Agri-Resources will be excluded following the quarterly review by FTSE Russell. The STI reserve list now includes Suntec Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel Reit, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, and NetLink NBN Trust. The next STI review will take place in March 2020, replacing ineligible constituents with reserve list stocks.

site_title: Design Studio chief quits; board reshuffles with interim CEO named
summary: Design Studio Group's CEO Edgar Ramani has resigned, effective December 4, to pursue other opportunities. Interim CEO Steven Salo, a Depa Limited director, has been appointed. Salo will lead the company until a permanent CEO is appointed. The company has also taken an unsecured loan of up to 20 million dirham from Depa United Group, requiring the approval of a business plan and restructuring strategy. The move follows the announcement of the loan and the transfer of executive leadership to a Depa nominee.

site_title: Chasen unit bags 50m-yuan China project to provide move-in services
summary: Chasen Holdings' wholly-owned PRC subsidiary secured a 50 million yuan (S$9.7 million) contract to provide move-in services for a 6th Generation AMOLED plant in Hefei, Anhui province, from December 2019 to November 2020. The project is expected to positively impact Chasen's results from the fourth quarter of the financial year 2020. Managing Director and CEO Low Weng Fatt expressed confidence in the company's performance, citing the expected pick-up of project implementation in the country. The contract comes at a time of economic slowdown in the region.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher for second straight session
summary: Wall Street opened higher for the second straight session on Thursday, driven by brighter hopes of a preliminary trade deal between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.31%, the S&P 500 opened 0.21% higher, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.25%. This follows a rally in previous sessions, with investors optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Three ways to drive a car - without a car loan
summary: New car leasing schemes have emerged in Singapore, offering alternative options to traditional car loans. Lexus distributor Borneo Motors launched Lex'plore, a lease-to-own arrangement, while BMW Financial Services Singapore and Sime Darby Services introduced subscription-based services, Access by BMW and Flow by BMW, respectively. These services allow customers to drive a car without a down payment, with options to pause or cancel subscriptions. The schemes cater to evolving customer preferences, prioritizing financial planning and flexibility over traditional car ownership.

site_title: Indonesia minister to sack Garuda CEO over smuggled Harley
summary: Indonesia's State-owned enterprises minister Erick Thohir plans to fire Garuda CEO Ari Ashkara over allegations of smuggling a Harley Davidson motorcycle into the country. Ashkara allegedly disassembled the 800 million rupiah motorbike and brought parts on a plane from France, using a subordinate's name on import papers to avoid detection. The alleged smuggling was meant to avoid declaring the motorbike to customs.

site_title: Two tech firms ink deal to build up AI in Asean
summary: Two tech firms, Huawei's cloud services unit and Skymind's regional arm, have partnered to develop an AI ecosystem in Southeast Asia. They will focus on smart city innovations in Indonesia and Malaysia, offering strategic and technical expertise. The joint working group will tackle regional infrastructure and talent development, including AI training schemes for local industry workers. No timeline or specific urban solutions were mentioned.

site_title: US trade deficit falls in Oct to lowest since May 2018
summary: The US trade deficit in October fell to its lowest level in over a year, dropping to its lowest since May 2018, as Americans imported fewer autos and consumer goods. This decline, attributed to a weakening global economy, could help lift US economic growth in the final quarter of the year. The reduction in deficit subtracts from GDP, a positive sign for the US economy.

site_title: Matt Jones, Long-Distance Pilot
summary: Pilots Steve Boultbee Brooks and Matt Jones, co-founders of the Boultbee Flight Academy, embarked on "The Longest Flight," a historic round-the-world expedition in a restored Spitfire MK IX aircraft. Supported by luxury watch brand IWC, the duo aims to inspire young people to pursue mechanics and engineering. The 43,000km journey, covering 30 countries, began in August 2019 and has already visited Iceland, Canada, Russia, Japan, India, and others, with stops in Italy and Switzerland. The Silver Spitfire's unique silver-chrome finish and live tracker allow the public to follow their progress.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit invests 53m euros in energy firm MET Group
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings' subsidiary, Keppel Energy Switzerland Holding AG, has invested $80 million (53.02 million euros) in MET Group, a Swiss energy company. The investment gives Keppel Infrastructure a 20% stake in MET Group. The two companies will also form a strategic partnership to explore investment opportunities in European energy infrastructure assets. This is Keppel Infrastructure's first step into the European energy market, with CEO Ong Tiong Guan citing MET Group's integrated strategy as a key factor in the investment. The transaction is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.65 points to 1,563.58. The market saw 2.4 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion, with 529 gainers and 305 losers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open
summary: European stock markets diverged at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 losing 0.2% to 7,172.54 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 remained flat and edged up, respectively. The divergence followed gains in Asia.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab launches a new payment card to tap into the Asean digital economy, with Mastercard partnership. Enterprise Singapore launches a second run of Scale-up SG to help local companies scale rapidly. HDB resale prices rose 0.6% in November, the biggest month-on-month gain this year. Manulife US Reit joins the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index, and Catalina buys Temasek-backed Asia Capital Reinsurance to build a regional portfolio. The STI rose 0.5% as risk appetite increased on trade deal hopes.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end lower as investors shrug off positive trade signals
summary: South Korea's KOSPI index ended lower on Thursday, declining 0.39% to 2,060.74, marking its third straight session of declines. Foreign investors were net sellers for the 21st consecutive session, posting losses of US$55.03 million. Despite US President Donald Trump's positive comments on trade talks with China, investors appeared to shrug off the signals, and the KOSPI advanced only 0.97% so far this year.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.5% as risk appetite rises on trade deal hopes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,174.19, driven by broad gains across Asia-Pacific markets amid hopes for the final details of the US-China "Phase One" trade deal. Investor appetite for risk assets increased, with Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and Taiwan posting gains. South Korea was the only exception. Trading volume was high, with Golden Agri-Resources and Manulife US Reit seeing significant activity. The STI's inclusion of Manulife US Reit in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Index from December 23 is expected to boost trading liquidity.

site_title: Catalina buying Temasek-backed Asia Capital Reinsurance to build regional portfolio
summary: Catalina Holdings has reached an in-principle agreement to acquire Asia Capital Reinsurance Group, a Singapore-based reinsurer backed by Temasek Holdings. The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2020, will give Catalina its first Asian presence and allow it to build a regional portfolio. Asia Capital Reinsurance had US$835 million of shareholder equity, US$1.3 billion of gross liabilities, and total assets of US$2.1 billion. The acquisition will be used to establish a strong Asian run-off platform, with Singapore as a hub.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2020 to be fully solar-powered, says organiser
summary: The Singapore Airshow 2020 will be fully solar-powered, marking the event's first time in its 12-year history. The show will be powered by 15,000 solar panels producing 7,840 megawatt hours of power annually. The event, held from February 11 to 16, 2020, will feature over 65 top aerospace companies, 1,000 companies from 50 countries, and 55,000 trade attendees from 150 countries. Despite geopolitical tensions, the air show expects strong participation numbers, with a 5% increase in private companies from China and a focus on urban mobility and innovation.

site_title: Cushman and Wakefield partners Suzhou Industrial Park to boost investment opportunities
summary: Cushman and Wakefield has partnered with Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) to boost investment opportunities, leveraging the firm's South-east Asia offices, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed following SIP's investment promotion symposium in Singapore. The partnership aims to improve outbound investment by combining the China and Singapore business environments, with plans to expand the SIP model to other Belt and Road locations.

site_title: Petrobras says it may divest billions more than forecast
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras may divest an additional $10-20 billion in assets, exceeding its initial 2020-2024 plan of $20-30 billion. This could include its Bolivian assets, stake in Braskem SA, legacy deepwater oilfields, and remaining stake in Petrobras Distribuidora SA. The divestment plan aims to reduce Petrobras' hefty debt load.

site_title: SK Group tycoon's wife lays claim to US$1.2b in divorce suit
summary: SK Group tycoon Chey Tae-won's wife, Roh Soh-yeong, has filed a US$1.2 billion divorce suit, demanding 42.3% of his stake in SK Holdings. The settlement, if successful, would make her the second-largest shareholder. Chey Tae-won, 59, has a current fortune of US$2.8 billion, excluding pledged shares. Roh Soh-yeong, daughter of former South Korean president Roh Tae-woo, is seeking to move on from the marriage, stating she no longer sees hope for reconciliation.

site_title: Japan's 2nd-largest bank says it takes more than changing dress code to shake things up
summary: Japan's second-largest bank, Sumitomo Mitsui, has introduced a relaxed dress code to shake up its staff's mindset, allowing Tokyo headquarters staff to wear jeans and sneakers. However, the bank's president, Jun Ohta, emphasizes that changing dress code alone is not enough, urging staff to change their ideas and approach to work. The move is part of a broader effort to modernize the bank's culture and attract younger talent in the traditionally formal Japanese financial industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on Trump's remarks on trade talks
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 6,683.00, rebounding from a one-month low, after US President Donald Trump's comments on trade talks with Beijing revived optimism. Trump said discussions were "going very well," easing concerns after he previously suggested a trade deal might wait until after the 2020 US presidential election. The benchmark fell 1.6% the previous day, and the S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also advanced 0.4%. The recovery was seen as a relief to investors, but analysts noted that market sentiment may continue to be dictated by trade talks uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday with the Hang Seng index gaining 0.59% to 26,217.04 following a report that US and Chinese officials are closing in on a mini trade deal, boosting trade hopes. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter gaining 1.15%. The gains were attributed to traders brushing off new Trump threats and maintaining a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon up 0.53% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.53% to 3,176.64 on Thursday, driven by healthy intraday gains. The index saw 176 gainers for every 92 losers, with offshore firm Rex International and Golden Agri-Resources leading the gains. Other Asian markets also rose, including Australia's ASX and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on stimulus package, US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.71% to 23,300.09, driven by a US$120 billion stimulus package announced by Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US rallies after upbeat trade talks. The broader Topix index also increased 0.48%. The news followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and despite US-EU trade talks and Trump's new threats.

site_title: NUS launches think tank to explore legal issues in technology use
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has launched the Centre for Technology, Robotics, Artificial Intelligence and the Law (Trail), a think tank to explore legal issues surrounding AI, robotics, and data analytics. The centre, under the Faculty of Law, aims to promote inter-disciplinary research in technology law. Senior Minister of State for Law and Health Edwin Tong officially opened the centre, highlighting the need for the law to respond quickly to the rapid pace of technological advancements. Trail will conduct research on regulatory questions, privacy, and data protection issues, and work with partners to produce valuable research and policies.

site_title: Asia coffee: Sluggish trade in Vietnam on low prices, Indonesia quiet
summary: Asia's top coffee exporters experienced sluggish trade, with Vietnam's coffee market slowing due to falling prices. Domestic prices in Vietnam's Central Highlands fell to 32,300-32,500 dong per kg, down from last week. January robusta coffee settled at US$1,370 per tonne, down 2.97% from the previous week. Vietnam's coffee exports in the first 11 months of 2019 fell 14.6% to 1.47 million tonnes. In contrast, Indonesia's main harvest ended and stocks receded, with traders predicting a quiet trade environment.

site_title: Gold prices gain on mixed US-China trade signals
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to a one-month high of $1,475.18 per ounce on Thursday, driven by uncertainty over a US-China trade deal. US President Donald Trump's comments on trade talks, which suggested a possible delay until after the 2020 presidential election, prolonged uncertainty. The US dollar index extended losses, making gold cheaper for investors holding other currencies. Gold has gained 15% this year, its biggest annual gain since 2010, amid the ongoing US-China trade war.

site_title: Manulife US Reit joining FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index
summary: Manulife US Reit will join the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Developed Index on Dec 23, 2019, marking a significant milestone for the US office real estate investment trust. The inclusion is expected to increase trading liquidity and visibility to institutional investors, potentially leading to a positive rerating. Manulife US Reit's market capitalization has tripled to US$1.5 billion since its IPO three and a half years ago. The index tracks the performance of global property companies and real estate investment trusts.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore launches second run of Scale-up SG
