summary: Enterprise Singapore has launched the second run of Scale-up SG, a 2.5-year programme to help local high-growth companies scale rapidly and contribute to the Singapore economy. 18 new enterprises are part of the programme, which will work with partners such as McKinsey & Company and PwC Singapore to develop business acceleration plans. The goal is to create good jobs for Singaporeans and contribute significantly to the country's economy.

site_title: Kampong Bugis white site, River Valley hotel site available for application: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has made available two sites for application: a 8.2-hectare white site at Kampong Bugis and a 1.02-hectare hotel site at River Valley Road. The Kampong Bugis site can yield up to 4,000 housing units and 50,000 square meters of GFA, while the River Valley site can accommodate 530 hotel rooms. URA has introduced a top-up option to incentivize exceptional concept proposals, which will be limited and offered to outstanding proposals.

site_title: Australian banks need extra NZ$13b to meet tougher New Zealand capital rules
summary: Australia's major banks, ANZ, Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Westpac, will need an additional NZ$13 billion (S$11.6 billion) to meet New Zealand's tougher capital requirements. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has set a minimum capital ratio of 18% for the top four banks and 16% for smaller banks, with the changes phased in over a seven-year period. The new requirements aim to better enable the country to weather economic turbulence, but Moody's says they may lead to higher lending rates and constrain growth in capital-intensive lending.

site_title: S-E Asia economic growth to remain sluggish at 4.5% in 2020: report
summary: South-East Asia's economic growth is expected to remain sluggish at 4.5% in 2020 due to high risks of a re-escalation in US-China trade tensions. The region's GDP growth has been sluggish since the third quarter of 2019, with export-oriented economies suffering the worst blow. Vietnam's GDP growth is expected to ease to 6.6% in 2020, while Indonesia's and Malaysia's growth is expected to ease to 4.9% and 4% respectively. Regional central banks have adopted more accommodative policies, with interest rate cuts and fiscal stimulus measures to cushion the economic slowdown.

site_title: China says tariffs should be reduced for phase one trade deal with US
summary: China's commerce ministry says tariffs should be reduced for a phase one trade deal with the US, as both sides maintain close communication. The ministry's spokesman, Gao Feng, stated that lowering tariffs is necessary for a deal, following a telephone call between China's lead trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, and US officials. The phase one deal was initially expected in November, with completion now uncertain. US tariffs on Chinese imports are set to increase on December 15, covering $156 billion worth of goods.

site_title: Japan unveils 13 trillion yen fiscal boost to fight external risks, post-Olympics slump
summary: Japan's government unveiled a 13 trillion yen fiscal package to combat external risks and post-Olympics slump. The package, which includes fiscal investment and loan programs, aims to support stalling growth and sustain economic vitality. The economic package amounts to 25 trillion yen when including government loans, credit guarantees, and private-sector spending. The package is smaller than the last major package in 2016, and the government will steer clear of fresh deficit-covering bond issuance to maintain fiscal discipline.

site_title: Design Studio takes 20m dirham unsecured loan from controlling shareholder
summary: Design Studio Group, a mainboard-listed company, has taken a 20 million dirham (S$7.4 million) unsecured loan from controlling shareholder Depa United Group. The loan, with an interest rate of three-month Eibor plus 5.5%, is to support working capital requirements. Design Studio's board and audit committee have approved the loan, stating it is on normal commercial terms and in the best interests of the company. The loan will also improve the group's cash flow situation.

site_title: Thai aquaculture to stay soft in 2020: Report
summary: Thai aquaculture producers are expected to face softness in 2020 due to commodity price fluctuations. Tuna prices are predicted to rebound to between $1,400 and $1,500 per tonne, while shrimp prices may stay flat due to higher supply from neighboring countries. The sector is expected to benefit from rising demand for meat and a shortage of swine supply in China and Vietnam. Despite this, the overall Thai food sector is predicted to see improved earnings in 2020 due to a low base. The analyst maintains a "market weight" rating on the sector.

site_title: China spends 202b yuan on pampering pets as birthrate slows
summary: China is expected to spend 202 billion yuan (S$39 billion) on pet care this year, a 19% increase from 2018, as the country's birthrate slows and pet ownership grows. The Asian nation now has the world's largest dog and cat population, with 188 million pets, surpassing the US. Pet owners in China, mostly women, consider their pets as family members and spend lavishly on their pets, with gourmet meals and premium products. However, concerns arise about the environmental impact of pet meat consumption and unregulated breeding practices.

site_title: Exxon's Texas refinery shuts large crude unit to repair leak
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp shut the large crude distillation unit at its Beaumont, Texas, refinery due to a leak. The unit, which processes 369,024 barrels per day, is expected to be repaired before restarting operations. The company had previously completed a two-month overhaul of other units, including a hydrocracker and reformer. Exxon continues to meet its contractual commitments despite the shutdown.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.6% in November in biggest month-on-month rise this year: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.6% in November, the biggest month-on-month increase this year, according to SRX Property. This follows a 0.5% rise in January. Non-mature estates saw a 2% year-on-year increase, while mature estates fell 2%. The volume of sales cooled 13.5% from October, but was 1.6% higher compared to last year. The most expensive resale flat sold for S$1.08 million, with buyers underpaying by an estimated S$1,000 on average.

site_title: India central bank keeps rates on hold in surprise move
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, kept interest rates unchanged at 5.15% in a surprise move, defying expectations of a sixth consecutive rate cut. The benchmark repo rate remains at a nine-year low, despite a contraction in consumer demand and manufacturing activity, and a decline in India's economy to 4.5% growth in the July-September period. The central bank also lowered its annual growth forecast to 5% from 6.1%. The decision was seen as a response to a sudden spike in retail inflation and the government's efforts to kickstart the economy.

site_title: Nike, 3M seek new weapon in battle against counterfeit goods
summary: Nike and 3M are seeking enhanced powers to block imports of counterfeit goods at the US border. The companies support draft legislation that would allow US Customs and Border Protection to seize goods believed to infringe patented designs. Currently, patent owners must go through a trial process, which can be slow and expensive. The proposal aims to extend design patent protections to 3.3% of global commerce, with the majority coming from China. If passed, the measure could help combat sophisticated counterfeiting methods, including products with removable logos.

site_title: Grab launches GrabPay card to tap Asean's US$300b digital economy
summary: Grab has launched the GrabPay Card, a virtual wallet that allows users to spend on a card, with a Mastercard partnership enabling borderless payments for 53 million merchants worldwide. The card is available in Singapore and will be rolled out in the Philippines and two other Asean markets in 2020. The card has no printed card number, offering added protection against fraud, and users can set a monthly budget and receive free mobile phone protection and e-commerce purchase protection. This move aims to bring financial inclusion to the rising middle-class in Asean, with the digital payments market expected to reach $300 billion by 2025.

site_title: Biotherapeutics startup Hummingbird raises US$19m in Series B funding
summary: Singapore-based biotherapeutics startup Hummingbird Bioscience has raised US$19 million in a Series B funding round co-led by Mirae Asset Venture Investment and GNTech Venture Capital. Existing investors joined the round, while new investors included Delian Capital and Kiwoom Investment-Shinhan Capital. The funding will support Hummingbird's discovery of new disease targets and expansion of its pipeline antibody therapeutics, with the startup expecting two assets to enter first-in-human clinical trials in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Euro zone bond yields inch up on US-China trade hopes
summary: Euro zone bond yields rose on Wednesday as reports of a potential US-China trade deal fueled a sell-off in "safe" assets, with yields inched up around 3 basis points. This followed comments from US President Donald Trump that a trade deal may not happen for another year. Despite mixed US data, euro zone yields rose, with German 10-year bond yields turning positive after being in negative territory. Yields across the euro area also rose, with US 10-year Treasury yields up 7.5 basis points.

site_title: Aged 50 and buying a home? Trend catches Deutsche Bank's eye
summary: The median age of US home buyers has increased to 47, driven by an aging population, affordability issues, higher student debt, and tighter mortgage lending standards. This trend has contributed to lower residential mobility and an eight-year gain in median home-buyer age since the financial crisis. Deutsche Bank economist Torsten Slok attributes the trend to broader generational inequality, affecting income, wealth accumulation, education, healthcare, and access to healthcare. This shift is expected to impact the housing market, with Toll Brothers benefiting from the trend.

site_title: Tesla competitor NIO launches another SUV in China
summary: NIO, a Chinese electric-car startup, has launched its third SUV model in China, targeting the slowing EV market. The new electric SUV coupe competes with vehicles like the Mercedes-Benz GLC Coupe and Tesla's Model Y. Despite facing cash struggles, NIO aims to sell hundreds of cars a month, making the product niche but potentially viable. The company has reduced its workforce and burned through $5 billion in four years, impacting fundraising for EV startups in China. NIO's stock has dropped 60% since its initial public offering last year.

site_title: British banks help keep coal industry alive, says Greenpeace
summary: Four British banks, Barclays, HSBC Holdings, Standard Chartered, and Royal Bank of Scotland Group, provided $31.8 billion in financing to coal companies between 2016 and 2019, despite publicly moving away from the industry. The environmental group Greenpeace says this funding is keeping the coal industry alive. The banks claim to have stopped lending to new coal-fired power plants and are instead financing renewable energy projects. However, Greenpeace disputes Barclays' methodology, highlighting the discrepancy between the banks' actions and their funding of coal companies.

site_title: Alita Resources refinances debt with A$70m loan from prospective Chinese buyer
summary: Alita Resources, a lithium miner, has refinanced its debt with a $70 million loan from China Hydrogen Energy Limited (CHE), a special purpose vehicle for an unidentified Chinese party. The loan repays a defaulted $40 million loan from Galaxy Resources and provides short-term bridging finance. A deed of company arrangement (DOCA) proposal will be submitted for consideration by creditors on December 16, which is believed to deliver a superior outcome for creditors.

site_title: Thakral Corp sets up JV to invest in Japan properties
summary: Thakral Corp has set up a joint venture (JV) to invest in properties in Japan, with collective direct shareholdings of about 79.1% in the new subsidiaries. The JV, Thakral Umeda Properties, aims to acquire, own, and manage properties in Osaka, capitalizing on Japan's strong economic fundamentals and tourism boom. The move is part of the company's overall strategy to diversify its asset and earnings base in Japan, enhancing shareholder value.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on trade deal optimism; NZ markets gain
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to 6,664.20, rebounding after US President Donald Trump eased investor concerns about the interim trade deal with China. Trump stated that discussions were going "very well," despite uncertainty over new tariffs. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also rose 0.5% to 11,266.17. The gains were driven by advances in the financial, mining, and energy sectors, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto rising 1.7% and 1.3%, respectively.

site_title: Singtel Optus deputy takes over the reins as CEO designate
summary: Singtel has named Kelly Bayer Rosmarin as CEO designate of both Optus and Consumer Australia, replacing Allen Lew. Bayer Rosmarin will join the Singtel management committee in April 2020 and has driven customer experience improvements and market share growth at Optus. She previously held senior roles at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and has been named among the Top 10 businesswomen in Australia and Top 25 women in Asia-Pacific finance. Lew will take on new roles as CEO of group strategy and business development and country chief officer for Thailand.

site_title: E-sports: Ferrari end the season with a title, unlike in real F1
summary: Ferrari's e-sports team, Ferrari e-Sports, won the F1 Pro Series championship, marking the team's first title in the virtual racing world. This achievement contrasts with the team's struggles in the real Formula One racing world, where they have not won a drivers' title since 2007. Ferrari's e-sports outfit took the top spot in the team trophy, surpassing Mercedes and Red Bull.

site_title: China hot-rolled steel coil rises for 6th day amid falling inventories
summary: China's hot-rolled steel coil futures rose for the 6th consecutive day, increasing 1.5% to 3,647 yuan (S$704.30) a tonne, amid falling inventories and a rebound in factory activity. Inventory levels reached 203.5 million tonnes, the lowest since January 18. The PMI data, which measures factory activity, showed a 50.2 reading, its highest since March, supporting steel prices. Experts expect further price improvements due to bullish market expectations.

site_title: Ikea invests in US logistics startup Optoro to better manage product returns
summary: Ikea has invested in US logistics startup Optoro to better manage product returns. The investment will help Ikea roll out Optoro's reverse logistics technology to its US distribution centers, stores, and customer support center. This move aims to tackle the growing issue of product returns, which are costly, logistically challenging, and environmentally negative. The technology will be expanded to other markets, addressing the increasing headache for retailers as shopping moves online.

site_title: Hong Kong bankers say city's divide is infecting office life
summary: Hong Kong bankers are facing increasing pressure to conform to their employers' political views due to the city's pro-democracy protests. Several have reported being pushed out of their jobs or facing retribution for their views, with some fearing retaliation from superiors. The divide is affecting office life, with some employees avoiding discussions about the protests or limiting their interactions with colleagues who hold differing views. Financial firms must balance employee professionalism with accommodating diverse perspectives, posing challenges to maintaining a positive and inclusive work environment.

site_title: Takata recalls 1.4 million more air bags
summary: Takata, the parts supplier behind the largest auto recall, has recalled an additional 1.4 million vehicles due to a defect linked to the death of a BMW driver and two other injuries in overseas markets. The recall involves air bags supplied to five major car manufacturers, including BMW, Volkswagen AG, Toyota, Honda, and Mitsubishi Motors, and affects vehicles produced from 1995 to 1999. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has reported one fatality and one injury in the US linked to the faulty air-bag inflators, with BMW recommending 8,000 vehicles be fixed before driving.

site_title: Microsoft shareholders vote against gender pay gap proposal
summary: Microsoft shareholders rejected a proposal to report more detailed information on employee pay gaps by gender and race, with less than 30% of shares voting in favor. The measure, tabled by Arjuna Capital, aimed to provide a precise statistical breakdown of pay disparities. Despite praising Microsoft's progress, the proposal's defeat suggests shareholders may not prioritize transparency on these issues.

site_title: Australia to trim government as PM demands policy delivery
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced plans to cut government departments from 18 to 14, effective February 1, 2020, to focus on policy continuity and service delivery. The changes include mergers between departments such as education and employment, agriculture and environment, and industry, innovation, and science with energy. Despite the reduction, Morrison will not cut the number of ministers in his cabinet. The goal is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of government services.

site_title: Petrobras plans US$34b in dividends by 2024 as debt shrinks
summary: Petrobras plans to pay US$34 billion in dividends by 2024, marking a significant shift from its previous minimal payouts. The state-controlled oil producer aims to reduce debt to 1.5 times earnings before certain items by the end of 2020. CEO Roberto Castello Branco has implemented cost-cutting measures and increased crude output to achieve this goal. Petrobras has already reduced its net debt to US$75 billion and has turned a profit since 2018. The company plans to pay US$3 billion in dividends next year, with payments increasing after 2021.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.47%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.47% on Thursday, driven by positive US market sentiment after US President Donald Trump mentioned progress in US-China trade talks. The Straits Times Index gained 14.74 points to 3,174.53. Gainers outnumbered losers 92 to 20, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB advancing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, while Europe and Asia followed suit, driven by optimism over the US-China trade deal.

site_title: Razer's fintech arm adds ex-DBS innovation chief to board of advisers
summary: Razer Fintech has appointed Neal Cross, former DBS innovation chief, to its advisory board. Cross, who co-founded Perth-based fintech PictureWealth, brings experience driving digital transformation to the lender. His appointment follows recent additions to Razer Fintech's board, including veteran corporate leader Koh Boon Hwee and former GIC president Lim Siong Guan. Razer co-founder Tan Min-Liang expressed excitement over Cross's joining the board, citing his innovative ideas and experience to guide the company's expansion into financial and digital banking services.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Sembcorp, Mapletree NAC Trust, Straits Trading, AHS
summary: Keppel Reit secured an unsecured S$150 million green loan facility from OCBC Bank, its second green loan facility. Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned subsidiary acquired the remaining 5.95% stake in Sembcorp Energy India Limited for S$77 million. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) closed 0.4% higher, driven by investors' positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Manna Tree invests in Nutriati as meat substitutes sizzle
summary: Manna Tree Partners, led by Gabrielle Rubenstein, has invested $12.7 million in Nutriati, a plant-based ingredient maker. This investment is part of the growing market for meat substitutes and gluten-free foods, following the success of Beyond Meat's IPO earlier this year. Nutriati sells ingredients used by food producers, and expects to grow revenues fivefold in 2019 and 10 times in 2020, with plans to expand capacity to meet market demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, driven by reports that China and the US were nearing a mini trade deal, easing concerns about a potential delay. The Hang Seng index increased 0.62%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The news followed a day of Trump's comments suggesting a deal might not happen until next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 7.63 points, or 0.49%, to 1,554.64 at 9:06 am on Thursday. The market saw 108.9 million lots traded, with losers beating gainers 153 to 95.

site_title: Indonesia preps US$40b to extend metro network
summary: Indonesia plans to spend approximately $40 billion to extend its metro network in Jakarta, aiming to add six new lines to the existing one, targeting 230 kilometers by 2030. This ambitious plan, part of President Joko Widodo's goal to create a $7 trillion economy by 2045, is expected to boost construction companies and reignite a rivalry between China and Japan. The project requires international funding and assistance, with both countries likely to compete for the contract.

site_title: US private hiring slows sharply in November
summary: US private hiring slowed sharply in November, with a 67,000 net new position increase, the weakest pace in seven months. Economists had expected an increase of 175,000. The slowdown is attributed to manufacturers, commodity producers, and retailers shedding jobs, leading to a decline in job openings and a potential increase in unemployment. The data may not reflect the government's employment report, which is expected to show a stronger jobs market.

site_title: Gucci owner Kering holds exploratory talks on deal for luxury skiwear maker Moncler
summary: Kering, the owner of Gucci and Saint Laurent, has held exploratory talks with Moncler, a luxury skiwear maker, about a potential deal. The talks come as Moncler's shares have risen 33% this year, giving it a market value of around $15.1 billion. A deal would require Kering founder Francois Pinault to win over Moncler's largest shareholder, Remo Ruffini. The acquisition would help Kering keep pace with rival LVMH, which recently bought Tiffany & Co for $16.2 billion, and would give Kering a label with significant growth potential.

site_title: Oil jumps 3% on US stockpiles drop; further Opec output cuts seen
summary: Oil prices surged 3% on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up $2.18 and WTI crude futures up $2.33, amid expectations of Opec and allied producers extending production curbs. US crude stocks fell 4.9 million barrels, exceeding forecasts. Analysts predict Opec+ will deepen cuts, with Iraqi oil minister Thamer Ghadhban supporting a roll-over of existing cuts. Despite uncertainty over a US-China trade deal, oil prices rose as Wall Street's main indices rose for the first time in four sessions.

site_title: Starbucks discloses gender and racial pay gap: There isn't one
summary: Starbucks has disclosed that it has no gender or racial pay gap, contrary to the US average of a 19% pay gap between men and women. Globally, female employees make 98.3% of what men do. The coffee chain joins Citigroup in reporting median pay figures, a rarity among US companies. Starbucks' parity in pay shows that women have achieved as many high-paying roles as men and have been compensated fairly. The company has prioritized pay equity and has made efforts to ensure women and men are compensated equally.

site_title: LinkedIn chief people officer leaves over compliance issues
summary: LinkedIn's chief people officer Christina Hall has resigned due to an internal compliance issue. Hall, who led the company's human resources team for six years, left the Microsoft-owned company after breaking compliance rules. LinkedIn's CEO Jeff Weiner announced the move to staff on Tuesday. Hall's interim replacement is Nina McQueen, who will oversee the global talent organization. Microsoft acquired LinkedIn in 2016 for $26.2 billion. The company is conducting an internal and external search for a permanent replacement.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler agrees to costly pay bumps for lower-wage workers
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) agreed to a four-year pay package worth $29,500 in wage increases and bonuses for its lower-wage workers, with newer hires reaching the top hourly rate by 2023. The deal also widens a pathway for temporary workers to become full-time employees, with about 3,800 temporary workers expected to become full-time next year. The pact comes after Fiat Chrysler posted double-digit profit margins in North America last quarter, and is seen as a response to pressure from General Motors' lawsuit alleging bribery and tainted labor contracts.

site_title: Beijing should let anti-mask case go through HK judiciary
summary: Beijing has suggested allowing Hong Kong to handle the case of anti-mask protests, which led to a high court ruling declaring the law unconstitutional. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam has indicated that her administration would not take action against the US without a directive from Beijing. The US had imposed sanctions on five NGOs accused of encouraging violent acts, but the measures seemed symbolic. Beijing's stance on the issue appears to be a test of Hong Kong's judicial independence, with the case set to proceed to the Court of Appeal.

site_title: US, China move closer to trade deal despite harsh rhetoric
summary: The US and China are moving closer to a phase-one trade deal despite recent harsh rhetoric. US President Donald Trump has downplayed the urgency of the deal, but officials from both sides say talks are making progress. Outstanding issues include guaranteeing China's purchases of US agricultural goods and determining which tariffs to roll back. The US is expected to complete a phase-one deal before American tariffs rise on December 15, and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi expressed hope for a deal based on mutual respect and consultations.

site_title: US: Wall Street bounces back on renewed trade optimism
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, snapping a three-day losing streak, as investor optimism boosted by President Donald Trump's comments on US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 146.97 points, the S&P 500 gained 19.57 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 46.03 points. Financial, healthcare, and tariff-sensitive technology stocks led the rally, despite weak November data from ADP and the Institute for Supply Management's PMI report. Investors remain optimistic about solid underlying market fundamentals and a "phase one" trade deal.

site_title: Democrat Kamala Harris ends 2020 White House bid
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris ended her 2020 White House bid on December 3, 2019, after underperforming in the crowded field and failing to raise sufficient funds. Her exit leaves 15 candidates vying for the presidency, with the general election set for November 2020.

site_title: Bye-bye, birdie: Study finds North American birds getting smaller
summary: A study of 70,716 birds killed in Chicago between 1978 and 2016 found that their average body sizes declined by 2.6% and leg bone length dropped by 2.4% over the four decades, while wingspans increased by 1.3%. The decline is attributed to climate change, with warmer temperatures causing birds to become smaller, possibly to enable continued long migrations. The study suggests that this trend may be widespread and consistent across North American bird species.

site_title: Singapore recalls 3 versions of metformin as diabetes drugs come under carcinogen scrutiny
summary: The US FDA and European Medicines Agency (EMA) are testing metformin for carcinogenic impurities, specifically NDMA. Singapore has recalled three versions of metformin due to NDMA levels above acceptable limits. The FDA is testing metformin samples in the US and may recommend recalls if NDMA levels exceed the acceptable daily intake limit of 96 nanograms. The EMA advises patients to continue taking metformin as prescribed, with no confirmed cases of cancer linked to the medication. The recall affects globally produced metformin, and manufacturers are being asked to test for NDMA in ranitidine and nizatidine medications.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump 1% as report revives US-China trade optimism
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Wednesday, rebounding from a four-day slump, after a report suggested Beijing and Washington are moving closer to a phase one trade deal. The STOXX 600 index closed at a one-month high, with financials and industrials leading the charge. Chipmakers and semiconductor companies also gained, while luxury stocks firmed up after a rough day on Tuesday. However, some stocks, such as French telecoms company Orange, fell due to disappointment over the firm's dividend outlook.

site_title: Private equity buys US$101b of European businesses
summary: Private equity firms have been actively buying European businesses, with US$101 billion in deals completed or pending as of December 2019. Low interest rates and cheap valuations have made the region an attractive target for these firms, which aim to reap double-digit returns. The trend is expected to continue, driven by the large amount of "dry powder" held by buyout firms. This influx of private equity investment has been facilitated by the region's cheap valuations, making it a "honeypot" for these funds.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Franchising bruise-free boxing
summary: Spartans Boxing Club is raising $1 million for its franchise, aiming to bring bruise-free boxing to everyone in Asia, the Middle East, Australia, and Europe. The club, led by managing director Russell Harrison, is targeting potential franchisees in these regions. Spartans Boxing Club aims to make boxing accessible to all, whether professionally or for fitness, with the goal of becoming a global brand.

site_title: Leshan Gardens in Geylang sold for S$26.28m
summary: Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital sold Leshan Gardens in Geylang for S$26.28 million, working out to S$623 per square foot per plot ratio. The 38-unit residential development is on a 104-year leasehold tenure, with an existing 20-year-old building and potential for redevelopment into a project with up to 50 units. The sale price includes an estimated development charge of S$2.35 million, and the buyer is an ear, nose, throat specialist doctor who also engages in property business.

site_title: F&N lays groundwork on S$80m integrated F&B facility in Tuas
summary: F&N Foods, a subsidiary of Fraser and Neave, is building an S$80 million integrated food and beverage facility in Tuas, Singapore, set for completion in late 2021. The 375,000 square foot facility aims to boost innovation efforts.

site_title: Greenback trades near one-month lows
summary: The US dollar traded near one-month lows on Wednesday due to market uncertainty over the Sino-US trade talks and US data. A Bloomberg report suggested the two sides are close to agreeing on phase-one tariffs, boosting the offshore-Chinese yuan by 0.2%. The dollar's weakness contrasts with the yuan's gain, which reached 7.05.

site_title: Expedia CEO, CFO resign after clash over strategy with board
summary: Expedia Group CEO Mark Okerstrom and CFO Alan Pickerill have resigned following a disagreement with the board over the company's business outlook. Chairman Barry Diller cited disappointing third-quarter results and a "lackluster" near-term outlook as reasons for the change. The company's shares rose 8% after the surprise resignations, as Diller expressed faith in the company's long-term future and plans to oversee executive leadership until a replacement is found. Diller will also purchase additional shares, a move seen as a show of commitment to the company's future.

site_title: Iswaran rolls out S$20m fund, partnerships to boost media hub status
summary: Singapore's Communications and Information Minister S Iswaran has rolled out a S$20 million fund, called the Financing Partnership Programme, to support media projects and develop talent in the Asian media hub. The fund aims to finance projects such as television shows, movies, and animated features, with no restrictions on types of projects. The programme is part of initiatives to boost Singapore's media status, including a public service media digital partnership fund and a south-east Asia co-production grant. The goal is to increase collaborations between local and international players, and to establish Singapore as a gateway for regional talent.

site_title: Firms move legal battles from protest-hit Hong Kong in fresh setback for business
summary: Firms are shifting arbitration hearings from Hong Kong due to safety concerns amid pro-democracy protests, which have pushed the city's economy into recession. This move could dent Hong Kong's position as a top arbitration hub, with cases moving to Singapore. At least two cases have already relocated, with more possible, as international firms seek neutral sites with trusted legal systems. The unrest risks undermining Hong Kong's reputation as a good place to do business.

site_title: Google's move to replace CEO raises new questions about company's structure
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet Inc, has appointed Sundar Pichai as the CEO of both the corporate parent and Google, replacing Larry Page and Sergey Brin. This change removes a potential split authority issue but raises questions about Pichai's ability to handle the demanding role. As a relatively untested executive, Pichai must balance making tough decisions and navigating complex politics, including dealing with governments and workforce divisions. The Alphabet structure, created in 2015 to separate Google's projects, may also be reevaluated as tech companies have more flexibility to invest in various ventures.

site_title: Will we rue letting genie out of bottle with gene therapy to make babies?
summary: Scientists are advancing human fertility treatment, creating ethical dilemmas worldwide. A Greek woman gave birth to a boy through a three-parent treatment, sparking debate on the use of gene therapy to make babies. Critics fear this technique could lead to "designer babies" and a slippery slope towards creating smarter offspring on demand. As fertility treatment becomes more accessible, Singapore is reviewing its ban on egg freezing, and some companies claim to predict the intelligence of embryos. Economically, breeding super humans may seem appealing, but it raises concerns of genetic modification and blurring the line between humans and genetically-modified crops.

site_title: COEs end mostly lower
summary: Singapore's latest COE (Certificate of Entitlement) tender saw mostly lower prices, with only the COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ending higher at S$33,009. COEs for larger vehicles and commercial vehicles decreased, with open COEs and motorcycle premiums also falling. Industry sources attribute the lower prices to motor dealers fulfilling their sales targets for the year and collecting orders for next year, causing a surge in demand for COEs near the end of the bidding period.

site_title: Thai stock exchange expects more listings of foreign Reits
summary: The Stock Exchange of Thailand expects more foreign real estate investment trusts (Reits) to list on the exchange, tapping long-term funds from neighboring countries. Authorities aim to expand investment alternatives for locals and foreigners amid slowing domestic growth. Companies from Laos, Cambodia, and Myanmar are being approached to raise funds through asset spinoffs, with Myanmar seen as having the highest potential. The move aims to attract Thai investors seeking stable income and high growth, as domestic growth slows and interest rates remain low.

site_title: China warns US over Uighur bill, raising doubts over early trade deal
summary: China has warned the US that a new bill targeting its treatment of Uighur Muslims will affect bilateral cooperation and cloud the prospects for a near-term trade deal, raising doubts about a quick resolution to the ongoing trade war. The bill, passed by the US House of Representatives, requires the US president to condemn abuse against Muslims and call for the closure of mass detention camps in Xinjiang. China has called the bill a malicious attack on its interests and has threatened to take "decisive" countermeasures if the US continues its protectionism and bullying over trade.

site_title: HSBC Jade brings clients to Borneo rainforest to learn about climate change
summary: HSBC's Jade clients embarked on a week-long Sustainability Expedition in Malaysia's Borneo rainforest, learning about climate change and sustainable investing through hands-on experiences. The program, aimed at high net-worth individuals, included visits to orangutans, pygmy elephants, and tree planting, as well as discussions on ESG investing and its role in a low-carbon economy. The program follows HSBC's report finding 80% of Asian investors prioritize ESG factors, highlighting a growing interest in sustainable living and investing in the region.

site_title: Fuisland presses on in environmental, youth causes
summary: Fuisland Offset Print, a Singapore-based printer, prioritizes environmental sustainability and corporate social responsibility (CSR). The company uses eco-friendly paper, vegetable ink, and recycling practices to minimize waste and carbon footprint. Fuisland has achieved near-carbon neutrality and switched to solar energy, reducing its carbon footprint by 71.4 tonnes. The company also engages in CSR initiatives, such as partnering with charitable organizations, supporting education, and promoting sustainable practices. Fuisland's managing director, Png Eng Lee, emphasizes the importance of CSR and sustainability in business, encouraging employees and partners to adopt environmentally friendly practices.

site_title: Steer your own learning journey
summary: Accountant Jing Li Yim chose the CPA Program offered by CPA Australia to stay updated with the latest developments in her field. With over 164,000 members worldwide, CPA Australia is one of the world's largest professional accounting bodies. The program provides a structured approach to learning and staying current with changing regulations, tax laws, and accounting standards. This strategic decision will help Li Yim navigate the complexities of her role and provide better services to her clients.

site_title: France's Bollore opens S$100m high-tech facility in Jurong
summary: France's Bollore Logistics has opened a S$100 million, fully-automated facility in Jurong, Singapore, dubbed the Blue Hub. The facility aims to improve operational efficiency in handling goods for businesses in the perfume and cosmetics sector, utilizing robotics and digital technologies. The project marks a significant investment by Bollore in Singapore, cementing the country's reputation as a global logistics hub. The facility will also serve as a hub for innovation and research, with partnerships with local institutes of higher learning and startups.

images.alt_text: Cyrille Bollore, chairman and CEO of Bollore Group, with Senior Minister of Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat on a tour of the facilities in the Blue Hub.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Reit secured an unsecured S$150 million green loan facility from OCBC Bank, its second green loan facility, following a S$505 million green loan facility in June.

site_title: Cross Island Line to run under nature reserve
summary: The Singapore government has decided to run the Cross Island Line under the central catchment nature reserve, instead of skirting around it, after considering the findings from an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) study and public consultations. The direct alignment will reduce commuting time by six minutes and lower public transport fares by 15%, while also resulting in lower construction costs of about S$2 billion. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will tunnel 70m underground to minimize environmental impact, and two worksites will be located outside the nature reserve.

site_title: Surface parking lots are now hot property across the US
summary: Surface parking lots are experiencing a surge in sales across the US, with over 200 transactions in 2016, more than double the amount from 2006-2014. Developers are buying these underutilized lots, often in urban areas, to capitalize on the booming real estate market. Analysts attribute the trend to increasing property values and the desire to build on prime sites. However, a report by IBISWorld forecasts a decline in annual revenue growth to 0.2% until 2024, as traffic congestion, carpooling, and public transportation usage increase, reducing the need for parking facilities.

site_title: Yes, climate-smart investing can be done
summary: The COP25 UN Climate Change Conference in Madrid highlights the urgent need for collective action to combat climate change. Climate-smart investing offers a promising alternative to traditional investments, with the potential to mitigate risks and create shared value for all stakeholders. The Asian Development Bank estimates that South-east Asia will face an 11% GDP dip by the end of the century due to climate change, but investing in renewable sources and climate-resilient projects can help. The growing trillion-dollar market for climate-smart investment opportunities provides a significant alternative to traditional investments, with examples such as the Althelia Climate Fund and RECOFTC. To unlock sufficient capital, enabling developing countries to access debt capital for climate-resilient economic development is crucial, and green bonds represent a promising tool.

site_title: Small galleries assess benefits of big art fairs
summary: Art galleries are reassessing the benefits of participating in big international art fairs, weighing the costs of exposure against financial viability. Smaller galleries face significant expenses, with costs ranging from €60,000 to €16,000 for participation. To address this, Art Basel has introduced a sliding scale pricing model and discounts for first-time participants, aiming to make these events more accessible to emerging galleries. While some galleries have reported limited sales, others see attending fairs as a long-term investment for building connections and growing their artists' careers.

site_title: MNACT buying 2 Tokyo offices that will help mitigate revenue loss from Festival Walk closure
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) has acquired two Tokyo office properties, the mBay Point Makuhari Building and Omori Prime Building, for S$482.5 million. The acquisition aims to diversify MNACT's portfolio and mitigate revenue loss from the closure of its Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong. The properties have a 4.5% net property income yield and are expected to contribute to the trust's distributable income. MNACT plans to finance the acquisition through new unit issuance, debt financing, and internal cash resources, and hopes to reopen Festival Walk in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Could Labour score surprise election win?
summary: The UK general election on December 12 is expected to be closely contested, with polls tightening in the final days. Labour's chances of winning a surprise victory are considered small, but possible, especially if tactical voting increases and the campaign focuses on issues beyond Brexit. The Tories are seeking a "safety-first" campaign to avoid mistakes made by Theresa May in 2017. A Labour-led government could emerge if the Conservatives fail to secure an overall majority, potentially leading to a new EU referendum. The election's outcome is uncertain, with factors such as voter turnout, Remain/Leave voting, and the framing of the ballot all playing a role.

site_title: New tax rules for foreign companies with Indonesian online business
summary: Indonesia has introduced new tax rules for foreign companies operating online businesses in the country. Effective immediately, firms with a significant economic presence must appoint a representative in Indonesia and pay all applicable taxes. This regulation aims to boost the country's booming internet economy, which is projected to reach $130 billion by 2025. The move is seen as a step to increase tax revenue and ensure fair taxation for foreign companies operating in Indonesia.

site_title: Gifting as part of the legacy
summary: Noel Gifts International Ltd, a Singapore-based company, has been conducting floral workshops for the elderly at St Luke's ElderCare (SLEC) centers as part of its corporate social responsibility (CSR) efforts. The 10-week program, which started in July, aims to bring joy and interaction to the elderly participants. The company's managing director, Alfred Wong, emphasizes the importance of CSR, stating that it is about aligning the company with its community and creating a positive impact. Noel Gifts' CSR initiatives have been ongoing since 1998, with various activities, including raising money for charities and reducing waste in their packaging.

site_title: I'm dreaming of a green Christmas
summary: A growing trend is emerging as people shift towards a more sustainable Christmas, with eco-friendly alternatives to traditional practices. Experts such as Bjorn Low and Tan Szue Hann suggest ways to reduce waste, including buying ethically-raised meat, upcycling gifts, and shopping from sustainable brands. Locavore restaurant owner Eelke Plasmeijer emphasizes the importance of balancing indulgence with sustainable habits, while others highlight unique dining experiences and innovative home decor ideas. As sustainability becomes a luxury, individuals are redefining what it means to celebrate a "green" Christmas.

site_title: Investors to see more useful data in mandatory sustainability reports
summary: Singapore's SGX Regulation aims to improve the usefulness of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) data in mandatory sustainability reports for investors. The current framework allows companies to choose material matters to report on, making data less comparable. To address this, SGX RegCo plans to engage investors globally for their views on improving report quality. However, some experts caution against a rigid framework, emphasizing the need for more guidance and mandates in certain areas. The average sustainability reporting score among 495 listed issuers is 60.6 out of 100, with room for improvement, particularly on climate change.

site_title: Google's Sundar Pichai named CEO at parent firm Alphabet
summary: Google's Sundar Pichai has been named CEO at parent firm Alphabet, replacing Larry Page, amid controversies surrounding the company's dominance in the tech world. Pichai, 47, takes over at a time when the company faces antitrust investigations, privacy concerns, and allegations of failing to address workplace issues. Pichai brings humility and a passion for technology, according to Page and co-founder Sergey Brin, who will continue as co-founders and board members. The move signals the founders' willingness to step aside and allow a new leader to navigate the company's challenges.

site_title: STI dips further as hopes for trade deal fade
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 13.29 points or 0.4% to close at 3,159.79 on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous session. The decline was attributed to US President Donald Trump's statement that a US-China trade deal might not happen until after the 2020 US presidential elections. The local benchmark did not fare as badly as its regional peers, with Australia's ASX 200 dropping 1.6% and China's Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.3%.

site_title: Keppel Reit obtains unsecured S$150m green loan facility
summary: Keppel Reit, the manager of the real estate investment trust, has secured a S$150 million green loan facility from OCBC Bank. This is the company's second green loan facility, following a S$505 million green loan facility obtained in June. The loan will be used to finance or refinance eligible green projects and grow Keppel Reit's green building portfolio. The company has also established a Green Loan Framework to guide its green funding sources, aiming to build a sustainable future.

site_title: Hong Kong IPOs enjoying hottest quarter since 2015
summary: Hong Kong initial public offerings (IPOs) are experiencing their hottest quarter since 2015, with companies raising a total of US$36.6 billion in fundraising for first-time share sales. The median retail subscription ratio for IPOs since October is 13 times, the highest since 2015. This surge in fundraising comes as the Hang Seng Index remains flat for the year, despite the strong demand from retail investors. The city is on track to surpass 2018's fundraising record, which stood at US$36.3 billion.

site_title: It's not easy being a green oil company
summary: Repsol, a sixth-largest European oil company, has set a goal to become carbon neutral by 2050. However, achieving this goal is uncertain due to factors outside its control, such as global demand for fossil fuels and the cost of carbon extraction. The company will prioritize value and cash generation, focusing on profitable refinery operations and investing in technologies that can reduce carbon emissions. Repsol's strategy relies on emerging technologies and carbon offsetting, but it faces significant challenges in achieving its goal, and its ability to transition to a genuinely clean oil company remains to be proven.

site_title: US$106m Singapore-based fund to keep plastic from Asian oceans
summary: Circulate Capital has launched a US$106 million fund focused on preventing plastic from entering Asia's oceans. The fund aims to achieve a mid to high single-digit internal rate of return, with a strategy to catalyze more investments in the area. It will invest in startups and SMEs across the plastics value chain in countries such as India, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with the goal of reducing plastic leakage in Asia. The fund's success will help draw bigger investors, with the ultimate goal of capitalizing the initial US$100 million into a billion dollars.

site_title: FWD to pull out of employee benefits business in Singapore
summary: FWD Group, the insurance arm of Hong Kong's Pacific Century Group, will wind down its employee benefits business in Singapore by December 2020, impacting over 80,000 members. The decision was made to focus on other lines of business for stronger future growth. FWD will no longer pitch for new contracts and won't renew existing ones, but will maintain its direct-to-consumer business offering life and general insurance products.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as report revives trade deal hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday as a report suggested the US and China were moving closer to signing a 'phase-one' trade deal. The Dow Jones rose 131.82 points, the S&P 500 gained 10.30 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 36.80 points. The positive start comes despite ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Seven companies added to SGX watch list from Dec 4
summary: Seven Singapore companies, including ASL Marine Holdings and XMH Holdings, have been added to the SGX watch list as of December 4, 2019, due to failing to meet financial entry criteria. The criteria include recording pre-tax losses for three consecutive years and failing to maintain a minimum average daily market cap of S$40 million over six months. To exit the watch list, the companies must record a consolidated pre-tax profit within 36 months and meet the market cap requirement. Failure to comply will result in delisting or trading suspension.

site_title: Collaboration is key to ride Asian student accommodation wave
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is experiencing a surge in university enrollment, driven by an expanding middle-class and increasing demand for tertiary education. This growth is expected to continue at a 4.2% per year pace until 2040, with East Asia and the Pacific accounting for the highest volume and largest share. Purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) is emerging as a lucrative investment opportunity, with institutional investors seeking to diversify away from traditional residential real estate investments. Collaboration between developers, investors, and operators is crucial to meet the growing demand for PBSA, which can provide a better overall student experience and contribute to local economic growth.

site_title: Mega projects to fuel Singapore's long-term tourism
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to continue growing, driven by mega projects such as the Mandai eco-tourism hub, Jurong Lake District, and the Greater Southern Waterfront development. The country's integrated resorts have been successful, with Jewel Changi Airport drawing over 50 million visitors since its opening. Despite global slowdown and regional competition, analysts remain optimistic, citing the potential for Singapore to benefit from mainland Chinese tourists shifting away from Hong Kong and Taiwan. The government is working to promote the country as a tourist destination, particularly through its neighboring countries, to maintain its long-term tourism momentum.

site_title: HK business downturn at its steepest in 21 years
summary: Hong Kong's business activity contracted at its fastest pace in 21 years in November, with a seasonally adjusted Hong Kong Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) of 38.5, down from 39.3 in October. The decline was driven by anti-government protests and softening global demand, with companies scaling back purchases of raw materials and citing political unrest and the US-China trade war. Retail sales fell 24.3% and tourist arrivals plummeted 44% in October. Economists predict a hard-landing recession, with GDP growth forecast to decline by 5.8% in 2020, unless a dramatic recovery occurs in December.

site_title: Hakka association selling 13 semi-detached houses at Bt Timah with S$38m guide price
summary: The Fong Yun Thai Association, an umbrella body for three Hakka clans in Singapore, is selling 13 semi-detached houses at 11 Holland Link with an indicative price of S$38 million. The houses, with built-up areas ranging from 3,692 to 4,348 sq ft, have been tenanted and are available for purchase by Singaporeans only. The sale will close on Jan 17, 2020, with an average asking price of S$767 per square foot. This is a 99-year leasehold cluster landed housing project completed in 2014, located in prime District 10.

site_title: US tariffs unfair, but a deserved response to French taxes
summary: US President Donald Trump has proposed tariffs of up to 100% on French goods, worth $2.4 billion, in response to France's digital services tax. The tax, which targets multinational internet platforms, is seen as unfairly targeting US companies. The US argues that the tax is tailored to exclude French companies and favors firms domiciled in France. France, however, has taken a unilateral approach, prompting the US retaliation. The OECD is set to propose a multilateral solution, which could alleviate tensions between the US and France, and potentially lead to a global tax on internet giants.

images.alt_text: The punitive tariffs on French goods proposed by the Office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) are a disproportionate response to France's digital services tax. But that's what French President Emmanuel Macron gets for his impatience to be the first to tax multinational Internet platforms without waiting for international organisations to agree on a coordinated solution.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust to acquire 2 Tokyo office properties
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) announced the acquisition of two Tokyo office properties for S$482.5 million, expanding its portfolio to S$8.2 billion. The properties, MBP in Chiba and OPB in Tokyo, have a gross floor area of 180,941 sqm and a 4.5% net property income yield. The acquisition aims to diversify MNACT's portfolio and reduce income concentration from its Hong Kong retail mall, Festival Walk. The manager plans to finance the acquisition with a unit issuance, debt financing, and internal cash resources.

site_title: Hyundai commits 20t won to adding electric, driverless cars
summary: Hyundai Motor has committed 20 trillion won (S$22.9 billion) over six years to invest in electric and self-driving vehicle technology, with 10 trillion won focused on electrification. The company aims to achieve a 5% global market share by 2025, increasing operating margins to 8% from 2.5%. This investment comes as the automotive industry faces significant changes, with competitors like Volkswagen and General Motors also investing heavily in electric vehicles. However, the transformation will result in significant costs, including 27.9 trillion won in expenses over the next three years.

site_title: UN launches US$29b emergency funding appeal
summary: The UN launched a $29 billion emergency funding appeal due to climate change and protracted conflicts, affecting 168 million people worldwide in 2020. This marks a record in modern era, according to UN emergency relief coordinator Mark Lowcock. The appeal aims to provide food, shelter, and healthcare to those in urgent need.

site_title: Synagie, third-party service provider to undergo mediation to settle legal disputes
summary: Synagie Corporation, an e-commerce solutions provider, has commenced legal proceedings against a third-party service provider in Singapore's High Court for a breach of contract, claiming S$751,971.25. The third-party service provider has filed a counterclaim for S$1.17 million. The parties are attempting to resolve the disputes through mediation, scheduled for early 2020. Disclosures on the claims have been withheld due to concerns of adverse impact on mediation efforts. Further announcements will be made as material developments occur.

site_title: UK's Johnson stresses US ties in Huawei decision
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson emphasized intelligence ties with the US in Britain's decision on excluding Chinese firm Huawei from building new 5G networks. Johnson stated that the decision will be based on protecting critical national infrastructure and Five Eyes relationships. The UK has repeatedly delayed a decision, with the election on December 12, and Washington has pressured Europe to exclude Huawei due to its close ties to the Chinese government. Johnson's comments come after Germany tightened rules on non-EU takeovers of high-tech firms.

site_title: Hong Kong unveils US$500m more in stimulus to help businesses
summary: The Hong Kong government announced an additional US$511 million in stimulus measures to support businesses affected by six months of unrest. The measures include subsidies for water and sewer bills, property tax waivers, and installment payment options for taxes. This brings the total stimulus package to about HK$25 billion (S$4.35 billion), which economists have deemed insufficient. Hong Kong's business outlook remains low due to ongoing unrest and export weakness, with the city's GDP growth expected to slow. The government's efforts aim to alleviate pressure on businesses, but critics argue that more support is needed.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists to acquire 51% interest in Cornerstone Asia Health
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists Limited (AHS) is set to acquire a 51% interest in Cornerstone Asia Health for S$32 million. The acquisition will be satisfied by S$5 million in cash and the issuance of shares at S$0.26 apiece. The deal is in line with AHS' business strategies and aims to diversify its portfolio and strengthen its existing business. Cornerstone Asia Health operates eight specialist and family medicine clinics across various medical specializations. The acquisition is expected to provide AHS with established healthcare assets and opportunities for future growth.

site_title: COE prices end mostly lower in latest tender
summary: COE prices ended mostly lower at the latest tender, with the exception of the $33,009 premium for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp. Industry sources attribute the weak consumer sentiment to motor dealers selling out their sales targets for the year, resulting in lower premiums for bigger cars. Commercial vehicle COE prices also decreased, settling at $23,704, while motorcycle premiums dropped from $3,921 to $3,789.

site_title: Rare Gauguin fetches 9.5m euros at Paris auction
summary: A rare 1897 painting by French artist Paul Gauguin, "Te Bourao II," sold for nearly twice its estimated value of 5-7 million euros at a Paris auction, fetching 9.5 million euros. The artwork, depicting a Tahiti landscape, was bought by an "international collector" and will remain in France. The sale comes amid controversy over Gauguin's relationships with young girls in Tahiti and his depictions of them in his paintings.

images.alt_text: The 1897 painting, Te Bourao II (or "tree" in the local Tahitian language), had been expected to go for around five million to seven million euros.

site_title: A decade in tourism
summary: Singapore's tourism industry has seen significant growth over the past decade, with the country welcoming over 14 million visitors in 2019. Meanwhile, global economic trends are shifting, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for a second consecutive month. In other news, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index, and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter will be cleared to serve as prime minister in an ethics case. Key economic indicators and geopolitical developments are shaping the global landscape.

site_title: Ayondo's partner receives whitewash waiver
summary: Ayondo's partner, Golden Nugget Jinzhuan Limited, has received a whitewash waiver from the Securities Industry Council, allowing the company to avoid making a general offer for shares if its voting rights reach 30% or more. The waiver is subject to conditions, including approval from shareholders and the appointment of an independent financial adviser. This comes after Ayondo entered into three convertible note agreements worth up to S$9.9 million in August.

site_title: Sembcorp to buy remaining 5.95% stake in Sembcorp Energy India Limited
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned subsidiary, Sembcorp Utilities, has entered into a non-binding term sheet to acquire the remaining 5.95% stake in Sembcorp Energy India Limited (SEIL) for approximately S$77 million in cash. Following completion, Sembcorp will become the sole owner of SEIL, a leading independent power producer in India. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of 2019, subject to shareholder approval, and is not expected to have a material impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset value per share.

site_title: What a new scramble for Africa could mean for the continent
summary: A new scramble for Africa's resources is underway, with Russia and China seeking contracts and exclusive trade agreements. This mirrors the "Scramble for Africa" in the 1880s, where European powers, including the US, divided the continent among themselves, often at the expense of local populations. Historically, this has led to exploitation and violence, as seen in the Congo Free State, where European powers extracted ivory and wild rubber, causing widespread suffering and loss of life. African nations must balance competing offers to ensure their own people's interests are protected.

site_title: Dominant US service sector slows in November
summary: The US service sector slowed in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index falling to 53.9%, below forecasts. The sector, which accounts for the majority of the US economy, remains in better health than the manufacturing sector, which has been in contraction for four months. Despite this, the service sector showed signs of growth, with 12 industries expanding, including real estate and rental leasing. The US-China trade war continues to pose a problem, with companies hoping for a resolution on tariffs. The slowdown is seen as a sign of a weakening US economy.

site_title: Developer Iskandar Waterfront revives listing plan, aims to raise up to US$1.5b in 2020: sources
summary: Malaysian developer Iskandar Waterfront Holdings Sdn Bhd (IWH) has revived plans to go public, aiming to raise US$1 billion to US$1.5 billion in an initial public offering (IPO) in 2020. The company, which bought the Bandar Malaysia transit-oriented project from scandal-hit state investor 1MDB, plans to use the funds to move forward with the project. The IPO is contingent on the project's progress, and IWH aims to expand its profile and national footprint through the listing.

site_title: Cross Island Line to run directly under central catchment nature reserve: MOT
summary: The Ministry of Transport (MOT) announced that the Cross Island Line will run directly under Singapore's central catchment nature reserve instead of skirting it. The decision was made after an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) study and public consultations. The direct alignment will reduce commuting time by six minutes per commuter and lower public transport fares by 15%. The tunnel will be 70 meters underground, ensuring minimal impact on the nature reserve and its flora and fauna. The decision aims to balance development and environmental concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.34 points to 1,560.93. The market saw 2.1 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion, with 492 losers outnumbering 339 gainers.

site_title: Pound jumps above US$1.31 first time since May on expectation of Conservative majority
summary: The British pound surged above $1.31 for the first time since May, driven by growing expectations of a Conservative majority in the upcoming election, reducing political uncertainty. Polls consistently show the Conservative Party leading the Labour Party, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowing to take Britain out of the EU. The pound strengthened to 7-month highs against the euro, with investors cutting back on short portfolios and hedges in anticipation of a single-party majority.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks tumble as Trump stirs concerns of trade war dragging on
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 0.73% as US President Donald Trump hinted that a trade agreement with China may not be reached until after the 2020 US presidential election, sparking fears of a prolonged trade war. The Kospi index ended down 15.18 points at 2,068.89, with foreigners selling US$318.49 million worth of shares for the 20th consecutive session.

site_title: Straits Trading to acquire property in Victoria, Australia for A$24m
summary: Straits Trading Company announced the acquisition of a mixed-use office and industrial property in Mulgrave, Victoria, Australia for A$24 million. The 12,157 square metre property is located 21km south-east of the Melbourne Central Business District. The acquisition is part of the company's expansion of its portfolio, and it is not expected to have a material impact on earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2019. The consideration will be satisfied by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: Hyundai Motor unveils plan to invest 61 trillion won over next 6 years
summary: Hyundai Motor has announced a plan to invest 61.1 trillion won (S$69.8 billion) between 2020 and 2025, with 20 trillion won dedicated to future technologies. The company aims to become one of the world's top three makers of battery and fuel cell vehicles by 2025, with annual electric vehicle sales of 670,000. Hyundai plans to achieve this through increased investment in electric and autonomous vehicles, with a focus on electric cars.

site_title: Qatar, Saudi edge towards diplomatic thaw despite hurdles
summary: Qatar and Saudi Arabia are moving towards a diplomatic thaw, with the Saudi monarch inviting Qatar's emir to a Gulf summit in Riyadh. This move could pave the way for a "reconciliation conference" despite numerous obstacles. Analysts believe signs of reconciliation are multiplying, with Kristian Ulrichsen stating that a thaw is impending. The outcome of Qatar's response will be crucial in determining the success of the reconciliation efforts.

images.alt_text: The three Gulf boycott countries are currently taking part in a regional tournament in Qatar after they announced their participation at the last minute, leading to speculation about an imminent diplomatic breakthrough.

site_title: China's Xiaomi launches online lending service in India
summary: Xiaomi has launched its online lending service, Mi Credit, in India, connecting smartphone users with lending firms for quick loans of up to 100,000 rupees. The service partners with five shadow banking and fintech firms, auditing customer creditworthiness and disbursing loans. This expansion widens Xiaomi's financial offerings in India's massive web services market, offering smartphone users an additional financial option.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore: IMDA launches S$20m fund for regional media projects, F&N's S$80m integrated F&B facility in Tuas to complete by 2021. COE prices end mostly lower in latest tender. The Straits Times Index (STI) shed 0.4% to finish at 3,159.79. Internationally, China's GDP growth is set to slow, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month.

site_title: Hong Kong Airlines plans injection, will pay salaries on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong Airlines plans to inject funds to address financial struggles, which were exacerbated by months of unrest in Hong Kong. The airline, backed by Chinese conglomerate HNA Group, will pay delayed staff salaries on December 5. The Air Transport Licensing Authority had threatened to revoke its license unless the company improves its finances. Services will gradually return to normal once funds arrive. The airline's financial woes are part of a broader economic downturn in Hong Kong, which is expected to contract 1.2% this year due to the social turmoil and recession.

site_title: Singapore shares continue downtrend, shed 0.4% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% on Wednesday, ending at 3,159.79, amid global market downturns sparked by US President Donald Trump's suggestion that a US-China trade deal might not happen until after the presidential election. Despite this, the local benchmark fared better than regional peers, with Australia's ASX 200 dropping 1.6%. The STI saw 13.29 points lost, with 24 out of 30 counters in the loss column, while 224 decliners outpaced advancers 134.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares sag on fading hopes for US-China deal
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.05% on Wednesday due to fading hopes for a US-China trade deal and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 244.58 points to 23,135.23, while the Topix index lost 3.46 points to 1,703.27. The decline followed US President Trump's recent threats to extend a stock rally, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: China says no 'time limit' on trade deal
summary: China and the US have no deadline for signing a trade deal, echoing President Trump's comments, amid strained relations over human rights issues. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying stated that the agreement must be based on equality and mutual respect, warning that Beijing will take resolute measures if faced with unilateralism and trade bullying. The tensions come after the US passed a bill backing pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong and a Uighur rights bill, which could impose sanctions on senior Chinese officials.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open
summary: European stock markets opened with divergent trends, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.3%. Paris's CAC 40 also rose 0.3%. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were a focus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit by Trump trade remarks
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.25% on Wednesday after US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about a phase-one trade deal with China, potentially delaying its completion until after next year's presidential election. The Hang Seng index dropped 328.74 points to 26,062.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.23%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.20%. The decline was attributed to Trump's remarks, which suggested the trade deal might not be finalized until after the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Typhoon Kammuri kills 17 people as it passes south of Manila
summary: Typhoon Kammuri has killed 17 people in the Philippines as it passed south of Manila, destroying houses and displacing hundreds of thousands. The storm caused at least 800 million pesos ($21.4 million) in damage to agriculture and left parts of 12 roads and three bridges closed. About half a million people were evacuated. The typhoon is the 20th to hit the Philippines in 2019, where about 20 cyclones pass through each year, and is similar to Super Typhoon Haiyan in 2013 that killed over 6,300 people.

site_title: China warns US over Uighur bill, raising doubts over early trade deal
summary: China has warned the US that legislation calling for a tougher response to Beijing's treatment of its Uighur Muslim minority will affect bilateral cooperation, clouding prospects for a near-term trade deal. The US House of Representatives passed the Uighur Act, which requires the president to condemn abuses and call for the closure of mass detention camps in Xinjiang. China has called the bill a malicious attack on its domestic affairs, demanding the US keep it from becoming law and threatening retaliatory measures. The US and China are still negotiating the phase one trade deal, which is expected to take until late 2020 to finalize.

site_title: ExxonMobil completes maintenance work at Singapore chemical plant
summary: ExxonMobil has completed maintenance work at its Singapore chemical plant, which was causing flaring at the facility. The company did not disclose further details about the maintenance, citing its practice of not discussing operational details. The plant, located on Jurong Island, produces a range of petrochemicals and feedstocks. The maintenance work is part of the ongoing operations at ExxonMobil's petrochemical complex in Singapore.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses as trade hopes wane; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares closed 1.6% lower on Wednesday, extending losses into a second session, amid growing concerns over a global slowdown and delayed trade talks between the US and China. US President Donald Trump signaled a potential delay in sealing a trade agreement, while new tariffs on Chinese imports were confirmed to take effect on December 15. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to its lowest in a month, with the heavyweight financial index also declining.

site_title: Malaysia SMEs see local market as more beneficial than overseas: study
summary: Malaysian SMEs prefer the domestic market over overseas due to research funded by ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. Despite e-commerce initiatives, firms don't automatically translate into export sales. Key findings show that CEOs are the most important factor in adoption, with varying perceptions on organizational, technological, and environmental barriers among e-commerce users and non-users. The study calls for a nuanced policy response that addresses differences in perceived barriers and firm sizes, including data protection, financial incentives, and technical knowledge.

images.alt_text: Getting firms to invest in e-commerce does not automatically translate into export sales, as exporting via e-commerce requires complementary policies that focus on specific issues, such as digital marketing at the targeted export destination.

site_title: Small galleries assess the benefits of big art fairs
summary: Small galleries are assessing the benefits of participating in big art fairs, despite high costs and uncertainty. Some galleries, like Acb Gallery from Budapest and High Art from Paris, are "graduating" to the main Galleries sector, while others, such as Karma from New York, are participating for the first time. Art Basel has introduced a sliding scale pricing model to make it more accessible to smaller galleries. The fair attracts over 80,000 attendees, including top museums and collectors, offering galleries a chance to connect with key players in the art world.

site_title: Seven companies join SGX's watch list from Dec 4
summary: Seven companies, including ASL Marine Holdings and XMH Holdings, have been added to the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch list as of December 4, 2019, due to failing to meet financial entry criteria. The companies must take active steps to satisfy the requirements within 36 months to avoid delisting or trading suspension. The criteria include recording a consolidated pre-tax profit and maintaining an average daily market cap of S$40 million or more. If not met, these companies will be delisted from the SGX.

site_title: Firms moving arbitration cases from Hong Kong to Singapore in fresh setback for business
summary: Firms are shifting arbitration cases from Hong Kong to Singapore due to safety concerns amid pro-democracy protests in the city. The unrest has led to a recession, prompting tycoons to move their wealth offshore and cancelling events. The city's position as a top arbitration centre is also at risk, with cases moving to Singapore. This move is seen as a fresh setback for Hong Kong's appeal as an international business hub.

site_title: Vietnam gas power holds long-term value: Report
summary: Vietnam's gas power sector is expected to hold long-term value due to increasing demand for electricity, driven by rising manufacturing investment and urban growth. Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng believe gas-fired plants, particularly those operated by PetroVietnam Power and Nhon Trach 2, will benefit from the trend. Despite low tariffs, the sector faces challenges such as fuel shortages and infrastructure inefficiencies. Authorities are working on a market-based tariff mechanism, which could lead to higher rates and improved earnings for power plants by 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.51% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.51% on Wednesday, following US President Donald Trump's comments on no urgency to strike a deal with China, stoking investors' fears over global trade tensions.
