Banking stocks, such as DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, also declined. However, Parkway Life Reit and Jardine Matheson Holdings bucked the trend, with gains of 0.6% and 1.6% respectively.

site_title: China's ride-hailing decline hurting car sales: report
summary: China's ride-hailing app usage declined 6.3% in the third quarter, marking a fifth consecutive quarterly drop, according to a Sanford C Bernstein report. Didi Chuxing, the largest ride-hailing operator, saw rider and driver app usage fall 5% and 23% respectively. This decline is attributed to scaling back incentives for drivers, contributing to a slowdown in car sales in China, the world's largest auto market.

site_title: IMF urges Hong Kong to boost spending to aid economic growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urged Hong Kong's government to boost spending to support the territory's convulsing economy, citing trade tensions and political unrest. The IMF projects a 1.2% economic contraction this year, but expects growth to recover to 1% in 2020. The fund recommended an additional 2.5 percentage points of GDP in targeted spending to vulnerable households and smaller enterprises. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced new measures to prop up the economy, following previous stimulus measures and a forecasted budget deficit.

site_title: Mercedes beats BMW in November, tightening US luxury-car race
summary: Mercedes-Benz outsold BMW for the second consecutive month in November, with 33,721 cars and SUVs sold, surpassing BMW's 31,213 vehicles. The refreshed GLC midsize SUV was the top seller, while demand for the GLE SUV rose 52%. BMW's lead over Mercedes narrowed to 3,280 vehicles through the end of November. The luxury car sales race between the two German rivals is the closest it's been since March.

site_title: Investors urge Big Oil to follow 'poster child' Repsol's climate pledge
summary: Investors are urging major oil companies to follow Repsol's lead in committing to net-zero emissions by mid-century, after the Spanish energy firm became the first leading company to set this target. Repsol's move outpaces Royal Dutch Shell's goal to halve emissions by 2050. Institutional investors are applying pressure on companies to meet the 2015 Paris climate agreement targets, which aim to limit global warming. The calls come as investors hope Repsol's pledge will prompt rival oil and gas companies to follow suit in the fight against climate change.

site_title: Hyundai Heavy says trying to allay Singapore's concerns over Daewoo shipyard merger
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries Holdings is working with Singaporean regulators to address concerns over its US$2 billion merger with Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering. The deal, which requires regulatory approval in several countries, threatens to remove competition in the supply of LNG carriers, container ships, and oil tankers to Singaporean customers. Competition and Consumer Commission Singapore has completed an initial review and a more detailed study may take four months to complete. Hyundai aims to alleviate concerns and complete the regulatory approval process.

site_title: United Airlines buys 50 Airbus aircraft worth US$6.5b to replace Boeing 757s
summary: United Airlines has ordered 50 Airbus A321XLR aircraft worth $6.5 billion to replace its aging Boeing 757s. The new planes, set to be delivered in 2024, will allow United to retire its 757-200s and serve additional European destinations from US East Coast hubs. The Airbus A321XLR's range is 15% above its predecessor model, making it a cost-effective alternative to long-haul wide-body planes. The order is a blow to Boeing, which currently has no aircraft to compete with the A321XLR in the mid-market range.

site_title: TikTok in US class-action lawsuit over alleged China data transfer
summary: A California university student, Misty Hong, has filed a class-action lawsuit against TikTok, accusing the app of harvesting and transferring large amounts of user data to China. The lawsuit claims TikTok has secretly collected private and identifiable user data, including unpublished videos, without user consent. Hong alleges the app's data is transferred to servers run by companies cooperating with the Chinese government. The lawsuit, filed on behalf of 110 million US TikTok users, marks the latest legal battle for the app, which has denied any wrongdoing and emphasized respect for US users and regulators.

site_title: Hong Kong's November business activity shrinks the most in 21 years
summary: Hong Kong's business activity contracted at the fastest pace in 21 years in November, with the Hong Kong Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) falling to 38.5. The decline was driven by anti-government protests and softening global demand, with companies scaling back purchases and predicting weaker activity in the year ahead. Retail sales and tourist arrivals also plummeted, with the largest decline on record in October. Economists warn of a hard-landing recession, predicting GDP growth of -7% in the fourth quarter and -2.25% for 2019.

site_title: Ping An's fintech halo is losing its glow
summary: Ping An's fintech arm, OneConnect, is set to go public with a valuation of US$4.8 billion, down from its most recent funding round last year. The company reported a nearly US$150 million net loss in the first nine months of 2019, but offers AI-assisted technology to small and mid-sized Chinese banks and insurers. The IPO comes after a string of poor Chinese fintech debuts, including Micro-lender Qudian's IPO, and raises questions about the industry's growth prospects.

site_title: Manhattan luxury condo sales moving slowly, even with freebies
summary: Manhattan luxury condo sales are moving slowly, with Extell Development reporting five apartments sold or under contract at its Kent building in the third quarter. Despite offering incentives such as paying up to five years of buyers' common charges, the developer still has 51 condos left unsold. Similar struggles are seen at other luxury projects, including One Manhattan Square, where only 202 of 815 units are spoken for. Extell CEO Sush Torgalkar attributes the slowdown to a buyers' market, citing increased sales velocity across all properties, but notes that concessions are necessary to attract buyers.

site_title: Australia bans life-insurance cold call sales after inquiry revealed abuses
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, has banned telephone sales of life insurance due to widespread abuse of "cold calling" practices, leading to poor consumer outcomes. The ban, effective January 13, 2020, aims to stop firms from pressuring consumers into buying unnecessary products. An inquiry revealed examples of abuse, including selling complex insurance to a man with Down Syndrome. The move comes after the Commonwealth Bank was fined A$700,000 for breaching anti-hawking laws by selling life insurance over unsolicited calls between 2014 and 2018.

site_title: South Korean actor Cha In-ha found dead in latest K-pop tragedy
summary: South Korean actor Cha In-ha, 27, was found dead in his home, marking the country's third young celebrity death in two months. Cha, a singer-actor, had previously been a member of the boy band Surprise U. His death comes after fellow K-pop idols Sulli and Koo Hara died under similar circumstances, sparking debate about the intense social pressures in the industry. The cases have raised concerns about personal attacks, cyber bullying, and the need for greater support for young stars.

site_title: Rich Capital's term sheet with JV partner lapses
summary: Rich Capital's non-binding term sheet with Indonesian joint venture partner Karya Indo Batam lapsed on November 30, 2019, without a definitive agreement. The lapse is not expected to impact the company's consolidated net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year ending March 31, 2020. Rich Capital's shares have been suspended since June 2019.

site_title: Thailand bourse sees more listings of foreign securities
summary: Thailand's Stock Exchange of Thailand expects more foreign companies from neighboring countries to list on its exchange through real estate investment trusts (Reits). Authorities aim to expand investment alternatives for locals and foreigners, driven by domestic growth slowing and an aging population. Companies from Laos, Cambodia, and Myanmar are being approached to tap the local market for long-term funds. This move is seen as a way to attract Thai investors, as the country seeks new investment opportunities amid a record-low interest rate and a slumping stock market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as trade hopes wane
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.07% on Wednesday, with the KOSPI index hitting its lowest level since October 21, due to US President Donald Trump's remarks that a trade deal with China might have to wait until after the US presidential election in November 2020. The won also depreciated against the US dollar, further dampening investor sentiment. Foreigners were net sellers of 200 billion won worth of shares, and the benchmark bond yield fell 3.7 basis points to 1.425%.

site_title: Sasa's shop staff say management did not inform them of Singapore closures
summary: Sasa, a cosmetic giant, has unexpectedly closed its shops in Singapore without informing staff. Shop staff learned of the exit through social media and media reports, with management reportedly not sharing any information about the closure. The sudden move has left workers and customers surprised.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong cosmetics retailer had announced on Monday that it would shut down all 22 outlets in Singapore, a move that is likely to affect about 170 workers.

site_title: F&N's S$80m integrated F&B facility in Tuas slated to complete in end-2021
summary: F&N Foods, a subsidiary of Fraser and Neave, is building an $80 million integrated food and beverage facility in Tuas, Singapore, with a planned completion in late 2021. The 375,000 square foot facility will boost innovation efforts, consolidate non-alcoholic beverage operations, and feature a smart factory design. It aims to be a "future-ready" facility with efficient water and energy use, targeting the Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark Platinum award. The investment marks F&N's confidence in Singapore's future and its ability to meet global challenges.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday's open as trade deal hopes dim; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.7% on Wednesday, triggered by US President Donald Trump's signals of delays in signing a trade deal with China, dimming hopes of a quick resolution. The index dropped 22.24 points to 3,150.84, with 95 losers outnumbering 30 gainers. The decline followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson says new tests show no asbestos in Johnson's Baby Powder
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced that recent tests showed no asbestos in Johnson's Baby Powder, contradicting earlier FDA findings of trace amounts. The company conducted 155 tests using four methods and found no asbestos in samples from a bottle tested by the FDA and retained samples from the finished lot. The FDA attributed its previous findings to test sample contamination or analyst error. This move aims to prove the safety of the widely used product, which has faced thousands of lawsuits over asbestos contamination.

site_title: IMDA launches S$20m fund to boost funding of regional media projects in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched a S$20 million fund to boost regional media projects, including TV shows, movies, and animated features, with no restrictions on project types. The fund is for media-fund partners to jointly fund projects in the region, with a focus on collaborations between local content producers and international partners. This initiative aims to support "made with Singapore" productions and facilitate regional talent exchanges. IMDA has also partnered with global players like Viacom and CJ ENM to co-produce content for online platforms and streaming services.

site_title: Star Pharma to delist from SGX main board on Dec 6
summary: Star Pharma to delist from Singapore Exchange's main board on December 6, following a compulsory acquisition exercise by its offeror, executive chairman Xu Zhi Bin. The exercise is for shares not accepted at S$0.45 per share. Delisting will allow the company to gain more control and flexibility in implementing strategic initiatives and operational changes, eliminating listing costs. Star Pharma has been listed since February 2006.

site_title: US crypto expert living in Singapore thought it would be 'cool' if North Korea mined Ether: source
summary: US crypto expert Virgil Griffith, 36, was arrested for allegedly aiding North Korea in violating sanctions. In 2018, Griffith expressed interest in helping North Korea mine Ether, a cryptocurrency, saying it would be "really cool." He planned to deliver equipment to North Korea's telecom agency, but the plans' success is unknown. Griffith faces up to 20 years in prison for allegedly sharing technical information with North Korean officials during a conference in April 2019. His lawyer disputes the allegations, and a judge has allowed Griffith to be released from jail pending trial.

site_title: Exit of Nokia's dealmaking chairman stirs talk of strategy shift
summary: Nokia Oyj's chairman, Risto Siilasmaa, is stepping down after eight years, sparking speculation about a potential strategy shift. His departure comes less than two months after the company's CEO, Rajeev Suri, cut the company's profit outlook and suspended the dividend due to heavy investment in 5G. New chairman Sari Baldauf, a former head of Nokia's networks division, will take over in April 2020. Analysts believe Siilasmaa's departure may lead to a review of the company's end-to-end product strategy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slip at Wednesday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.4% to 1,555.82 on Wednesday, with 71.2 million lots traded worth RM28 million. The market saw 127 losers and 77 gainers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Parkway Life Reit, OCBC, Thakral, Accrelist, Yanlord, UE, Mirach
summary: Several Singaporean companies saw notable developments, including Parkway Life Reit buying nursing facilities in Japan for approximately S$46.3 million, OCBC Bank using data analytics to target the mass affluent market, and Thakral Corporation acquiring 46.4 hectares of land in Australia for S$18.7 million. Meanwhile, Mirach Energy's shares rose 35.8% after being removed from the SGX watch list due to artificial valuations. Other companies, such as Accrelist and Yanlord Land Group, also made announcements.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as trade optimism collapses
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day, as concerns about global trade tensions weighed on the mining and financials sectors. US President Trump suggested the Sino-US trade deal may not be resolved soon, and new tariffs on Chinese imports are set to take effect on December 15. Heavyweight financial stocks declined, with the "big four" lenders falling 1.3-2% and miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto dropping 2.8-3.4%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted at Wednesday's open, with the Hang Seng index sinking 1.21% to 26,071.39. The decline followed US President Donald Trump's statement that a potential trade deal with China might not be achieved until after next year's US presidential elections. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.38%. The decline was attributed to investors' reduced hopes for a China-US trade deal.

site_title: United Airlines nears US$7b order for longest-range Airbus A321 jet
summary: United Airlines is nearing a $7.1 billion order for 50 Airbus A321XLR jets, with deliveries starting in 2024. The long-range jets will enable the airline to handle North Atlantic routes, expanding its US foothold in a single-aisle variant. This deal follows similar orders from American Airlines Group and JetBlue Airways, and will replace some of United's older 757-200 planes. The order comes as Boeing struggles to recover from the grounding of its 737 MAX, with United also being a major customer of the MAX 10 planes.

site_title: Thakral buys Queensland property to grow its retirement housing portfolio
summary: Thakral Corporation, a Singapore-listed company, is acquiring 46.4 hectares of land in Queensland, Australia, to expand its GemLife joint venture's "resort-style" retirement housing portfolio. The A$20 million project will feature 450 homes and is Thakral's largest GemLife resort to date, with a total of over 1,800 residences. Construction is expected to begin in the fourth quarter of 2020, and the gated resort will offer modern, low-maintenance homes and premium community facilities. The acquisition aligns with Thakral's strategy of growing its real estate investments for sustainable returns.

site_title: Starbucks is replicating its too-fast US growth in China
summary: Starbucks is slowing its growth in China, citing cannibalization from too many new locations, despite a 5% growth rate in the latest quarter. The company warned of 1-3% growth this fiscal year, slower than the 3-4% expected in the US. This intentional strategy aims to boost total transactions and sales, amid rising competition and slowing economic growth. Starbucks plans to open 600 new cafes in China this year, a slower pace than in the US, where it has focused on smaller locations and rural areas.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on faded hopes for US-China deal
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to fading hopes for a US-China trade deal, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.75% to 23,203.77. US President Donald Trump's comments on not having a deadline for a trade deal with China added to trade uncertainty, prompting a reassessment of market expectations. The absence of a deal raises the possibility of new US tariffs on China imports on December 15, causing market volatility and a strengthening of the yen.

site_title: Moving up the value chain
summary: Yan San Metals (YSM) is a Singaporean company that has successfully moved up the value chain by positioning itself as a solutions provider, tailoring its products to customers' needs. The company has developed innovative technologies, including a machine that converts waste to energy, which can reduce haze problems in Indonesia. YSM has also invested in indoor farming solutions, which utilize multi-layered hydroponics systems and recirculating aquaculture systems to produce 10-15 times more food than traditional methods. The company's focus on quality, investing in equipment and skills, and collaborating with government agencies has enabled it to expand its capabilities and enter new markets, such as Thailand. With a strong foundation in Singapore and a willingness to invest in the right technologies, YSM is poised for continued growth.

site_title: Elon Musk defends 'pedo guy' tweet in defamation trial
summary: Elon Musk defended his "pedo guy" tweet during a defamation trial, claiming he didn't literally mean British caver Vernon Unsworth was a pedophile. Musk said he was upset by Unsworth's insults and responded in anger, using a common insult in South Africa. However, Musk's defense was challenged by Unsworth's attorneys, who presented evidence of other tweets that suggested Musk believed Unsworth was a pedophile. The trial continues, with Unsworth seeking damages for pain, suffering, and emotional distress.

site_title: US has not ruled out imposing tariffs on imported cars
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that the Trump administration has not ruled out imposing tariffs on imported autos, despite a six-month review period ending in November without action. The review was sparked by a Commerce Department investigation into whether imported autos pose a national security threat. Ross acknowledged that the administration has been negotiating with companies, but did not set a new deadline for imposing tariffs. Senator Pat Toomey urged the Commerce Department to launch a new investigation before imposing tariffs, citing concerns over national security and fairness.

site_title: Trump has upended relationships with 9 of 10 top US trading partners
summary: US President Donald Trump has strained relationships with 9 of the 10 top US trading partners, including China, Mexico, Canada, and the European Union. The US-China trade war has been ongoing for 17 months, with no clear timeline for a deal. Trump has also threatened tariffs on EU auto imports, and the US has imposed tariffs on French products. Other countries, such as Japan and India, have also seen trade tensions rise under Trump's administration.

site_title: Indonesia aims to start making green diesel in 2022
summary: Indonesia plans to start producing green diesel from palm oil in 2022, with an estimated output of 3.7 million kilolitres. The country aims to increase production to 6.1 million kilolitres by 2024. The development of green diesel is part of Indonesia's efforts to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and offset a current account deficit caused by large energy imports. The Indonesian government is also planning to expand its biodiesel programme, including the use of B30 fuel, which has sparked a palm price rally due to concerns about reduced exports.

site_title: Europe: Shares down for 4th day on trade worries; Germany outperforms
summary: European shares declined for a fourth consecutive session, with London's FTSE losing 1.8% due to trade worries and weaker crude prices. US President Donald Trump's comments on delaying a trade deal with China, which could come after 2020 US elections, further dented hopes of a near-term resolution. The World Trade Organization rejected EU claims of Airbus subsidies, prompting US retaliatory tariffs on European goods. German shares rose 0.2% despite the global sell-off, while Italy's blue-chip index finished marginally higher.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls as trade hopes wane
summary: US stocks plummeted for a third consecutive session on Tuesday, with the Dow falling 1.01% to 27,502.81, after President Donald Trump and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross dampened hopes of a near-term US-China trade deal. Trump suggested a deal may wait until after the 2020 US presidential election, while Ross confirmed new tariffs on Chinese imports would take effect on December 15 unless progress was made. The decline was widespread, with nine of 11 major sectors in the S&P 500 in negative territory.

site_title: Google's Sundar Pichai named CEO at parent firm Alphabet
summary: Google's Sundar Pichai to become CEO at parent firm Alphabet, replacing Larry Page. Pichai will continue as Google CEO while Page, co-founder, will remain involved as a co-founder, shareholder, and board member. This shakeup aims to streamline the company's leadership structure.

site_title: Cyber Monday sales on track to hit US$9.2 billion
summary: US Cyber Monday sales are projected to reach a record $9.2 billion, surpassing the previous year's total of $9.4 billion. The sales are driven by earlier-than-usual promotions and free shipping, building on a successful Black Friday weekend. Adobe Analytics predicts a 16.9% increase in sales over last year, with nearly 69 million Americans shopping online for deals. However, protests against Amazon's treatment of workers and environmental impact have been held, with demonstrators marching outside CEO Jeff Bezos' penthouse in New York City.

site_title: Oil steadies after brief slide on Trump's US-China trade comments
summary: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday after a brief slide following US President Donald Trump's comments that a US-China trade deal may be delayed until after the November presidential election. Opec producers are discussing a plan to increase output cuts by 400,000 barrels per day and extend the pact until June, aiming to deliver a positive surprise to the market. Despite concerns over the global economy and the US-China trade war, US crude inventories are expected to have declined last week, providing some support to prices.

site_title: Opec, Russia debate deeper oil cuts as new glut looms
summary: Opec and Russia are set to approve deeper oil production cuts this week to prevent a new glut and stabilize oil prices. The cuts, which could be as deep as 400,000 barrels per day, aim to counter oversupply and rising US production. Saudi Arabia, which is seeking to increase its budget revenue, is pushing for deeper cuts. A meeting between Opec and Russia is scheduled for Thursday, followed by an Opec+ meeting on Friday. If agreed, the cuts could help prevent a large oversupply and build-up in inventories in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Salaries projected to rise 3.7% in 2020: Mercer survey
summary: Singapore's salary increase is projected to rise 3.7% in 2020, according to a Mercer survey. This modest increase may not be sufficient to retain staff, prompting companies to turn to other incentives such as retention bonuses. The survey found that companies are shifting towards holistic talent strategies, acknowledging pay as only one means of differentiation and motivation. Nearly 1,000 companies participated in the survey, with some industries, such as consumer goods and life sciences, recording small upward swings in salary increases.

site_title: Huawei urging suppliers to break the law by moving offshore: US Commerce chief
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross revealed that Huawei is pressuring suppliers to move operations offshore to avoid US sanctions. The move is in response to the US government's entity list, which blacklisted Huawei due to national security concerns. The blacklisting has limited the ability to track overseas suppliers selling to Huawei, prompting frustration among US authorities. This development highlights the challenges in enforcing US sanctions on the global tech giant.

images.alt_text: China's telecoms giant Huawei has been encouraging its suppliers to violate US law by telling them to move operations offshore in a bid to avoid US sanctions, Commerce Department Secretary Wilbur Ross told Reuters on Tuesday.

site_title: China's pork prices rebound as consumption picks up
summary: China's pork prices rose 1.1% on Monday, rebounding from a 20% drop in October, as colder weather and the Lunar New Year holiday approach, increasing meat consumption. Prices have been volatile since African swine fever led to a 40% decline in the country's hog herd. Despite the rebound, analysts say supplies remain tight and prices could continue to rise, driven by increased demand during winter and the holiday season.

site_title: Institutions have subscribed for 5.9b shares of Aramco IPO: lead bankers
summary: Saudi Aramco has received subscription orders for 5.9 billion shares from institutional investors in its planned IPO, worth 189.04 billion riyals (S$68.8 billion). The deal, which could raise up to US$25.6 billion, plans to sell 1.5% of its shares. The institutional bookbuilding began on November 17 and investors have until December 4 to place orders.

images.alt_text: The institutional tranche of Saudi Aramco's planned initial public offering (IPO) has been almost three times oversubscribed, receiving orders worth 189.04 billion riyals (S$68.8 billion), financial advisers for the IPO said on Tuesday.

site_title: Rare Gauguin fetches 9.5m euros at Paris auction
summary: A rare 1897 painting by French artist Paul Gauguin, "Te Bourao II" or "tree," sold for nearly twice its estimated value of 5-7 million euros at a Paris auction, fetching 9.5 million euros. The painting drew keen interest amid controversy over Gauguin's relationships with young girls in Tahiti.

site_title: Thousands of Thyssenkrupp steelworkers protest against German job cuts
summary: Thousands of Thyssenkrupp steelworkers in Germany protested against planned job cuts, accusing the company of mismanagement. The planned cuts, which include at least 6,000 jobs globally, were announced after a failed merger bid with Tata steel. The workers demand more investment and financial resources to save the steel division, citing a challenging environment. Thyssenkrupp has committed to 570 million euros in annual investment, but labour representatives want nearly three times as much. The company plans a sale or stock market flotation of its elevators arm to fund a restructuring.

site_title: Govt strategy will be to transform, support, sustain, says Indranee
summary: Singapore's government has outlined its strategy for Budget 2020, focusing on "transform, support and sustain" amidst challenging external environments, including US-China trade tensions and growing income inequality. Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah emphasized the need for innovation, regional expansion, and upskilling to seize new opportunities. A Goods and Services Tax hike, planned for 2021-2025, will support financial sustainability, while security spending is expected to rise. A GST off-set package for Singaporeans is also in the works, and the government calls for public input to shape Budget 2020.

site_title: Indonesia's anti-graft agency warns of risk of Chinese investment
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency has warned of the risks of Chinese investment, citing concerns over Beijing's efforts to exert economic influence in the country. The agency's deputy chairman, Laode Muhammad Syarif, advised the government to be cautious of Chinese firms, which he said are expanding their economic influence as part of their business. This comes as Indonesia's two-way trade with China jumped 22% to $72.3 billion in 2018, and foreign direct investment is on the rise. The warning raises concerns about corruption and the potential for Indonesia to become too indebted to Beijing.

site_title: Bank of Thailand says inflow curbs so far are 'baby steps'
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) considers the measures taken to curb capital inflows as "baby steps," with policy makers having multiple tools available to manage the baht's strength. The baht has appreciated over 8% against the US dollar in the past year, impacting exports and tourism. The BOT has relaxed rules to spur outflows and is reviewing these measures every three months. The central bank may lower interest rates further if economic growth disappoints, but caution is exercised against setting rates below zero.

site_title: Huawei plans to shift US research centre to Canada
summary: Huawei plans to relocate its US research centre to Canada, according to founder Ren Zhengfei, amid US efforts to halt foreign shipments of US tech to the firm. The US Commerce Department placed Huawei on a trade blacklist in May due to national security concerns. The relocation is part of Huawei's efforts to build new factory capacity in Europe and assuage fears of US allegations that its products could be used for spying. Huawei has denied these allegations and is currently facing extradition proceedings for its CFO, Meng Wanzhou, who is fighting US charges.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment up slightly in Q1 2020; hiring to drop
summary: Singapore's business sentiment has improved slightly in Q1 2020, with the services sector being the most upbeat, while construction and wholesale trade are the gloomiest. The Business Optimism Index rose to +5.31 percentage points from +4.82 percentage points in Q4 2019. Hiring is expected to drop, with the construction and transport sectors being the most pessimistic. Despite this, increases in net profits and volume of sales are expected to help offset negative hiring sentiments.

site_title: T-Mobile beats rivals to become first to offer nationwide 5G wireless service in US
summary: T-Mobile has become the first US carrier to offer nationwide 5G wireless service, beating its rivals. The low-band 600-megahertz signal provides broad coverage but not blazing speeds. The service is a precursor to a more robust network that will be made possible with the combination of Sprint's airwave holdings. T-Mobile will initially offer 5G service to regular subscribers and pay-as-you-go customers at no extra cost, with plans to follow up with higher-frequency signals in the coming months.

site_title: Dissent against Nato ill-judged amid challenges
summary: Nato, the 70-year-old alliance, remains strong despite some reports of disunity. Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg emphasized the need to address terrorism and defend democracies against aggression. The alliance will discuss Turkey's threat to vote against a defense plan for Baltic nations and Poland, amid concerns over Turkey's ties with Russia. Despite criticism from French President Emmanuel Macron, Nato has adapted and grown stronger, with 29 members protecting a billion people. The alliance must be ready to counter threats from Russia, global terror groups, and hostile states, and has seen increased defense spending from European allies and Canada in 2019.

site_title: Saudi Aramco rebrands itself as the low-carbon choice for investors
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, is rebranding itself as a low-carbon choice for investors amid growing environmental concerns. The company's massive reserves, however, pose a challenge, with estimates suggesting up to 50 years' worth of oil may become "stranded assets" in a carbon-constrained future. Despite implementing some emission-cutting programs, Aramco's full-cycle emissions have increased sharply, and governance concerns remain due to the Saudi state's dominant control over the company. As investors increasingly prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, Aramco's transition to becoming a publicly listed company is set to be closely scrutinized.

site_title: As govts dither, cyber crooks snigger
summary: Cyber attacks are increasingly being viewed as a significant threat to society, with the World Economic Forum ranking them as the fifth biggest risk. The estimated annual economic cost of cybercrime exceeds $1 trillion, with a single cloud computing provider attack costing between $50 billion and $120 billion. To combat this, governments and international organizations are calling for harmonized cybersecurity laws and regulations. However, current efforts have been hindered by fragmented regulatory landscapes and differing geopolitical objectives. Experts propose solutions such as a unified treaty, bilateral cooperation, and penalties for non-cooperative nations to address the growing threat of cybercrime.

site_title: Ping An's OneConnect launches US IPO of up to US$504m
summary: Ping An's OneConnect Financial Technology launched a US initial public offering (IPO) of up to US$504 million, selling 36 million American depositary shares at an indicative range of US$12 to US$14 a share. This valuation is below its US$7.5 billion valuation from last year, potentially marking a down round. The IPO comes as tech investor SoftBank faces challenges, including a failed WeWork share sale and its first quarterly loss in 14 years. OneConnect had revenue of 1.55 billion yuan in the first nine months of 2019, but widened losses to one billion yuan.

site_title: China's economists take up positions on how far to push for growth in 2020
summary: China's economists are debating how much to support growth in 2020, with some advocating for more stimulus to prevent a slowdown and others preferring a conservative approach to manage debt and structural risks. Former central bank adviser Yu Yongding and Goldman Sachs' chief China economist Song Yu argue that a 6% growth rate is necessary to stabilize the economy, while Xia Bin, an economic adviser to the State Council, proposes a target range of 5.5-6% for 2020. The government's decision on 2020 targets, including the amount to spend and the growth rate, will be made at the upcoming Central Economic Work Committee meeting.

site_title: Twitter makes global changes to comply with privacy laws
summary: Twitter is updating its global privacy policy to comply with the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), giving users more information about data advertisers receive. The changes, effective January 1, 2020, will provide transparency and control over personal information, including the ability to request data deletion and opt out of third-party sales. Twitter is also moving accounts outside the US and EU to San Francisco, allowing for experimentation with new controls and settings. The company has launched a "Twitter Privacy Center" to showcase its data protection efforts.

site_title: The problem with 'green' monetary policy
summary: A UN report highlights climate change as a major challenge. Central banks may need to address the issue, but discussing it outside their primary remit can compromise their credibility. As central banks focus on making themselves "popular" with the public, they may be tempted to discuss topics outside their expertise, potentially blurring the lines between monetary policy and other issues. This could lead to a broader, more politicized approach to monetary policy, undermining its effectiveness in addressing economic challenges.

site_title: Manufacturing doldrums may be hitting nadir with gradual recovery in 2020
summary: The manufacturing sector, hit by the ongoing trade war, is showing signs of bottoming out, with a gradual recovery expected in the second half of 2020. According to UOB Private Bank, new technology and inventory adjustments will contribute to the turnaround. The semiconductor industry's "remarkable performance" and potential 5G technology adoption in China are indicators of the sector's improvement. This recovery is also driving a broad risk-on market rally, with investors expecting an economic recovery in 2020 and tracking average historical performance of similar recovery episodes.

site_title: AirAsia bets its in-flight menu can win diners on the ground
summary: AirAsia Group Bhd has opened its first restaurant, Santan and T&CO, featuring dishes inspired by its in-flight menu. The restaurant in Kuala Lumpur marks the airline's entry into the retail food business, with a goal to franchise the concept internationally. 30% of the menu is based on AirAsia's existing in-flight menu, including classic Malaysian dishes such as nasi lemak. The airline plans to open five outlets this year and 100 over the next three to five years, with a focus on franchising to tap into young entrepreneurial talent.

site_title: New Trump tariffs send jitters through markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's reimposition of tariffs on base metals from Brazil and Argentina sent jitters through regional markets, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 0.5% to close at 3,173.08. However, tech manufacturers in Singapore bucked the trend, with UMS Holdings and Avi-Tech Electronics advancing. China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.3% lifted by financials and consumer stocks, while Taiwan also posted slight gains.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit to buy three nursing rehabilitation facilities in Japan for 3.7b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) is acquiring three nursing rehabilitation facilities in Japan for approximately S$46.3 million, expanding its portfolio to 53 properties valued at S$1.92 billion. The facilities, located in Gifu, Wakayama, and Yamaguchi prefectures, are expected to generate a 6.8% net property yield and deliver immediate yield growth to PLife Reit. The acquisition will be funded by a yen-funded bank facility and is expected to be completed this month.

site_title: Sending ship carbons to the bottom of the sea
summary: A new technology, decarbonICE, aims to capture ship carbons at sea, turning them into dry ice and storing it in sea floor sediments. This project, developed by a group of world-leading shipping companies and ship builders, could transform the task of slashing maritime emissions. The technology captures CO2 onboard in a cryogenic process and transports it into sediments, where it is safely stored. The project's organisers claim it can create carbon-negative shipping and contribute to atmospheric carbon reduction at a lower cost than shore-based carbon capture.

site_title: The myth of China's solid consumer demand
summary: China's consumer market is often touted as a key driver of economic growth, but a closer look reveals a more complex reality. Despite the presence of a large middle class and a growing population, domestic demand is not growing, with consumption accounting for only 60.1% of economic growth in the first half of the year. External pressures, including the US-China trade war and economic slowdown, are hindering the restructuring of China's domestic economy, casting doubt on the consumer market's ability to propel sustainable growth.

site_title: Government holds housing land sales steady amid supply-demand gap
summary: The Singapore government has maintained a steady supply of private housing units for the first half of 2020, with around 39,000 units in the pipeline. Three new sites have been confirmed for the H12020 government land sales (GLS) programme, which can yield 1,775 private home units and 22,000 sq m of commercial space. The move aims to keep the residential market stable amid a high supply of unsold units, with demand increasing in the past two quarters but overall transaction volume remaining modest.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mirach Energy will not be able to exit the Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to "Trade with Caution" alerts and artificial valuations. Accrelist is acquiring 49% of Ozhean Accrelist Aesthetics Sdn Bhd for RM490,000. WBL Corporation has appointed SAC Capital as its IFA to advise on Yanlord Land Group's mandatory offer. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: India's HDFC sees signs of a rural revival
summary: HDFC Bank, India's most valuable lender, sees signs of a rural revival, with 52% of its outlets in rural and semi-urban areas. The bank's loan growth eased to 15% in the September quarter, compared to the overall banking system's slowdown to 8%. HDFC Bank executive director Kaizad Bharucha attributes this to successful loan outreach programs in rural areas. The government's efforts to boost the economy, including a corporate tax cut, are also expected to have a positive impact. Bharucha remains cautiously optimistic about corporate investment and credit demand.

site_title: Builder of ex-1MDB project weighs IPO for as early as 2020
summary: ISKANDAR Waterfront Holdings (IWH) is considering an initial public offering (IPO) as early as 2020 to fund the US$33.5 billion Bandar Malaysia project. The project, initially conceived under 1MDB, has been revived after a dispute over payments in 2017. IWH holds a 60% stake in the joint venture, and the IPO could fetch a valuation of about RM30 billion (S$9.82 billion). The project aims to attract Chinese tech giants and is part of Malaysia's efforts to boost its real estate market.

site_title: OCBC revs up data engine for edge in financial management
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest bank, is leveraging AI and data science to enhance financial management for its customers. The bank's mobile app, Money In$ights, now predicts customer actions and provides personalized advice on spending, saving, and investing. OCBC aims to increase customer engagement with the app, with the goal of four interactions per day, up from current 20 times per month. The bank is also using data analytics to improve insurance underwriting decisions and target "lazy money" in customers' accounts, with the aim of boosting loyalty and market share in the mass affluent segment.

site_title: Two plum sites in latest land sales; Bt Timah plot to revive Jln Anak Bukit vicinity
summary: Two prime land sales in Singapore's Government Land Sales (GLS) programme for 1H 2020 have been announced. A mixed development site on Jalan Anak Bukit, near an MRT station with an integrated bus interchange, and a residential site on Tanah Merah Kechil Link are up for grabs. Both sites are expected to attract a healthy number of bidders due to their prime locations. The sales are part of the government's efforts to boost land sales and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Yuan hit after Trump says trade deal may be after 2020 polls
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a possible delay in a trade deal with China until after the 2020 US presidential election, causing a sell-off in shares and a decline in the Chinese yuan to its weakest since October. The US dollar rose 0.4% against the yuan, while the Japanese yen and Swiss franc strengthened. The dollar fell against a basket of currencies, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars surged. The announcement also sparked a sell-off in shares, with investors dumping the currency that tends to rise with optimism over a trade deal.

site_title: Will the Democrats get their act together?
summary: The US presidential election is approaching, with the Iowa Caucuses set to take place in two months. The Democratic field is crowded, with over 20 candidates vying for the nomination. Former Vice President Joe Biden is seen as a likely frontrunner, but faces challenges from new entrants like billionaire Michael Bloomberg and former Governor Deval Patrick. The field is also being shaped by the rise of progressive candidates like Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who are drawing support from the party's left wing. With the election just over a year away, it's unclear who will emerge as the Democratic nominee, adding to the uncertainty and chaos in the party.

site_title: Lam promises more economic stimulus amid record decline in HK retail sales
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam pledged more economic stimulus measures to address the city's record decline in retail sales, driven by unrest. The measures, to be "targeted," will focus on sectors affected by the protests. Lam's announcement comes after October's retail sales contracted 24.3% and a 2% decline in economic growth. The new stimulus package will build on previous measures, including a HK$19 billion package in August. Lam also reiterated her support for Beijing's stance on the protests, calling US legislation supporting protesters "unnecessary and unwarranted."

site_title: China hints US blacklist imminent in threat to trade talks progress
summary: China is expected to publish a list of "unreliable entities" that could lead to sanctions against US companies, amid trade talks progressing under threat from disputes over human rights in Hong Kong and Xinjiang. The move comes after a bill sponsored by Senator Marco Rubio requiring measures against Chinese officials involved in alleged abuses of Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang. This development adds another obstacle to finalizing a "phase one" deal to de-escalate the trade war between the two nations. China's actions could lead to visa restrictions and travel bans for US officials.

site_title: Europe's finance chiefs to call for anti-money laundering agency
summary: Europe's finance chiefs will recommend the European Commission to establish a regional agency to combat illicit financial flows, following a string of high-profile money-laundering scandals in the banking industry. The proposed agency would oversee supervision and address weaknesses in current legislation, which is often handled at the national level. The move aims to prevent crimes and promote cooperation among EU authorities, with several countries, including the Netherlands, France, and Germany, already supporting the idea. A common agency would centralize supervision and enhance the fight against money laundering.

site_title: Growth, consumption may prop up Asian equities
summary: Asian equities may be supported by technology and consumption demands in 2024, driven by the broader urbanization trend. Credit Suisse believes the downward pressure on earnings has hit an inflection point, with analysts raising earnings estimates. However, BlackRock remains cautious, citing subdued global growth and under pressure on earnings.

site_title: Trade wars supercharge China's drive to tech self-sufficiency
summary: China is rapidly advancing its tech self-sufficiency, driven by the US-China trade war, which has supercharged the country's semiconductor industry. The US tariffs and Huawei ban have forced China to focus on developing its own chip production, with companies like Huawei replacing US-made components with Japanese and Chinese-made alternatives. Meanwhile, China's internet companies, including TikTok, are expanding globally, and the country is poised to dominate the 5G market, potentially giving it a first mover advantage in the next generation of technology.

site_title: Abe administration calls for fiscal boost for economy
summary: Japan's government has proposed a fiscal stimulus package to boost the economy, which is facing risks from natural disasters. The package includes spending on disaster-prevention infrastructure, extending a cashless rebate program, and providing IT support to small and mid-sized companies. The government is urging decisive action combined with central bank easing to ensure economic recovery.

site_title: Moon's property rules hurt South Korea's growth
summary: South Korea's economy expanded 0.4% in the third quarter, its slowest annual expansion in a decade, due to a slump in the building sector. The government's efforts to curb housing prices, including stricter lending rules and property taxes, have led to slower growth. Construction investment shaved 0.9 percentage points off the reading, and economists predict it will remain a drag on growth in 2020, with forecasts of 0.36 percentage point subtraction from economic growth and 72,000 fewer job creations.

site_title: UN says 2010s hottest decade in history, as emissions rise again
summary: The UN says the 2010s were the hottest decade in history, with global temperatures 1.1°C above pre-industrial average, and 2019 on track to be among the top three warmest years. Emissions are rising again, and oceans have reached their highest recorded temperatures, with a quarter more acidity than 150 years ago. The world's seas are expected to continue rising, and over 22 million people could be displaced by weather extremes by the end of the year. Nations are in talks in Madrid to finalize rules for the Paris climate accord, which aims to limit global temperature rises to below 2°C.

site_title: Trade deal only after US election: Trump's remarks bash markets
summary: US President Donald Trump said a trade deal with China may have to wait until after the US presidential election in November 2020, indicating no urgency to reach a deal by December 15 when tariffs on more Chinese imports will be levied. This news led to a decline in European and US stock markets, as investors had hoped for a quick resolution to the trade dispute. Trump stated that a deal must be "right," and that China's economic growth has been negatively impacted by the trade tensions.

site_title: Why luxury retailers should target the lucrative travel segment in APAC
summary: Luxury retailers in the Asia-Pacific region can capitalize on the booming travel segment, which has grown 6% in 2017 to reach 323 million international tourist arrivals. Elite travelers are more likely to engage with luxury brands, and travel data can be used to target high-value consumers. By leveraging travel insights, luxury retailers can create personalized campaigns and build special experiences for unique customers. With large travel hubs in Singapore and Hong Kong, luxury brands can reach relevant audiences and target them with appropriate experiences, offering a lucrative opportunity for growth.

site_title: Keppel pledges S$500,000 over 3 years to strengthen SPD's sheltered workshop
summary: Keppel Corp's philanthropic arm, KEPPEL CARE Foundation, has pledged S$500,000 over 3 years to support SPD's sheltered workshop, which provides employment for individuals with disabilities. The partnership aims to improve efficiency, financial viability, and skills-based volunteerism. Keppel will also organize activities to engage SPD's clients and enhance vocational training. The initiative includes a new apprenticeship program, with 5 trainees already selected to receive grooming and skills development. The partnership aims to promote impactful collaboration between companies and charities to support persons with disabilities.

site_title: Europe's fragile US$2t stock rally fails to win over big investors
summary: Europe's stock market, which has seen its best year of gains in a decade, failed to impress big investors with its performance, despite optimism over the region's potential for outperforming the US in 2020. The European market underperformed the US on weak US manufacturing data and German political uncertainty, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index falling for the fourth day. Analysts cite concerns over Brexit, the German economy, and corporate earnings, leading some to prefer the US market, where earnings growth is expected to outpace Europe's.

site_title: Putin says Russia ready for cooperation with Nato
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed readiness for cooperation with NATO, citing common threats such as international terrorism and uncontrolled proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. However, he also criticized NATO for its expansion into former Soviet republics, calling it "inappropriate" and "rudely" acting without considering Russia's interests. Putin stated that Russia views NATO expansion as a potential threat to its security and that the alliance is outdated. Despite this, he assured NATO that shared security interests prevail and a peaceful future is desired.

site_title: Surprise fall in US construction spending in Oct
summary: US construction spending unexpectedly fell 0.8% in October, the lowest level in three years, as private projects declined 1% to $956.3 billion. Residential construction also dropped 1.1% in September, despite lower mortgage rates. Non-residential structures saw a 1.2% decline, while public construction projects slipped 0.2%. This report contrasts with recent upbeat economic data and may signal a cautionary note on the economy, despite economists' boosted GDP estimates for the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Condos under construction in New York. In October, spending on private construction projects dropped one per cent to US$956.3 billion, the lowest level since October 2016, after declining 1.1 per cent in September.

site_title: Kenya forcing importers to use costly new Chinese railway
summary: Kenya's new Chinese-built railway, a $3.3 billion line connecting Mombasa to Nairobi, has been criticized for increasing transport costs for importers by nearly 50% due to extra fees, congestion at the Nairobi train depot, and the need for a truck to collect goods. The railway, intended to reduce travel time, has instead become a costly option for businesses. The government's decision to force importers to use the rail has been met with resistance from the business community.

site_title: Tech startups finding few takers from private equity - for now
summary: Private equity firms are showing little interest in investing in tech startups at this time, preferring instead to focus on traditional sectors like consumer, healthcare, and education. This is due to various factors, including the lack of profitability and high valuations among many tech companies. Private equity firms typically require a minimum level of Ebitda before investing and prefer control-oriented investments, which is not typical of early-stage tech firms. However, as tech companies mature, private equity may become more interested in investing, blurring the lines between asset classes.

site_title: Olam to sell permanent water rights in Australia for A$490m
summary: Olam International is selling 89 billion litres of its permanent water rights in Australia to PSP Investments for A$490 million. The deal, expected to be completed in December 2019, will also involve the sale of 12,000 hectares of almond orchards and related assets in Victoria, Australia. The transaction will allow Olam to focus on operations and deliver best-in-class products, while PSP Investments will operate the orchards and water rights under a new revenue sharing arrangement for 25 years.

site_title: US factory output extends fall, hitting economic growth hopes
summary: US factory activity contracted for the fourth straight month in November, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) index falling to 48.1, below the 50 threshold. This contraction, combined with a drop in new orders and construction spending, has tempered optimism over the economy. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta has slashed its GDP estimate for the fourth quarter, and economists warn of downside risk. The manufacturing sector, which accounts for 11% of the US economy, remains vulnerable to global trade and domestic demand.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as Trump signals delay in China trade deal
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Tuesday as President Trump hinted at delaying a China trade deal until after the 2020 presidential election, sparking fears of a prolonged tariff dispute. The Dow Jones fell 281.06 points, the S&P 500 dropped 26.46 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 107.27 points. Investors expressed concerns about the uncertainty affecting the global economy.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit seeks to buy Beijing mall for S$455m
summary: BHG Retail Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is proposing to acquire Beijing Badaling Outlets mall for S$455 million. The mall has a gross floor area of 58,348 sq m and is fully occupied. The Reit's manager aims to enhance the portfolio and exposure to China's premier retail outlet mall sector. Unitholder approval is required for the purchase and issuance of new units. The acquisition is the Reit's first investment in an outlet mall.

site_title: Bottega Veneta wins big at London awards
summary: Bottega Veneta won four awards at the 2019 Fashion Awards, including "brand of the year" and "designer of the year" for its young artistic director Daniel Lee. Lee, 33, took over management of the Italian fashion house in 2018 and was recognized for his work in womenswear and accessories. Rihanna received the "urban luxe" award, Adut Akech was named model of the year, and Sarah Burton was awarded the "trailblazer" award for her work at Alexander McQueen. The ceremony also honored fashion icons and industry legends.

site_title: Glencore CEO to deliver management transition 'shortly'
summary: Glencore CEO Ivan Glasenberg announced a management transition "shortly" as part of a company-wide overhaul. Glasenberg, who plans to retire in 3-5 years, did not provide further details on the transition. This move comes amid a shift in the global commodities market, with rising gold prices and ongoing trade tensions between the US and other countries. The transition is expected to bring in new leadership at the mining and trading company, marking a significant change in Glasenberg's tenure.

site_title: WBL Corporation appoints SAC Capital as IFA
summary: WBL Corporation has appointed SAC Capital Private Limited as its independent financial adviser (IFA) to advise on a mandatory offer by Yanlord Land Group. The offer, valued at S$2.5947 per share, was triggered when Yanlord's stake in United Engineers (UE) crossed 50%. UE owns 69.14% of WBL, while Yanlord owns 29.9%. A circular with the IFA's advice will be sent to shareholders within 14 days.

site_title: France says EU will retaliate if US imposes tariffs on French products
summary: France's government warned that the European Union will retaliate with tariffs if the US imposes penalties on French products, valued at approximately $2.4 billion, over a tax dispute with tech companies. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that such behavior from the US is "not worthy of an ally" and that the EU is prepared to respond.

site_title: Singapore's men golfers aim high at SEA Games
summary: Singapore's men's golf team, consisting of Chiam, Low, Leow, and Hiroshi, is competing at the Southeast Asian Games in the Philippines. They will aim to win individual gold and defend the team title. However, their experience at the 2019 SEA Games, where they lost under pressure to defend their 27-year winning streak in water polo, suggests that motivation can be a stronger factor than defending a crown. The team's performance will be closely watched in the golf event.

site_title: White House considered kicking Huawei out of US banking system
summary: The Trump administration considered banning China's Huawei from the US financial system, including placing it on the Treasury Department's Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) list, as early as this year. The plan, which was ultimately shelved, aimed to thwart Huawei's blacklisted telecoms equipment by making it virtually impossible for the company to complete transactions in US dollars. The move was seen as a nuclear option and would have had broad, widespread implications for Huawei globally, but was tabled in favor of other measures, such as placing Huawei on a trade blacklist.

site_title: Activist Thunberg reaches Europe to take youth angst to UN climate summit
summary: Teen activist Greta Thunberg has arrived in Portugal after a 21-day catamaran journey across the Atlantic, where she will attend the UN climate summit in Spain. Thunberg, 16, has inspired a global protest movement with her determination to minimize her own carbon footprint and invoke the fury of global youth at politicians' foot-dragging over climate change. Her presence is seen as a symbol of resourcefulness and defiance, with some delegates calling for radical action to transform energy and transport systems to curb global temperatures.

site_title: Foxconn's Gou to discuss trade war, investment on US trip
summary: Terry Gou, founder of Apple supplier Foxconn, is discussing investment and the China-US trade war during his 10-day US trip, including meetings with administration officials and a possible meeting with President Trump. Gou, who stepped down as Foxconn's chief, aims to understand the trade war's conclusion and may discuss his company's investment plans in Wisconsin, where Foxconn initially pledged to create 13,000 jobs and build a $10 billion campus. However, the company has been reconsidering its plans due to difficulties in finding workers.

site_title: Trump will 'stay out' of UK election during Nato visit
summary: US President Donald Trump will not interfere in the UK election during his visit, promising to "stay out" of the campaign. Trump praised Prime Minister Boris Johnson and expressed his intention not to complicate the election process. Trump's visit to the NATO military alliance in Britain comes days before the December 12 vote.

site_title: Singapore factory activity stays in contraction in November, though PMI is up
summary: Singapore's factory activity remained in contraction for the seventh straight month in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising 0.2 point to 49.8. The improvement was driven by faster expansion in factory output and inventory, and slower contraction in new orders and employment. The manufacturing industry is believed to have bottomed in the third quarter, with some stabilisation expected, but modest growth in 2020 is unlikely. The electronics sector PMI also improved, but remained in contraction.

site_title: FWD to pull out of employee benefits business in Singapore
summary: FWD Group, an insurance arm of Hong Kong's Pacific Century Group, will wind down its employee benefits business in Singapore by December 2020. The move will impact over 80,000 members across various companies, and the insurer will no longer pitch for new contracts or renew existing ones. FWD will focus on other lines of business, including life and general insurance, and is in discussions with affected staff about next steps.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment renamed Zheneng Jinjiang Environment
summary: China's waste-to-energy firm, Zheneng Jinjiang Environment, has changed its name from Jinjiang Environment following a stake acquisition by state-owned enterprise Zhejiang Energy Group in August. The name change, effective November 25, reflects Zhejiang Energy's largest controlling shareholder status. The acquisition did not affect the company's legal status or shareholder rights. Zheneng Jinjiang Environment will leverage Zhejiang Energy's strength to build on its position as a leading private waste-to-energy operator in China.

site_title: Singapore public healthcare sector gets training boost
summary: Singapore's public healthcare sector is getting a training boost, with the National Healthcare Group (NHG) and Singapore Health Services (SingHealth) partnering with the Healthcare Academy to upskill and reskill 33,000 workers. The initiative aims to help workers adapt to a rapidly evolving healthcare landscape, with a focus on jobs such as health attendants, hospital porters, and pharmacy assistants. The training programs will be developed in collaboration with the management of NHG and SingHealth, with the goal of enhancing skills upgrading initiatives and preparing workers for new job roles.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.5% on Tuesday after Trump's tariff offensive
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-imposition of tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Brazil and Argentina led to a 0.5% decline in Singapore's stock market, despite a rally from tech manufacturers. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,173.08, with UMS Holdings and Avi-Tech Electronics advancing, while AEM Holdings fell. The market was also affected by soft US factory data and Trump's comments on the Federal Reserve.

site_title: China iron ore futures rebound as Vale cuts production outlook
summary: China's iron ore futures surged over 2% on Tuesday after Vale SA, the world's largest iron ore miner, lowered its production outlook for the first quarter of 2020. Vale cut output from its Brucutu mine in Brazil due to dam concerns, reducing its forecast to 68-73 million tonnes. This move, combined with low iron ore inventory at Chinese ports, led to a 2% increase in iron ore prices. Analysts expect steel prices to rise further, supporting further recovery in iron ore prices.

site_title: Europe set to overhaul its entire economy in green deal push
summary: The European Union is set to unveil a radical overhaul of its economy in an effort to become a climate-neutral continent by 2050. EU leaders will commit to cutting net greenhouse-gas emissions to zero, with a draft plan calling for increased green investment and policy adjustments. The European Commission will draft rules to transform the economy, with a proposed law in March aiming to make the transition irreversible. The EU aims to put the bloc ahead of other major emitters, including China and the US, in the fight against climate change.

images.alt_text: "If our common goal is to be a climate-neutral continent in 2050, we have to act now," Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, told a United Nations climate conference.

site_title: Singapore retailers score hat trick with mega sales events
summary: Singapore retailers achieved a "hat trick" of successful sales events, with Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and Singles Day resulting in significant revenue growth. Consumer electronics retailer Gain City reported a 413% increase in revenue for Black Friday, while Amazon Singapore saw an 84% year-on-year increase in sales. E-commerce platform Shopee found that Singles Day sales focused on mobile and gadgets, while Cyber Monday sales focused on beauty and personal care products. Despite some retailers experiencing dampened sales due to the proximity of Singles Day, overall, the sales events were a success, with many retailers reporting significant revenue growth.

images.alt_text: It's officially sale season, and while consumers are happy with the deals they scored from the Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales, retailers are even happier with their takings at the till.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.7%. Paris's CAC 40 rose 0.2%. The divergence is attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks are a focus.

site_title: Budget 2020 to 'transform, support and sustain', says Indranee Rajah
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 aims to "transform, support and sustain" the economy amidst an increasingly challenging external environment, including US-China trade tensions and growing income inequality. Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah emphasized the need for strategic financial planning to position the country for the future. A Goods and Services Tax hike, rising security spending, and increased social spending on younger families and older workers are expected. The government also plans to introduce a GST offset package for Singaporeans.

site_title: Singapore salaries to rise in 2020 as talent pool is 'shrinking': Mercer survey
summary: Singapore companies plan to increase salaries by 3.7% in 2020, up from 3.6% this year, to retain staff amid a shrinking talent pool. One in three companies now offer retention bonuses, up from one in four in 2017. This move aims to counteract the headwinds facing the Singapore economy.

site_title: Grocery wars await amid Indonesian retail woes
summary: Indonesian grocery stores face a challenging 2020 due to declining revenue and earnings, according to Fitch Ratings. Despite year-end festivities, analysts expect revenue and earnings to remain stagnant. Large-scale retailers, such as Hero Supermarket and Matahari Putra Prima, struggle due to cuts in store count and operational inefficiencies. In contrast, minimart chains like Alfamart and Indomart are expected to benefit from increasing customer preference for mini-markets. The report highlights the need for these retailers to improve operational efficiency and target middle- to high-income customer segments to regain profits.

site_title: Trump says China trade deal might have to wait for 2020 election
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that a trade agreement with China might have to wait until after the 2020 presidential election, potentially delaying a resolution to the ongoing trade dispute. Trump expressed willingness to wait, but emphasized the need for a "right" deal, contrasting with China's desire for a quick agreement. This development could have implications for the global economy and ongoing trade negotiations.

site_title: Builder of ex-1MDB project weighs IPO for as early as 2020
summary: Iskandar Waterfront Holdings Sdn, the builder of the Bandar Malaysia project, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) as early as 2020 to fund the US$33.5 billion development. The company is working with an adviser for a listing that may value it at about 30 billion ringgit (S$9.82 billion). The project, initially conceived under 1MDB, was revived in April after a dispute over payments was resolved. The IPO would help the developers meet the project's funding requirements.

site_title: Mirach Energy to remain on SGX watchlist
summary: Mirach Energy will remain on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watchlist due to two Trade with Caution (TWC) alerts and unusual trading activities. The company's share price rose, but the SGX regulator found artificial valuations, with a small group of individuals responsible for most buy volume. Despite meeting the minimum trading price criteria, SGX RegCo will ignore the artificial distortions, keeping Mirach Energy on the watchlist.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with slight losses on Tuesday due to fresh trade war worries. The Hang Seng index fell 0.20%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.31%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.55%. The losses were pared from the start of the day, with investors reacting to new US President Trump's threats to extend trade tensions.

site_title: Accrelist to acquire 49% stake in Malaysian aesthetics company
summary: Accrelist's subsidiary, Accrelist Medical Aesthetics, is acquiring 49% of Ozhean Accrelist Aesthetics Sdn Bhd in Malaysia for RM490,000 (S$161,535), valuing the company at approximately RM860,646. Ozhean offers cosmetic dermatology, skin laser services, and other health services. The acquisition price is a premium to the company's net asset value due to startup costs, but Accrelist believes the value will increase once operations begin.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall as Trump's tariffs on Brazil, Argentina hit risk appetite
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.38% on Tuesday, with the KOSPI index closing at 2,084.07, after US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on select imports from Brazil and Argentina, sparking fears of a trade war. Weak US manufacturing data also contributed to the decline. Foreigners sold $229.88 million worth of shares for the 19th consecutive session, bringing the KOSPI's year-to-date gain to 2.11%.

site_title: Thakral buys Queensland property to further expand into retirement housing
summary: Thakral Corporation, a Singapore-listed developer, has acquired 46.4 hectares of land in Queensland, Australia for A$20 million to expand its GemLife joint venture's retirement housing portfolio. The site, located in Pimpama, will feature 450 modern, low-maintenance homes and premium community facilities. Construction is expected to begin in Q4 2020, bringing the total number of residences under GemLife's umbrella to over 1,800. The acquisition aligns with Thakral's strategy to grow its real estate investments for sustainable returns, driven by the growing demand for retirement housing.

site_title: MVLLABS raises US$5m in Series A funding to grow mobility ecosystem
summary: Singapore-based startup MVLLABS, the company behind ride-hailing service TADA, has raised US$5 million in Series A funding led by South Korean venture capital firm SV Investment. The investment will be used to develop competencies for delivering new products based on MVLLABS' blockchain technology, capitalizing on TADA's growth. MVLLABS' CEO Kay Woo expects to announce "many other firsts" in the region in the coming months.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit to acquire 3 Japanese healthcare properties for S$46.3m
summary: Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) is acquiring three nursing rehabilitation facilities in Japan for approximately S$46.3 million. The acquisition, expected to be completed by December 2019, will bring PLife Reit's portfolio to 53 properties with a total value of S$1.92 billion. The properties are located in Gifu, Wakayama, and Yamaguchi Prefectures, marking PLife Reit's maiden foray into Gifu and Wakayama Prefectures. The acquisition is expected to generate a net property yield of 6.8%.

site_title: SIA under probe in Australia after B-747 engine pod hits the ground at Sydney Airport
summary: Singapore Airlines is under investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau after an engine pod on a Boeing 747 freighter aircraft hit the ground during a missed landing at Sydney Airport on November 28. The incident, described as "serious," occurred during a go-around procedure and involved no passengers. Investigations will include interviews with flight crew and review of cockpit recorded data, with a report expected by mid-2020.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.28 points to 1,562.27. The market saw 2.3 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 539 to 289.

site_title: Hong Kong protests force Ce La Vi sky bar to quit lease early
summary: Ce La Vi, a luxury rooftop bar and restaurant in Hong Kong's Lan Kwai Fong district, is closing early due to the ongoing protests. The business asked for an early lease termination in January, citing the protests as a factor, and will be replaced by another concept possibly including an Italian restaurant, cigar bar, and rooftop terrace. The protests have already led to the closure of around 100 restaurants and affected 2,000 employees.

site_title: Italy's biggest bank UniCredit to shed 8,000 jobs by 2023
summary: UniCredit, Italy's largest bank, plans to eliminate 8,000 jobs in Western Europe and close 500 branches by 2023, cutting costs by 1 billion euros. The measures, 12% of full-time equivalent positions and 17% of branches, aim to increase shareholder payouts to 50% of net profit by 2023. The bank's 2020-2023 Strategic Plan also includes a 40% payout to shareholders, with 2 billion euros coming from share buybacks, and forecasts annual revenue growth of 0.8%.

images.alt_text: UniCredit, Italy's biggest bank by assets, said on Tuesday that it would eliminate 8,000 jobs in Western Europe and close 500 branches by 2023 to cut costs by a billion euros.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down after falls in US
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.64% and the Topix index down 0.45%, due to investors locking in profits following declines in US shares. The US shares were pressured by weak data and trade worries.

site_title: France and EU ready to fight back over US tariff threat, ministers say
summary: France and the European Union are prepared to retaliate against the US threat to impose up to 100% tariffs on $2.4 billion of French imports, including champagne and cheese, over a digital services tax. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire described the US proposals as "unacceptable," while junior economy minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher vowed that France would not back down on its digital tax plans. The EU is ready to "riposte" if the US imposes sanctions, and shares in French luxury goods fell 1.4% in early trading.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Ministry of National Development reported that the supply of private housing units in Singapore remains high at around 39,000 units, despite a decline over the past few quarters. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The US and South Korea are in trade talks, with South Korea seeking a 'landing zone' for negotiations. In other news, the UK economy shrank for the second month, and Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May. US Senator Rubio is set to meet China's Wang on the sidelines of Asean talks.

site_title: Huawei plans to shift research centre to Canada from US
summary: Huawei plans to shift its research centre to Canada from the US, according to founder Ren Zhengfei. The move comes as the US weighs expanding its power to stop foreign shipments of products with US technology to Huawei, which was placed on a trade blacklist in May due to national security concerns. Huawei will also build new factory capacity in Europe to make 5G networking equipment.
