site_title: Shelley Morrison,'Will & Grace' actress, dies at 83
summary: Shelley Morrison, actress best known for her role as Rosario on NBC's "Will & Grace" from 1999 to 2006, died in Los Angeles on Sunday at 83 due to heart failure. Born in the Bronx to Spanish immigrant parents, Morrison had a 64-year acting career, including roles in "The Flying Nun," "Murder She Wrote," and "L.A. Law." Her husband, Walter Dominguez, described her as a proud advocate for social equity and fairness for the LGBTQ+ community through comedy. Morrison lived in the same Los Angeles apartment building for 69 years.

site_title: Hong Kong airlines given one week to save its licence
summary: Hong Kong Airlines has been given a one-week deadline by the Air Transport Licensing Authority to raise more cash or risk losing its licence. The airline's finances have deteriorated due to the ongoing anti-Beijing protests in Hong Kong, which have led to a decline in visitor numbers and economic growth. If Hong Kong Airlines fails to improve its financial situation, it could have its licence revoked or suspended. The airline has acknowledged the difficulties and is working to improve its finances, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: Choose hope or climate surrender, says UN chief
summary: UN chief Antonio Guterres has urged world leaders to choose between hope and surrender in the face of the climate crisis, warning that humanity is at a "point of no return" if it fails to take drastic action. The UN climate conference in Madrid comes as the US, under President Donald Trump, has withdrawn from the Paris Agreement, despite many states and cities in the country committing to its targets. Guterres cited new findings from the World Meteorological Organisation confirming the last five years have been the hottest ever recorded, and urged governments to put a price on carbon and stop subsidies on fossil fuels.

site_title: Sterling falls as probability of hung Parliament grows
summary: The pound fell 0.1% to $1.2935 due to a narrowing of the Conservative Party's lead over Labour in polls, increasing the probability of a hung Parliament in the UK's Dec 12 election. The lead had narrowed from 7 points to 9 percentage points in the past week. Investors have been preparing for potential volatility in the pound, with implied volatility gauges rising to 13.7 vol, the highest in six weeks. A hung Parliament would make it harder for Prime Minister Boris Johnson to pass the Brexit deal, potentially affecting the pound's value.

images.alt_text: The pound was sluggish on Monday as polls showed that the Conservative Party was leading albeit with a smaller advantage, increasing the probability that the Dec 12 UK election will end in a hung parliament.

site_title: Supply chain solutions startup DiMuto secures investment from SGInnovate
summary: Singapore-based supply chain solutions startup DiMuto has secured an investment from government-owned venture firm SGInnovate. The investment will help DiMuto further capitalize on its global growth momentum and drive international expansion into Europe and Latin America. DiMuto, which provides end-to-end supply chain visibility for the fruits industry, has tagged over 30 million fruits and tracked $100 million worth of agri-food trades. The company will leverage blockchain, IoT, and AI to tackle global trade and supply-chain problems.

site_title: Napoleon's boots walk tall at Paris auction
summary: A pair of boots worn by Napoleon during his final exile on St Helena sold at a Paris auction for 117,000 euros, more than twice the initial estimate. The size 40 boots, saved by General Henri Gatien Bertrand, were gifted to a sculptor and later passed down to his family. Napoleon, who was 1.69 meters tall, had a large collection of footwear, and the boots were expected to fetch between 50,000 and 80,000 euros. The sale highlights the enduring fascination with Napoleon's life and legacy.

site_title: Brenda Ong named head of Cushman & Wakefield's industrial, logistics business in Singapore
summary: Cushman & Wakefield appoints Brenda Ong as head of its industrial and logistics business in Singapore, bringing over 20 years of experience in the sector. She joins from CBRE, where she was part of several senior-level departures. Ong's appointment is seen as a strategic move to bolster the company's industrial and logistics capability, as the sector continues to evolve with technological advancements. She reports to Dennis Yeo, CEO of Cushman & Wakefield in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: Most civil servants to get 0.1 month year-end bonus amid 'economic uncertainties'
summary: Civil servants in Singapore will receive a year-end bonus of 0.1 month and an additional lump sum of S$250 to S$1,500, with senior civil servants in superscale grades receiving a one-off payment of S$400. This decision was made due to prevailing economic uncertainties, with the Public Service Division exercising restraint in the bonus payment.

site_title: Nomura CEO to step down
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc CEO Koji Nagai is stepping down after seven years, handing over to Deputy CEO Kentaro Okuda on April 1. Nagai's departure comes as the company's overseas restructuring shows signs of success, with shares reaching a 52-week high. Okuda faces the challenge of reviving Japan's retail operations, which have slumped in stock trading. Nagai's departure follows a narrow reappointment to the board earlier this year after regulatory penalties, and his shares have climbed 69% from the year's low.

site_title: BreadTalk Group terminates JV agreement with Indonesian partner for Toast Box
summary: BreadTalk Group announced the termination of its joint-venture agreement with Indonesian partner PT Pura Indah Berkat, effective immediately. PT PIB will transfer its 30% equity interest to BreadTalk Pte Ltd for US$1.00, resulting in BreadTalk International holding 70% and BreadTalk Pte Ltd holding 30%. The JV company, PT BTG Pura Indah Berkat Venture, will continue to operate the Toast Box chain in Indonesia, with no expected impact on the group's financials. The agreement was mutually agreed upon and completed on December 2, 2019.

site_title: Saudi exchange to limit Aramco index weighting with cap
summary: Saudi Arabia's Tadawul exchange has introduced an equity index cap of 15% to limit the weighting of Saudi Aramco, the largest oil company, when it lists on the exchange. The move aims to address concerns over Aramco's dominance and ensure more balanced indices. Aramco is expected to list 1.5% of its shares this month, which could raise over $25 billion, and the cap will be effective by the end of the year. The cap will limit any constituent's index weight to 15% to prevent dominance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's FLT and FCOT propose a S$1.58 billion merger, aiming for a 50% stake in a UK business park. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra is confident that a Thai court will clear his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case. The Asean region agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy shrinks for the second month, and South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Japan to buy US$146m island for US military drills
summary: Japan has agreed to purchase the uninhabited Mageshima island off its southwest coast for $146 million to support US military drills. The island was previously chosen as a training site for US fighter jets in 2011, but the US requested a move due to its distance from a military base. A facility will be built on the island for landing practice, and Japan's military will rely on the US under a bilateral security alliance. The acquisition is part of Japan's efforts to support US military operations and has raised concerns among local residents.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher on upbeat China factory activity data
summary: South Korea's main stock market, the KOSPI, closed higher on Monday, rising 0.19% to 2,091.92 points, driven by positive China factory activity data. China's Caixin/Markit manufacturing PMI rose to 51.8 in November, the fastest expansion since December 2016. However, South Korea's factory activity continued to shrink for an eighth straight month, and exports fell for the 12th month in a row. The US-China trade deal is now "stalled" due to Hong Kong legislation, according to a source close to US President Trump's negotiating team.

site_title: S-Reits face limited risk of big price correction: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse believes Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) face limited risk of significant price corrections in 2020, as long as global borrowing rates remain low. S-Reits with strong acquisition pipelines and those with opportunities to enhance assets are likely to outperform. Despite a muted growth environment, Singapore equities are expected to perform in line with regional markets, with a forecasted 3.5% earnings growth and an average dividend yield of 4.4%. The low interest rate environment may keep S-Reit prices stable but cap yields, while limiting upside for Singapore's three banks.

site_title: Germany aims to shield tech firms from foreign takeovers
summary: Germany's economy ministry plans to tighten rules on non-EU takeovers of high-tech firms, aiming to shield German companies from foreign acquisitions. The proposed amendment would allow the government to review or block foreign purchases of stakes as low as 10% in critical technology companies, including those in robotics, AI, semiconductors, biotechnology, and quantum technology. The move comes amid growing concerns about Chinese firms buying up German know-how.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare's mandatory offer turns unconditional
summary: ISEC Healthcare's mandatory offer has turned unconditional, with Aier Eye International and its concert parties controlling approximately 50.58% of total shares. The offer price marks a 5.88% premium over the previous closing price and will remain open until Dec 20. An independent financial adviser, CIMB Bank Berhad, deemed the offer "not fair but reasonable", citing the offer price's relation to historical trading performance and valuation multiples. The offeror is seeking statutory control to grow its own business, but the price is considered reasonable compared to the company's historical performance.

site_title: 800 Super opens S$130m Tuas plant, announces new business lines
summary: 800 Super, a Singapore waste management company, has officially opened a new integrated energy and resource recovery facility in Tuas South, costing over S$130 million. The company also announced plans to enter the animal feed processing business and provide heating services for third-party ISO tank containers. Executive chairman Lee Koh Yong stated that the company is seeking opportunities to strengthen its value proposition to customers.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares gain on improving China data
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, driven by improved China data, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.01% to 23,529.50. This marked the first time China's factory activity had rebounded in seven months, despite uncertainty over US-China trade talks. The broader Topix index also rose 0.89%. The gains were seen as positive for the market, as investors look to the ongoing US-China trade talks for signs of a resolution.

site_title: Japanese restaurants rocket to top of best in world list
summary: Two Japanese restaurants, Yosuke Suga's Sugalabo and Ryugin, have reached the top spot on the La Liste ranking of best places to eat in the world, alongside Paris's Guy Savoy. Sugalabo, with only 20 tables, rose 30 places to share the top spot, while Ryugin jumped 30 places to also reach the shared number one spot. Japanese cuisine leads the country table with 130 top-ranked restaurants, followed by China with 126.

site_title: Prime US Reit included in MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index
summary: Prime US Reit has been included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index, effective as of November 26. The company's inclusion is seen as an important milestone, aiming to diversify its unitholder base and enhance trading liquidity. Prime US Reit focuses on US office assets with a portfolio of 11 freehold properties valued at US$1.2 billion. The company's CEO, Barbara Cambon, stated that this inclusion will help maximize value-creation for unitholders in the long run.

site_title: Gold slips on firm US dollar, positive China factory data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,459.23 per ounce as investors shifted to riskier assets following China's expanding factory sector and a rising US dollar. The unexpected expansion in factory activity in China, combined with a stronger dollar, reduced demand for gold. Analysts expect gold to recover, citing supportive fundamentals, and predict prices will trade between $1,450-$1,500 until year-end.

site_title: 'Curry for salarymen': Top 'La Liste' chef recalls early days
summary: Tokyo chef Seiji Yamamoto, 49, of Ryugin restaurant, which ranked joint top of La Liste's "guide of guides," once relied on whipping up lowly curry to fill his empty tables. Yamamoto's meticulous approach, including using CT scans to understand fish bone structure, contributed to his restaurant's success. He attributes his innovative approach to attracting diners to his early days, recalling a time when he had to be creative to attract customers to his restaurant.

site_title: Chaswood proposes to issue S$50m in 1% convertible notes
summary: CHASWOOD Resources is proposing to issue S$50 million worth of 1% convertible notes due 2022 to private subscribers in four tranches. The notes can be converted to shares from the time of issuance until one week before maturity. The first three tranches will be S$10 million each, and the final tranche will be S$20 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.01% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Monday afternoon, edging down 0.01% on the day to 3,193.46. Despite this, gainers outnumbered losers 170 to 136, with Singtel up 1.5% and Thai Beverage up 1.7%. Other Asian markets, including Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong, gained on Monday morning. The Straits Times Index was nearly flat, with UOB up 0.1%, DBS down 0.3%, and OCBC down 0.2%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks skid 1.5% on foreign investor selling amid HK unrest
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.5% on Friday amid foreign investor selling due to concerns over Hong Kong unrest and the uncertainty of a US-China trade deal. Foreigners sold 450.9 billion won worth of shares, the largest since August 2015. The won dropped 0.19% against the US dollar, and the Kospi index fell 1.45% to its lowest close in a month. The central bank left interest rates steady, but trimmed growth and inflation projections, suggesting more policy easing next year.

site_title: Innovative Supply Chain Changing the SME Game
summary: Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Southeast Asia are quickly adopting innovative technologies to lower barriers and catch up with larger players. Lean teams are embracing off-the-shelf technology to streamline their supply chains, aided by supportive governments and business environments. Thailand and Singapore have introduced initiatives to help local SMEs digitalize, positioning them for success in the digital economy. This shift is expected to significantly improve SMEs' competitiveness and growth prospects.

site_title: Thailand reverses ban on weed killer linked to cancer
summary: Thailand has reversed its decision to ban glyphosate, a weedkiller linked to cancer, and will permit its limited use for farmers until June 1, 2020. The decision, made by the National Hazardous Substances Committee, also extends the use of two other pesticides, paraquat and chlorpyrifos, for six months. The move is seen as a compromise between the agriculture industry and environmental groups, who have raised concerns about the health risks of these chemicals.

site_title: HSBC gives Hong Kong staff extra day off for 'perseverance'
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is giving its Hong Kong employees an extra day off next year as a gesture of appreciation for their perseverance during six months of street protests. The bank, which employs about 21,000 people in the city, cited the need to sustain operations and support customers amid the turmoil. The move comes as HSBC faces pressure from trade tension and economic challenges in Hong Kong.

site_title: OUELH to co-develop Shenzhen hospital for 126.3m yuan
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare (OUELH) will co-develop a hospital in Shenzhen, China, with China Merchants Group (CMG) for 126.3 million yuan. OUELH acquired a 50% stake in Riviera Quad International, which owns the land parcel, from China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone (CMSK) for the investment. The hospital project is expected to complete within the fourth quarter of fiscal 2019. This deal marks OUELH's collaboration with CMG, with which it is already working to manage three hospitals in China.

site_title: LG replaces CEO, top executives after losses
summary: LG Electronics replaced its CEO, Jo Seong-jin, and top executives after net profits slumped 30.5% in the third quarter. Jo, who lacks a college degree, struggled to turn around the failing smartphone division, which reported its 18th consecutive quarter of losses. He was replaced by Brian Kwon, a 32-year LG veteran with a degree in industrial engineering. The company also changed its CFO and created a new CSO position. The move aims for a "fast decision-making process" and comes after a period of declining profits.

site_title: China picks new leaders for Macau, replaces economy chief
summary: China has appointed new officials to head Macau, a special administrative region, with Ho Iat Seng becoming the new Chief Executive. The changes come as Macau's casino industry experiences declining revenues and ahead of President Xi Jinping's visit. Fujian-born Lei Wai Nong replaces Lionel Leong as economy secretary, with a fresh outlook that may help diversify the economy. The new team will play a key role in determining the future of the casino industry, which accounts for over 80% of government revenues.

site_title: Norwegian Air to end routes from Sweden, Denmark to US, Thailand
summary: Norwegian Air is ending flights from Copenhagen and Stockholm to the US and Thailand due to weak demand and technical issues with its Boeing 787 Dreamliners. Flights between Oslo and the US will continue. The airline cited high debts and reduced capacity by 10% next year as reasons for the cuts. The decision affects routes that challenged traditional carriers like British Airways with low fares. Norwegian will instead increase flights from European cities to US destinations.

site_title: Shootouts in northern Mexico kill 21, pile pressure on president
summary: Shootouts in northern Mexico between police and suspected cartel gunmen killed 21 people, including four police officers. The incidents occurred in the town of Villa Union, near the Texas border, and raise concerns about the government's approach to handling powerful gangs. Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador repeated his stance against foreign intervention, while the US is set to discuss security cooperation with Mexico amid bilateral tensions sparked by US President Donald Trump's comments on designating the cartels as terrorists.

site_title: Tuas Avenue 6 industrial site on reserve list triggered for tender: JTC
summary: JTC has accepted an application to put up the 0.55-hectare Tuas Avenue 6 industrial site on reserve list for sale by public tender. The site has a 20-year tenure, gross plot ratio of 1.4, and is zoned B2 for industrial purposes. A committed bid price of not less than S$2.55 million was received, and the public tender is scheduled for Dec 31 with a six-week tender period. This is the first site to be triggered for launch under the second half 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales Programme.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise, bonds slide after China industry data
summary: Asian stocks rose, with Japan's Topix index leading gains, after China's better-than-expected manufacturing data suggested the global economy is stabilizing. The Shanghai Composite and Australian markets also rose, while US Treasury yields climbed to 1.8%. Hong Kong shares gained modestly despite ongoing protests. Oil prices recovered from a 5%+ sell-off on Friday. The data release also boosted S&P 500 futures, but US-China trade deal uncertainty remains a concern.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; up 0.31%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.31% to 3,203.79 at Monday's open, tracking gains in Tokyo amid China's November factory activity rebounding for the first time in seven months. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 46, with Singtel, ThaiBev, and Golden Agri-Resources among the most active counters. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC trading higher.

site_title: China may slow up on IPOs amid waning investor interest
summary: China's stock regulator has vowed to slow down initial public offerings (IPOs) amid waning investor interest. The China Securities Regulatory Commission will approve future proposed IPOs at a "steady" pace, limiting risks in the market. This follows recent IPOs experiencing quick price pullbacks and cooling investor demand. The regulator aims to strike a balance between reforms and affordability, with stricter requirements for listing candidates. As of this year, 174 companies have gone public in China, raising 202.7 billion yuan. The move is seen as a response to market concerns and efforts to control risks.

site_title: Hong Kong says unrest costing 2 percentage points of GDP growth
summary: Hong Kong is expected to record its first budget deficit since 2004 due to an adverse economic environment caused by ongoing protests and the US-China trade war. The economy is forecast to contract 1.3% in 2019, with a 2% point loss in GDP growth. Financial Secretary Paul Chan attributed the deficit to decreased tax revenue, land sales, and relief measures, urging different sectors to come together to restore social order and create room for rational dialogue. The current fiscal year ends March 31, 2020.

site_title: S Korea to suspend 25% of coal plants to fight pollution
summary: South Korea plans to suspend up to a quarter of its 60 coal-fired power plants from Sunday until February 29 to combat air pollution. The move aims to reduce fine dust production by up to 44% and is expected to maintain a stable power supply despite peak electricity demand during winter. The country will suspend 15 plants and reduce output of the remaining 45 plants to 80% capacity. The measures are in response to growing public concern over airborne pollutants and are seen as a step to address the issue.

site_title: Nigerian farmers hope to spread shea butter wealth
summary: Nigerian farmers are seeking to capitalize on the growing demand for shea butter, a valuable oil extracted from the nuts of the shea tree. The global market is expected to be worth $3.5 billion by 2028, and Nigeria has the potential to satisfy up to 60% of global demand. However, the country's export of shea nuts is limited, with only 10% being processed and sold to lucrative world markets. Nigerian authorities aim to boost domestic agriculture and tap into the value of millions of shea trees, but improving quality and addressing logistical challenges will be crucial to unlocking the industry's full potential.

site_title: PBOC ready with prudent policy for long global downturn
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang says the country's monetary policy should remain prudent, with room for adjustment, as a prolonged global economic downturn is likely. Yi wrote that lowering interest rates to zero won't work and that the mission of monetary policy is to keep prices stable and protect people's money from inflation. The PBOC will stick to conventional policy, avoiding competitive depreciation and quantitative easing, as the world's economic downturn is expected to last for a long time.

site_title: In Deutsche Bank's giant yard sale, Goldman is eager buyer
summary: Deutsche Bank has sold securities worth about 40 billion pounds (S$71 billion) to Goldman Sachs, the US bank's second major purchase of unwanted assets since the German lender's turnaround plan was announced in July. The deal involves emerging market debt and is part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to reduce assets and replenish capital buffers. The sale is expected to help Goldman expand its market share and brand, while also allowing the German bank to meet its leverage exposure goals. Deutsche Bank shares rose 1.9% on the news, paring this year's decline.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG has found a willing partner in Goldman Sachs Group Inc as the German lender tries to quickly offload billions of euros worth of unwanted assets.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, driven by data showing a rise in Chinese factory activity. The Hang Seng index increased 0.51% to 26,480.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.09% to 2,874.45. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.17%. The gains followed easing concerns about China's economy.

site_title: China Everbright bags 2 waste water treatment projects worth 279m yuan
summary: China Everbright Water has secured two waste water treatment projects worth 279 million yuan (S$54.2 million). The company has entered into 20-year concession agreements with two Chinese cities, Zhuanghe and Ju County, to operate projects with capacities of 50,000 and 80,000 cubic meters. Everbright Water will invest 140 million yuan in the Zhuanghe project and 139 million yuan in the Ju County project.

site_title: Michelin brands French chef 'diva' in 'Cheddargate' case
summary: French celebrity chef Marc Veyrat is suing Michelin for "dishonouring" him after the guide stripped his restaurant of a third star, claiming an inspector mistakenly identified a souffle as containing cheddar instead of French cheeses. Michelin calls Veyrat a "narcissistic diva" and is counter-suing for costs and compensation. If Veyrat wins, it could set a precedent for other chefs and force Michelin to release its secret judging notes, potentially causing an earthquake in the restaurant world.

images.alt_text: A French celebrity chef has been branded a "diva" for taking the Michelin guide to court Wednesday for suggesting he used cheddar cheese in a souffle.

site_title: In New York, grocery deliveries go high-tech
summary: In New York, grocery delivery company FreshDirect has implemented a high-tech system to streamline its operations at its Bronx warehouse. The system recognizes individual customers and optimizes delivery times based on their ordering history. The warehouse features conveyor belts that carry large bins through multiple levels of shelves, with robots picking out small products and employees handling larger items. FreshDirect's data-driven approach allows it to accurately predict supply and minimize waste, and the company dominates the New York grocery delivery market with 68% market share.

site_title: Japan's cherry blossom scandal starts to drag down Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support rating dropped 6 percentage points to 42% in November amid the cherry blossom scandal, the lowest since his cabinet reshuffle in September. The opposition accuses Abe of misdirecting public funds to supporters from his constituency by inviting them to exclusive Tokyo package tours. The scandal has deepened with questions about organised crime figures and shredded documents, prompting concerns about Abe's favoured treatment of supporters. A decline in support could influence whether Abe decides to call an early election before the 2020 Olympics.

site_title: Record M&A in Singapore property managers as investors pile in
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (REITs) have seen record-breaking M&A activity, with US$16.9 billion spent on asset purchases this year, triple the previous peak. The sector has also raised a record US$5 billion in fundraising, with analysts predicting more deals in the coming year. The trend is driven by investors seeking yield, with the sector's estimated dividend yield at 5.36%, and looser debt rules being considered by the central bank to facilitate further acquisitions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on sound China data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by China's rebounding factory activity, which marked the first time in seven months. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.43% and the Topix index rose 0.41%. The positive news comes despite uncertainty over US-China trade talks, with stocks continuing their rally ahead of GDP data from Singapore and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Japan Q3 corporate capital spending jumps; profit and sales fall
summary: Japan's Q3 corporate capital spending rose 7.1% from the same period last year, driven by manufacturers' expenditure gains, but corporate profit and sales fell 5.3% and 2.6% respectively due to a prolonged Sino-US trade war and slowing China's economy. Capital expenditure slipped 0.8% seasonally adjusted from the previous quarter. The data is a rare bright spot for an economy weakened by falling demand, with firms boosting spending on plants and equipment to offset a labour market that remains close to its tightest in 45 years.

site_title: Well-located One Holland Village Residences draws healthy sales
summary: A consortium comprising Far East Organization, Sekisui House, and Sino Group sold 92 units of One Holland Village Residences in Singapore, with 90% of buyers being Singaporeans. The average sale prices were S$2,600 psf for Sereen, S$2,900 psf for Leven, and S$3,200 psf for Quincy Private Residences. The project's proximity to the Holland Village MRT Station and surrounding amenities contributed to the positive sales outcome, with buyers praising the apartment layout and design.

site_title: Trump off to London for Nato summit, under pressure to steer clear of British election
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to attend the NATO summit in London, where he will face pressure from British Prime Minister Boris Johnson to refrain from commenting on the UK's upcoming election. Trump has a history of showing support for Brexit and criticizing British politicians, but Johnson's pressure has prompted the White House to stress the need for Trump to avoid wading into the election. Trump will meet with NATO leaders and discuss China's expansionist policies during the two-day summit.

site_title: Israel's drone industry becomes global force
summary: Israel's drone industry has emerged as a global force, competing with China and the US in the multibillion-dollar UAV market. With its unique selling point being its extensive military experience, Israel has developed cutting-edge drones, such as the WanderB VTol, which can take off and land vertically. The country's industry benefits from its former military and intelligence officials, who provide real-time feedback and accelerate development cycles. Israel is reportedly the world's largest exporter of drones, but the US has recently surpassed it due to increased exports of its Global Hawk and Predator drones.

site_title: Oil rebounds as Iraq signals deeper cuts ahead of Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1.9% after Iraq signaled deeper production cuts ahead of an Opec+ meeting, contrary to initial indications. Iraq's oil minister said the nation may cut 400,000 barrels a day, while Saudi Arabia is expected to indicate it's no longer willing to compensate for non-compliant members. The news lifted West Texas Intermediate to $56.22 a barrel and Brent to $61.34 a barrel. The rebound came as a gauge of China's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery in November, and a potential trade deal between the US and China may also support oil prices.

site_title: Nissan's new CEO takes over with long list of problems to fix
summary: Nissan's new CEO, Makoto Uchida, takes over with a long list of challenges, including profits at decade lows, 12,500 job cuts, and a damaged relationship with Renault. Uchida, a 53-year-old former joint venture executive, aims to restore the brand image and roll out new cars to appeal to buyers. He faces pressure from shareholders, who have seen the stock fall 23% this year, and must repair ties with Renault, which has a 43% stake in Nissan. Analysts predict a slow recovery, and time is running out for Uchida to deliver results within half a year.

site_title: Online sales break Black Friday record as clicks beat queues
summary: Black Friday broke a US$7.4 billion online sales record, surpassing previous records set by Cyber Monday. This marks the second-largest US online sales day, with $2.9 billion of sales made by smartphone on Friday. Shoppers increasingly prefer buying online, with many opting for mobile purchases. Despite this, some shoppers still prefer the in-store experience, with 6% more people visiting stores this year. Overall, it remains unclear how much of the holiday season's sales will be spent online versus in stores.

site_title: Hong Kong property faces a trust deficit
summary: Hong Kong's property market is facing a trust deficit due to the reluctance of developers to divest their prized assets, resulting in a discount to net asset value. Spinning off rental properties into real estate investment trusts (Reits) could help narrow the gap, but income taxes are a major obstacle. Unlike Singapore, Hong Kong's Reit market is taxed like corporations, limiting its growth. The Hang Seng Properties Index has slumped 17% since April, and many developers are trading at a discount to the value of their assets, stifling growth and limiting shareholder value.

site_title: Australia home frenzy returns as prices surge most in 16 years
summary: Australian home prices surged 1.7% in November, the largest gain in 16 years, according to CoreLogic data. Sydney and Melbourne led the rebound, with prices up 2.7% and 2.2% respectively. The rapid recovery is attributed to record-low interest rates, loosened lending curbs, and a shortage of properties on the market, fueling a renewed fear among buyers to miss out on the opportunity to buy. The Australian housing market is now experiencing its fifth consecutive month of rapid growth.

site_title: Flights axed as Typhoon Kammuri intensifies ahead of Philippines hit
summary: Typhoon Kammuri, intensifying with winds of 150km/h, prompted airlines to cancel flights and local authorities to suspend classes in the Philippines. The storm, the 20th to hit the country this year, follows a similar track to the 2014 typhoon Rammasun, which killed 106 people. Maximum gusts of 185 kph were recorded, causing concern for property damage. Residents were advised to take precautions as the storm approached the main island of Luzon.

site_title: Mapletree targets 12% IRR for Australia office fund
summary: Mapletree Investments successfully closed a new Australian private commercial trust, MASCOT Private Trust, at A$654 million (S$608 million) in total fund equity. The trust owns 10 Grade A office assets in key Australian cities, targeting a 12% internal rate of return. Mapletree will retain a 27% stake in the trust, with a term of five years and provision for two extensions. The trust has a 94% occupancy rate and draws from institutional investors, with a strong focus on Australia's growing economy and limited supply of quality office assets.

site_title: CCCS raises competition concerns on proposed merger of S Korean shipbuilders
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has raised concerns over the proposed merger of South Korean shipbuilders Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering Co Ltd (KSOE) and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co Ltd (DSME). The merger could remove competition in the global supply of liquefied natural gas carriers, large containerships, and large oil tankers, potentially harming customers in Singapore. KSOE and DSME may offer commitments to address concerns or face a detailed Phase 2 review by the CCCS.

site_title: 'Still angry': Hong Kong protesters return to the streets
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters in Hong Kong took to the streets on Sunday, a week after pro-democracy candidates won a landslide local election victory, as tensions with the Beijing-backed government escalated. Police fired tear gas and pepper spray, and hardcore protesters vandalized businesses, leading to multiple arrests. The rally marked a return to large-scale demonstrations after a rare lull, with protesters demanding direct elections and an end to authoritarian rule. The government has offered no concessions, fueling the protesters' determination to continue their fight for freedom.

site_title: British PM Boris Johnson doubles down on security theme after knife attack
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is focusing on security ahead of a terror attack in London that killed two people. Johnson's Conservatives will emphasize law and order, while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn criticizes the government's handling of early prisoner releases. A YouGov poll shows voters trust Johnson more than Corbyn on security, and Home Secretary Priti Patel will highlight the benefits of Brexit in bolstering UK security. The general election is on December 12, and both parties are trying to capitalize on the situation.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson's Conservatives will paint their party as one of law and order on Monday, while London reels from a terror attack and prepares to welcome Donald Trump this week for a Nato summit.

site_title: Billionaires pay seven-figure property taxes for Palm Beach homes
summary: Billionaires in Palm Beach pay seven-figure property taxes, with Citadel founder Ken Griffin facing a $5.4 million tax bill. Six of his neighbors also face seven-figure levies, while dozens pay over $500,000. The high taxes underscore Palm Beach's status as a top destination for the world's wealthiest individuals.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Sustainability is critical to how we do business
summary: SecondMuse, an innovation agency, launched the Plastics Data Challenge alongside the Circulate Initiative to reduce plastic pollution in oceans. Matteo Chiampo, technical director, discusses the importance of sustainability in business, highlighting the need to address climate change. The agency aims to create a more sustainable future through innovative solutions and partnerships. This initiative underscores the critical role of sustainability in shaping the future of business and the environment.

site_title: Another record-breaking week for US equities on the cards?
summary: US stocks hit new record highs after hints of progress on the trade front and better-than-expected retail sales and economic data, with investors optimistic about a holiday-season shopping spree and trade-deal anticipation. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. A new funding round for eSIM platform Airalo valued the company over $1 billion.

site_title: Irving Burgie, songwriter of calypso hit 'Day-O', dies at 95
summary: Irving Burgie, songwriter of the calypso hit 'Day-O', has died at 95. He co-wrote the enduring Harry Belafonte hit and helped popularise Caribbean music. Burgie's songs have sold over 100 million records worldwide, including "Island in The Sun", "Angelina", and "Mary's Boy Child". A Barbados Independence Day Parade attendee announced his death, with Prime Minister Mia Amor Mottley requesting a moment of silence for the Brooklyn-born composer, who wrote the national anthem of Barbados.

site_title: Telegraph Media group CEO heralds digital growth amid takeover talk
summary: The Telegraph Media Group, publisher of The Daily Telegraph and The Sunday Telegraph, expects to surpass digital subscribers with print, reaching 418,000 combined subscriptions. CEO Nick Hugh aims to add 100,000 digital subscribers by 2020 and double operating profit. The company is considering a sale or part-sale amid speculation, but no process has been initiated. Despite lower subscription rates for digital, Hugh remains optimistic about the company's growth path, citing the influence of recent political events.

site_title: New South Wales rolls out mobile phone detection cameras
summary: New South Wales, Australia, has launched a mobile phone detection camera program to reduce road fatalities by a third over two years. The cameras, operating day and night in all conditions, will determine if drivers are handling mobile phones. This system aims to change the driving culture, with similar initiatives already implemented in the Netherlands. The program is part of Transport for NSW's efforts to improve road safety.

site_title: November PMI shows China's manufacturing is back in expansion
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery in November, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 50.2, the first reading above 50 since April, and the non-manufacturing gauge at 54.4. However, economists question whether a single-month data is a reliable indicator of stabilisation, citing deflationary risks, rising borrowing costs, and squeezed household consumption. While a sub-index of new export orders climbed to a seven-month high, businesses still face headwinds, and Chinese authorities may need to adjust policy easing measures to maintain stable growth in 2020.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: The Singapore Government published quotation for taxable book-entry bonds on December 1, 2019. No further information is provided in the given article list.

site_title: FLT and FCOT propose S$1.58b merger, eye 50% stake in UK business park
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) propose a S$1.58 billion merger, with FLT acquiring all FCOT units for about S$1.54 billion. The deal is expected to create a top 10 S-Reit with a portfolio of around S$5.7 billion in assets across the Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the UK. FLT's international portfolio will include FCOT's UK business park, Farnborough Business Park, while FCOT's portfolio will gain FLT's Australian and German properties. The merger is expected to be accretive to both unitholders, with a gross exchange ratio of 1.355 times and a premium of around 0.6% to FCOT's last traded price.

images.alt_text: If the merger goes through, the enlarged Reit's portfolio will comprise around 2.6 million square metres of space with some 300 tenants in 98 properties spread across five countries.

site_title: Director activity continues to grow
summary:

Key transactions included Wilmar International's executive director Teo La-Mei exercising 250,000 share options, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings' chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increasing his stake to 36.53%. Other notable transactions involved UOB-Kay Hian Holdings, AEI Corporation, and GL.

site_title: Nokia says it's working to end patent licensing row with Daimler, other firms
summary: Nokia is working to resolve a patent licensing dispute with Daimler and other companies, including German electronics firm Bury Technologies and car parts maker Continental, over fees for essential patents in navigation systems and vehicle-to-vehicle communication. The dispute was referred to the European Commission, which may launch an investigation if Nokia is found to be abusing its position. Nokia has submitted a proposal to resolve the issue, which could pre-empt any Commission investigation and fines. The goal is for the technologies to be widely adopted across industries, benefiting consumers and customers worldwide.

site_title: The game changers
summary: The past decade has seen significant global developments, including climate change, the rise of China's dominance, and the increasing importance of technology. Experts agree that the success of the COP 21 Paris Accord on Climate Change is a defining moment, with 197 countries signing the agreement. Other notable developments include the growth of the mobile internet, the emergence of the platform economy, and the increasing impact of artificial intelligence. However, there is also concern about the rise of disinformation campaigns and the growing geo-political rift between China and Western powers. Many believe that the next decade will be shaped by the need for sustainable practices, inclusiveness, and responsible use of technology.

site_title: Apple reviews policies after maps app shows Crimea as part of Russia
summary: Apple is reviewing its mapping policies after criticism for including Crimea as part of Russia in its Maps app. The issue arose when Ukrainian officials accused Apple of insensitivity for showing Crimea as part of Russia on Russian versions of the map software. Apple claims the change was made due to a new law in Russia, and users elsewhere see locations in Crimea displayed without specifying the country. Apple has stated it will review how it handles disputed borders and may make changes in the future.

site_title: Prices of connected cars may rise if Qualcomm wins antitrust case: carmakers
summary: Qualcomm's patent licensing practices are under scrutiny, with trade groups representing major automakers and suppliers arguing that the company's practices could lead to higher prices for connected cars equipped with 5G wireless technology. If Qualcomm loses its appeal, prices may rise as the company seeks to renegotiate licensing agreements at reasonable prices. The US Federal Trade Commission had previously ordered Qualcomm to renegotiate its licensing agreements, but the company has denied the accusations. The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals will begin hearing the case in January.

site_title: Iskandar still having hangover from residential market overhang
summary: The Johor government has lowered the minimum purchase threshold for foreigners to purchase high-rise residential units in Iskandar Malaysia from RM1 million to RM600,000, effective January 1 to September 30, 2020. This move aims to boost the high-rise residential market, which has been impacted by a lacklustre property market in Johor. However, the impact of this change remains to be seen, and the outlook for Iskandar Malaysia is expected to remain subdued next year.

site_title: Asean's share of global GDP 'could rival eurozone'
summary: AHSBC report suggests ASEAN's share of global GDP could rival the eurozone by 2030 if policymakers enact the right reforms. The region is expected to see a surge in investment and FDI inflows, driven by its openness to trade and foreign investment. ASEAN's electronics industry is a key driver of growth, with countries like Singapore and Malaysia playing a significant role in regional supply chains. However, regional integration and the pace of reforms are key challenges, and if not addressed, growth may disappoint, leading to employment and inequality issues.

site_title: South Korea's export decline suggests no easing up on world trade slump yet
summary: South Korea's exports declined 14.3% in November, marking the sixth straight double-digit fall, indicating a possible continuation of the global trade slump. The decline was more than expected and follows preliminary data that offered hope of respite. The country's export-dependent economy has been heavily impacted by the US-China trade war and global slowdown, with shipments to China and Japan also declining. The Bank of Korea has slashed its growth projections for this year and next, citing a gradual recovery next year, but economists remain cautious about the global slowdown's continuation.

site_title: British PM vows to strengthen prison sentences after London attack
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to strengthen prison sentences in response to an attack in London by a convicted terrorist who was released early from prison. The attack, which killed two people, has raised concerns about law and order ahead of the UK's general election. Johnson promised to invest more money in the prison system and make sentences tougher for serious offenders, while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn suggested that convicted terrorists should not necessarily serve their full prison terms. The issue has become a key part of the election agenda, with both parties vying for support on the issue of public safety.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of December 1, 2019, reveals a strong market for dry bulk and tanker shipping. The Capesize 5TC index increased from $18,930 to $23,865, while the Atlantic Basin saw significant gains. The Pacific Basin struggled to keep pace, with the C5 index closing at $9.95. The Panamax market also saw gains, with an 80,000dwt ship achieving $13,500 for a Skaw-Gibraltar round-trip route. The US Gulf grain shipments gained traction, with an 85,000dwt ship fixing $16,000 plus a $600,000 ballast bonus.

site_title: China introduces mandatory face scans for phone users
summary: China has introduced mandatory face scans for new phone users starting December 1, as part of its efforts to tighten cyberspace controls and leverage AI technology. Telecom operators must use facial recognition to verify identities when issuing new phone numbers, with some users expressing concerns over data privacy risks. This move follows China's push for real-name registration for phone users since 2013, with the government citing the need to "promote the healthy, orderly development of the Internet" and "protect state security and public interest."

site_title: Online sales break Black Friday record in US
summary: US online sales broke the Black Friday record with $7.4 billion in sales, surpassing 2018 Cyber Monday's $7.9 billion. This marks the second-highest online sales day in US history. Smartphone purchases accounted for $2.9 billion in sales, the highest ever. The trend of online shopping is increasing, with many consumers opting to buy online instead of waiting for Cyber Monday. Cyber Monday sales are expected to outshine 2018's record by 19%.

site_title: Police again fire tear gas as thousands hit streets in fresh wave of protests
summary: Police in Hong Kong fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters in the Tsim Sha Tsui shopping district, following a rare lull in violence. The protests, which began in June, are driven by anger over Chinese meddling in the former British colony's freedoms. Despite a recent surge in arrests, protesters vowed to maintain momentum, with some building barricades and blocking roads. The US consulate was also targeted, with hundreds showing gratitude for US support. Further protests are planned, and a top Hong Kong official has announced the government's intention to review the crisis.

images.alt_text: Some protesters, equipped with gas masks, built barricades and blocked roads near luxury stores, including Armani, while others headed towards Hung Hom, a district near the ruined campus of Hong Kong Polytechnic University.

site_title: MOF seeks views and suggestions for Budget 2020
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance (MOF) is seeking public feedback on Budget 2020, which will be unveiled in February. The government invites individuals, households, and businesses to provide input on topics such as business growth, training, and support for families and seniors. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a strategic financial plan to address near-term and long-term issues, while strengthening support for Singaporeans. The public can submit their views through various channels from December 2 to January 10.

site_title: Rising development costs: Silver lining for US commercial real estate?
summary: US commercial real estate continues to experience record-high building costs, but this trend has limited new development and prolonged the lifespan of existing assets. Rising construction costs have driven appreciation and rent growth of existing assets, while limiting over-supply risk. The challenges of high costs and lengthy entitlement processes are affecting new construction projects, with many reporting budget overages and delays. This situation presents opportunities for well-capitalized owners, developers, and investors to redevelop existing properties, while also driving movement to less costly regions or secondary cities.

site_title: Tackling tough issues with seniors
summary: Law firm TSMP Law Corporation organized a seminar and party for over 45 seniors at the Tembusu Senior Activity Centre in Singapore to discuss end-of-life issues, including making a will and Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA). The event aimed to empower the elderly with pertinent information to help with their end-of-life planning. More than 6 out of 10 seniors had no trouble discussing the topics, but many were unaware of how to obtain an LPA or what an Advanced Medical Directive (AMD) was. The event was part of TSMP's corporate social responsibility (CSR) outreach efforts, which also target migrant workers and at-risk youths.

images.alt_text: TSMP staff (all photos) at play with seniors at the Tembusu Senior Activity Centre. The fun element in the activities helped cheer up seniors and break the ice for discussions on more serious matters.

site_title: Six European countries join Instex barter system for trade with Iran
summary: Six European countries, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, Norway, and Sweden, joined the Instex barter system, designed to circumvent US sanctions against trade with Iran. The system, led by France, Germany, and the UK, allows Iran to sell oil and import other products in exchange without using the US dollar. The accession strengthens Instex and demonstrates European efforts to facilitate legitimate trade between Europe and Iran. Iran must return to full compliance with the 2015 nuclear deal without delay, according to the European countries.

site_title: Keppel Reit open to more development exposure
summary: Keppel Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is open to participating in its sponsor's redevelopment of two freehold office towers in Hoe Chiang Road, potentially increasing its property development exposure. The towers, formerly known as Keppel Towers and GE Towers, qualify for the Urban Redevelopment Authority's CBD Incentive Scheme, offering up to 25% additional gross floor area. Keppel Reit's CEO, Paul Tham, is seeking to boost yields through development projects, with medium to long-term benefits expected. The trust is also focusing on positive rental reversion and overseas acquisitions to drive growth.

site_title: 92 apartments sold at One Holland Village Residences
summary: A consortium of Far East Organization, Sekisui House, and Sino Group sold 92 units at One Holland Village Residences between Nov 21 and Dec 1, with the official launch held on Nov 30. The units were priced at S$2,600 psf for Sereen, S$2,900 psf for Leven, and S$3,200 psf for Quincy Private Residences. Ninety percent of the sold units were bought by Singaporeans, with the remaining 10 percent by permanent residents and foreigners. The mixed-use development will feature serviced residences, retail, and office space.

site_title: Travel woes from winter storms pile up for Americans
summary: Millions of Americans are facing travel disruptions due to a fast-moving winter storm expected to impact the US this weekend. The National Weather Service predicts significant travel impact across the country, with parts of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut under a winter storm watch. Delays and cancellations have already started at major airports, with over 3,850 flights delayed by Saturday afternoon. Snowfall of 25cm or more is expected in the High Plains and around Duluth, Minnesota, with blizzard conditions also possible in the lower Mississippi Valley and East Coast.

site_title: STI looking cautiously bullish
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has been trading near a price-to-book ratio of one, indicating a valuation disparity with US indices. The index has recovered from its January low, reaching a peak of 3,415 in April and recently hitting 3,285. The Singapore economy is stabilizing, with a 0.5% year-on-year growth in the third quarter, driven by the finance and telco industries. Technical analysis suggests the index may be consolidating before charging to a higher landscape, but a clear catalyst is needed. The author remains cautiously bullish for shorter-term trading but sees a positive outlook for longer-term investors.

site_title: Mapletree announces closing of Australian private trust of A$654m in fund equity
summary: Mapletree Investments has successfully closed a new Australian private commercial trust, MASCOT, at A$654 million (S$608 million) in total fund equity. The trust owns 10 Grade A office assets in key Australian cities, with a total asset value of A$1.4 billion. Mapletree will retain a 27% stake in the trust, targeting a 12% internal rate of return through semi-annual distributions. The trust's strong property and economic fundamentals are expected to drive growth, with occupancy at 94% and a tenant pool of reputable occupiers from diversified industries.

site_title: Kim says North Korea to show 'new strategic weapon' in near future
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un announced his country will continue developing nuclear programs and introduce a "new strategic weapon" in the near future, citing the US failure to meet a year-end deadline for denuclearization talks. Kim criticized the US for making "gangster-like demands" and maintaining joint military drills with South Korea, which he believes invalidates North Korea's self-declared nuclear and ICBM test moratorium. The announcement comes after the US missed the deadline to restart negotiations, which Kim had repeatedly called for.

site_title: UBS Singapore celebrates handover of 9 Penang Road
summary: UBS Singapore celebrated the handover of its new 381,000 sq ft office at 9 Penang Road, marking a significant milestone in the bank's growth in the region. The ceremony included a light-up of Singapore's tallest sustainable tree made from plastic bottles, and the launch of UBS's Sustainable Arts Programme for Youths. The facility is designed to be energy-efficient and features innovative technology, with a long-term deal with Sembcorp to run operations on renewable energy. The building has been awarded Singapore's BCA Green Mark Platinum certification, further solidifying UBS's commitment to sustainability.

site_title: There is method to Mitsui's finger-in-every-pie strategy
summary: Mitsui & Co, a Japanese conglomerate, is diversifying its investments from its mainstay resources business into healthcare, environment, and consumer sectors in Asia. The company aims to shift its investments to the mid- to downstream of value chains, closer to the consumer, and has made significant investments in Asia, particularly in India, Vietnam, and Japan. Mitsui's healthcare investments include IHH Healthcare, Davita, and various other companies, and the company expects the healthcare sector in Asia to grow at 12% per annum. The company's goal is to become a "Mitsui of Asia" rather than a "Mitsui of Japan".

site_title: Trade tensions back in focus as December begins
summary: US-China trade tensions resurfaced in December, with investors increasingly concerned about the progress toward a "Phase One" deal. The passing of the Hong Kong pro-democracy bill and China's response sparked concerns of "strong counter-measures." Market experts, including KGI Securities' Joel Ng, expect a risk-reward imbalance, advising clients to hedge and sell overperforming equities. The Dow Jones fell 0.4% on Friday, while Singapore's Straits Times Index extended losses. The start of December brings key economic releases, including purchasing managers index (PMI) readings and monetary policy decisions from Asia-Pacific central banks.

site_title: Inspector for Eagle Hospitality Trust's Queen Mary loses job
summary: Inspector Edward Pribonic, who conducted monthly inspections of the Queen Mary floating hotel for nearly three decades, has been fired by the City of Long Beach in California. His scathing reports on the ship's deteriorating condition sparked a public outcry, but city officials disputed his findings, citing hyperbolic language. The city plans to expand inspection reports and open the job to engineering companies in January 2020. The firing comes amid an ongoing audit of the Queen Mary lease agreement and a review of Urban Commons' proposal for critical repairs to the ageing vessel.

site_title: SGX RegCo seeks to revise listing rules for more power, enforcement
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is seeking to revise its listing rules to give itself more powers to deal with potential misconduct and protect shareholder interests, particularly in the area of interested person transactions. The proposed changes include raising standards for issue managers and sponsors, and giving the Listings Disciplinary Committee more authority to impose sanctions. The move aims to secure faster enforcement outcomes and provide clarity to the market.

site_title: New opportunities for law firms as Laos' economy seeks to diversify
summary: Laos' economy is diversifying, shifting from hydropower to solar energy, real estate, and tourism, driven by the Lao government's goal to reduce reliance on resource-intensive industries. Despite strong demand for hydropower services, other sectors are showing great potential. The government plans to increase small-scale renewable energy production and promote foreign investment, leading to growing needs for legal services on investment and business laws. Chinese investment and financing have also led to increased demand for cross-border legal services with China. However, the Lao market is characterized by intense competition and limited legal talents.

site_title: MOF seeks views, suggestions for Budget 2020
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) in Singapore is seeking feedback from individuals, households, and businesses on the upcoming Budget 2020. The budget aims to address near-term issues and build a future Singapore together, reflecting the country's values, aspirations, and direction. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of public input in shaping the budget. The MOF is working with the People's Association and government feedback unit Reach to gather suggestions on topics such as business growth, training, and support for families and seniors.

site_title: New Zealand's Metlifecare agrees to NZ$1.49b buyout, says market regulator
summary: New Zealand's Metlifecare has agreed to a NZ$1.49 billion buyout, with NZX Regulation stating the offer price represents a 9.7% premium to the company's shares. The acquisition is expected to be finalized between December 28-29, with the buyer completing due diligence and obtaining final approval. The deal values Metlifecare at NZ$1.49 billion, following its shares being placed on a trading halt on December 20.

site_title: AEM acquires French test solutions provider for 7.5m euros
summary: AEM Holdings acquired French test solutions provider Mu-TEST for 7.5 million euros (S$11.3 million), complementing its chip testing solutions with Mu-TEST's customisable low-cost tester capabilities. Mu-TEST's founder and CEO Mathieu Duprez will continue as general manager and director after the acquisition. The deal aims to offer complete system-level test solutions for the semiconductor and electronics industries.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on worries over US repo market
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 6,783.70 on Monday, tracking a weak US stock market finish, amid concerns over the US repo market's year-end liquidity. The US Federal Reserve injected $500 billion in liquidity earlier this month to address a shortage in funds, which could impact US repo rates and corporate tax payments. The mining sector led losses, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto plummeting, while gold stocks rose.

site_title: India's Modi party loses state election amid protests over citizenship law
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) lost control of the eastern state of Jharkhand, marking another electoral defeat amid nationwide protests over a citizenship law critics say discriminates against Muslims. The opposition alliance won the polls, which took place before the protests began. The BJP's loss is seen as a boost to India's opposition parties, who have used public anger against the Citizenship Amendment Act to their advantage. The Modi government defends the law, claiming it helps persecuted non-Muslim minorities from Afghanistan, Bangladesh, and Pakistan.

site_title: Hyflux investor to engage with PnP holders 'as soon as practicable'
summary: Aqua Munda, a potential investor, has expressed interest in engaging with Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares (PnP) holders, but has not extended a separate offer to them. Aqua Munda is focusing on launching an invitation for Hyflux's noteholders and unsecured creditors to tender their debts, which may impact the company's proposed rescue deal with Utico. The firm aims to facilitate a debt restructuring that is fair and equitable for all stakeholders, but has not yet released a memorandum detailing its proposal, which is expected by December 27.

site_title: Gold dealers in India charge premium on limited supply
summary: Indian gold dealers charged a premium of up to $1 an ounce due to limited international supplies during the holiday season. Domestic prices include 12.5% import tax and 3% sales tax. Gold futures rose to a four-month high of 38,980 rupees (S$738) as Chinese gold traders offered premiums of $4-5 an ounce. Physical demand remains weak, particularly for jewelry, due to ongoing protests in Hong Kong. Traders in Singapore charged similar premiums, but demand is expected to improve in January ahead of the Chinese New Year.

site_title: Tesla secures 9b yuan loan from Chinese banks for Shanghai factory
summary: Tesla secures a 9 billion yuan (S$1.75 billion) loan from Chinese banks for its Shanghai factory, with the funds to be used for construction, production, and debt repayment. The electric car maker has also signed an unsecured revolving loan facility of 2.25 billion yuan. The loans are part of Tesla's efforts to boost sales in China's massive auto market and avoid higher import tariffs on US-made cars. The Shanghai factory is Tesla's first car manufacturing site outside the US, and the loans are expected to support the factory's operations and expansion plans.

site_title: Vodafone Hutchison Australia partners Nokia to kick off 5G rollout
summary: Vodafone Hutchison Australia has partnered with Nokia to roll out 5G services in Australia, starting in the first half of 2020. The joint venture, which is in the midst of a legal appeal process against an antitrust regulator's block on its A$15 billion merger with TPG Telecom, will use Nokia's network equipment. This move comes after Australia expanded its national security rules to exclude Huawei from the country's 5G rollout due to concerns over foreign government ties. Nokia has been a beneficiary of restrictions in Western nations on Huawei's market access.

site_title: German parliament passes disputed climate reform package
summary: Germany's upper house approved a climate policy reform package, ending months of debate. The package includes plans to reduce rail prices and increase taxes on air travel, addressing concerns over costs. The breakthrough comes after lawmakers reached a compromise on a higher carbon price. The reform aims to reduce emissions and meet Germany's climate targets.

site_title: 21 suffer carbon monoxide poisoning at French Christmas mass
summary: Twenty-one people were hospitalized in northern France after suffering carbon monoxide poisoning during Christmas mass on December 25, 2019. The incident occurred at a church in the Oise department, where emergency services were called after several people complained of headaches during the ceremony. Two people were in serious condition, one of whom was placed in a hyperbaric oxygen chamber.

site_title: Betting on tomorrow's winners: thematic investing
summary: Thematic investing, a strategy focused on betting on emerging trends and megatrends, is gaining momentum in Singapore, particularly among technology and disruptive innovation-related funds. Over 39 thematic funds are available for retail and accredited investors, with most keeping in line with the global equity benchmark MSCI AC World Index. Thematic funds adopt a longer-term investment horizon, incorporating structural trends from environmental changes, technological advancements, and demographic shifts. Key to their success is identifying secular growth opportunities that transcend business cycles and geographic regions. However, these funds also come with higher risks and fees, and investors should approach them as satellites rather than core portfolio holdings.

site_title: Investors shrug off impeachment vote against Trump as non-factor
summary: Investors in Asia largely ignored the US Congress' vote to impeach President Donald Trump, with markets trading in a directionless fashion typical of pre-Christmas trading. The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 0.07% to 3,207.42, while other Asia-Pacific markets were mixed. Analysts note that Trump's acquittal in the Senate trial is likely, and his removal from office is unlikely. Trading volume was 96% of the daily average, with total turnover at 87% of the January-to-November daily average.

site_title: UOB buys more shares in troubled Hengfeng Bank for 1.86b yuan
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is buying an additional 1.86 billion shares in troubled Chinese mid-sized lender Hengfeng Bank Co for 1.86 billion yuan, reducing its stake from 13% to 3%. The move is part of a capital increase exercise to raise 100 billion yuan, with Chinese state-owned companies becoming controlling shareholders. The deal is aimed at prop up smaller lenders in China's slowing economy, following previous state rescue efforts.

site_title: Going 100% green will pay for itself in 7 years: Study
summary: A Stanford University professor's study suggests phasing out fossil fuels and transitioning to 100% clean energy worldwide could pay for itself in under 7 years, with estimated annual savings of $11 trillion. The $73 trillion cost of revamping power grids and systems would be offset by these savings. The study, published in One Earth, analyzed 143 countries and found no significant economic downside to making this transition. The findings challenge concerns about the economic viability of a 100% renewable energy future.

site_title: Brooklyn project once pitched for Amazon lands first tenant
summary: A new Brooklyn building, 25 Kent Ave in Williamsburg, has secured its first tenant, fashion brand Kith, signing a lease for 57,679 square feet. The eight-storey building, completed in July, was initially designed as an office space but has been repurposed for manufacturing and retail. The move follows a trend of fashion manufacturers relocating to Brooklyn, with Kith relocating from its Soho headquarters. The developers aim to fill the building by mid-2021, with talks underway with potential tenants.

site_title: The miles game
summary:
